webTitle: Hoddle sets out to revive the great days in Europe

fields.headline: Hoddle sets out to revive the great days in Europe
fields.trailText: Glenn Hoddle's last match as a Tottenham player was an FA Cup final, so it is fitting that his first as manager could take them to another, only their second since his departure in 1987.
fields.body:
Given that Glenn Hoddle's last match as a Tottenham player was an FA Cup final, it is perhaps fitting that his first as manager could take them to another, only their second since his departure in 1987.

It is lucky too, for without the Cup Hoddle would have started his Spurs career with two meaningless months at a club already guaranteed a mid-table finish. Tomorrow's semi-final allows him to continue a pastime that must have brought him great pleasure at Southampton - dreaming of Europe.

"I'm thankful we've actually got some silverware to aim for," Hoddle says. "I could have been joining just to see out the end of the season, to get to know the players and who I need to bring in, but there's an added incentive of an FA Cup and a European place.

"Europe is important to this club. There's been some wonderful European nights over the years and we can bring them back by winning the FA Cup. And if you're in Europe it gives you the opportunity to entice the players that you might want to bring in. So it's not just an FA Cup semi-final, and it's not just a match against Arsenal. It's much bigger than that."

It is hard to think of many more important fixtures in the club's recent past and it is equally hard to imagine more trying circumstances in which to have approached it. Not only do Spurs have new owners and a new manager but their preparations have been hampered by an extensive injury list. A shadow side lost 2-0 to Arsenal last week and several players will return tomorrow before, in truth, they should.

"It's a strange scenario," says Hoddle. "Especially with it being against Arsenal and against Arsene." Wenger, of course, is the manager who opened Hoddle's eyes to coaching while both were at Monaco.

"Arsene saw something in me that I didn't see in myself at the time. I've always got respect for Arsene and I'm always going to be a friend of his because, well, sometimes in life you just gel with someone. Our trouble is that we've never had time to get together socially. That might be a bit difficult now."

Despite the hype and hyperbole surrounding the game, Hoddle is looking confident and composed as the pressure rises. "I feel very relaxed," he says. "I feel as though I've sort of come home. You wouldn't expect to go to a new job in any environ ment, wherever you're working, and feel comfortable straight away. It always takes you a while to slip into gear. I just feel like I've been here all my life."

It helps that several staff, from the coach Chris Hughton down to the kit man, remain from when he was last there. But it adds to the sense of circumstance that has surrounded Hoddle's return. "I had a chance to come here before, when I went to Chelsea, and I turned it down." he says. "At the time I felt the circumstances weren't correct - I can't explain why, it's too private - but I thought maybe the opportunity had passed me by.

"It's ironic how Arsene's a strange name but the way it's spelt is very close to Arsenal. And you think why, of all the clubs in Europe, in the world, why does he end up at that one? Perhaps he was destined to coach there."

There will be more talk of destiny should Spurs win tomorrow, given that the year ends in Tottenham's lucky one. But for Hoddle the game is just the start of a greater mission.

"I'm the first to put pressure on myself," he says. "That's where the main pressure for me will come but within five years my ideals are that we will be qualifying for the Champions League; that's got to be realistic. It'll be hard but at the end of the day you've got to believe in your principles. So I won't hide away from a challenge. And this is a massive challenge."

And Hoddle's first real test has already arrived. "Arsenal are one of the best sides in the country," he says, "but in FA Cup semi-finals, and in London derbies, a lot of that can go out the window frankly. I think we can win the game." It could be their destiny.

webTitle: Barmby hoping for third time lucky

fields.headline: Barmby hoping for third time lucky
fields.trailText: After defeating the champions and surviving in the Nou Camp, Liverpool must adjust to life as favourites in their third semi-final of the season.
fields.body:
Liverpool, fresh from a defeat of the champions and stoic resistance in the Nou Camp, must adjust to life as favourites again as they turn their attentions to Wycombe Wanderers and an FA Cup semi-final they are expected to win.

For their England midfielder Nicky Barmby, tomorrow's match could be third time lucky. Twice a semi-finalist with Tottenham, against Arsenal in 1993 Tony Adams sucker-punched his hopes with a late header; two years later Everton upset the purists by denying Spurs a final against Manchester United.

"The semi-final is a bad one to lose," said the 27-year-old. "You're so close to the final. It takes a while to get over disappointments like that. If you lose the semi-final you've nothing to play for in the last month of the season. Players desperately want to win games and get to an FA Cup final. The incentive is massive."

The loss to Everton, whom he later joined, still smarts. Joe Royle's side nullified the attacking brio of Jurgen Klinsmann, Teddy Sheringham and Barmby, winning 4-1.

"We were favourites for the semi after beating Liverpool in the quarter- finals," recalled Barmby. "There was so much expectancy, but Everton were different class."

Liverpool have not won the Cup since 1992 but with limbs still weary after Thursday night's adventure, Gerard Houllier is set to alter his line-up tomorrow with Barmby expected to feature.

Arguably, Liverpool's most important game of the week comes on Tuesday when the pursuit of a Champions League place gathers pace with a visit to Ipswich. Yet the manager refused to play down the magnitude of their third semi-final of the season.

"The Wycombe game is a huge match," he said. "We have done our homework and are totally focused. We're treating our games like drawers at the moment; we've closed the Uefa Cup semi-final one and opened the Wycombe drawer. After that we'll have Ipswich. It's tough, but the players want to achieve.

"We've managed clean sheets against Manchester United and Barcelona in our last two matches but Wycombe are organised, compact and physically strong too. We'll give them the respect and consideration they deserve, but this is not like a two-legged semi-final. It's make or break."

webTitle: Ron Manager: Thursday on the toilet, Steven Gerrard on my mind

fields.headline: Thursday on the toilet, Steven Gerrard on my mind
fields.trailText: Saturday ... Sunday ... Monday ... Wednesday ... er ... Tuesday ... er ... hang on ... Yes! A big welcome to Ron's Week! ... isn't it? ... hmm? ... marvellous! ... right ho! ...
fields.body:
Saturday! ... Destination Manchester! ... for some top Premiership action! ... ho ho! ... er, no ... it's off to Maine Road for City against Villa ... And a dismal first half ... even John Gregory's sloped off early to grab some tea-cups and limber up for his team talk ... Craaash! ... "We need that second goal!" "... Er, no John, we've got it already ..."

Reminds me of when I first took over at Yeovil ... striding into the dressing room at half-time ... and giving the performance of my life! ... Henry V! ... "Cry havoc and let slip the dogs of war!" ... ho ho! ... "Cry haddock!" I used to bawl out at Grimsby ... er, not one of my "funnies" actually ... a genuine mistake ... but no one ever had the heart to tell me ... nobody stops Ron Manager in full flow! ... ask the Somerset Constabulary! ... scrumpy, isn't it? ... er ... where was I?

Yes! ... Yeovil! ... stumbling gingerly down the famous sloping pitch into the dressing-room ... I did my pieces! ... the players gazing sheepishly at their boots! ... dumbstruck! ... and out they went ... unrecognisable from the team I'd sent out in the first half ... at which point it dawned on me that I'd been in the wrong dressing-room ... And carrying out my instructions to the letter ... they lost their shape ... lost a bit of belief ... and finally the three-goal lead they'd taken in from the first half ... still, all's well that ends well! ... hmm? ... marvellous!

Sunday ... Whoah! ... time for a well-deserved break! ... some half-hearted gardening ... bit of brisket for lunch ... and a video! ... Psycho! ho ho! ... not the film ... it's Stuart Pearce on MOTD ... and a horrendous tackle! ... "He should be locked up!" says Mrs Manager ...

Reminds me of the time I made a citizen's arrest on the pitch! ... 1962! ... a cup tie against Bolton! ... clattered off the ball by a burly defender ... the ref waving play on ... then trying to book me as I read the fellow his rights! ... So I arrested the ref, three more of the Bolton team and some of their fans ... got a bit carried away, actually ... even arrested myself while cooling my heels down at the station ... marvellous!

Monday Soton 0, Ipswich 3. Ho ho! ... long faces at the Dell! ... "We want our manager back!" ... ho ho, sorry lads ... he's now in the clutches of the mysterious Enic! ... who are they? ... hmm? ... a sinister organisation? ... is it an "acronym"? ... what does it stand for? ... Les Ferdinand knows what Tottenham stands for: "Style, Innovation, Tenacity and Excitement" ... er ... Site! ... well, it might not be much of an acronym, but ... stick an H for Hoddle in there and ... er ... hang on, let me think about this ...

Tuesday Bayern Munich ... still haunted by the big toe of the baby-faced assassin ... prepare to meet Man Utd with typical teutonic mind-games ... "Beckham's useless!" hmm? ... the jury's still out ... but there's a degree of sympathy in the Manager household!

Yes! ... in some ways myself and Mrs Manager were the Posh 'n' Becks of our day ... but chez Manager it was always Ron who wore the trousers ... Foul-mouthed chanting from the terraces? ... let me tell you ... Mrs Manager did not take it ... er ... lying down!

Wednesday In comes big Norm with the papers ... He'd run into some Bayern fans when leaving his club in the early hours ... what a good-natured bunch! ... hoisted him aloft in his cowboy boots and lederhosen!

Shows me an interview with Steven Gerrard! ... ho ho! ... that distinctive furrowed brow in one so young ... like one of those wrinkly Chinese dogs ... marvellous! ... He's looking forward to playing Barcelona in the Nou Camp: "I'll probably spend most of Wednesday night on the toilet, but I know it'll be a great game" ... ho ho! ... me too! ... and a quiet night in ... scrabble and a curry!

Thursday er ... spent most of Thursday on the toilet ... Barcelona v Liverpool on the box! ... 0-0 ... bloody awful!

Friday time for a breather and ... Ron dips his toe in the Nationwide . Norwich! Played 38, points 43. Crewe! Played 37, points 45! ... ho ho! ... gripping stuff! ... isn't it?

... And a reader's letter! ... from America! ... GW Bush writes: "Ron, what do you think about the World Cup being held in Korea? I wouldn't go there, you might end up in a cooking-pot or something!"

... Er ... hang on ... it's you again Mark ... isn't it? ... And here's another reader's letter! Chelsea fan Mark Pitts writes: "Ron, if you was that good a manager, why are you never linked with the top jobs?"

Ho ho! ... don't speak too soon, Mark ... a Premiership club quite close to your heart have been making overtures recently ... eager for someone to help steer them back into Europe! ... and if they're as "strapped for cash" as they make out ... I'm an Arabian Sheikh! ... ho ho! ... can't say any more ... but watch this space!

webTitle: A French bench connection looks good for Cardiff

fields.headline: A French bench connection looks good for Cardiff
fields.trailText: In FA Cup semi-finals anything can happen but the most obvious possibility for the Millennium stadium is a final between Arsenal and Liverpool.
fields.body:
This weekend the FA Cup will hope to provide the city of Cardiff with a final on May 12 which has a potential worthy of a historic football occasion, always provided that traffic jams and Will Hay's railways allow fans to get across the Severn in time.

Certainly two teams can emerge from tomorrow's semi-finals capable of producing a memorable match to mark the first final played outside England in the competition's 129 years - or, if not memorable, then at least a better game than the last one to be played at old Wembley, the dire affair between Chelsea and Aston Villa 11 months ago.

The most obvious possibility for the Millennium stadium is a final between Arsenal and Liverpool which would bring back memories of 1950 and all that when the teams met on a filthy afternoon at Wembley and a goal in each half from Reg Lewis took the Cup to Highbury, not to mention Arsenal's 2-1 win in 1971, when they did the Double.

The likeliest alternative would see Liverpool and Tottenham Hotspur meeting in an FA Cup final for the first time although Liverpool did beat Spurs 3-1 at Wembley to win the 1982 Milk Cup. The remotest prospect is of Wycombe Wanderers getting to the final at all, yet they are managed by an FA Cup winner, Lawrie Sanchez, who has personally cocked a snook at pundits' prognostications.

A Millennium May meeting of Tottenham and Wycombe would have a special appeal: part-historic, part- romantic and part-curiosity. One day a club from outside the top two divisions will reach an FA Cup final and who is to say this is not Wycombe's destiny?

Well, a Liverpool side fresh from denying Barcelona more than one shot on target at the Nou Camp in the Uefa Cup for one. How on earth can Paul McCarthy, say, expect to succeed where Rivaldo failed?

It is highly unlikely, of course, but 13 years ago Wembley blinked in disbelief when Sanchez met a free-kick from Dennis Wise with a looping header past Liverpool's Bruce Grobbelaar to win the Cup for Wimbledon - helped by Dave Beasant saving a penalty from John Aldridge.

Moments like these belong to traditions which will offer silent support to Wycombe's efforts this afternoon. The Nationwide team may also be assisted by a conflict of ambitions at Anfield for, while Gerard Houllier would like to add the FA Cup to the Worthington Cup Liverpool won in Cardiff at the end of February, his priorities lie elsewhere.

Liverpool are desperate to get into next season's Champions League and finishing third or better in the Premiership is their most obvious route. So Tuesday's visit to Ipswich, one of the two teams they need to overtake, will be more important than whatever occurs at Villa Park tomorrow.

No doubt Houllier will continue to rotate his team to this end, which probably means a start for Robbie Fowler tomorrow with Michael Owen on the bench. More crucial for Liverpool will be the improbability of Steven Gerrard being able to play three big games in six days. If it comes to a choice, the midfielder will surely be saved for Portman Road.

Tomorrow's earlier semi-final between Arsenal and Spurs has acquired considerably more interest following the decision of Enic, Tottenham's new owners, to sack George Graham, the manager who brought this very ordinary team to the last four, and appoint Glenn Hoddle in his place.

Hoddle is, without doubt, a proven organiser of teams for big matches. He proved this when his England side forced a scoreless draw with Italy in Rome to reach the 1998 World Cup. Graham, however, is a proven winner. His record at Arsenal is evidence of that and the way Tottenham beat West Ham United at Upton Park to reach the semi-finals showed he had not lost the touch.

Hoddle's managerial mentor, Arsene Wenger, may be in charge of the opposition at Old Trafford tomorrow but it is from Graham's book that Spurs' new manager will need to take a leaf if he wants to lead the team out in Cardiff on May 12.

In other words Tottenham will need to stifle Arsenal's midfield as successfully as they bottled up Frank Lampard, Michael Carrick and Joe Cole at Upton Park.

Patrick Vieira and Ray Parlour will surely be harder to contain and, if Sol Campbell is not fit, Tottenham's defence will be no better equipped to deal with the pace of Thierry Henry than it was at Highbury last Saturday. At least Sergei Rebrov will be back to support Les Ferdinand up front.

In FA Cup semi-finals anything can happen but it still looks like a French bench connection between Wenger and Houllier in the Millennium stadium.

fields.headline: Loftus ambition sends good money after bad
fields.trailText: When the ownership of a rugby club seems a more plausible financial investment than Queens Park Rangers, football is in trouble.
fields.body:
How do you make a small fortune out of football? It's easy: start with a large one and buy your own club. The latest wealthy man to discover the truth in the old gag is Chris Wright. In the space of little more than five years Wright has seen the fortune he began to accrue back in the 70s selling prog-rock albums to hairy sixth-formers rapidly ebb away down the open drain otherwise known as Queens Park Rangers.

This week Loftus Road PLC went into administration; there was simply not enough cash around to run the business. In truth it had been like that for some time but Wright's cheque book had been subsidising affairs. The moment he felt he could no longer support his hobby (a moment, incidentally, which coincided with sections of the crowd turning against him) was when stark reality hit.

And stark it is. The Rangers case is the most dramatic example yet that the football business is in profound trouble. It all began back in 1996, when Wright, a long-standing fan and season ticket holder, paid £10m for a controlling stake in a club which had just been relegated from the Premiership. At the time he appeared to be going into ownership with his eyes wide open. "I'm a £40m man," he told a group of fans. "And what this club needs is a £;400m man."

Even so, he behaved as if he were a £400m man, his love of the club clouding his business sense. In his anxiety to return to the top division, Wright allowed money to be lavished on inadequate players.

"Mistakes were made early on," one Loftus Road insider told me this week. "There was this overwhelming desire to get back at all costs and it changed the way the club had always been run."

QPR had traditionally been a selling club. That was how they survived, nurturing talent, cashing it in, then using the profit to maintain operations. Wright - displaying the ambition every fan wants to see in their chairman - affected the balance. It is best illustrated by the case of Trevor Sinclair. Widely reckoned a £10m asset when he scored the goal of the season in 1996, instead of being cashed in at the peak of his value, Sinclair was tied to the club by golden handcuffs.

But his subtle skills were not appropriate to a First Division scramble and, when he was finally let go to West Ham, it was in a deal largely made up by second-rate players coming in the opposite direction. No more than £1m was banked for him. Meanwhile young players who might have been developed and sold found their progress blocked by old lags signed in the forlorn hope they might achieve promotion. The last QPR player to raise a decent fee was Nigel Quashie, sold to Nottingham Forest for £2.5m more than two seasons ago.

But it was the wages that finally undermined Wright's vision. It is not the remuneration of box- office performers such as Roy Keane and Alen Boksic that is football's achilles heel. It is the fact that at a club like QPR at least half a dozen players were paid £5,000 a week each. In no other walk of life would employees who are not very good at their job be earning a quarter of a million pounds a year.

Yet that was the business plan Wright felt obliged to follow. And, as the depressing cycle of poor performance and falling crowds kicked in, as the gap between income and expenditure stretched to over £;50,000 a week, it was the business plan that brought the club to the lip of bankruptcy.

"The sad thing is," my Loftus Road mole suggested, "I don't think those who come into the game because they love it can survive any more. They certainly don't have any fun. Money rules. Nothing else matters. And only those clubs backed by serious money will succeed."

A glance at the First Division table, with Fulham and Blackburn perched at the top, would suggest he has a point. As for Chris Wright, from the tatters of the multi-sport empire he hoped to create in west London, he has emerged clutching Wasps rugby club, retained in a deal with the administrators yesterday. And when the ownership of a rugby club seems a more plausible financial investment, football is in trouble. If Wright needs a shoulder to cry on, he could do worse than set up an ex-chairman's support group with the eternally bitter Alan Sugar, comparing the burns on their fingers and waiting for the next man looking to make a small fortune out of football to join them.

Dennis' investment is not so wise

Never use the Chelsea match programme as a source of financial advice. On January 26 1997 Ken Bates dedicated his column in the publication to promoting his latest venture.

"People are queuing up to buy Chelsea Village shares since we floated on the AIM," he wrote. "Our shares in circulation have increased by over 50% and the share price has doubled."

Dennis Wise, he revealed, had bought £75,000 worth, the first player to become a shareholder in his own club.

"Thanks Dennis for the vote of confidence," Bates added. "You keep banging in the goals and I'll keep trying to bang up the share price."

On December 30 1997 Wise also used the programme to endorse his stock. "I'm doing this column on Wednesday afternoon and it's approaching 4 o'clock, I need to go and get the latest prices in the Evening Standard so I can check my Chelse a Village shares. They're flying at the moment. The boys call me Batesey's son and they reckon he says I'm the second most important person in the club after him because I've got the second most number of shares."

Yesterday, as Chelsea Village shares hit 33.5p, Wise's investment was worth about £25,000. Presumably the next Chelsea programme will include a column by the city analyst who this week described football shares as the dot.coms of the mid-90s;today's fashion is tomorrow's tank tops.

webTitle: United look for new fish to fry as the Reds bite back

fields.headline: United look for new fish to fry as the Reds bite back
fields.trailText: Doubts about Manchester United's future are being raised in unexpected places.
fields.body:
Nothing lasts for ever and to emphasise the fact a large stick of rock off Beachy Head has just fallen into the sea, coastal erosion having been helped along by all the rain.

Approach Old Trafford from Salford Quays and it is hard to imagine the mighty multi-tiered home of Manchester United sinking, Usher-like, into the surrounding waters. But what about the present team: is there a crack or two in the plaster or are these merely a few cobwebs to be easily brushed away?

The question is put not so much because Sir Alex Ferguson's team lost the home leg of their European Cup quarter-final 1-0 to Bayern Munich on Tuesday, a result United are quite capable of overturning in the Olympic stadium, but because of some of the comments which have followed that performance.

When the media predict the beginning of the end of the Manchester United era it is often a case of the wish being father to the thought. Most professional critics do not share the Manuphobia of rival supporters but they would like to have something fresh about which to comment.

Dissenting voices from within Ferguson's squad, however, are an entirely different kettle of Red snappers. No sooner had Paulo Sergio come off the Bayern bench to score the goal which threatens to remove Manchester United from the European Cup at the quarter-final stage for the third time in four seasons than doubts about the team's future were being raised in unexpected places.

Ryan Giggs, for example, was quoted as saying that the present side were not the team they had been in winning the tournament two years ago. United, he declared, had lost their spark.

Then Teddy Sheringham was reported to have misgivings about what would happen once Ferguson had retired at the end of next season. Fergie's successor, he felt, would have an extremely difficult task, not least in controlling the big names in the side.

This hardly paints a rosy picture of the world's richest club advancing to ever greater glories, while the best the rest of English football can hope for is the odd cup with entry to the Champions League by a side door.

Even the latest evidence of Old Trafford's seemingly limitless capacity for making money was accompanied by some financial caveats. While Manchester United's interim results reveal large increases in turnover and respectable pre-tax profits, with cash from the latest television deal still to come and the £303m Nike contract due to start next year, the club are concerned about players' wages getting out of hand.

Because of this United are to implement a tiered salary structure, whereby the money individual players receive will depend on the amount of club revenue they are estimated to have generated, as well as what they are thought to be worth in the transfer market - always assuming that one still exists.

It sounds like a recipe for dressing-room rebellion although the players are said to be happy with the new arrangement. Either way, and with a number of contracts still to be renegotiated, it is clear that the millions of pounds which normally dominate football headlines in the close season will be spent equally trying to keep the players they already have as signing new talents like PSV Eindhoven's striker Ruud van Nistelrooy.

Given the sums that David Beckham - who is likely to be on £100,000 a week next season - Giggs and other regulars in Ferguson's team will be earning there seems little doubt that the present side will stay together for some time yet -unless, that is, Ferguson agrees with Giggs that the team could do with a fresh set of spark-plugs.

Sheringham is undoubtedly correct when he forecasts the difficulties the next man in charge of Manchester United will face. Like all successful managers Ferguson has the priceless knack of knowing when his side, however successful it has been, is due for changes of personnel, shape, tactics or organisation. Sir Matt Busby had it at Old Trafford before him, Bill Shankly and Bob Paisley had it at Liverpool and Arsene Wenger has it at Arsenal.

What Manchester United will be extremely fortunate to rediscover, however, is another burgeoning youth side ready to mature and thrive together over a period of 10 years. Footballers of the quality of Giggs, Beckham and Paul Scholes do not come along that often as individuals, let alone in a bunch.

United would not have won the Premier ship in 1993 without the singular spiky Gallic influence of Eric Cantona or Peter Schmeichel's goalkeeping, and so much of their subsequent success is owed to Roy Keane.

Expensive signings like Dwight Yorke, Jaap Stam and, this season, Fabien Barthez have done much to maintain and heighten the standards of excellence within the side and Andy Cole's prolific scoring record speaks for itself.

Yet the best of Manchester United has always had youth at its core, from Busby's doomed babes to Ferguson's fulfilled fledglings, and once the Premiership hat-trick has been achieved - probably at home to Manchester City a fortnight today - as much interest should be taken in Darren Fletcher and others queuing up behind Wes Brown and Luke Chadwick as anyone waiting at airport immigration just off the M56.

fields.headline: Wiltord comes into his own
fields.trailText: The French frontman has found the net in every round of the FA Cup, a feat which has not been carried throughout the tournament since Peter Osgood did it in 1970.
fields.body:
Recent events suggest at least two things are guaranteed at tomorrow's Old Trafford semi-final. Outside, the Southampton chairman Rupert Lowe will be flogging "Saints say be a Gooner for the day" T-shirts and Sylvain Wiltord will score for Arsenal.

Wiltord has found the net in every round of the FA Cup, a feat which has not been carried throughout the tournament since Peter Osgood did it in 1970. Wiltord's reputation as a man for the big occasion is well established. Scorer of France's equaliser in the Euro 2000 final, he struck twice on the last day of the 1998-99 season to bring Bordeaux the French title. The sense of anticipation at facing Tottenham is apparent. "It's going to be a real battle," he says with a smile.

The 26-year-old could hardly look more relaxed in the dining room at Arsenal's training ground, a mood not always associated with him since his protracted £13m move from Bordeaux last August. Shortly after his arrival one headline bemoaned "Another case of French whine".

Frustrated by his lack of first-team opportunities, late for training and reportedly "pining for France", Wiltord left some wondering whether Arsenal had landed a second Nicolas Anelka at around 20 times the price. Even acceptance from within was not automatic. "I could read in the eyes of our English players," Wiltord said, "that they thought I was not mentally tough."

The striker is beginning to justify his value now. The comparisons are less with Anelka's antics and more with the explosive talent of Ian Wright. The two goals that removed Chelsea from the Cup were followed by a hat-trick against West Ham in the league. On Wednesday Wiltord's introduction helped turn the Champions League match against Valencia. Tomorrow he is expected to start. The message is emphatic: Je ne regrette rien.

"I think I needed about two and a half months before I was really in the English groove," he reflects. "People thought that I wanted to go back to France and that I wasn't totally committed but I think that was only part of the process of settling in. You have to be very patient. You have to watch, learn and listen to the coach.

"The adaptation period when you come to England can be difficult because we have certain habits in France which don't necessarily fit in with the English culture. But I feel I have settled in very well now. I'm playing more, scoring more and I'm very, very happy. There are other French players here who have made it easier."

Robert Pires, with whom he lived in the same hotel for a while, is a close friend. The knowledge that Thierry Henry also needed time to settle, hopping on and off the bench and scoring only once in his first 12 league games, has given Wiltord further heart. The proximity of several compatriots at other clubs has helped him adapt quickly to London.

"We see the Chelsea players, Marcel Desailly, Frank Leboeuf and Bernarde Lambourde," he says. "We chat, go to restaurants. We talk about France, about going out and we try to forget about football."

Initially Wiltord had plenty he was keen to forget about. As an automatic choice at Bordeaux he did not find it easy coping with Arsene Wenger's rotation policy or fighting for selection with Henry, Nwankwo Kanu and Dennis Bergkamp, who is now injured.

"When you regularly play a lot of matches you develop a rhythm and when I arrived here I wasn't playing much," he says. "It was hard because I had to get my head straight. I had to keep motivated and that wasn't easy. I prefer it if the best players are playing on the field the whole time."

A hint that Arsenal's record signing feels he should start more often? "If things are going well for me during the match, then yes. If I perform well, play well with my strike partner and score goals, that's the reward for the work you do. But unfortunately, despite playing well, I find myself back on the bench."

Kanu is likely to be given the substitute's role tomorrow as Wenger deploys Henry and Wiltord. Of eight games they have started together, Arsenal have won only one, at home to Tottenham last weekend, and Wiltord knows this Spurs side will be tougher than the one beaten 2-0 at Highbury.

Wiltord's relationship with Wenger has had its icy moments. "From time to time we clash but that's normal between a manager and a player," he says. "Sometimes it's fine and other times it's more tense. When you are a player you are going to have to ask the manager what's going on."

In any case Wiltord is hardly the shy, retiring type. At the training ground he has been known to walk into a room, scream and burst out laughing. His infectious personality has, some believe, helped to replace the void left by Wright. "I'm just full of life, explosive and I like to show it," Wiltord says.

The rebellious streak he displayed in France appears to have subsided but a toughness remains, the legacy of his childhood in Neuilly-sur-Marne, near Paris, where he and his seven brothers and sisters were raised by their mother, a nurse.

"My mum brought me up when it wasn't easy," says Wiltord, who returned to Paris on Thursday to launch a children's football tournament. "She was pretty strict and I'm even stronger because of that. It's allowed me to have a hard personality and taught me how to look after myself."

Nine goals in 24 games for France prove Wiltord can look after himself at international level. His equaliser against Italy last summer elevated not just his standing in his homeland but his transfer fee.

Now he recognises the need to defeat Tottenham: "The championship is the most important thing to win but that will be Manchester United's. It's important for everyone, the fans, the players and the manager, that we win the Cup."

With six Cup goals so far, no one can accuse Wiltord of not doing his bit.

webTitle: England is a 'tax paradise' for players

fields.headline: England is a 'tax paradise' for players
fields.trailText: A footballer in England earning £1m a year gross will be £110,000 better off than a player on the same salary in Germany.
fields.body:
England has become Europe's "tax paradise" for foreign players, an indicator that the tide of imports into the Premiership and lower divisions is likely to continue in the immediate future.

A footballer in England earning £1m a year gross will be £110,000 better off than a player on the same salary in Germany, and bring home £180,000 more than a comparably paid player in France. In this respect, players here are substantially better off even than in Italy and Spain.

This is because players pay much less in tax and national insurance in the United Kingdom than in any of the other so-called "big five" European football countries, according to a report by a leading finance firm, Arthur Andersen's Sports Consulting Group (Score). Score reports that players in England pay 39% of gross income in tax and insurance, while the figure is 45% in Italy, 46% in Spain, 50% in Germany and 57% in France.

The tax advantage also highlights why a quarter of Premiership players are imports. It is an obvious attraction of Britain for not only younger foreigners seeking long contracts but also those nearing the end of careers and seeking a last lucrative deal.

According to Lutz Meyer, Score's coordinator: "Europe's football-related 'tax paradise' can be found in England, due to favourable taxes and social security contributions."

webTitle: Bhoys' own scramble for title seats

fields.headline: Bhoys' own scramble for title seats
fields.trailText: With six games of the Scottish Premier League season remaining, a measly three points lie between Celtic and the championship.
fields.body:
Celtic's manager Martin O'Neill could sleep well last night in the knowledge that, were his side to drop a point this afternoon against St Mirren, the worst that could happen would be a slight dampening of the party atmosphere.

With six games of the Scottish Premier League season remaining, a measly three points lie between Celtic and the championship. Celtic Park yesterday had a twitchy air as tickets became like gold dust.

If St Mirren are not cowed by the cacophony, they are likely to be hypnotised by Celtic's sense of destiny. The matter of St Mirren's own desperate need for points, to lift them off the bottom, has been relegated to that of footnote as the ink dries in another's historic chapter.

The SPL has decided against having the trophy waiting in the wings to be presented, in the event of a Celtic victory, at full-time. But O'Neill's team look set to win the title ahead of the hoped-for grand finale as the league splits into two after this weekend, with the top six playing each other and the bottom six likewise.

"Celtic is a major club; you know the pressure is on from day one. I would like to think you could have a year's honeymoon but I just knew that wouldn't happen," said O'Neill.

"Things have exceeded all our expectations. We have been lucky in many aspects, major players have stayed pretty fit. We definitely need to add to the squad; a blind man could see it," a reference to Celtic's need to launch a sustained European challenge next season.

Over at Ibrox the Rangers manager Dick Advocaat highlighted his rivals' good fortune with injuries.

"Celtic deserve to be champions because they played very consistently this season, without many injuries," he said. "It's a key factor in football and on results.

"Celtic were a better side this season than Rangers. We have to concentrate on second place." His side go to Hibernian, their only challengers for the runners-up berth, tomorrow.

Meanwhile Celtic's Neil Lennon has been named player of the month for March. O'Neill, who worked with the midfielder at Leicester, rates him alongside Roy Keane and Patrick Vieira.

"His contribution has been immense with Paul Lambert being out [through injury]," he said. "Whether we would have been in this position without Lennon is highly debatable.

"His ability on the ball, his ability to keep the momentum going with a five-yard pass, his ability to take the sting out of the game . . . I have seldom seen him beaten for pace or for trickery. Lennon aspires to get into that world-class group and he is not far removed from it.

"He doesn't score goals. If he could score 10 goals a season, he would be the best player in the world."

The respect was mutual. "He's relentless, he drives players on. He doesn't dazzle you with science, everything is simple, black and white," Lennon said of O'Neill.

Next season's Scottish Cup final is to be moved from its traditional end-of-season date to a week before the last league fixtures so that the turf at Hampden Park can be protected for the European Cup final. The 2002 Scottish Cup final will be on May 4, with the last league games on May 11.

fields.headline: Crazy gang, crazy fans
fields.trailText: Crazy gang, crazy fans: from Vladivostock to Belarus via Ukraine.
fields.body:
"A really funny thing happened when I was in Belarus with Norway," reports Trond Andersen at icons.com. Trond bumped into a man called Max who had travelled from Ukraine just to watch him play. Max has been a Wimbledon fan for 12 years but can only afford to see his heroes when they go to eastern Europe for internationals. "I asked him if he knew any other Wimbledon supporters in Ukraine," Trond goes on. "He said he didn't, but he knew there were a couple in Siberia and a few in Vladivostock." Time for a fighting fund to bring Max to Selhurst Park, surely.

Also in the area recently was the Fifa president Sepp Blatter, who accepted the Order of Merit of the Ukrainian Republic (should look nice next to the knighthood from the Sultanate of Pahang). Leonid Kuchma's government is in crisis after tapes were made public that appeared to show he had ordered the murder of an journalist. Another blow for freedom struck by Fifa's fearless crusader.

"London is a great city," says Bayern Munich's funster Stefan Effenberg, who may be on his way. "It doesn't matter which of the three clubs you play for." Three? What about Spurs?

Last week's call for Alan Shearer "funnies" fell on predictably stony ground. Tony Mole from Dunedin asks: "Wasn't he being funny when he kicked that Leicester player in the cobs just before the World Cup?" Sorry Tony, doesn't count. John Lord offers: "His classic funny was his 'that's life' quote to hundreds of blubbing Blackburn kids who bought replica shirts prior to his move to Newcastle." Yes, how we laughed.

Very best of luck to American Samoa (bottom of Fifa's 203 ranked countries), who make their World Cup debut against Fiji in Coffs Harbour, Australia, today, before a crunch derby against Samoa and a daunting challenge against the hosts. The coach Tony Langkilde lost almost his entire squad when it was discovered only players with American passports were eligible and the rest have an average age of 19, with the youngest only 15. Their first job on arrival was to go out and buy some boots. "Our boys play with sheer courage and a tremendous determination to win," Langkilde said. They may need it.

"When you are small like Marian Pahars you have to be good and he is definitely that," says Bobby Robson, said to be preparing a bid for the Latvian. "He's only a little speck, like a decimal point." Finally, the signing Newcastle's accountants have been waiting for.

Lillestrom have hired Norway's pop star and self-styled "champion lover" Rune Rudberg for their first home game of the season next week (v Bryne) in the hope of attracting more female fans. "To woo 1,000 women won't be a problem at all," said Rudberg. "I can perform both before and after the match, but I have to be allowed time to watch the game." Eat your heart out Robbie Williams.

Dennis Green adds to our collection of inappropriate music (out on CD for Christmas) with news of Bath City's admirable policy of allowing fans to bring their own tapes. "So," he says, "the other week we had Voodoo Chile by Jimi Hendrix and the Velvet Underground's Waiting For The Man - chosen by the club chaplain. This was the same afternoon the Guess The Gate competition was won by the turnstile operator." mike.ticher@theguardian.com

webTitle: Jones denies there is a 'booze culture' at Wolves

fields.headline: Jones denies there is a 'booze culture' at Wolves
fields.trailText: The Wolves manager Dave Jones reacted quickly yesterday to deny reports that there was a "booze culture" at Molineux after tabloid newspapers carried accusations from two of their foreign playars, Ludovic Pollet and Mohamed Camara.
fields.body:
The Wolves manager Dave Jones reacted quickly yesterday to deny reports that there was a "booze culture" at Molineux after tabloid newspapers carried accusations from two of their foreign playars, Ludovic Pollet and Mohamed Camara.

The two players also moved quickly to distance themselves from the allegations. Pollet said: "The French reporter asked us about life in England and how we had settled down at Wolves. I said that the players made me very welcome and took me for a drink after the game.

"I made a joke that they could drink faster than I could but now this has been reported as if there is a big drink problem at Wolves. There is not. I am upset by this because what I meant was that the players had made me feel very welcome. I meant my comments to be positive."

Jones spoke to both players as well as the journalist who interviewed them. "I'm told the story hasn't appeared over here as it did in France," he said. "It seems to have altered in the translation."

In the article Camara, from Guinea, claimed he could smell alcohol on a player's breath in training and the Frenchman Pollet boasted of his £8,000-a-week salary, more than any player earns in France outside the biggest clubs like Lyon, Paris St-Germain and Marseille. In a statement the club said that Pollet "does not earn anywhere near £8,000 a week after tax as reported - nor does any other player at Molineux".

"I'm not going to hide from it," said Jones. "I'm going to speak to the players properly and speak to my staff. But there is not a drinking culture at this club, I can assure you of that. We will get to the bottom of it, but it's a bit of sensationalism that will become tomorrow's fish-and-chip paper.

"We have both young and experience players in our squad and they all adhere to my rules rigorously," he continued. "I have never tolerated abuse of alcohol and I make that very clear to the whole squad, junior and senior. They know that if they break those rules they would have me to answer to.

"My concern was whether they were talking about the past or the present," said Jones. "If Ludo was referring to when he first arrived here, that was well before I was appointed. But I would want to be fair to the previous manager and speak to him as well. What annoys me is that it appears to be tarring everyone with the same brush."

While Pollet has been made captain since Kevin Muscat's suspension last week, Camara has been a bit-part player since arriving from Le Havre last August. Jones also dismissed Camara's complaint that he has to do weight training twice a week: "He only does that once a week," he said.

webTitle: Robins fights to master his glorious past

fields.headline: Robins fights to master his glorious past
fields.trailText: Rotherham's nomadic striker cannot escape his two famous United goals.
fields.body:
Some people live entirely in the past; others spend their lives trying to get away from it. Mark Robins, at the moment, is very much one of the latter.

Eleven years ago almost to the day, the then 20-year-old met Terry Phelan's cross to score Manchester United's extra-time winner in an FA Cup semi-final against Oldham. In the third round, as the critics rounded on the United manager, he had scored what was tagged "the goal that saved Alex Ferguson", against Nottingham Forest.

"It's not necessarily true that it saved his career, it's just something that the press cottoned on to," Robins says. "At the end of the day we won the game, he picked the team, I was lucky enough to score the goal and that was it really. I'm not really interested in that to be honest. And I don't think he particularly liked the idea that I'd saved his job."

After two further years spent kicking his heels on the United bench - if he was lucky - Robins left to join Norwich, and started an odyssey which has so far taken in eight clubs in nine years. Only at the latest, Rotherham, has he threatened to return to medal-winning ways. The Millers, promoted from the Third Division last season as runners-up, travel to Millwall today with leadership of the Second Division at stake.

"When I came the aim was to try to consolidate in this division. The manager said that if we can stay in this league and build for next season, then that's success. Obviously being in the position we're in now we've got to reassess the situation."

Only goal difference separates them from the Lions with seven games to play, a magnificent return helped in no small part by the 22 goals scored by Robins, making this his most prolific season ever. But the 5ft 7in striker has never quite lived up to his youthful promise.

"Eventually Mark Robins will become a top player," said Ferguson in 1990 while others muttered of England call-ups. "I am one of his admirers. He is a great finisher and has a good football brain."

Though United's youth scheme has since become renowned for producing world-class talent, the 1989 vintage was not its best. Along with Robins emerged Russell Beardsmore, Tony Gill, Deiniol Graham, Lee Martin, Giuliano Maiorana, David Wilson and Lee Sharpe, who had been signed from Torquay aged 17. Only Sharpe is still playing.

"I think I've been lucky in certain things and unlucky in others. I'm lucky to be playing still, to be doing something I love doing, and I'm still relatively successful at it," says Robins. "Even Lee Sharpe, he's done well financially but apart from that, since he left United, I don't think he's had a great time of it.

"There's a lot of players I know from school or from Lilleshall [the former FA school of excellence, of which he was among the first graduates], and the ma jority have gone out of the game. Of the 25 of us at Lilleshall only two are still playing. The rest have either gone out through injury or just didn't make it."

Robins himself was on the slow train to nowhere until he was rescued by Ronnie Moore, Rotherham's 48-year-old manager. "He's a good coach, he's well organised, his tactics have always been spot on," says Robins. "He's a hard taskmaster but he's always available to talk to and can have a laugh when the time's right. He's a good manager, as good as anything I've worked for." Praise indeed, when that list includes Ferguson and Martin O'Neill. But Moore's job is not yet complete.

"There's a very hopeful, optimistic atmosphere here," Robins says. "We've surpassed everybody's expectations, but now it would be disappointing to slip out of the automatic promotion spots. We know it's going to be difficult but, as the old cliche says, the next game's always the most important." On this occasion the cliche is true.

webTitle: The third-tier sides who have reached the last four

fields.headline: The third-tier sides who have reached the last four
fields.trailText: Seven teams from the old Third Division or new Second Division have reached the FA Cup semi-finals. None made it to the final
fields.body:
Seven teams from the old Third Division or new Second Division have reached the FA Cup semi-finals. None made it to the final

1937 Leeds Road, Huddersfield

Millwall 1 Sunderland 2

Millwall, who in 1900 had reached the last four as a Southern League side, knocked out three First Division teams - Chelsea, Derby and Man City - assisted by nine goals from Dave Mangnall. Here he scored a tenth, but they lost.

1954 Villa Park

Port Vale 1 WBA 2

Defence was the main virtue of Freddie Steele's team. They kept a clean sheet from the third round but Albion came from behind to win.

1955 Hillsborough

York City 1 Newcastle Utd 1 Replay, Roker Park

York City 0 Newcastle Utd 2

York looked set for Wembley when Arthur Bottom put them ahead, but Vic Keeble's goal saved Newcastle. Although beaten in replay,York had gone further than any Third Division side.

1959 White Hart Lane

Norwich City 1 Luton Town 1 Replay, St Andrews

Norwich City 0 Luton Town 1

Archie Macaulay's team were strongly fancied to win the Cup in 1959. The big names had gone out, Manchester United and Tottenham at Carrow Road. Yet in the semi-finals a Billy Bingham goal won the replay.

1976 Stamford Bridge

C Palace 0 Southampton 2

Fedorahs in Palace colours showed affinity with Malcolm Allison's headgear. With Peter Taylor on the left Palace were fancied for the final but Lawrie McMenemy's side, then in the Second, had other ideas.

1984 Villa Park

Plymouth Argyle 0 Watford 1

John Hore managed Plymouth for one full season but packed a lot into it. While Argyle had knocked out only one First Division side, WBA, a Wembley place looked possible. But George Reilly's goal settled matters and Hore was sacked the following October.

1997 Old Trafford

Chesterfield 3 Middlesbrough 3

Replay, Hillsborough

Chesterfield 0 Middlesbrough 3

Chesterfield would surely have made history had David Elleray or his assistant seen a Jonathan Howard shot cross the line. That would have given the Spireites a 3-1 lead against 10 men. Instead, Boro survived and won the replay.

webTitle: Comment:Who do Eurosceptics think they are kidding?

fields.headline: April fool? Who do Eurosceptics think they are kidding?
fields.trailText: Hardly surprising that little attention is given to the euro in the week the nation is consumed with anticipation over who killed Phil Mitchell. Very surprising that in such a week, the Sun gives so much space to coverage of Germany.
fields.body:
Hardly surprising that little attention is given to the euro in the week the election is postponed, foot and mouth rages on, the United States and China lock horns and the nation is consumed with anticipation over who killed Phil Mitchell. Very surprising that in such a week, the Sun gives so much space to coverage of Germany.

But the Sun, crowing over its election postponement "exclusive", was in no mood to thank the government for thinking of it first when it decided to release the news. You would have thought gratitude and common decency would have persuaded it to go easy on its euro crusade, if only for a week.

Other Eurosceptic newspapers found it easy enough to put to one side their "save the pound" obsession. But the Sun could not miss a heaven-sent chance to demonstrate that its passion over the euro could not be neutered by a government leak. So when 75% of Germans (as polled by the Allensbach Institute for Public Opinion) said they wanted to keep the mark rather than go over to the euro at the end of the year, the Sun devoted a news story, a leader, and a commentary article to the subject.

The leader asked Sun readers how they would feel if their pensions, mortgages and savings were all to be switched into euros. It was "quite disgraceful" that the Germans had not been able to vote on this, but the British had cause to celebrate, because they would get a chance to vote on the euro. The Sun's political editor, Trevor Kavanagh, supported the leader line, reporting "an explosion of German anger towards the sickly euro, months before it replaces the deutschmark for ever". Top economists, he said, were fighting a hopeless last battle in Germany's constitutional court to abort the switchover. "As the clock ticks, German politicians are looking enviously at Britain's decision to keep the pound until voters agree in a referendum to join."

The Times took up the same theme, if in a less strident way. Its reporter, Roger Boyes, visited an event designed to enthuse Germans about the euro. He found two men dressed as mice distributing chocolate euros to children, and generating very little interest indeed. Real euro coins were laid out before the indifferent public. "To touch the euro is to understand it," said the head of the Bundesbank, Ernst Weltecke. But nobody wanted to.

Perhaps the most significant story for the euro in Britain appeared in the Telegraph: "Goldman Sachs, the American investment bank, has told its clients that it does not think Tony Blair could win a referendum on the euro, and the chance of Britain joining is less than 50%." Goldman Sachs had circulated a research note to its major clients which included this negative message for the euro-enthusiasts: "Given all the hurdles on the way - ensuring economic convergence, winning a referendum, negotiating an acceptable entry rate - we judge the odds in favour of the UK joining EMU in the lifetime of the next parliament are still less than 50%." The Sunday Telegraph, one of the more Eurosceptic papers, ran two characteristic stories, one suggesting that Europe was planning to ruin the fun for chalet girls, the other suggesting that the European commission was bringing in new legislation "recognising individuals' rights over their own voices and distinctive mannerisms". This would prevent Rory Bremner from impersonating Tony Blair or William Hague.

Since it was April 1, clearly one of these was a joke. Since it was the Sunday Telegraph it was not immediately obvious which this was. Actually it was the story suggesting that Rory Bremner's political satire would be outlawed. Which left the chalet girls as the "serious" story: The story said the French authorities intended to implement the code de travail, the "thick red book of 1,862 pages which contains the embodiment of French employment law". Although "not a single complaint" had been received, one Christian Desfontaine felt obliged to look after the welfare of the chalet girls anyway, and that meant paying them a proper wage. But, according to the Sunday Telegraph, this would simply result in ruining their fun by stopping their employment. This is the sort of thing Europeans do, in the eyes of the Eurosceptics.

 Peter Cole is professor of journalism at Sheffield University

webTitle: Madrid mourns the loss of Tombola, the best of the worst TV

fields.headline: Madrid mourns the loss of Tombola, the best of the worst TV
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: And so, farewell, television's Tombola. Where now will we hear the latest rumours about the size of the Count of Lecquio's genitals, the love life of television priest Father Apeles or the sexual exploits of countless minor celebrities?
fields.body:
And so, farewell, television's Tombola. Where now will we hear the latest rumours about the size of the Count of Lecquio's genitals, the love life of television priest Father Apeles or the sexual exploits of countless minor celebrities?

After four years, and 200 shows, Tombola has been purged from Madrid's television screens. The programme in which the famous, nearly famous, and those desperately seeking fame bitched, bickered and defamed, has finally been deemed unfit for public consumption.

"It is absolutely vile," said the new broom at Telemadrid, Francisco Gimenez-Aleman, as he launched the moral and political cleansing of Madrid's public broadcaster.

He was right, of course. Tombola was cheap rot. But that does not mean Madrilenos can live without it. Half-a-million regular viewers are furious.

Imagine a live television cross between the News of the World and OK! Throw in a panel of four piranha-like "journalists" and let them loose on a cast of hundreds of people whose main, or only claim to fame is, well, fame. Oh, and let the programme continue for up to five hours at a time, just so the gossip, insults and tears run and run.

"The guests were paid to be insulted, to reveal the most intimate details of their lives, to awaken the basest instincts in viewers," moaned the new Telemadrid director. So what, say the viewers.

Tombola was addictive. Bullfighters, beauty queens and Latin crooners cropped up - but most guests were only famous for who they claimed to have slept with.

Guests sat through a stream of insults and rude, probing questions. Then they went home with fat cheques. Singer Julio Iglesias's daughter, Chabeli, walked out, hurling insults back. "You're scum!" she shouted. She reportedly pocketed up to £10,000, too.

Sometimes guests were so drunk that they could barely speak. Occasionally there was violence. A descendant of General Franco hurled a glass at an interviewer who had accused him of trafficking cocaine.

The closest Tombola ever got to serious journalism was a claim that the sudden glut of Cuban lovers sported by female Spanish celebrities was the result of a secret operation by Fidel Castro.

The Cuban president, it was argued, had apparently surmised that celebrities were more important than politicians for winning over Spanish hearts and minds, the logic being that a good-looking Cuban on the arm of a Spaniard was good for Cuba.

Without Tombola, what now will the city's taxi drivers talk about? And what about the housewives whose morning coffee break I eavesdrop at my local cafe?

Tombola's share of the ratings, at its peak, hit 63%. The show's advertising revenues subsidised a whole raft of programme-making at Telemadrid, which is otherwise propped up by taxpayers.

Unfortunately, the real reasons for bringing in Mr Gimenez-Aleman and his broom has little to do with improving the minds of Madrilenos. Public television here has always been a political affair.

The previous director was sacked after Telemadrid's current affairs unit broadcast parts of an interview with Arnaldo Otegi, leader of the armed Basque separatist group Eta's political allies in the Herri Batasuna party, during a programme on the Basque country.

It was too much for the prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar's conservative Popular party, which runs the Madrid regional government and, hence, Telemadrid. Balanced reporting of the Basque issue is banned.

"It was not sufficiently belligerent or explicit in its condemnation of terrorism," officials said.

Now Tombola has been replaced by a dull current affairs debate called Loud and Clear. Viewers have simply switched off in droves and Telemadrid's advertising income has tumbled.

Madrilenos hope they will not be asked to fill the hole with their tax money - especially now they have been deprived of their favourite, salacious viewing.

webTitle: SMG warns on downturn in ad revenues

fields.headline: SMG warns on downturn in ad revenues
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Television and radio group SMG yesterday joined the ranks of firms warning about a downturn in advertising.
fields.body:
Television and radio group SMG yesterday joined the ranks of firms warning about a downturn in advertising.

Results for the three months to April showed that SMG's revenues from television interests fell 9% compared with the same period last year.

Chairman Don Cruickshank yesterday told the annual general meeting the company - formerly Scottish Media Group - faced a "challenging" six months, with acute uncertainty over revenues from television and radio advertisers. Mr Cruickshank told an audience at SMG's Glasgow head office that revenues had been hit by poor trading conditions and the reduction in advertising, particularly from dot.com firms. "The economic outlook is [now] less certain.

"A number of advertisers have been holding back on marketing budgets and only committing spend on a very short-term basis, thereby reducing our visibility on prospects over the coming months. As a consequence, we are managing our businesses and controlling our costs very tightly," he said.

One analyst said the first six months of the year were likely "to prove a nightmare" for the media group - which owns Virgin Radio as well as Scottish TV and Grampian TV.

Analysts said they were concerned about the level of revenues from SMG's radio interests, which showed no change from the same period in 2000. One said he had expected a rise of at least 2%, and added that the group was losing ground to competitors such as Capital Radio.

But a source close to the group said that while London-based Virgin Radio has suffered from advertising cutbacks it came after a period of exceptional growth. Virgin's revenues for the year to January were up by more than 22%.

SMG said it had also had to swallow the unexpectedly steep costs for renewing 10-year licences for Scottish TV and Grampian. Yesterday shares in SMG fell 14p, to 187.5p.

Mr Cruikshank also took the opportunity to reaffirm SMG's acquisitive mood. "It is our view that, in the radio sector in particular, consolidation is inevitable, and to that end we have built up our shareholding in Scottish Radio Holdings to just over 29%," he said.

Mr Cruikshank told his audience that the communications white paper had given an indication that Labour was prepared to overhaul cross-media ownership law.

"It is essential for the government to relax the existing regulations if its aim of creating British champions in the global world of media and communications is to be achieved," he said.

webTitle: Why big names went public about being gay

fields.headline: Why big names went public
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText:
Elton John
In a 1976 interview with Rolling Stone magazine, he told the world: "There's nothing wrong with going to bed with someone of your own sex." But then, homosexuality was still widely regarded as a perversion: Caroline Boucher, PR at his record company Rocket, wrote years later: "We had dodged round the issue for years, more from a desire to protect himself than out of fear about what the truth might do to his image."
fields.body:
Elton John
In a 1976 interview with Rolling Stone magazine, he told the world: "There's nothing wrong with going to bed with someone of your own sex." But then, homosexuality was still widely regarded as a perversion: Caroline Boucher, PR at his record company Rocket, wrote years later: "We had dodged round the issue for years, more from a desire to protect himself than out of fear about what the truth might do to his image."

Neil Tennant
One half of the Pet Shop Boys, decided to state the obvious in an interview with Attitude magazine in 1994, nine years after the group's first No 1 single. "I did the piece in Attitude because I think it's a good magazine, but I had a vague feeling that I'd kind of given in about it. But, then, part of me also thought that it was sort of pathetic that when we occasionally gave interviews this issue was always skirted around out of respect for us."

Michael Barrymore
His coming out was rather more accidental: newspapers ran the story after he got on stage to a crowd of East End gays at the White Swan bar in London in 1995. Six years later he still has trouble dealing with his personal life: "I'm still not sure what being gay is - I didn't suddenly become gay," he told the Guardian recently.

Stephen Gately
After fearing he would be outed, the Boyzone singer gave an interview to the Sun in 1999. "This is the most important day of my life. From today I will have the freedom to finally be myself," he told the paper.

fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Guardian reporter Vikram Dodd was named national newspaper journalist of the year at the commission for racial equality's annual race in the media awards.
fields.body:
Guardian reporter Vikram Dodd was named national newspaper journalist of the year at the commission for racial equality's annual race in the media awards.

The judges praised his work on a broad range of racial issues, saying: 'His writing promotes understanding of race relations.'

Maya Jaggi, a Guardian feature writer, was shortlisted.

"To touch the euro is to understand it," said the head of the Bundesbank, Ernst Weltecke. But nobody wanted to. Perhaps the most significant story for the euro in Britain appeared in the Telegraph: "Goldman Sachs, the American investment bank, has told its clients that it does not think Tony Blair could win a referendum on the euro, and the chance of Britain joining is less than 50%." Goldman Sachs had circulated a research note to its major clients which included this negative message for the euro-enthusiasts: "Given all the hurdles on the way - ensuring economic convergence, winning a referendum, negotiating an acceptable entry rate - we judge the odds in favour of the UK joining EMU in the lifetime of the next parliament are still less than 50%." The Sunday Telegraph, one of the more Eurosceptic papers, ran two characteristic stories, one suggesting that Europe was planning to ruin the fun for chalet girls, the other suggesting that the European commission was bringing in new legislation "recognising individuals' rights over their own voices and distinctive mannerisms". This would prevent Rory Bremner from impersonating Tony Blair or William Hague. Since it was April 1, clearly one of these was a joke. Since it was the Sunday Telegraph it was not immediately obvious which this was. Actually it was the story suggesting that Rory Bremner's political satire would be outlawed. Which left the chalet girls as the "serious" story: The story said the French authorities intended to implement the code de travail , the "thick red book of 1,862 pages which contains the embodiment of French employment law". Although "not a single complaint" had been received, one Christian Desfontaine felt obliged to look after the welfare of the chalet girls anyway, and that meant paying them a proper wage. But, according to the Sunday Telegraph, this would simply result in ruining their fun by stopping their employment. This is the sort of thing Europeans do, in the eyes of the Eurosceptics.  Peter Cole is professor of journalism at Sheffield University

webTitle: Coming out nerves for Radio 1's early bird

fields.headline: Coming out nerves for Radio 1's early bird
fields.standfirst:
DJ Scott Mills hopes to head off tabloid hounds by declaring his homosexuality before they do, but he risks a conservative backlash

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: DJ Scott Mills hopes to head off tabloid hounds by declaring his homosexuality before they do, but he risks a conservative backlash.
fields.body:
While it may seem odd that the sexuality of a Radio 1 disc jockey could still be an issue in the 21st century, coming out when your target audience includes millions of teenagers risks incurring the wrath of conservative forces who still see homosexuality as a corrupting influence.

But Scott Mills, regarded as one of the station's most promising young stars, has decided that his sexuality is an important part of his character and should be acknowledged publicly. "It's not a secret at all, and I've always felt comfortable with it. But that's all people need to know really," he told the Guardian in an interview yesterday.

Mills, 27, decided to speak now to get the issue out of the way. As his profile grew, the news would have emerged anyway: better to manage it than be forced by tabloid hounding.

Seated on a leopard-print sofa in the basement bar at Bush House in London, home of the BBC World Service, Mills appeared nervous about the whole idea. But he insisted that, while he never made a pretence about his homosexuality, he had become aware that there was a part of his personality that was hidden from listeners.

"A lot of [gay] people in the public eye will talk about their girlfriends, and I've certainly never done that. It's not ever something I've really felt like I wanted to talk about before, or that I've had the opportunity to talk about before."

Mills will appear next week on That Gay Show, a new series for the digital entertainment channel BBC Choice, and in the gay lifestyle magazine Attitude.

"I've been offered the chance to do this TV show. Paul [the Radio 1 publicist] and I had this conversation about it and said it would be a good idea, and then we thought we'd better do the rest of it as well. A lot of people know anyway, but it's never been really said on the air."

Mills reckoned his listeners would not be fazed. "The target Radio 1 audience will, I hope, be fine about it. The climate has changed, even in the past five years."

But despite his public statement now, he insisted that he would not make an issue of his sexuality, or prattle on about his love life (his is single) on air. "I'm certainly not going to turn into some gay ambassador all of a sudden, because that's not me. I'm not a campaigner."

Mills, 27, presents Radio 1's early breakfast show, 4am to 7am. He was the likeliest internal candidate to take over from Zoe Ball on the main breakfast show when it came up at the end of 1999 but was narrowly beaten by the TV presenter Sara Cox.

He is now Cox's regular stand-in and sometimes presents the Top 40 chart show on Sundays. At the BBC, the frequency with which he deputises for other presenters has brought him the nickname "Scott Mills In For".

He joined Radio 1 three years ago from Heart FM in London, where he had to endure years of playing Elton John and Simply Red records. At age 16 he had become Britain's youngest professional radio DJ when he joined Power FM in Hampshire. At the BBC his star is rising. Some critics say Cox's show is not performing well; Mills is bound to get a peak time show sooner or later.

Mills said tactfully he was not ready for the breakfast show when it came up, but he is clearly ambitious. Musically, he claims not to be a "pop snob" but sees dance and R&B as the focus of his interests. But he says that predictions of the demise of chart singles are premature.

"I'm not a fan of Hear'Say, but that whole Popstars thing is amazing for the music industry," he said. "Even if you don't like the songs, you have to look at the figures. A while ago records were selling three copies and getting to number one, and the credibility and longevity of the singles chart could be questioned."

The future of the chart is now secure, even if original musicians s find it hard to break through. "I wish sometimes it was still a bit special, like it was 10 years ago. But I still think it's an event, if you look at the audience figures for the Top 40."

Mills has a nervous period ahead, but hopes to be accepted - or rejected - for his talent behind the microphone rather than his sexuality.

His bosses are backing him: station controller Andy Parfitt, on paternity leave, is supportive; his deputy, Lorna Clarke, head of mainstream programmes, said: "Scott's sexuality has never been an issue since he joined Radio 1. He's always been 'out' to his colleagues at the station. Sexuality just isn't so much of an issue in the 21st century, particularly amongst our target audience."

Mills added: "I just want to be me, to be Scott and be a DJ on Radio 1 that people either like to listen to or don't like to listen to. I'm not going to start appearing on Gaytime TV in pink shirts - I'd just like to be accepted as a normal bloke who is gay and is on the radio and the television."

webTitle: Collectors gunning for the one-armed bandits

fields.headline: Collectors gunning for the one-armed bandits
fields.standfirst: Christie's is slotting in to a new niche market with an auction of gaming machines and automatons. Stewart Dalby reports
fields.trailText: Christie's is slotting in to a new niche market with an auction of gaming machines and automatons. Stewart Dalby reports.
fields.body:
In its endless drive to create new collectable niches, Christie's South Kensington is adding gaming machines, automata and enamel signs to the first of its tri-annual mechanical music sales of 2001. This will take place on April 12 and estimates range from £300 to £12,000.

As often happens, the impetus for a new category of sale has been the availability of a collection. The machines belonging to the Marquis of Bath were on display at Longleat, his estate in Wiltshire, until 1997. The collection comprises seven devices, including a two-player cricket gaming machine, circa 1905 (estimated at £3,000 to £5,000), while a pair of miniature cast iron shooting ranges are expected to fetch up to £800 each.

A football game produced in the 1930s is estimated at £2,000 to £3,000. There are two rare working models of a haunted house and a witch's cave. These mechanical scenes, enclosed in wood and wrought iron cases, would have originally been found on the piers or in the arcades of seaside resorts, a sort of what-the-butler saw attraction where tourists would be tempted to pay their penny and see the witch at her cauldron casting spells or the inhabitants of the haunted house being terrified by ghosts. Each model is estimated at £2,000 to £3,000.

One of the star attractions of the sale is the Enigma enciphering machine. I reckon it will be of special interest. These machines are now rare and there was a lot of publicity in October when one was stolen from the Bletchley Park museum and a £25,000 ransom was demanded; it was later posted to Newsnight presenter Jeremy Paxman at the BBC.

Before that, they were highlighted by Robert Harris' best-selling novel Enigma about how these machines helped crack Nazi codes during the second world war.

The four-rotor example in the sale is believed to have been used in Scandinavia by a businessman in touch with the German authorities during the war. It is similar to those famously used at Bletchley Park to break the codes. This was crucial in allowing the North Atlantic convoys a clear run.

The machine is estimated to fetch £8,000 to £12,000, but, since they do not come up very often, it will be interesting to see what it does realise.

Also on offer is a musical automaton carousel made by the Swiss firm Bornand Freres. This is a coin-operated merry-go-round, which is driven by a musical movement that makes two dolls dance in the glazed hexagonal case. This is priced at £7,000 to £10,000.

Another piece is a Roullet et Decamps automaton of a saint holding a christchild that raises its arm and blinks, produced around the turn of the century. This has an estimate of £3,000 to £5,000.

And there is an array of gaming machines and technical apparatus. In particular there is a rare "John Wayne" one-armed bandit, from the late 1950s made by the American company Mills. It stands 7ft tall and is estimated at £1,500 to £2,000.

There is also a carved, polished Native American slot machine. This is based on a series of machines designed by Frank Polk, concentrating on American folk art, and is expected to fetch up to £3,000.

Nicholas Hawkins, at Christie's in South Kensington, says: "There is a small but very dedicated bunch of collectors for musical and other machines. However, prices are very steady. They do not rise that much year on year."

With gaming machines the market is a bit different. Theme restaurants, and a growing band of collectors are interested. Mr Hawkins adds: "Whether they equal the number of buyers for ski posters is debatable."

Christie's, tel: 020-7581 7611, or go to www.christies.com
