webTitle: The pension revolution starts with a whimper

fields.headline: The pension revolution starts with a whimper
fields.standfirst: Most workers believe that the government should raise state payouts rather than introduce new retirement plans - and 17% of employers do not intend to set up a scheme.
fields.trailText: Most workers believe that the government should raise state payouts rather than introduce new retirement plans - and 17% of employers do not intend to set up a scheme.
fields.body:
Nearly two-thirds of workers believe the government should continue to provide an adequate state pension rather than force people to rely on a mix of basic pension, income support benefits and the new stakeholder pension, according to exclusive research this week for Jobs & Money.

The nationwide poll, commissioned by the Post Office, reveals that 63% of people questioned want the government to beef up the current state pension, eliminating any need for the stakeholder scheme that was officially launched yesterday.

Currently 52% of the population do not contribute to a pension, according to the study. Many of them preferred to rely on savings to top up the state pension, while 16% invested in either individual savings accounts (Isas) or property.

The government wants everyone who cannot currently rely on a company pension scheme to join its stakeholder scheme, either by switching their personal pension to a stakeholder scheme or starting one from scratch.

Anyone who pays into a company scheme, whether it is a defined contribution scheme or linked to their final salary, can also top up their payments into a separate personal stake holder pension provided they earn less than £30,000.

Stakeholder rules restrict management charges to 1%, allow minimum payments of no more than £20 and protect people from penalty fees if they stop and start their payments. Contributions up to £3,600 gross a year can be made regardless of earnings, which means that a non-earning wife or husband and even children can take advantage of the tax-efficient funding for a personal pension for the first time.

Unfortunately for the gov ernment, the survey also reveals that many of the people currently without a pension are unlikely to start one, despite the dramatic cut in costs heralded by the stakeholder scheme.

A lack of spare cash (35%), confusion over how to put a foot on the pensions ladder (18%) and concern over high profile pension scandals (10%) topped the list of excuses not to invest. The percentage of people unlikely to join a stakeholder scheme rises to nearly three-quarters when the number of people who refuse to plan more than five years ahead are included.

A survey by Marks & Spencer Financial Services heaps on more pain for the government. The company's regular barometer of awareness of stakeholder pensions found that while an additional 4m people have heard of stakeholder since its last survey in January, "only 6% of the population intend to take action in the near future".

The survey also found that 70% of people questioned remained unaware that stakeholder pensions even existed.

One crucial target for the government is small and medium-sized businesses. Stakeholder rules will force employers with five or more staff to set up a stakeholder pension scheme that all employees can join. Employers have until October to set up a scheme, after which time they will be liable for fines that could reach £50,000 if they fail to take action.

Several surveys, including one commissioned by the Prudential, have found that many employers show little sign of knowing about or understanding their obligations. The Pru's survey shows that 17% of employers said they had no intention of offering their staff access to a scheme or are unsure whether they will.

More cheerily for the government, the survey points to a dramatic increase in the number of small and medium sized businesses that are aware of the scheme. It shows that 96% of employers know about the scheme and 83% plan to offer employees the chance to save in a stakeholder pension for their retirement.

Most pension providers have put in place a range of stakeholder funds, though not all will be signing up. Companies such as Allied Dunbar, which has a large door-to-door salesforce, will continue to offer old-style pensions. They claim that the benefits offered by their tailor-made schemes and higher performance outweigh the benefits of lower costs.

But most of the biggest players are jumping aboard the stakeholder bandwagon, including Norwich Union, Standard Life, Legal & General and the Pru.

Many of them are offering special benefits through organisations such as the Trades Union Congress, which is offering five funds, two of them backed by Standard Life and the other three by the Pru. The TUC has cut a deal that will allow trade union members and non-members to reduce the management costs they pay to 0.85%.

Most providers have set their management fees below the government ceiling of 1%, but in general savers must have more than £10,000 in their fund to get this rate. The TUC deal takes effect from the first £10.

Some critics of the government's plan believe that encouraging large numbers of people on low and medium incomes into pensions that rely heavily on a rising stock market to grow, needs greater safeguards.

The Industrial Society said this week in a report, Pension Tension, that the stakeholder rules should be strengthened, requiring employers to make a contribution to schemes. It also calls for a government-backed insurance scheme to underwrite stakeholder schemes and to raise the basic state pension. There will be many sympathisers for this last recommendation.

fields.headline: Big freeze cuts Autonomy price
fields.standfirst:
Worst-ever day for one of software sector's brightest hopes as sales dry up

More internet news
fields.trailText: Worst-ever day for one of software sector's brightest hopes as sales dry up.
fields.body:
Autonomy, one of the British software sector's brightest hopes, suffered its worst ever day on the stock market yesterday when the price of its shares halved on the back of an announcement that sales had suddenly dried up.

Shares slumped by 51% at one stage and closed down 245p at 325p. It left a company - less than six months ago one of Britain's 50 biggest concerns with a market value of £5bn - worth just £408m.

Founder Dr Mike Lynch, whose holding propelled him to within a whisker of becoming Britain's first internet billionaire, has seen the value of his shares fall by almost £900m to £73m during that time.

Analysts across the City slashed their forecasts for the Cambridge-based company after it admitted that it would miss its first quarter financial targets by some distance.

It blamed a sudden freeze on information technology spending by big European customers and worsening economic conditions in its important US market.

Ten weeks after issuing a positive trading statement Autonomy said that revenues for the three months to March 31 are now likely to come in at $14m to 15m compared to the $24m that house broker Deutsche Bank was expecting.

The broker, fearing things could get worse, slashed its revenue forecast for the second quarter by almost two thirds to $10m and admitted it could see the shares fall below 200p.

"The UK and European slow down was a shock," said analyst Darren Curtis. "If second quarter revenues are in the region of $10m, only a very strong recovery in the second half would enable Autonomy to grow year on year."

Richard Gaunt, Autonomy's chief technology officer and co-founder, said that the figures looked so bad because customers had frozen their budgets in the last two weeks of the quarter which is the period when most technology companies sign deals they have been working on in previous months.

"We were doing normal business through the entire sales cycle but when it came to the final signing on the dotted line their budgets simply froze. These companies are looking at revenues, seeing their problems, jumping on costs and cutting spending wherever they can. It's a ripple effect that is happening across the US but we had not expected it to become a European phenomena."

He added that he was optimistic that the deals that had been frozen would eventually be signed and insisted that because Autonomy's software sales generated such high profit margins the company was likely to remain profitable. There are no plans to lay off any staff or restructure.

"This is not a case of a company going to the wall and we have plenty of money in the bank," he said.

The global software sector has experienced a significant slowdown since the start of the year. Analysts believe it will grow by just 6% this year, compared to 30% in 2000.

Several of the big manufacturers that Autonomy sells products through, such as Sybase and E.Piphany, are experiencing problems of their own suggesting that an upswing in sales may not be immediate.

Richard Gaunt, Autonomy's chief technology officer and co-founder, said that the figures looked so bad because customers had frozen their budgets in the last two weeks of the quarter which is the period when most technology companies sign deals they have been working on in previous months. "We were doing normal business through the entire sales cycle but when it came to the final signing on the dotted line their budgets simply froze. These companies are looking at revenues, seeing their problems, jumping on costs and cutting spending wherever they can. It's a ripple effect that is happening across the US but we had not expected it to become a European phenomena." He added that he was optimistic that the deals that had been frozen would eventually be signed and insisted that because Autonomy's software sales generated such high profit margins the company was likely to remain profitable. There are no plans to lay off any staff or restructure. "This is not a case of a company going to the wall and we have plenty of money in the bank," he said. The global software sector has experienced a significant slowdown since the start of the year. Analysts believe it will grow by just 6% this year, compared to 30% in 2000. Several of the big manufacturers that Autonomy sells products through, such as Sybase and E.Piphany, are experiencing problems of their own suggesting that an upswing in sales may not be immediate.

fields.headline: Savers face a slow torture
fields.trailText: The Bank of England's decision to cut another quarter-point off the base rate means that savers can expect to see the returns they enjoy shrink even further. So it's crucial to review the rate you are being paid and move your money if it is not working hard enough.
fields.body:
The Bank of England's decision to cut another quarter-point off the base rate means that savers can expect to see the returns they enjoy shrink even further. So it's crucial to review the rate you are being paid and move your money if it is not working hard enough.

Most banks and building societies will trickle out details of their savings rate reductions over the next two or three weeks, so keep an eye out for the ads they put in newspapers to notify customers - and watch future editions of Jobs & Money too, of course.

Halifax says full details of changes to its savings rates which will take effect on May 1 will be unveiled "later this month", while Nationwide says its savings rates are under review with an announcement to be made "in due course".

One of the few providers to announce rate reductions immediately after the base rate cut was Abbey National's online bank Cahoot. However, its current account rate cuts do not affect existing customers, who will continue to benefit from returns of up to 7.1% gross.

Those investing less than £5,000 in a new Cahoot current account who don't opt for a chequebook will receive 6.2% instead of 6.5%. The biggest cut is being imposed on new customers who stash away more than £50,000 and forego a chequebook: the 7.1% rate has been slashed to 6%.

New research from Sainsbury's Bank highlights the poor deal millions of savers are getting. It reveals that the average rate of interest for £5,000 in an instant access account is now just 1.40% gross compared to 12.27% ten years ago. Yet it found that almost two-thirds of savers are under the illusion that they would not be any better off if they switched.

As things stand, the best instant access-style account rates include Capital One Bank's 6.1% on its Direct Saver 2 account (includes a 0.4% interest bonus for the first six months), internet and phone bank Intelligent Finance's Direct Access account paying 6%, and Standard Life Bank's 5.55% on its Direct Access account, says data provider Moneyfacts. For online accounts the best rates are offered by Nationwide, Halifax and Egg (6.3%, 6.1% and 6% respectively).

Investment watchdog the Financial Services Authority (FSA) says savers need to understand that today's low-inflation, low-interest environment means lower returns - but also that low inflation protects the value of savings.

It is worried that savers in search of higher returns will buy risky products, unaware of the dangers. "Consumers should be wary of any investment product offering the sort of high returns commonly available during the 80s and early 90s," says the FSA.

fields.headline: Who offers the best deals?
fields.trailText: Building societies and other mutuals frequently make the point that they can deliver better rates to their customers because they don't have shareholders to satisfy. Here we look at whether they really do offer a better deal than banks and other non-member-owned companies.
fields.body:
Building societies and other mutuals frequently make the point that they can deliver better rates to their customers because they don't have shareholders to satisfy. Here we look at whether they really do offer a better deal than banks and other non-member-owned companies.

Savings and investment

A glance at the savings account best buy tables would seem to suggest mutuals don't exactly wipe the floor with the opposition when it comes to which providers offer the best interest rates. For example, of the six top-paying instant access-style account providers listed by financial data providers Moneyfacts, only one - Standard Life Bank - bats on the mutuals' side. Its Direct Access account pays from 5.55%.

However, while they might not always top the rate tables, research indicates that on many savings products mutuals tend to deliver a better performance over time than their banking rivals. Online bank Egg is a good example of a non-mutual that has topped the tables in the past, but whose standard savings account rate has fallen back significantly recently.

A new Moneyfacts survey of mini-cash Isas found that 23 of the 25 best performers were offered by building societies. The survey looked at the maturity value of accounts this week, assuming the maximum £3,000 was invested exactly a year ago. The best return - £3,224 - was achieved by Coventry building society's members-only Privilege Isa, followed by Cumbria-based Furness building society's 100-day notice Isa (£3,216). A study of Tessa-only Isa accounts produced a similar result - 22 of the top 25 institutions were building societies.

Mortgages

Do building societies offer better deals than banks? "Sometimes they do, sometimes they don't," says Ray Boulger at mortgage broker Charcol. As if to illustrate the point, of the six best buy fixed-rate mortgage deals he highlights, three are from building societies and three from banks. The building so ciety deals include separate loans from the Cheshire and Derbyshire building societies each fixed at 5.59% for five years.

The Nationwide has also muddied the waters by phasing out its old standard variable mortgage rate and bringing in a new "base mortgage rate" - a decision which has been welcomed by some of its borrowers, but has infuriated others who will not enjoy the benefits.

With mortgages in particular, it's the long-term performance that's important. As with Isa savings accounts, building societies trounced the opposition in a Moneyfacts survey of mortgage lenders which looked at the total interest paid on a £50,000 standard variable rate mortgage between January 1 2000 and December 31 2000. Of the 10 cheapest lenders, eight were mutuals. Standard Life Bank came out best value of all with a total annual interest repayment of £3,444, followed by the Cheshire and Coventry building societies, which both offer lower mortgage rates to loyal members.

Life insurance and pensions

The mutual insurance sector is shrinking rapidly, but the remaining players are delivering good returns in some areas. While bonuses for with-profit endowments have been cut across the industry, Co-operative Insurance stands out following its decision to maintain last year's rate of 5%.

Looking at low-cost with-profits endowments, based on a non-smoking 30-year-old male paying in £500 a year over 10 years, Liverpool Victoria (the UK's largest friendly society and a mutual) came out top, delivering a fund worth £10,253. Second, third and fourth place were also taken by mutuals or companies owned by mutuals: Standard Life, Co-operative Insurance Society and Scottish Friendly.

But Patrick Connolly at IFA Chartwell Investment Management says: "There is certainly nothing to suggest mutuals outperform non-mutuals."

fields.headline: Mutual friends and deadly enemies
fields.standfirst: The fight to repel carpetbaggers is being stepped up - not least by Britain's biggest building society. But, reports Phillip Inman, many people genuinely feel they have been let down
fields.trailText: The fight to repel carpetbaggers is being stepped up - not least by Britain's biggest building society. But, reports Phillip Inman, many people genuinely feel they have been let down.
fields.body:
When Barclays tried to charge customers from rival banks £1 to use its cash machines, critics argued that we were witness to a public company using a commercial decision as a cloak for greed.

The bank, along with its high street neighbours NatWest, Lloyds and HSBC, had just gatecrashed the Link atm network, set up 20 years previously by a group of building societies. Despite making billions of pounds in profits, the banks argued that the costs of running their atm networks must be recouped by higher charges.

Many Link members had converted to banks over the years and sympathised with the new, aggressive membership, but those that remained mutually owned, led by the Nationwide building society and the Co-op bank, refused to roll over.

"It was profiteering," says Brian Davis, the Nationwide's chief executive. "And quite clearly for customers it was a rip-off." To the supporters of mutual societies, companies like the Nationwide acted as a bulwark against greedy banks in spectacular fashion.

"The banks have got to charge you more to keep driving up their profits," says Mr Davis. "It's just a case of how they do it. They must pay their shareholders. We distribute surpluses to our members."

Next month, a think tank funded by the mutual insurers, building societies and retail co-operative societies, including the Co-op Bank and Co-operative Insurance Services (CIS) will be officially launched. It aims to demonstrate that victory in the cash machine war was not an isolated incident.

Communicate Mutuality will argue that there are many areas of our lives that can be run co-operatively or by mutual societies with hard-nosed business acumen to the fore. Books and discussion documents will be published under the Mutuo.co.uk banner.

Peter Hunt, who will be executive director of the unit, says that mutuality is a hard concept to sell, but it will be his job to generate ideas for new kinds of mutual and co-operative businesses.

Yet, looked at from a different angle, you could say the mutual sector has been less than successful at defending itself against carpetbaggers over the past decade. And this year looks as though it will be no exception. Despite Mr Davis' protestations, this week his building society received 820 nominations for a motion that recommends the society transform itself into a public company and turn each member into a shareholder. If the signatures are declared valid, the move would translate each "share" in the mutual society into stock market listed shares worth £700-£800.

Votes for demutualisation are expected in several mutual insurers later this year. Scottish Provident is in the process of being taken over by Abbey National, Friends Provident is converting into a plc and National Mutual has put itself up for sale. In the case of Scottish Provident, payouts for with-profits members are expected to top £4,500.

Many of these companies have simply given up the ghost in the face of competition from the banks. The need to fund huge marketing campaigns and keep up in a fast moving industry sapped their resources and rather than wait for a carpetbagger to come along the board of directors recommended selling.

The victims are everywhere. Scottish Widows (bought by Lloyds) and Scottish Amicable (swallowed by Prudential) are two of many that are now divisions of their respective owners.

Society members have often said they are susceptible to voting for the money because mutuals have acted much like public companies, paying little attention to their members. For instance, many building societies have been accused of relying on obscure clauses in their rule books to avoid demutualisation motions, rather than argue the merits of the case.

The Portman was accused this week by pro-mutuality campaigner Tim Tanner of doing just that, after he found that 250 of the 700 signatures he secured in support of motions calling for greater democracy had been ruled out of order. A spokesman for the Portman vigorously denies underhand tactics. "We don't think we have been nitpicking or devious," he says.

Andrew Muir, who is running the campaign against the Nationwide board, makes similar noises about the frustrations of members. He says he believes in mutuality but makes a distinction between large organisations like the Nationwide and smaller, local and inherently more democratic mutual businesses.

"When you have an organisation this size it is fairer that members have a tradeable share in the business, which a stock market listing would give them," he says. Of course those shares can go down, as Halifax shareholders found.

Once, running a mutual would also mean lower pay for the directors. Not now. Brian Davis at the Nationwide, for instance, pocketed annual pay and bonuses of £695,000 last year. His counterpart at the Abbey National, Ian Harley, received £774,162. The Abbey, which demutualised 10 years ago, is a bigger company and arguably more complicated to run.

Jonathan Michie, the Sainsbury professor of management at Birkbeck College, University of London, has written widely about mutual societies. He believes societies react more quickly to their members' con cerns than they did 10 years ago. "It's true that many organisations didn't have a different ethos to the plcs, but now many have changed their ways and adopt good governance, which in turn places them in a better position to fight off carpetbaggers," he says.

The Nationwide looks certain to survive as a mutual, at least in the near future. While it has accepted that Mr Tanner, who has targeted the Nationwide along with the Portman, has received sufficient valid signatures to put forward his resolutions, it has already signalled that Mr Muir's plan is probably unconstitutional.

Part of its protection plan after the demutualisation move three years ago forced new members to donate any windfalls to charity. "The long-term interests of members were being jeopardised by new members," says Mr Davis.

The phrase long-term lies at the heart of the Nationwide's problem. In a world where a significant proportion of customers are willing to switch to the latest "best buy", a mutual without tough rules against carpetbagging cannot survive. And yet those rules make it seem insulated and aloof.

Even so, despite the efforts of Mr Muir, other mutuals seem safe from carpetbaggers for now.

fields.headline: Pop's so-so Guru
fields.standfirst:
Guru's Jazzmatazz
Brixton Academy, London
***
fields.trailText:
Guru's Jazzmatazz
Brixton Academy, London
***
fields.body:
New York's Guru lives up to his moniker, which stands for Gifted Unlimited Rhymes Universal. He is as swaggering as you would expect of someone whose first name is Gifted, and as inclined to put on a meandering show that seems staged for his own amusement rather than that of the audience.

The esteem in which he holds himself was reflected by a huge backdrop photo, which for long chunks of the set was all we saw of him. Refusing to be bound by the convention that expects the star of the show to actually be on stage most of the time, Guru left much of the work to guest stars while he flitted backstage to polish his leather suit.

Luckily for him, there was no shortage of talent to fill the gaps. The respect he has accrued as the rapping half of the hip-hop duo Gang Starr enables him to borrow serious muscle when he puts out occasional albums as Jazzmatazz. The latest, Streetsoul, features Craig David and Macy Gray, along with old-school heavyweights such as Isaac Hayes. For this sole British date - the 30th stop of his European tour, he kept reminding us - he had prevailed on the hippest names passing through town this week, including Kelis and the operatic soul sensation Lina.

Lina's flirtatious opening set was worth the price of admission alone, but during the long subsequent interval an increasingly harried DJ jollied us along: "Are you ready for Guru? Do you know what time it is?" Yes, it's 9.45. Get Guru on.

Eventually he strolled in, and plunged into one of Streetsoul's jazz-rap numbers - he gruffly rapped, the band sauntered through a seemingly unrelated piece of loose-limbed jazz. Courtney Pine arrived with his avenging saxophone, the veteran soulstress N'Dea Davenport added her voice to the melee and Lina came again and went, as did a vibrant Kelis. Good thinking, surrounding himself with sexy girls, because it was only too plain that he lacks the ideas to carry a long evening alone.

After a while, linear time ceased to have meaning. It wasn't a gig, it was a rehearsal, and a so-so one at that. Gifted Unlimited he may be, but he has plenty to learn about this showmanship thing.

fields.headline: Global vision boosts Peps
fields.standfirst: This week's loosening of investment rules may trigger a sales bonanza and a rise in returns for investors, write Tony Levene and Jill Papworth.
fields.trailText: This week's loosening of investment rules may trigger a sales bonanza and a rise in returns for investors, write Tony Levene and Jill Papworth.
fields.body:
Teenagers can now buy tax-free cash Isas - provided it is their own money and not cash from parents - following a change in the rules this week.

And new legislation has replaced the old UK and continental Pep investment boundaries with the Isa worldwide investment range.

Sixteen and 17-year-olds will be able to invest up to £3,000 a year into a cash mini-Isa - and pay no tax on the interest. For most in this age group, there is no obvious, immediate benefit. Only a small number have full-time work and, while many have Saturday jobs, few earn enough to pay tax.

Any existing savings are tax-free providing they fill in form R85, unless the capital comes from parents, when interest is only untaxed if it does not exceed £100 a year.

But providing the teenager is prepared to save for the longer term, the cash mini-Isa can make sense. Putting £3,000 a year into the scheme will keep it out of the taxman's clutches for as long as Isas exist - at least another eight years. That would give today's teenager a tax-free cash fund even after their earnings top the personal allowance limit.

It also gives access to Isa accounts where interest rates can be higher, especially on small amounts.

Peps - whether in unit or investment trusts or individual companies, including the single company plans - have been off the sales agenda for two years. But they are now back in the sights of advisers and unit trust companies because they have the same investment freedom as Isas - opening up the US, the Far East, technology, hedge funds, world bond trusts, and big international investment trusts.

They see a potential sales bonanza in convincing millions of holders to switch out of old funds into new trusts. One estimate is that total Pep holdings exceed £150bn.

Most Pep holders have never moved their funds, even though they were able to do so, providing they didn't stray outside the EU.

A further change ends the rule that different Peps with the same provider have to be treated as one investment. Now they can be unbundled so an investor unhappy with the growth fund, but pleased with the same manager's bond fund, can keep the good trust while ditching the other.

Darius McDermott, at discount broker Chelsea Financial Services, believes that anyone hoping to revitalise an old collection of Peps should look at online fund supermarkets. "We've set up the Chelsea Portfolio as a cost-effective way of diversifying investments," he says.

"Some of our clients now have in excess of £100,000 in Peps. We give a choice of 230 funds from 25 managers, but investors end up with just one valuation for all their Pep and Isa investments in this wrapper, and one point of contact for problems."

Chelsea's portfolio operates through Cofunds - whose website is not due to start until midsummer, six months later than planned. "Wherever you go, all transfers are paper-based at the moment," says McDermott. "We aim to make transfers of old Peps free or costing no more than 0.5%, depending on the fund."

Fidelity's FundsNetwork is Cofunds's rival and it is already online. This features a £1,000 trust minimum for the 440 funds from 32 providers on the scheme.

Sticking with their HTT holding, either by receiving a share certificate in their own name, or transferring it to a comparable wrapper product offered by Polar Capital;

Switching to any other Henderson managed investment trust offered within its wrapper products;

Moving into the Henderson Global Technology OEIC, now managed by a new team;

Transferring your HTT holding to a different Isa provider;

Selling the HTT holding through the plan.

fields.headline: The gasman cometh
fields.standfirst:
But only when you are outeth

Guardian Unlimited Shopping
Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: Right now we wish we were waiting for the plumber. Or the gas man. Or that sofa we ordered six weeks ago.
fields.body:
Right now we wish we were waiting for the plumber. Or the gas man. Or that sofa we ordered six weeks ago.

We wish we were expecting them today, Saturday, because we are at home today. We work during the week, but are at home on weekends, so today or tomorrow would have been perfect for a delivery.

But, for some reason we cannot quite fathom, weekends are the one time when repairmen and the like never come. Instead, they come when we are out and stay away when we are in. It is so frustrating!

We are not the only ones to suffer this irritation. A survey this week found that British employees spend up to 56m working days a year waiting for items to be delivered or repairmen to call.

On average, we have to waste two days a year hanging around at home for a visit that would have been much more convenient in the evening or at the weekend. And the misery does not end there.

Half of us are given no clear idea of when to expect someone. We are fobbed off with a mere "am or pm", forcing us to waste a whole morning or afternoon. Even when a time has been fixed, 44% of delivery staff or repairers turn up late or not at all.

This might have made sense back in the dark ages, when at least one person - usually the wife - was at home all day. But now that so many of us are out at work, a policy of daytime house calls only is silly. These days we expect service around the clock. Thanks to the internet and the telephone, plenty of tasks once confined to the daylight hours, like banking, are now available 24/7.

How can we force the deliverers into line? Perhaps we should give them a taste of their own medicine. Next time they tune into the ten o'clock news, they should have to wait three hours. They should visit a restaurant in the evening, only to find it closed. And when they go downstairs for their morning paper, it should be missing - with a pre-printed note of apology, explaining that we only deliver in the afternoons.

fields.headline: Hallé/Vanska
fields.standfirst:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
****
fields.trailText:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
****
fields.body:
Elisabeth Batiashvili is rapidly emerging as one of the most exciting violinists of her generation, attracting widespread attention since gaining second prize in the 1995 Sibelius Competition, aged just 16. Her Hallé debut, partnering Osmo Vanska in Beethoven's Violin Concerto, gave Manchester audiences a chance to hear a repeat of her acclaimed performance at last year's Proms. At 21, her supreme technical mastery of Beethoven's Concerto is enviable; but that is not what makes her special. Technique is overlaid with a musical authority that is both distinctive and commanding.

The Beethoven Concerto is one of the most lyrical in the repertoire, with long stretches of haunting stillness that require careful handling if they are not to drag. But Batiashvili was in no hurry: each phrase was lingered over with loving care, as though she had all the time in the world. Arguably, the larghetto is not well served by this approach: some momentum is inevitably lost.

Perversely, to apply rubato so consistently also robs this movement of its timeless, static quality. In Batiashvili's hands, it became a kind of recitative-fantasia, both spellbinding and touching.

To respond to every nuance as the Hallé did takes extraordinary flexibility. There was no lingering in the usually light-hearted finale, though. Its whimsical humour was replaced by something far more elemental; at the end of a breathtakingly virtuosic performance, the audience erupted.

Two of Jean Sibelius's Lemminkainen Legends remained unpublished until 1954; in the meantime, the second of the cycle, The Swan of Tuonela, and the final movement, Lemminkainen's Return, became established repertoire. It is easy to see why the third, Lemminkainen in Tuonela, was not able to flourish independently: it is dark and so tightly woven that it appears almost monothematic. But the exotic first movement, depicting the maidens of Saari, is self-contained and colourful.

Together, the four legends constitute an epic narrative of love, enchantment, death and rebirth almost symphonic in scale. The Hallé's performance of the third and final movements bristled with nervous energy under Vanska's fast tempi; the eerie melancholy of the second movement was mesmerisingly captured in Tom Davey's haunting cor anglais solo.

webTitle: Jazz review:  Julian Joseph/ Gary Thomas

fields.headline: Julian Joseph/ Gary Thomas
fields.standfirst:
Wigmore Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Wigmore Hall, London
****
fields.body:
The uncharitable might observe that you can tell something about the age and dispositions of the Wigmore Hall's core audience from its gents' lavatories - where most venues exhibit a condom-vending machine, the Wigmore's dispenses Anadin and indigestion tablets. Yet Julian Joseph, one of this country's best jazz pianists, believes that the Wigmore's regulars offer another listenership.

Joseph tests this theory every year with a spring season of chamber-jazz recitals featuring star guests at the Wigmore, and the 2001 version began this week with the pianist's trio and the powerful American tenor saxophonist Gary Thomas.

Joseph sensibly eschews drummers in a venue built for delicate brush strokes, and performed with his sharp and sensitive regular partners Orlando Le Fleming (bass) and Adam Salkeld (guitar). He also seemed in a provocative mood, and his unbroken streams of suggestive counter-melody and occasionally oddly-voiced chords behind his partners forced them to probe for other melodic ways out.

Joseph and Thomas were both in freewheeling form, in conversation with each other and separately. In recent years the pianist's straightahead playing has developed an unquenchable vivacity on swingers. He also delivers rich, spontaneously-generated arrangements behind other soloists on the fly, like the busy, jangling lines chattering away behind Thomas's dark tenor phrasing on Invitation, and the oppositional chording he threw at Le Fleming's solo on You Stepped Out of A Dream.

Thomas is devastating at fast tempos, low-flying lines skimming and skidding across the harmonies, the beginnings of phrases almost venomously spat out. Yet he could reduce all this firepower to dolorous puffs of air and the restrained motif-juggling of a whirring repeated phrase or an unbearably suspended coda on a ballad such as Billy Strayhorn's Chelsea Bridge, responding to Joseph's delicately trickling runs behind him.

Sonny Rollins's Strode Road, with its succession of unison declarations of the minimalist theme by all the players, revealed the Rollins-like grittiness in Thomas's tone.

 Des'ree is the Joseph trio's guest at the Wigmore Hall (020-7935 2141) on Monday.

fields.headline: Dohnanyi's maze of sound
fields.standfirst:
Dohnanyi/ Philharmonia
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Dohnanyi/ Philharmonia
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.body:
The South Bank's Hans Werner Henze retrospective drew to a close with Requiem, one of his most difficult and ambivalent scores, a work at once upfront and baffling, blatant and secretive. A sequence of nine Spiritual Concertos for piano, trumpet and chamber orchestra, it was triggered by the death, in 1989, of one of Henze's close friends, Michael Vyner, former artistic director of the London Sinfonietta. Its subject is the nature of grief and memory, and it depends partly for its effect upon a game of free association played between musicians and audience.

The concertos, written between 1990 and 1992, can be performed individually, in sequence or in any combination. The structure is consequently fluid, and the work's impact depends not on a sense of totality but on a lexicographical cross-referencing between sections. You are drawn into a maze of sound, through which you have to make your own way, though you are given clues.

Lyricism is juxtaposed with violence, implicit or explicit, in each concerto. Timbres and sonorities are full of echoing allusions throughout. The soloists are allotted carefully differentiated characters. The pianist is an abiding presence, though his lines are often subsumed by the remainder of the instrumentalists, from whom he occasionally struggles free with brief, playful solos: the effect is of a persistent memory that wafts in and out of focus. The trumpeter, however, seemingly absents himself from the work for long stretches at a time, only to return to it as an exuberant, galvanic presence, carving the air with ebullient baroque solos.

Occasionally you are left in the dark as to who, or what, is being remembered and mourned. References to both Austro-German and modernist musical traditions thread their way through the work. The term "spiritual concerto" derives from Schütz and reflects Henze's fascination with the baroque. Vicious marches recall Mahler. Sudden convulsive rhythmic pile-ups bring echoes of Stravinsky in their wake, while one sonic cluster - saxophone solo over strings - hints at Berg's Lulu.

It is a darkly impressive, if flawed work that never fails to grab your intellect, but doesn't always fully engage your emotions. A whiff of objective cool certainly permeated Christoph von Dohnanyi's performance, though the Philharmonia, on wonderful form, were urgently responsive to every flicker of timbre and nuance. The soloists were tremendous: the pianist, Paul Crossley, was wistfully reflective and teasing by turns; the trumpeter, Haken Hardenberger, was electrifying.

Dohnanyi prefaced the Requiem with Mozart's Symphony No 25, a curious performance, hampered by a certain reticence. It is an inherently wild work in which enlightenment values collapse into a voice to be replaced by emotional violence. The first movement, in which the brass seems to pursue the strings in some sort of savage hunt, is particularly terrifying. Dohnanyi, throughout, seemed unwilling to let rip, while the Philharmonia's playing, though often energetic, was characterised at times by an almost clinical astringency.

fields.headline: Death and deceit in Soho
fields.standfirst:
The Coming World
Soho Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
The Coming World
Soho Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
Christopher Shinn is a 26-year-old American writer who has already made an impact here with Four and Other People. But, while this new play continues his fascination with the quiet desperation of American lives, it has a self-consciously literary quality and somewhat tantalising obliqueness: if anything, it is the direction and acting that make the evening hum.

Shinn's setting is a New England beach where the distant echoes, in the first part, are not just of waves but of other plays. Dora has come to meet her flaky ex-lover, Ed, who is in hock to a mobster after being robbed of a stash of ecstasy pills he was supposed to deliver: shades of Shopping and Fucking. But the hapless Ed has a scheme to make up the missing 10 grand by robbing the video store where Dora works: a touch of American Buffalo. It is only after Ed's suicide, when Dora has a nocturnal rendezvous with his twin-brother, Ty, that we begin to piece together the threads of the story and realise that everyone is being economical with the truth.

As a near two-hour narrative, it has the ingenuity of a spider's web: I certainly wanted to know why Ed, having raised the money from his twin, had gone on to rob the store before killing himself. But Shinn plays so many games with the spectator that one is never quite sure what point he is making. He may be arguing that mankind - Americans most of all - cannot bear very much reality. Or he may be suggesting that people tell each other stories to disguise their fear of communication. Or he could be writing about the crushing conformity of small-town America where the exceptional few are, quite literally, marginalised. The play suggests so many possible ideas that it becomes like a mystery tour that never reaches its destination.

But I was impressed by Mark Brickman's bare-stage production which mostly allows the words to do the work, except for a night-time ocean dip cleverly evoked through swirling bodies and miniaturised torches. Andrew Scott, who plays both Ed and Ty, also distinguishes between them with deft economy: the druggy Ed wildly semaphores while the shy, computer-buff Ty restricts his gestures to picking imaginary fluff off his trousers. And as Dora, mysteriously drawn to both brothers, Doraly Rosen sexily mixes swagger and sadness.

I have seen slimmer Shinns than this over-written piece but I have the feeling there is a rich seam of talent still waiting to be mined.

 Until April 28. Box office: 020-7478 0100.

fields.standfirst: Tax and your investments
fields.trailText: Elderly people who find the self-assessment tax return form daunting can ask Help the Aged's tax services to fill it in for them, writes Liz Stuart.
fields.body:
Elderly people who find the self-assessment tax return form daunting can ask Help the Aged's tax services to fill it in for them.

"The service will not only calculate your tax for you - however complicated your affairs - it will also run a check on your overall tax affairs, from checking your tax code to making sure that you are claiming your allowances and entitlements," says a spokeswoman.

The charity charges £75 for the service, or more in complicated cases, and ploughs any profits made into other Help the Aged services. Returns will be completed within 28 days.

Separately, the Low Incomes Tax Reform Group (LITRG) is set to offer free assistance in completing their tax return to low-income pensioners. The scheme, whereby tax professionals would offer free advice, and possibly a home visit, is currently being piloted. It should be available around the country shortly.

Help the Aged has these tips for people who are attempting to complete the tax return themselves:

Have you been given the correct age-related personal allowance? The key to this is your age on April 5 2002. Your age allowance increases when you reach 75.

If you are a registered blind person, you can claim an additional personal allowance, which will reduce your tax bill.

Are you holding your investments in the most tax-efficient way? If you have unit trusts or savings accounts, you might want to think about holding them through an Isa.

If you have a partner, have you considered joint investments that you may have? You could save tax by transferring your investments to whichever of you pays the lowest rate of tax.

Banks and building societies deduct tax at 20% from the interest on accounts before it is paid to you. If you are a non-taxpayer, you can have your interest paid in full.

Selling shares can leave you liable to capital gains tax if you are going to realise a profit of more than £7,500. This catches out hundreds of people each year and can prove costly. One of the best strategies to avoid paying capital gains tax is by selling part of your holding this year and part the following year. Alternatively, you can transfer part of your holding to your spouse so that you can both make a profit of up to £7,500 before you incur any capital gains tax.

Not everyone needs to submit a self-assessment form. If you do not receive one in the post from the Inland Revenue, then it probably means that you don't need one.

webTitle: Chaos as taxman gets it wrong

fields.headline: Chaos as taxman gets it wrong
fields.standfirst: The Inland Revenue sent out 400,000 letters, many in error. Its helpline is jammed by worried taxpayers. Tony Levene reports
fields.trailText: The Inland Revenue sent out 400,000 letters, many in error. Its helpline is jammed by worried taxpayers.Tony Levene reports.
fields.body:
Nearly half a million taxpayers received a demand for "unpaid self-assessment" earlier this week. But Inland Revenue employees dealing directly with the public admit the stock letter - known as Rita 500 - was riddled with potential confusion. They say it should never have been sent to many recipients.

Several of the "pay up or else" demands were posted to those who owe nothing - in some cases recipients had no idea what the taxman wanted, leading to worried taxpayers jamming the switchboard at the Inland Revenue accounts office at Shipley, Yorkshire.

Yesterday, accountants condemned the letter as yet another example of the taxman's tendency to "hit taxpayers for small misdemeanours while never admitting they get anything wrong".

In one instance, there was a demand for £17,000, a sum paid in January. In a second case, the taxpayer is owed money by the Inland Revenue. And to judge by the blocking of lines to the payment enquiry lines at Shipley, countless others and their accountants are in the same position.

Although the Inland Revenue is unwilling officially to say how many Rita 500 letters were sent, sources at Shipley point to 420,000 over the past two weeks.

The unsigned communication tells taxpayers:

Your self-assessment account shows an amount unpaid.

Unless you have paid in the last few days, you will need to deal with this matter now (their emphasis) .

It says taxpayers will find a breakdown of how much they owe "on the self-assessment statement of account recently sent to you".

It then warns of interest increasing "every day until we receive full payment". The letter suggests phoning for "help or advice".

It took one taxpayer two and a half days to get through to the help desk - and then only via a roundabout route.

The switchboard admitted that it was "chaotic" with never a second between calls. The Inland Revenue, which denies chaos, sets targets - 90% of calls made to a direct phone number should be answered within 15 seconds - but it admits it neither counts nor tracks calls that go unanswered.

The Inland Revenue officially says: "We apologise that the taxpayer could not get through. There has been an unprecedented demand for the number." There is no email or fax facility.

One taxpayer asked what had happened to his "recent" statement, only to be told that "it was sent out last June. It was paid in full and cleared. Nothing has been sent since."

Shipley sources suggest that many who sent in their forms after September 30, the deadline for the Inland Revenue calculating the bill, have not yet received a statement. It can take up to two months between the receipt of self-assessment forms and keying details into the computer.

Many problems involve taxpayers whose bill involves a substantial fall from last year - some are working less, while others have large pension premiums to set against tax.

Shipley says taxpayers should have filled in form SA303, which allows a "reduction of payments on account" even though the self-assessment form itself has a box to do exactly this.

Inland Revenue headquarters says no copies of statements are sent out with Rita 500 "because many tax payers have opted to work out their own tax bill. Therefore, they should know how much to pay."

Martin Donn, at accountants Blick Rothenberg, says: "Many clients have wrongfully been sent this new demand without a statement of account, including one who had paid in £17,000 to clear his bill in January. They banked his cheque, so where was the money?

"We have no more success than the public in getting through to Shipley. The problem arises for those whose taxable income falls - there are no difficulties if it rises year on year. The statements of account are obscure, even for accountants."

Andrew Shaw, tax partner at accountants Kingston Smith, says: "It's another example of one rule for them, and one for everyone else. They can do things wrongly; the taxpayer can't."

He cites the case of a blind, elderly client being chased after she had paid in full. He also believes that many boxes on the self-assessment form are ignored by tax officials.

"Rita 500 is new. But the system is already tortuously complicated. Joe Public has not a chance and it's not cost effective for us to check every line in statements," he says.

He says taxpayers should find out if their cheque has been cleared. "If so, sit back and wait. Writing to Shipley is a waste of time."

The Inland Revenue says: "Rita 500 is only wrong in so much as, in a few cases, it refers to a statement which has not been sent out. The money is still due and taxpayers still need to make payment to prevent further action being taken."

webTitle: Older people get the benefit of new rules

fields.headline: Older people get the benefit of new rules
fields.trailText: Next week the new income support levels for older people come into effect, meaning that a single person will now be entitled to up to £13.70 extra a week and a couple to £18.60 more. Claimants will also be permitted higher levels of savings.
fields.body:
Next week the new income support levels for older people come into effect, meaning that a single person will now be entitled to up to £13.70 extra a week and a couple to £18.60 more. Claimants will also be permitted higher levels of savings.

From Monday, the minimum income guarantee means that older people on a low income will have at least £92.15 a week, or £140.55 for couples. Under current benefit rules, single people aged between 60 and 74 receive just £78.45 a week, rising to £89.05 for those over the age of 80. Couples have been getting £121.95.

Older people will now be able to have £6,000 in savings before benefits are affected, and up to £12,000 before they fall outside the eligibility band. Until now, these figures have been £3,000 and £8,000 respectively.

Income support is not granted automatically: people have to apply for it. Age Concern is launching its Your Rights week (the charity's annual campaign to inform older people about their entitlements) to coincide with the benefit changes.

A spokeswoman says: "These changes mean that an additional 100,000 people will be eligible for income support, so, with these higher levels, it's more important than ever for people to find out whether they can claim.

"Age Concern helps people claim millions of pounds in benefit and we will help people fill out the necessary forms. Even if you are not entitled to income support, you may be be able to receive other help, such as housing benefit or council tax benefit."

Age Concern estimates that up to 670,000 older people miss out on benefits each year. One of the benefits most commonly overlooked is the attendance allowance, which is awarded to people who are physically or mentally ill or who need supervision from someone else, for instance if help is needed in washing or moving around the house.

"Most people think they have to be completely disabled to qualify for this allowance, but in fact you just have to have impaired movement. It also does not require a medical, which is why it is particularly important to fill out the form for this benefit correctly and to describe your precise needs correctly. Many people downplay their physical limitations. Again, Age Concern will help people fill out their form," says the spokeswoman.

There are two weekly rates for the allowance: £37 if you only need help during the day, and £55.30 if you need assistance by day and night. Normally you must meet the conditions for six months before you can claim, although exceptions are made for the terminally ill.

Also on Monday, new rules on long-term care kick in, allowing a three-month payment holiday for permanent care home residents. Currently, people can be in a home for up to 52 weeks without the value of their house being included in the calculations as to how much they should be paying, provided they are only temporary residents.

This new regulation means that elderly people, whom it has already been decided will need to be cared for in a home on a permanent basis, will be able to stay for the first three months without the value of their house being taken into consideration for the calculation of fees, which can cost up to £25,000 a year.

"This will be useful in terms of assessing whether the person is happy in that home and whether they are getting the right amount of care, without having to make any difficult decisions about having to sell a house," says the Age Concern spokeswoman. "But it is not nearly enough in general. It does nothing to address the issue of free personal care, for instance, which would affect far more people."

Older people are still fighting battles on other financial fronts. The Employers Forum on Age says that they are still being discriminated against when it comes to work.

Almost two years after the government published its code of practice on age diversity, just one in four employers is adopting the guidelines. Only half of employers have, or are planning to, put in place policies specifically aimed at recruiting older workers.

Paul Suff, author of the report Employing Older Workers, says: "Most employers are aware of the need to recruit older workers, yet few have been imaginative in adapting their workplaces. Most have simply added age to the existing equal opportunities policies without establishing monitoring mechanisms and few are attempting to tackle their own complex occupational pension rules."

Minimum income guarantee claim line 0800-028-1111; Age Concern 0800-009-966. Your Rights 2001-2, which explains all the allowances older people can claim, is available from Age Concern for £4.50.

webTitle: US slide means no more kicks on Route 66

fields.headline: US slide means no more kicks on Route 66
fields.standfirst: UK electoral stew unappetising but keep an eye on warning signs in America
fields.trailText: Comment: The UK electoral stew is unappetising but keep an eye on warning signs in America, writes Edmond Warner, chief executive of Old Mutual Securities.
fields.body:
If it's political kicks you're after, I suggest you search for them elsewhere. I'm delighted to be able to declare this column an election-free zone for the duration of the UK's protracted campaign. Rarely, if ever, has a general election mattered less for financial markets.

There is, of course, an economic policy chasm between Britain's two leading political parties. But it only pertains to one issue - membership of Europe's single currency - and is unlikely to prove sufficient to create a genuine two-horse race. The prospect of a referendum means one has the opportunity both to oppose the euro and not vote Tory.

Were the differences between Labour and Conservative on all other economic matters visible to the naked eye, there might be some impact on markets from the size of a Labour re-election majority. The government talks earnestly of mandates. But where the economy is concerned, it lacks any reforming zeal. The only mandate it seeks is to continue to act as cautious custodian of the status quo.

Which is all something of a relief. Investors have much to fret over without the added complication of political risk. Let others examine whether or not Labour's conservatism is in fact a cloak for cowardice.

Keep a small fraction of an eye on the debate, just in case it prompts an unexpected dash of radical sauce in the electoral stew. But focus most of your attention on the American economy.

A colleague has unearthed a paper by a US academic written last December that makes very salutary reading now. Under the title B2B and B2C in 2001; Back 2 Bankruptcies and Back 2 Cycles, professor Ed Leamer lists a series of warning signs of a recession in the US.

Watch hours, employment, durable sales especially autos and housing. And watch the value of the dollar and the external deficit."

Four months on from the paper's publication and those signals are collectively flashing amber. Some are clearly red. The number of hours worked by the average employee in the manufacturing sector has dropped sharply, from around 42 per week to 40.5 - the lowest for five years.

It is not hard to see why. Orders for durable goods are lower than a year ago. This represents a dramatic turnaround in industrial fortunes. This time last year durable goods orders were growing at around 10% year on year. If the orders aren't coming in, there isn't the work to do and lay- offs can only increase.

Double squeeze

Consumers are subject to a double squeeze. Equities down; job insecurity up. There has been much speculation about the "negative wealth effect" of falling share prices on consumer spending. Whatever the truth, there is an eerie symmetry to the Nasdaq's collapse and the slump in consumption growth from over 10% a year ago to less than 3% now.

Not all of Leamer's indicators are pointing down yet. The dollar remains buoyant, seemingly oblivious to the softening of the economy that underpins it. The currency has soared in recent years as foreigners have ploughed their investment funds into the "miraculous" US economy. This capital inflow has balanced US consumers' unprecedented appetite for imported goods as they spent their spoils from the miracle.

Leamer believes America has much to be grateful for to gullible European investors. "Had we financed the internet boom with bonds issued by viable American companies, we would be deeply in debt to Europe today, but we wisely issued them with worthless equities, and those Europeans will never get their money back."

I've never met Professor Leamer, so I have no idea whether he is one of the vast majority of his countrymen and women who have never owned a passport. But it's difficult to find his remarks too offensive when there's clearly so much truth in them.

His conclusion? "The bad news is that we may have to adjust painfully to a new lifestyle that is no longer being paid for by issuing worthless paper to unsuspecting Europeans. This adjustment could require a relatively long and deep recession."

At least - with the curious exception of the European Central Bank (gullible? unsuspecting?) - the authorities are now aware of the fragility of the US and its wider implications for global growth.

Beaks filed

The hawks on the UK's monetary policy committee have filed down their beaks and cut interest rates once more. US rates will doubtless fall further.

Investors are fully apprised of current economic conditions. How could they not be, with profit warnings a daily occurrence across all sectors of the market? The problem, as ever, is the fog shrouding future prospects.

In this column three weeks ago I stated my belief that economies were slowing not collapsing, and that as a consequence my intuition was to begin to buy equities. This prompted a letter from a reader reminding me that "waiting is activity in stock market strategy".

How right you are Mr Friedlander. "What are you waiting for?" can be an exhortation to act, or an honest, unemotional enquiry.

If you want to see hard evidence of the full extent of the slowdown before buying, it pays to choose a selection of indicators that you believe in, and watch them closely. Leamer's will do for starters.

Lest there be any doubt, however, my intuition remains unchanged.

 Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities

In this column three weeks ago I stated my belief that economies were slowing not collapsing, and that as a consequence my intuition was to begin to buy equities. This prompted a letter from a reader reminding me that "waiting is activity in stock market strategy". How right you are Mr Friedlander. "What are you waiting for?" can be an exhortation to act, or an honest, unemotional enquiry. If you want to see hard evidence of the full extent of the slowdown before buying, it pays to choose a selection of indicators that you believe in, and watch them closely. Leamer's will do for starters. Lest there be any doubt, however, my intuition remains unchanged.  Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities mailto:edmondw@omsecurities.co.uk

fields.headline: Easing the struggle for Monica
fields.trailText: Monica Foulger will be 85 in July. She has been disabled since since she was 27 - she only has half a lung - and she has never been able to work.
fields.body:
Monica Foulger will be 85 in July. She has been disabled since since she was 27 - she only has half a lung - and she has never been able to work.

Until last year she received income support, but this stopped when she came into a small amount of money, pushing her over the £3,000 savings threshold.

Now that this threshold is being doubled Monica will again be eligible, giving her the statutory minimum income of £92.15 a week.

"It's really been difficult since my income support was stopped as I cannot leave the house without help," says Monica. "Somebody prepares my food for me, but I have to heat it in a microwave. The extra money will make it less of a struggle."

webTitle: Ensuring our genes are a looser fit

fields.headline: Ensuring our genes are a looser fit
fields.standfirst: MPs want insurers to suspend testing in their search for future human perfection. Patrick Collinson reports
fields.trailText: MPs want insurers to suspend testing in their search for future human perfection. Patrick Collinson reports.
fields.body:
In the film Gattaca, genetic testing has created a near-future divided between humans with perfect genes and an underclass who have failed the tests. This week MPs took steps against insurance companies to ensure that the dark future pictured by Gattaca remains in the realms of science fiction.

The MPs called for a two-year moratorium on further genetic testing, amid expectations that the Department of Health is preparing to ban insurance companies from unfairly discriminating against people who "fail" genetic tests.

In a damning report, the select committee on science and technology said that:

 Insurers are giving genetic tests a predictive significance that cannot, at present, be justified;

 Insurers are keener on establishing the right to use tests rather than their relevance or reliability;

 It would cost little for insurers to ignore the results of tests currently available;

 Research into genetics will be hindered by fears about insurers' reactions;

 Insurers have become judge and jury on genetic tests.

Unlike many other countries which have banned insurers from asking about genetic tests, Britain's self-regulated insurance industry has adopted a hotch-potch approach to genetic testing.

In 1998, the Association of British Insurers identified tests for seven conditions which insurance companies could take into account when setting premiums. Individuals who tested positive could still obtain insurance, but with a higher premium and restricted level of cover.

But four of these tests have come under severe attack. The Royal Society told MPs that the selection of tests appeared "arbitrary" and this year the ABI admitted that four of the tests could no longer be considered reliable.

The Prudential, in its submission to MPs, said that the tests for familiar adenoma tous polyposis and hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy are irrelevant to insurers owing to their, typically, early onset; that for myotonic dystrophy it is, apparently, not sufficiently predictive, and multiple endochrine neoplasia has too wide an age of onset.

The MPs concluded that: "The ABI's decision that four of the tests it recommended insurers use for the past three years are no longer rel evant or reliable casts the gravest possible doubts on the validity of all the tests not explicitly approved by the [government's] genetics and insurance committee."

But despite criticism from many corners, the ABI and big insurers are clinging on to their rights to take into account the results of tests for Huntington's disease, and are seeking approval for genetic tests on the early onset of familial Alzheimer's disease and hereditary breast and ovarian cancer.

Mary Francis, director general of the ABI, said: "We cannot lightly ignore information that tells us that someone applying for insurance is at significantly higher risk than the majority of policyholders.

"Applicants are normally charged according to the risk they bring to the pool of people insured - for instance, because of their age or their medical history."

But the Alzheimer's Society, which has long campaigned against the use by insurers of genetic tests, called the MPs' report a "strike against discrimination" and urged the government to act swiftly to enforce a moratorium on tests.

Harry Cayton, the society's chief executive, said: "This report endorses a long-running Alzheimer's Society campaign against the use of genetic information by the insurance industry.

"I particularly welcome the concluding statement of the report, which states that for government and for our soci ety the choice is clear - expose people with conditions such as Alzheimer's disease to further stigma and discrimination or restrict access to genetic information by insurers.

"The industry case is based on bad science. They have continually made the spurious claim that they will be commercially damaged if prevented from using the results of genetic tests. This is untrue.

"I hope that the insurance industry and the government will act on these recommendations swiftly and that people will no longer be deterred from seeking genetic tests or from volunteering to take part in medical and scientific research for fear of future discrimination."

A curious fact emerging from the committee's report was the tiny volume of genetic testing. For example, Prudential dealt with seven applications involving genetic test data in 2000; Norwich Union, 50 out of 150,000 applicants for insurance in 2000; and the CIS only 14 out of 460,000 in three years.

Tests they want and ones they dropped

1. Huntington's disease: Test approved

2. Early onset familial Alzheimer's disease : Pending approval

3. Hereditary breast and ovarian cancer: Pending approval

4. Familiar adenomatous polyposis (may lead to colon cancer) : Abandoned

5. Hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy : Abandoned

6. Myotonic dystrophy (form of muscle weakness): Abandoned

7. Multiple endochrine neoplasia (disease of endochrine glands which can lead to kidney stones and stomach ulceration): Abandoned

webTitle: A small step forward for same-sex couples

fields.headline: A small step forward for same-sex couples
fields.trailText: Amsterdam saw Europe's first officially blessed gay weddings last week, as Dutch law granted full equality to homosexual couples on issues such as adoption, inheritance, pension rights and tax.
fields.body:
Amsterdam saw Europe's first officially blessed gay weddings last week, as Dutch law granted full equality to homosexual couples on issues such as adoption, inheritance, pension rights and tax.

Britain is many years away from matching the Netherlands - even the Liberal Democrats have backed away from endorsing gay marriage - but gay financial advisers this week hailed the launch of stakeholder pensions as a small step forward in their battle against discrimination.

Until now the private and company pension system has refused to recognise gay and lesbian couples; if one dies, the other has no automatic right to a pension income in the way of married spouses. In employer schemes the discrimination has been blatant; even public sector schemes refuse to acknowledge gay partners. The NHS pension scheme, for example, recognises only a spouse as eligible for a survivor's pension, and that means a husband or wife.

In personal pensions, discrimination is less direct, based more on ignoring lesbian and gay couples rather than being actively prejudiced against them. Partners' benefits can be obtained for a same-sex partner, although the scheme has to be written within a complex discretionary trust.

Once the personal pension has matured and the saver has bought an annuity, the situation becomes more difficult; if one half of a same-sex partnership dies, an annuity can be paid to the survivor, but only if the survivor can prove that he or she is financially dependent on the annuity. The dependency test is not applied to married spouses.

But stakeholder pensions sweep away the dependency test, and allow a same-sex partnership to enjoy the same annuity rules as heterosexuals. Stakeholder plans can also be more easily put into a discretionary trust which nominates the same-sex partner as the beneficiary.

This week one firm of financial advisers specialising in the gay and lesbian community began marketing a stakeholder Freedom pension which it says allows same-sex partners to enjoy the same rights to pension benefits as married couples.

"We have taken the lottery out of pension planning for gay men and lesbians," says Joe Swanson of Massow Rainbow Group, whose chairman is high-profile gay financial adviser Ivan Massow.

The Freedom pension will be invested in the funds offered by pension providers NPI and Friends Provident, both of which have a strong track record in ethical in vesting. "Sexuality is important, but we also wanted to offer a quality scheme with quality providers," says Mr Swanson.

Like other stakeholder plans, the Freedom pension will have its costs capped at 1% a year, and can be started with as little as £20 per month.

But Mr Swanson cautions against gays and lesbians ditching their company pension schemes in favour of Massow Rainbow's non-discriminatory scheme. Pulling out of a pension scheme early can cost around 5% of the amount you have saved, plus you will lose the contributions paid in by your employer.

"It would be nearly impossible to justify telling someone that they should get out of a company scheme on the grounds of their sexuality," says Mr Swanson.

Instead he recommends putting pressure on company pension scheme trustees to ensure that the scheme recognises same-sex couples.

Mr Swanson also recognises that many of the pension discrimination problems encountered by lesbians and gays are shared by unmarried couples.

He adds: "We believe that our scheme will be attractive to anyone concerned about equality and non-discrimination, gay and straight alike."

All employers with five or more staff have to put in place a stakeholder scheme by October 8 unless they already offer access to another type of scheme. Massow Rainbow says many employers have already turned to them to offer an ethical and gay-friendly plan to staff, including coffee and sandwich chain Pret a Manger.

Massow Rainbow can be contacted on 020-7539-7777 or at www.massowrainbow.com

webTitle: New stakeholder pensions criticised by advisers

fields.headline: New stakeholder pensions criticised by advisers
fields.standfirst:
Concern that low earners will not be attracted

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Concern that low earners will not be attracted.
fields.body:
The government's low cost stakeholder pension scheme, launched yesterday, was criticised by the government's own advisers who said the scheme was unlikely to encourage low income earners to save for their retirement.

Most firms yesterday reported a rise in enquiries and sales of policies, while millions of pension savers also benefited from the decision by many providers to shift them into the new stakeholder charging structure, which limits ongoing management costs to 1%.

Norwich Union, Legal & General, Standard Life and Scottish Widows, the pensions arm of Lloyds bank, which between them account for more than 2.5m customers, said they had seen encouraging signs from the public that stakeholder pensions would prove popular.

The new pensions were inaugurated by social security secretary Alistair Darling who said they offered a low cost option for people who could not afford a private pension or were not in a company scheme.

Up front pensions sales charges that average 5-7% have been largely wiped out and providers must allow savers to make payments of as little as £20. Firms with five employees or more, unless they are specially exempt, have until Oct 8 to provide their relevant employees with access to a stakeholder pension or face fines that could rise to £50,000.

However the chairman of the government-appointed Pension Provision Group, Tom Ross, said recent increases in means-tested pensioner benefits could lead many low earners to conclude it was not worth taking out a stakeholder pension. He highlighted the up-rating of the minimum income guarantee which boosts the basic state pension of £72.50 by more than a quarter to £92.15 and is linked to earnings rather than prices. "If today's savers at lower level of income look at that, I think they are going to ask themselves 'do I need to save and am I going to get an adequate reward for saving?'," he said.

A 35 year old who starts saving £20 in a pension this year until retirement at 65 will receive a monthly payment of £76, according to figures supplied by the City regulator, the Financial Services Authority. Currently, extra income saved by pensioners is deducted from benefits pound for pound.

Mr Darling said the pensioner credit, due to take effect in 2003, would allow pensioners who save to benefit from the minimum income guarantee because the credit would offset 40% of extra income against benefits, allowing pensioners to keep 60%.

webTitle: Now rock stars demand their rights

fields.headline: Now rock stars demand their rights
fields.standfirst:
Courtney Love has become an unlikely campaigner for better pensions

Advice bank: personal pensions
fields.trailText: Courtney Love has become an unlikely campaigner for better pensions, as Patrick Collinson writes.
fields.body:
Courtney Love, the rock widow of Nirvana's Kurt Cobain, has become an unlikely campaigner for better pensions. Last week she called on the world's biggest stars to join a new music trade union demanding better contract terms, health care and pension benefits for recording artists.

Already, REM, U2, Alanis Morrissette and Prince have signalled their support in what is expected to be a popmungous clash between the monsters of rock and the Big Five record companies.

In a letter to "fellow recording artists" last week, Courtney Love wrote: "Recording artists don't have access to quality pension plans like the ones made available to actors and athletes through their union... the baseball players' union has negotiated a pension plan that ensures that NO major league player ever finds himself without an income. Why shouldn't recording artists get the same benefits?"

Music industry executives privately scoff at the criticisms on contracts raised by Courtney Love. They believe artists are paid fair royalties in a business where only 5% of the 3,000 albums they released last year made a profit, according to the Los Angeles Times.

But Courtney Love has found an unlikely endorsement from Virgin, which is no stranger to bust-ups with recording artists.

Gordon Maw, spokesman for Virgin Direct, which sells pensions and insurance, said: "The new stakeholder legislation (in the UK) will improve work benefits for many employees, but some may still find their bosses slow to react. Staff may not want to copy Courtney Love's approach, but it may well be a good time to ask what your company plans to do about stake-holder pensions".
