fields.headline: Hit the self-destruct button
fields.standfirst: Don't be fooled by the slight recovery in share prices, the tide has turned, so more bad news can be expected, argues Robin Stoddart
fields.trailText: Don't be fooled by the slight recovery in share prices, the tide has turned, so more bad news can be expected, argues Robin Stoddart.
fields.body:
Once in destructive mode, markets, like civilisation itself, do not easily resume their former course.

The key technology sector is in the doghouse, after providing the theme that drove the US economy and share market ahead for almost a decade. Software firms, in particular, are being culled nearly as fast as the livestock on England's pastures.

But there is nothing parochial about the plague that has hit paper wealth. It is a global trend and one of the more threatening, particularly for the UK, with its reliance on international trade and financial deals.

It is mainly warnings of harder times from US-based companies that have been pushing share prices down. So far there has been a deafening silence from Marconi and little news from BT's ruffled board. Even among UK software firms, it is usually smaller and unprofitable ones that admit that trading is poor.

British industrial leaders mostly feel that the virus of recession is not affecting them. This may be because several have been selling out to foreign buyers. At the other end of the scale, jobs are still readily available in the most populous areas and house prices keep augmenting wealth.

But the midweek rebound in share prices looks like what a Wall Street wit in the middle of a past recession termed a "dead cat bounce".

In the City there is no sign of panic. After several fat years, one lean one can be absorbed without too much pain. Banks, property issues and some other old-economy stocks are much higher than they were a year ago, thanks to buoyant consumer spending and borrowing.

However, smaller companies with limited cash resources are beginning to feel the pinch. That is affecting the trusts invested in them. The smaller company sectors of unit and investment trusts that sometimes made a killing in a single stock, such as BATM or Recognition Systems in the case of star performers, AIM Trust and Finsbury Technology, are finding life much harder now, even though sales were made close to peak prices in some such cases. Funds such as Eaglet, which has bought large stakes of more than 10% in some companies, may be hard put to sell at a reasonable price as the bear market deepens.

The end is nigh for some investment trusts that leaped on the internet bubble but borrowed from banks to "gear up" their income and hoped-for growth. Split trusts, where part of the fixed capital is in zero coupon preference shares entitled to first repayment at a rising price in place of dividends, are near the point where or dinary shareholders may have little hope of recouping losses.

Framlington NetNet and European Technology and Income Trust, which, along with Amerindo Internet, are valued at a small fraction of their issue prices just over a year ago, have paid back bank loans as the technology market collapsed.

Even if prices in the sector were to stage a strong rebound, the ordinary shares would only recover a fraction of their losses now that the gearing has gone.

Among conventional investment trusts, particularly those with broad European stakes, the appearance of large discounts presents a buying opportunity. But the converse applies to those investment trust shares that, surprisingly, still stand at premiums above their underlying values.

The real giants of the investment world, the life assurers' managed funds that invest for the long term, are now showing the pressure.

Until last month's further slide in markets, balanced funds - with a spread of holdings, the great majority in equities, but with some gilt-edged and other fixed interest holdings - were still showing scattered gains over the last year.

Now the billions managed by the Prudential, Standard Life and the rest with balanced general funds managed for the benefit of bondholders, pension savers and other medium and longer-term investors, are suffering from the general equity market setback. That is why annual bonus rates are down and likely to remain at no more than 6%, around half the level that savers in this medium have became accustomed to. In times of low inflation that is a good return. The overwhelming consensus has it that inflation will remain low. That might need calling in question before the year is out.

In a destructive and disaster-prone world, more shocks are likely.

After several fat years, one lean one can be absorbed without too much pain. Banks, property issues and some other old-economy stocks are much higher than they were a year ago, thanks to buoyant consumer spending and borrowing. However, smaller companies with limited cash resources are beginning to feel the pinch. That is affecting the trusts invested in them. The smaller company sectors of unit and investment trusts that sometimes made a killing in a single stock, such as BATM or Recognition Systems in the case of star performers, AIM Trust and Finsbury Technology, are finding life much harder now, even though sales were made close to peak prices in some such cases. Funds such as Eaglet, which has bought large stakes of more than 10% in some companies, may be hard put to sell at a reasonable price as the bear market deepens. The end is nigh for some investment trusts that leaped on the internet bubble but borrowed from banks to "gear up" their income and hoped-for growth. Split trusts, where part of the fixed capital is in zero coupon preference shares entitled to first repayment at a rising price in place of dividends, are near the point where or dinary shareholders may have little hope of recouping losses. Framlington NetNet and European Technology and Income Trust, which, along with Amerindo Internet, are valued at a small fraction of their issue prices just over a year ago, have paid back bank loans as the technology market collapsed. Even if prices in the sector were to stage a strong rebound, the ordinary shares would only recover a fraction of their losses now that the gearing has gone. Among conventional investment trusts, particularly those with broad European stakes, the appearance of large discounts presents a buying opportunity. But the converse applies to those investment trust shares that, surprisingly, still stand at premiums above their underlying values. The real giants of the investment world, the life assurers' managed funds that invest for the long term, are now showing the pressure. Until last month's further slide in markets, balanced funds - with a spread of holdings, the great majority in equities, but with some gilt-edged and other fixed interest holdings - were still showing scattered gains over the last year. Now the billions managed by the Prudential, Standard Life and the rest with balanced general funds managed for the benefit of bondholders, pension savers and other medium and longer-term investors, are suffering from the general equity market setback. That is why annual bonus rates are down and likely to remain at no more than 6%, around half the level that savers in this medium have became accustomed to. In times of low inflation that is a good return. The overwhelming consensus has it that inflation will remain low. That might need calling in question before the year is out. In a destructive and disaster-prone world, more shocks are likely.

webTitle: Tax chaos as 420,000 told to pay twice

fields.headline: Tax chaos as 420,000 told to pay twice
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: The Inland Revenue has been swamped by calls from confused taxpayers after demanding payment from more than 400,000 people, many of whom have already settled their accounts in full.
fields.body:
The Inland Revenue has been swamped by calls from confused taxpayers after demanding payment from more than 400,000 people, many of whom have already settled their accounts in full.

Telephone operators at the Revenue's accounts office in Shipley, Yorkshire, described the situation as chaotic as callers jammed the switchboard to query a demand that they pay up immediately or face soaring penalties.

The mass mailshot - believed to have been sent to 420,000 people - tells taxpayers that they owe money and should settle the bill immediately, as interest will increase "every day until we receive full payment". But a number of those who received the de mand have already paid their tax bill, or are even owed money by the taxman. One taxpayer spent two and a half days trying to get through to the Revenue's helpline, at which point the operator confirmed that he had settled his tax bill in June. In another instance a demand for £17,000 had been paid in January.

Adding to the administrative confusion, the letter, known as a Rita 500, does not tell taxpayers how much they owe, but alludes to a statement "recently sent to you". The Inland Revenue admitted yesterday that many people had never been sent a statement.

"People who have got the letter really should know what their liability is anyway," said a spokesman. "It is only sent to people who owe money, so if you got the letter you should not wait for the statement."

Accountants yesterday said the incident showed the revenue was struggling to deal with the enormous administrative burden created by the introduction of self-assessment in 1996-7.

David Gibbs, a tax partner at Grant Thornton, said many accountants believed the present tax system was "very sick" and in desperate need of reform. A number of his clients had been wrongly served a penalty for sending back their returns late, he said, because the Revenue had not processed them in time. "The burden of proof is on the taxpayer, but many people are frightened of the Revenue."

The letter comes after a number of embarrassing gaffes by the Inland Revenue, which admitted in December that more than a quarter of self-assessment returns had been wrongly processed in the previous year. In March last year it demanded £100 penalties from 20,000 people who it incorrectly said had failed to return their forms on time.

Perhaps the most embarrassing mistake came in April 1999, when 680,000 tax returns were sent out asking for information for the wrong year. Accountants were told to cross out the incorrect date and write on the right year with a ballpoint pen. Four months earlier an administrative mistake led to 800,000 customers being asked for twice the amount they owed.

In a survey by the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants in 1999, 96% of accountants said their tax returns had been affected by systems failures or mistakes by the Inland Revenue.

webTitle: Theatre review: 1900: The Pianist on the Ocean

fields.headline: 1900: The Pianist on the Ocean
fields.standfirst:
Andrew Lane Theatre, Dublin
****
fields.trailText:
Andrew Lane Theatre, Dublin
****
fields.body:
Over two decades, the Irish actor-writer Donal O'Kelly has delivered many epic performances. More recently, these have been tales of the high seas, such as his Catalpa. Now comes this oddly charmed, musical folktale from the Turinese novelist Alessandro Baricco.

The director Leticia Agudo plays into O'Kelly's concentrated theatrical style by using nothing more than a coat and hat, some tea chests, a swinging rope and a barrel and plank. But this time, he is leavened by a five-piece jazz ensemble.

Baricco's tale is of an abandoned infant, left on an immigrant ship that steamed back into New York in 1900. A Negro sailor adopted the child, and gave him his date-name.

The boy became a permanent stowaway on the liner. But he flowered into an extraordinary pianist, inspired by the waves. He played the "regular notes" for the passengers, while down in the engine rooms he played music "that simply didn't exist before" for the grubby-faced workers.

O'Kelly frames the narration as a lost, gravel-voiced American trumpeter who befriended 1900 - intimately witnessing incidents such as his triumphant piano "duel" with the jazzman Jelly Roll Morton.

The innocent-seeming text is suffused with an almost spiritual appreciation of music. The pianist-composer Justin Carroll has elegantly scored his ensemble through illustrative ragtime and swing. When it comes to the mystic waif of 1900 at the ivories, Carroll whimsically pastiches Debussy and Satie, even Gershwin where appropriate.

Meanwhile, O'Kelly twitches between characters but ultimately settles into the rootless genius of the keyboard. O'Kelly's solidarity with the working man battles through the folk-romanticism. There is a grim determination to his performance, which makes no particular judgment on the sweetly mythic tale.

Apart from the luscious setting of the music, the production is pared back, with its oddly corrugated-aluminium, portholed wings. Sometimes, O'Kelly races through his lines, abandoning himself to the music. Yet he draws you further into the wistful tale, grabbing wisps of legend to soothe lost ancestors, forever churned into a merciless tide.

 Until April 28. Bookings: 00 353 1 6795720.

webTitle: How to make the most of a holiday in the UK

fields.headline: How to make the most of a holiday in the UK
fields.standfirst: Responsible Travel's advice to tourists
fields.trailText: Responsible Travel's advice to tourists
fields.body:
 Think small when booking a holiday in the UK

 Bed and breakfasts, village houses and locally owned accommodation benefit local families.

 Buy locally-made goods and use locally provided services wherever possible

 Your support is very important to local people.

 Minimise your environmental impact

 Keep to footpaths and marked routes, don't remove any of the natural habitat and reduce the packaging you bring.

 Read up on the area you plan to visit

 The welcome will be warmer if you take an interest.

 Use public transport

 Hire a bike or walk where convenient - you'll meet local people and get to know the place.

 Don't discard litter - take it home with you.

 Be aware that the area you are visiting is also a working environment

 Your hosts will be running a business, so help them by being considerate and aware.

fields.headline: Roddick backs responsible travel
fields.trailText: The latest initiative to be backed by Body Shop founder Anita Roddick is a website that hopes to encourage responsible travel. A longterm advocate of fair trade, Roddick hopes that its complementary concept of fair travel will become as familiar concept.
fields.body:
The latest initiative to be backed by Body Shop founder Anita Roddick is a website that hopes to encourage responsible travel. A longterm advocate of fair trade, Roddick hopes that its complementary concept of fair travel will become as familiar concept.

www.responsibletravel.com launched yesterday with hundreds of holidays in 36 countries. Co-founder and former Body Shop employee Justin Francis explained: "When you travel, you do have an impact on the environment, and what we're about is minimising the negative impact and maximising the benefits for the environment and also for the local communities. We encompass a lot of environmental travel but we're also very focused on the social benefits for the local community. It's our holidays, but it's their homes, these places we're actually visiting."

Travellers' tips, links to Amnesty International and the likes of Future Forests, where you can calculate your carbon emissions and plants trees to offset the environmental damage, ensure that the site remains on message. Members will be checked annually, and customer feedback will be posted on the site, ensuring that users get a full and unbiased account of each holiday on offer.

Responsible Travel's tips for UK tourists

fields.headline: Car sick
fields.standfirst: During her first week in New Zealand Sue is impressed with the country's beauty, if not with its climate. Find out how she managed to get through three cars in about as many days...
fields.trailText: Australia to New Zealand During her first week in New Zealand Sue is impressed with the country's beauty, if not with its climate. Find out how she managed to get through three cars in about as many days...
fields.body:
Quite a few changes this week - from sunny Australia to rather cold and rainy New Zealand, from shorts and t-shirts to long trousers and jumpers, from backpacker buses to posh cars (I am on my third - Ace Car Rentals must rue the day I walked through the door).

My last day in Australia was spent with Simon and Yuki who live in the Northern Beaches area of Sydney. I wonder if my house will look like theirs when I get back - full of beautiful things acquired from my travels around the world. I doubt it, as I can't match the view over the forest and the sea or Yuki's wonderful sculptures. I gather from friends' emails that my house has been rechristened 'the party house', but is still standing.

I spent Saturday beach-hopping on the bus. I seem to have developed a fascination with watching surfers - the long wait for the right wave, the tumble at the end (or the beginning if they're not so good) and then the long swim back out, dipping under the waves as they crash down. I sat on a clifftop watching for hours. That night we went to the cinema to see Traffic - my first film for four months - and followed it up with some delicious Italian gellato. I should have known that a scoop each of pistachio, choc-chip and tiramisu would be too much but I gave it my best shot.

The next day, Sunday, I set off for Auckland. The plane was going on to Buenos Aires and my South American neighbour during the journey gave me plenty of tips about where to go in Argentina. In Auckland I was again lucky enough to be staying with John and Lucy and their family - friends of a friend in Ely, where Lucy used to live before emigrating. I was going to set off south on Monday, but the relentless heavy rain that met me off the plane continued, so instead I went into Auckland to see about hiring a car and to find a 'teach yourself Spanish' tape to listen to while driving. I had to go back at four to pick up the car. We sorted out the paperwork and I got in, only to discover that it was an automatic. Since I've never driven one before I asked to change to a normal car, but that meant redoing all the paperwork. By the time I finally set off in car number two it was dark, and still pouring with rain. I suddenly realised that I didn't have a clue how to find John and Lucy's house. After a few fruitless attempts to consult a map which only had tourist spots marked on it, I somehow managed to end up in the right district. Then began a long and panicky search to try and find their road, which seemed to have completely vanished - if indeed it ever existed. A hunt for the piece of paper with their phone number on also proved fruitless. I eventually arrived back at 7pm, to great relief all round.

It was still raining on Tuesday morning, but I set off regardless. It was only then that I noticed the hole where the radio/cassette player should be. The rain eventually stopped at about 11am, and the sun came out. I drove to Rotorua, nicknamed 'sulpher city' as it's the centre of an active thermal area. I booked myself on to a Maori dance and hangi tour for the evening and had a quick look at the huge Rotorua Lake and Kuirah Park near the hostel.

The tour to a Maori village complex, run entirely by Maoris, was excellent. As you may have gathered I'm not too keen on organised coach tours to cultural centres, but this had a genuine feel to it that raised it above the odd Butlins-type moments. The performers welcomed us in traditional manner, and the music and dance performance - including a fearsome haka - were good. The hangi food cooked in earth ovens was delicious, with as much as you could eat. With a full stomach and plenty of wine, I could even bear the singing on the coach back.

Wednesday was a long day of driving, with lots of breaks to go sightseeing. First stop was Waiotapu, an area rich in thermal activity. I arrived in time to see the Lady Knox geyser go off on the dot of 10.15, aided by a dose of biodegradable soap which apparantly breaks down the surface tension and sets off the 50ft high plume. I then walked around the pools, craters and steaming fumerols, all different colours due to the chemical elements - the purples, emerald greens, blues and reds of the rocks and the water were unreal in their brightness. I have never before been to an area like this, where you can almost imagine that you're looking down into the centre of the earth. It makes you aware of how fragile and alive the ground we stand on really is. Quite an experience.

I set off next for the huge Lake Taupo, driving around it to Turangi on the other side for lunch. I decided to carry on taking the scenic route through Tongariro National Park. It was a beautiful drive past the snow-capped Mount Ruapetu volcano, and up, down and round the hills to Ohakune. I had thought of stopping there and doing one of the short walks, but the town seemed to have shut down - even the park office was closed at 3pm - so I started off again for Wanganui, a town on the Whanganui river (extra 'h' for the river). This wasn't much livelier. I spent a frustrating hour trying to find a telephone, an email facility and a cafe - failing on all three counts. I did find a Chinese takeaway to take back to the hostel and eventually managed to get on the one phone there to tell Mike and Clare, my travelling companions around India, that I was arriving in Wellington the next day.

Thursday was another day spent driving down the coast road to Wellington. Not long into the day my car suddenly but briefly made a horrible noise and the steering seemed to change. I stopped and checked the tyres and opened the bonnet. This is always a rather pointless exercise for me, as I doubt I'd even be able to tell if the whole engine had dropped out. No sign of anything wrong so I carried on cautiously. This time I managed to find Mike and Clare's house without trauma. I had unknowingly arrived on Mike's birthday. We did a tour of Wellington by night, driving up a mountain where you could see the whole city and bay lit up - a magnificent view. Back to their house for lots of lamb and wine and reminiscences about India.

Clare and Mike said goodbye and set off for work at an unearthly hour the following morning. I decided to have just five more minutes in bed before heading into Wellington and a net cafe. An hour later I woke, hastily threw my bags into the car and closed their door behind me. The engine was dead, not a splutter. Cursing all cars the world over, I knocked on the door of a neighbour and asked to use the phone to call the AA. I got back in the car to wait, tried the engine again and - yes, you've guessed it - it started perfectly. I drove off to find a phone to cancel the call-out and then headed straight for the Wellington branch of Ace. I was almost relieved when he told me that the power-steering belt was completely mangled and he had never known this happen before. At least it wasn't my imagination. I'm now on car number three. They seem to get bigger each time - a far cry from my little Fiesta at home. A different car meant that I had to go and change my ticket for the ferry to the South Island which included details about my car.

All in all, then, it was a bit of a frustrating day and I doubt now whether I'll have time to go to the Te Papa Museum of New Zealand. Hopefully I can do it on the way back. I have deliberately rushed down through the North Island to get across to the South before the schools break up. From now I intend to travel more slowly and do more active things (but no bungy jumping). The plan is to see more of the North Island on the way back. I have been impressed by the beauty of New Zealand, if not by it's climate. It is still very strange to see trees losing their leaves and to think that winter is coming. My own fault for not even considering seasons when I planned my route. How many cars will I get through next week? Maybe tour buses aren't such a bad thing...

My own fault for not even considering seasons when I planned my route. How many cars will I get through next week? Maybe tour buses aren't such a bad thing...

fields.headline: Up down under
fields.standfirst: 'Now, I know it's only been two days but I'd like to end the website New Zealand debate now for once and for all.' Newly arrived on South Island, Milly sets the record straight about New Zealand
fields.trailText: 'Now, I know it's only been two days but I'd like to end the website New Zealand debate now for once and for all.' Newly arrived on South Island, Milly sets the record straight about New Zealand
fields.body:
The first few days of this week I was still a working girl, and I think you've got the general gist of how that goes. Crazy hours but good food and good company. In fact I was almost sad to be leaving Coogee, although I have decided to come for 10 days at the end of April - definitely not an event I would have foreseen way back in England. Travelling is full of surprises.

Sunday April 1 was officially my last day at work for 19 days - quite a cheeky length holiday when you consider I'm on a three-month contract, but as long as they're happy I'm very happy! That evening me and Josh could actually celebrate safe in the knowledge the alarm wouldn't go at 3am the next morning. We headed to a Thai restaurant for dinner - the food type I eat most, of which will make actually being in Thailand an interesting culinary experience. The meal was delicious, as ever, and the fact that I didn't lose my taste buds through excess chilli consumption was an added bonus.

The bizarre thing about the next day is that I almost felt gloomy. I saw it as some kind of post-work comedown where my body clock was thrown into confusion by still being in bed at 6 in the morning. I assure you I have quickly adjusted! Early afternoon we caught the harbour ferry across to Watson's Bay despite the rain. We had lunch at Doyle's, an old and famous fish restaurant/pub where I amused our waitress by requesting a child's fish and chips meal - which was outstanding value and came complete with ice-cream covered in hundreds and thousands. The real lunch highlight was undoubtedly the view from the window across the harbour to the grey outline of the city skyline. After lunch we wandered round the national park but had to pause regularly under bushes to shelter from the rain.

Tuesday was a big day for me - the day I packed up my bag and said goodbye to Coogee and the life I'd had there. Unsurprisingly I had mixed feelings - some sad because I guess a small piece of my heart will always be there, as in all my homes, but some excited as I'm no longer certain what the future will hold. I'm a real traveller again! The flight to Christchurch, on New Zealand's South Island was short and sweet. At the airport we randomly chose Cokers Hostel as our first stay and I'd say it's a very decent place, set on Manchester Street - one of many comparisons between Christchurch and England. That afternoon on a total impulse I got my hair cut and highlighted blonde - I'd been through so many changes these last few days I decided to get the whole lot done at once. They say a change is as good as a start so who knows what will happen next? Do (slightly) blondes have more fun?!

A brief exploration of Christchurch showed it to be totally different from Sydney in lay-out and atmosphere. It seems relaxed, a lot flatter skyline-wise, and more like an English town. After eating take-away that evening (I'm yet to break into cooking again) we headed out to see what the night life was like. To be honest it was very quiet, though a lot of this was probably due to it being a Tuesday night. We tried two excellently named pubs: the Grumpy Mole and the Loaded Hog, but besides the latter giving us a beer the size of my arm it was a particularly mellow evening.

In the morning we rose early to explore Christchurch properly as this was to be our second and last day there. After having a massive take-away salad we decided to hire a couple of bikes. The rest of the day was spent cycling beside an enclosed area of water that leads to the Pacific Ocean enjoying the fresh air and exercise.

Now, I know it's only been two days but I'd like to end the website New Zealand debate now for once and for all. This country is wonderful. Today was the most perfect day imaginable; the air was clean, the sky was blue and it felt like a gorgeous spring day in England (yes I know it's autumn here). There was no hint of cloud, grey or rain and cycling beside the water on excellent cycle lanes, passing idyllic hillside dwellings I couldn't have felt happier or more peaceful. Stopping for a picnic by the grey sands of Sumner Beach it occurred to me this is a place I would happily live. The people are exceptionally friendly. Debate over. We've booked a coach to Arthur's Pass tomorrow, as someone wrote it to recommend, although we've decided to forsake all organised coach tours in favour of doing it ourselves, so I'll keep you posted on how that's working out.

Until next week (when no doubt I'll still be loving the South Island)

fields.headline: National Newspaper of the Year
fields.trailText: The Guardian has scooped two of the most prestigious prizes at the annual Newspaper Awards which recognise excellence in the industry.
fields.body:
The Guardian has scooped two of the most prestigious prizes at the annual Newspaper Awards which recognise excellence in the industry. The Guardian was named National Newspaper of the Year and Guardian Unlimited given the accolade of Best Daily Newspaper on the World Wide Web.

The judges said the newspaper showed 'clear design, production and marketing strengths...and was innovative with change ensuring a successful product'.

Commended in the same category were the Daily Telegraph and The Independent.

Guardian Unlimited, said the judges, guides readers effortlessly through a vast range of services. "It wins because it is unlimited in its scope. A very, very full and easy to use web site."

Commended in the same category were Sport.Telegraph and FT.com

webTitle: Government urges tourists to enjoy the countryside

fields.headline: Government urges tourists to enjoy the countryside
fields.standfirst: Foot and mouth Special report
fields.trailText: Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott today went cruising on the Norfolk Broads as the government moved to persuade people to return to the countryside.
fields.body:
Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott today went cruising on the Norfolk Broads as the government moved to persuade people to return to the countryside.

Mr Prescott said many parts of the country were now open for business as usual, and visitors could tread safe in the knowledge that they would not be running the risk of spreading foot-and-mouth disease.

"Easter is coming. Let's enjoy our countryside," said Mr Prescott.

"A lot of people have cancelled but it is still not too late to have a break. The daffodils are coming out and the message is that it is important that people come to the countryside."

Mr Prescott met officials from the Broads Authority to discuss the problems the tourist industry was facing in East Anglia, and took a 15-minute trip on a cruiser at Brundall, near Norwich.

Mr Prescott stopped short of insisting that British politicians should not go abroad this summer as a sign of support to the tourist industry, but he said it was important for everyone to do what they could to support rural businesses.

"As always it's a matter of getting the balance right," he said. "Sometimes I go abroad, sometimes I holiday at home.

"This Easter I will be taking a break in Buckinghamshire. But what we want to get across to everyone is that the best thing you can do to support the countryside is to visit those areas where it is safe to do so.

"Businesses in the countryside want you to come and there are areas where you can visit where you will pose no threat."

Broads Authority officials told Mr Prescott that as a result of discussions between local businesses and farmers many footpaths that had been closed were now being re-opened. Although many areas bordering on the rivers and many mooring points remain out of bounds.

In Cumbria, one of the areas worst hit by the foot and mouth outbreak, the county council have announced that they are to remove many road signs banning walkers from the countryside, and change the wording of others to be more 'tourist friendly'.

"In areas currently infection free, although such signs are desirable to prevent further infection spread, there is a case for balancing this with the pleas of the hard-hit tourism industry for an 'Open for Business' image," said a council spokesperson.

"A group has therefore offered to review signage policy in infection free areas as a matter of urgency."

fields.headline: Animal magic
fields.standfirst: 'It was my deep desire to see elephants that had made me send in my entry to the Netjetters competition all those months ago. Seeing them at last has been the highlight of my trip so far.' Sam goes on safari in Malawi
fields.trailText: 'It was my deep desire to see elephants that had made me send in my entry to the Netjetters competition all those months ago. Seeing them at last has been the highlight of my trip so far.' Sam goes on safari in Malawi
fields.body:
Cape Maclear's beach boys were becoming too much of an irritation (see last week's report), and it was time to leave. We booked ourselves into Mvuu safari camp in Liwonde National Park to do a bit of game spotting. We needed to be in Liwonde to catch the boat transfer at 11.30am.

However, getting out of Cape Maclear wasn't going to be easy. There was no public transport and part of the road had been washed away by the floods earlier in the week. One of the locals, Bruce, said he could arrange a lift for us all the way to Liwonde. But on the morning of our departure, Bruce turned up empty-handed. Unfortunately his car was 'broken', but he could get us a lift with a friend. The price would have to double though. We rejected this (H made her feelings very clear), and set out to make our own way. We found a ride in the back of a bumpy pick-up truck and crawled gingerly to the main road. There we caught a bus. Like all African buses it was incredibly slow and seemed to stop every 100 yards. It was also packed full with screaming babies, squawking chickens, rotting fish and the radio was playing at full volume. We eventually made it to Liwonde town, three hours late, saddle sore, having missed our boat.

Liwonde was like every other Malawi town we'd seen. An assortment of shacks and stalls strung out along the road offering everything from tailoring to used tyres to bottle shops. As the bus pulled in it was besieged by market traders trying to sell fast food to the remaining bus passengers. I saw a man in a ragged T-shirt carrying a tray of roasted sparrows. Another was banging the windows and offering bowls of peanuts.

We pushed through the throng, struggling with our rucksacks and crossed over the river to the other shore. A small jetty was the pick-up point for the transfer to Mvuu camp. We were relieved to find a Dutch couple waiting there. They told us that another boat should be along soon.

Shortly a small motor boat buzzed around a corner of the river and coasted up to the jetty. We clambered aboard and sped off up the Shire river, skimming the waves and into the park.

Liwonde National Park is one of the best in Malawi. While you don't get the numbers and variety of animals that you might see in other parks in Africa, it is well managed and your are virtually guaranteed to see elephants, crocodiles and hippos. Mvuu camp is the only place you can stay in the park. It's managed by Central African Wilderness Safari and lies deep in the central African Wilderness Safaris in the northern part of the park on the banks of the Shire.

Our first sight of the camp above the reeds was the large thatched restaurant fronting a long grassy slope down to the river. Two large baobab trees provided shade.

Getting off the boat we were met by one of the Wilderness management team, who told us that as it was low season and midweek we were being upgraded to the luxury lodge. Now very excited, we were driven through the bush, glimpsing impala and scampering monkeys along the way, and shown through the jungle to our secluded accommodation. We had a large, walk-in covered tent with a double bed and a wooden balcony overlooking a lush watering hole full of birds. There was a beautiful bathroom in a stone-built area adjoining the tent. This, unbelieveably, had a sunken bath and freshly laundered, fluffy robes and towels. H and I jumped around the tent hugging each other in disbelief.

This was the start of a fabulous relaxing three days of fine food, game viewing and lazing on the veranda. Our first activity that afternoon was a boat trip further up the river in search of wildlife. Our guides, Jim and Paul, quickly found a group of hippos submerged near the bank, just their nostrils, ears and eyes above the surface. They stared at us unblinkingly, snorting plumes of spray into the air. Jim said we needed to be careful and not get too close as one of the cows had a baby. You do not want to get between an over-protective 2,000kg mother and her child. When one of the hippos dived and we saw a line of bubbles ominously moving towards us, Jim opened up the throttle and we sped away. We saw more hippos, crocodiles and an amazing variety of rainbow-coloured birdlife. Taking us out into midstream, Jim switched off the motor and opened the coolbox for our 'sundownders'. Sitting back, we sipped gin and tonics and exchanged travel stories with our fellow passengers.

Back at the lodge, we luxuriated in our sunken tub before a delicious dinner in the thatched restaurant overlooking the crocodile infested river. We were joined by the camp manager Chris who told us about life in Malawi.

That night, tucked up in our huge bed we were gently being lolled to sleep by the croaking frogs outside when a loud snorting noise made up jump. A hippo had emerged from the water and was blundering up track alongside our tent. Terrified, we cowered under the sheets until it moved off. We didn't get that much sleep, but when did drop off our dreams were full of man-eating hippos.

The following days continued in the same wonderful vein. We went for early morning wildlife walks and tracked impala and water buck. There were more leisurely boat trips and sundowners on the river. The staff at the lodge were wonderful. Nothing was too much trouble - we even got our laundry washed and pressed.

The only thing I was disappointed about was not seeing an elephant. It was so wet that they did not need to come to the river for water. The last herd had been seen over three weeks ago. But, on the morning of our last day, Jim took us down the river again. We were watching the hippos floating about and occasionally yawning when Jim suddenly pointed - "Look! elephants swimming!" His eyesight was incredible. Even with binoculars it was a long time before I managed to spot the dark shapes moving in the water. As we got closer, we could see it was a herd of 12, including two young ones. Most were grazing among the trees but three big males were splashing each other in the shallows. We watched spellbound as the huge graceful grey creatures slowly walked out of the water and back into the trees.

It was my deep desire to see elephants that had made me send in my entry to the Netjetters competition all those months ago. Seeing them at last, and the last few days at Mvuu has been the highlight of my trip so far.

We left the lodge extremely reluctantly. We had had a magical time and hope to return one day.

Tomorrow we catch a 1940s steamboat up the lake to the north.

fields.headline: Westferry dispute hots up
fields.trailText:
Friday 6pm: Relations between Hollinger and Richard Desmond have reached a new low in the Westferry printing plant dispute, reports Dan Milmo.
Apr 5: Express in crunch talks with Hollinger
fields.body:
Express owner Richard Desmond has been warned that the multimillion pound Westferry printing plant dispute will only be settled if he gives assurances about future payment of bills.

Mr Desmond is holding out for an £11m dividend from the plant, which he co-owns with Daily Telegraph owner Hollinger International, and is refusing to pay a £6m printing bill in the meantime.

The Express owner has told colleagues he is confident that Hollinger boss Conrad Black will cough up between £4 and 5m in the "next four or five days".

However, senior executives at Hollinger today said relations between both parties have reached such a low that they cannot trust Mr Desmond and Northern & Shell Company anymore.

Dan Colson, vice-chairman of Hollinger, said the dividend will be paid if Northern & Shell promise to pay bills on time.

"If we can find a way to ensure that they will pay their bills to date and on an ongoing basis, then we will be willing to pay a dividend," said Mr Colson.

Mr Colson added that a court battle is imminent, because he believes Northern & Shell will not respond to Hollinger's demands.

"I don't think they will be able to do what we are proposing, so I think a writ will be issued against them at the beginning of next week," he said.

Today's developments still leave the ownership of the plant up in the air.

Hollinger has agreed to buy Mr Desmond's 50% stake in Westferry, but the companies cannot agree on a price.

Northern & Shell is demanding £80m for its holding in the lucrative business, whereas Hollinger will only offer £30m.

Mr Desmond has offered ex-QC Anthony Evans as an arbitrator, but Hollinger wants the price to be settled by accountancy professionals and not by lawyers.

A Northern & Shell insider today said the company is confident Hollinger will pay the dividend, regardless of assurances about prompt settlement of bills.

"We are very confident that they will pay," he said.

fields.headline: China arrests international scholars
fields.trailText: This week brings to three the number of international scholars arrested on spying charges, writes David Cohen.
fields.body:
The case of the United States plane that was forced to make an emergency landing in China was not the only Sino-American imbroglio to have taken place this week. A few days earlier, Chinese security services brought to three the number of international scholars they have arrested over the past month on charges of spying, and in the process sent a shiver down the spines of many researchers in Hong Kong. One of the arrested academics is a naturalised American, another enjoys permanent residency rights in the US. The remaining scholar is an Oxford PhD who is based in Hong Kong but was doing research at two institutions in nearby Guangzhou.

"Theories and questions are whizzing through the websites on which China experts communicate," noted Jonathan Mirsky, a China analyst, in an op-ed piece published in the International Herald Tribune. "Are any of the prisoners really spies? Are their arrests random? Are they to warn Mr Bush not to harden his policies towards China? Are Mrs Gao and Mr Li being held as hostages, to be released in exchange for the Chinese colonel who recently defected to the United States? Are the authorities trying to deter Chinese-born scholars who live abroad from pursuing 'sensitive' research inside China?" As a matter of fact, Mr Mirsky wasn't sure of any likely answers himself.

Another East Asian educational row grew stronger this week after internet users in South Korea crippled at least six Japanese websites by logging on en masse to protest against the Japanese government's decision to authorise the controversial publication of eight high school history textbooks. The nationalist editors of the books have revised some 137 generally accepted facts about Japan's wartime history.

The books now claim that Japan "liberated" Asia, particularly Korea and China, from Western colonisers during the first half of the last century, while omitting any mention of the thousands of Asian women who were abducted and raped by Japanese soldiers or else forced to work at Japanese factories.

An editorial in the Korea Herald quoted from the words of Shigehiko Hasumi, the president of the University of Tokyo, who said that such efforts by his own countrymen to distort history may give the Japanese people "a little satisfaction" but it will never enable them to pass on the courage to mould their future. "History cannot be erased," the paper said. "Neither can it be the subject of deception. This is why many Japanese intellectuals and civic group leaders are joining hands with Korean and Chinese in condemning the repeated statements of Japanese politicians to justify and glorify their wartime atrocities."

No such protest looks likely in Zimbabwe, where the government of Robert Mugabe has announced that foreign (read: British) examinations will be scrapped in the public education system, effective from next year, as part of its ongoing quest to "decolonise" former Rhodesia.

A long editorial published in the Zimbabwe Independent began by pointing out that, curiously enough, the same "black elite" that favours the creation of a more localised culture has not hesitated to send its own offspring to private institutions where teachers tend to be white, English the preferred language of instruction and examinations decidedly British.

"It is difficult to take a long, hard look at the education ministry without a touch of pathos," the newspaper said. The ministry's "ban on foreign exams has the look of cultural assertion - for the first time Zimbabweans will set and mark all examinations - but it hasn't escaped notice that Zanu PF is a party battling for survival and will do anything to spite Britain."

The University of Sydney, in Australia, has granted an honorary degree to a businessman who, by a remarkable coincidence, also helped secure a A$1.2m grant to establish the university's first chair of pharmacy practice. On the same day, the Sydney Morning Herald reported that the practice of awarding honorary degrees to people who have not put in the expected years of academic slog (or have risen to great social status) is becoming an increasingly common feature across many of the nation's 39 cash-strapped universities.

Still, things could be worse. If you have tears, prepare to shed them for the sons of Michael Schwartz. Only a year ago, according to the Wall Street Journal, Mr Schwartz's stock portfolio had grown to around $2m, allowing its owner to go into semi-retirement in Florida, where he looked forward to enjoying his spacious home on a canal near the Gulf of Mexico and sending the kids off to attend Ivy League colleges. Alas, the paper noted, because Mr Schwartz's portfolio happens to be telecommunications-laden, "it has lost more than half its value in the past year". This has meant that all earlier plans have had to be put on hold.

In other words - and this appeared to be the human tragedy part of the report - that Mr Schwartz has only about $1m left in his savings account, which means that he can't retire at 50 and may even have to reconsider paying for all of his kids' expenses at Harvard University.

webTitle: Bright children live longer, study suggests

fields.headline: Bright children live longer, study suggests
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Children with high IQs seem to have a better chance of a long life than their less able classmates, according to research.
fields.body:
Children with high IQs seem to have a better chance of a long life than their less able classmates, according to research.

Researchers tracked the survival rates of 2,230 people who took an intelligence test in 1932, and found that seven in 10 women who were in the top 25% of IQ scores at 11 years old reached the age of 76. Only about 45% of those in the lowest-scoring quarter survived that long.

Around half of the brightest men lived to a similar age, while well under 40% of the least able reached 76. The research concluded that the influence of childhood IQ on men may have appeared weaker because men who died on active service during the second world war had relatively high IQs.

Based on the records of Aberdeen schoolchildren, and reported in today's British Medical Journal, the research could help in understanding how factors in childhood affect health in adult life, say its authors, Lawrence Whalley and Ian Deary.

They admit they do not know why the association exists, or whether it is unique to Aberdeen and the era in which the people grew up. Possible explanations include the health of their mothers, childhood illness, privation, decisions about healthy lifestyles as adults, or increased safety at work. Social class was probably not the only factor.

The research will be followed up by checking the links between childhood IQ and specific diseases such as heart problems and cancers. The researchers will also interview volunteers, now almost 80 years old, who live in Aberdeen and Edinburgh in an attempt to find out why some people keep mentally and physically fit well into old age.

Professor Whalley, of the department of mental health at Aberdeen University, said the association with low IQ "may be because childhood factors predispose to both disease and lower IQ. Alternatively, perhaps children with lower IQ grow up to be adults less able to avoid disease or get help when they need it."

Professor Deary, of Edinburgh University's psychology department, said: "It's not so much that IQ is a very important factor, it's more that it has been a missing element in other studies which looked at education and social class... We've done the easy bit. The hard work comes in unravelling the reasons for the link."

webTitle: Cambridge lecturer gives up online identities

fields.headline: Cambridge lecturer gives up online identities
fields.trailText: The World Intellectual Property Organisation has ordered a Cambridge University lecturer to hand over internet sites registered in the names of two authors and a pornography star.
fields.body:
A French pornography star and two of Britain's most famous authors have joined forces to claim back their internet identities from a Cambridge University philosophy lecturer.

Yesterday, the United Nations' World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO) announced that Julian Barnes, Louis de Bernieres and French erotic film star turned singer Laure Sainclair had won control of internet sites registered in their names.

Mark Hogarth, a Cambridge University philosophy lecturer, registered hundreds of sites, mainly linked to famous names, a year ago. The WIPO had already ordered Mr Hogarth to hand over rights to a site registered under the name of another British writer, Jeanette Winterson.

Before Ms Winterson took Mr Hogarth to court, she approached him and asked him to voluntarily hand over the site. She asked him, "Why do you want to be me?" Apparently the lecturer made no response.

Clearly seeing the trend, Mr Hogarth handed over the domains he registered to Old Barnes Studios Ltd. The three complainants allege he is still behind the company, an allegation they say is supported by Midland Company Services Ltd, who found that all Old Barnes' mail is sent on to Mr Hogarth's address and that, as of June 20, the company had no directors.

The assistant director of the WIPO, Francis Gurry, hailed the decision as a success, saying that there must be a principle behind domain name registration.

"I can't see any reason for allowing misleading registration, the authenticity of identity on the internet is important and that's about domain names. People don't want to be misled," said Mr Gurry.

Since it began work in December 1999, the WIPO has received over 2,200 complaints about domain name registration, mainly from the rich and famous and from companies. But they have also been contacted by various national governments.

Mr Hogarth was not available for comment.

Read the full WIPO judgement

webTitle: Court to rule on exclusion from Catholic school

fields.headline: Court to rule on exclusion from Catholic school
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited Education
Special report: human rights in the UK
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The parents of a 12-year-old boy are to take a local authority to court over its decision to refuse their son a place in a Roman Catholic secondary school on the grounds of his religion.
fields.body:
The parents of a 12-year-old boy are to take a local authority to court over its decision to refuse their son a place in a Roman Catholic secondary school on the grounds of his religion.

Nathan Mackay was denied a place at a Catholic school only five minutes walk from his home in Livingston, West Lothian, because the school gives priority to children who are baptised Catholics.

St Margaret's Academy was oversubscribed last year and West Lothian education authority rejected a placement request from Nathan's parents and placed him 37th on the school's waiting list.

The family now plan to challenge the decision under the European convention on human rights. They are seeking to have the decision overturned in judicial review.

Cameron Fyfe, the solicitor representing the family, said: "The family were very angry when they were refused permission to send their child to the school of their choice. It is seen as a flagship school in their area, and is only five minutes from their home."

The European convention states that no person shall be denied the right to education, and that the employment of rights secured by the convention must be secured without discrimination on any grounds such as religion.

Mr Fyfe said these two elements would be the basis of the legal challenge. "If we win it would mean that the state could not discriminate in favour or against a child of any religion," he said.

If the legal challenge is successful it could have fundamental implications on denominational education.

Tony Blair is an enthusiastic advocate of church schools and the Department for Education and Employment said church schools had a particular character which the 1998 school standards act allowed them to preserve.

A spokesman said: "The department believes that church schools do not conflict with the human rights act provided alternatives are available."

A spokesman for West Lothian education authority said: "There is every sympathy with the family in this case but the school was oversubscribed.

"We have to set each application against robust admissions criteria. One of these is whether the child is a baptised Catholic, but there are other criteria."

A spokesman for the Catholic Education Commission - the church's schools advisory body - yesterday defended the right of schools to give priority to pupils from Catholic backgrounds.

"We would argue that the European convention on human rights gives parents the right to have their children educated according to their religious or philosophical beliefs," he said.

webTitle: Eton boy in suicide pact with depressed mother

fields.headline: Eton boy in suicide pact with depressed mother
fields.standfirst:
Doctor finds wife and son dead at home after drugs overdose

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Doctor finds wife and son dead at home after drugs overdose.
fields.body:
An Eton schoolboy and his mother have been found dead after a double suicide apparently prompted by the woman's debilitating battle with the chronic fatigue syndrome, ME.

The bodies of Keshan Gunawardena, 13, and his mother, Dinesha, were found at their home in North Ascot, Berkshire, on Wednesday evening by the boy's father, Kulasiri, an eminent doctor and director of a clinical research company.

Dr Gunawardena, 52, called an ambulance, but by the time paramedics arrived at the scene shortly after 6pm, both had died. The Sri Lankan-born respiratory specialist was said to be devastated by the loss.

Postmortem examinations were carried out yesterday. Although the toxicology results will not be available until later today at the earliest, it is understood that the deaths were caused by overdoses of prescribed drugs.

No note was found at the scene, but Thames Valley police confirmed that no one was being sought in connection with the deaths, which are being treated as suicide. According to police sources, it was clear from the scene that both knew what they were doing.

As neighbours in the cul-de-sac of Prides Crossing, North Ascot, came to terms with the news, it emerged that Mrs Gunwardena, 45, an accountant with British Airways until contracting ME, had suffered from bouts of severe depression brought on by the illness.

Keshan, described as a brilliant and polite boy who was at home on his Easter break from Eton, had become increasingly distressed by his mother's condition.

One neighbour, who asked not to be named, said: "Keshan had been a boarder at Eton College which meant that his mother did not have to look after him day in day out, as she did when he was at the prep school.

"However, the boy broke up for the Easter holidays almost two weeks ago and was at home. I think he was quite up set at seeing how ill his mum had become."

Yesterday, the family's £500,000 five bedroom home was deserted.

The couple, who came to Britain in the 1970s from Sri Lanka, moved into the cul-de-sac in 1997, and were described by neighbours as friendly but quiet.

After spells as a hospital consultant, Dr Gunawardena was the clinical research director of Chiltern International, a Slough-based company specialising in testing drugs for the pharmaceutical industry.

Keshan, an only child, was in his first year as a boarder at Eton after winning a King's Scholarship - instituted in the 15th century by Henry VI - in May last year.

Rhidian Llewellyn, headmaster of Papplewick prep school in Ascot, which Keshan attended before Eton, described him as a very hard worker and a great games player who had pushed himself to perform academically.

"He came to this school at the age of seven and was a brilliant child. He was quiet and much loved by everybody.

"He was his own person, self-contained and brilliant with computers."

Mr Llewellyn said Mrs Gunawardena had been determined to widen her son's interests beyond computers but her illness often made her depressed.

"Keshan's mother had been unable to work for some time because of the ME. She was a lovely, gentle frail woman. Keshan would worry about her like any child."

Eton College also paid tribute to the boy. The school's provost, Eric Anderson, said: "We are very sad to hear about the death of him and his mother. He had a very bright future."

Neighbours greeted news of the deaths with disbelief yesterday. Harold Tew, who lives opposite the Gunawardenas, said the last time he had spoken to the family was at a Christmas drinks party organised by another resident. Mrs Gunawardena had shown no sign of depression, he said, mingling and chatting with the other guests, while her husband had been more reserved.

Last night, Dr Gunawardena was being comforted by friends and relatives.

A police spokesman said: "He has taken this incident very badly and, not surprisingly, needs some time to come to terms with what has happened. We will be interviewing him to try to piece what went on at the house and will be preparing a full report for the East Berkshire coroner."

A spokesman for Chiltern International said: "We are very sad to hear the tragic news of the death of Dinesha and Keshan. Our sympathies go out to Dr Gunawardena and his family."

webTitle: Blunkett defends increase in infant class sizes

fields.headline: Blunkett defends increase in infant class sizes
fields.trailText: Education secretary said the government still expected to meet its election pledge by September.
fields.body:
Education secretary David Blunkett defended the small increase in English infant class sizes announced this morning, saying that the government still expected to meet its election pledge by September this year.

But the Conservatives claimed that secondary classes were at their largest in 30 years.

Ensuring that no infants were taught in classes larger than 30 was one of Labour's five key election pledges, but 2% of children under seven (36,000 pupils) are still learning in bigger classes.

Mr Blunkett told the Today programme: "We had almost half a million in classes of over 30 three years ago. We will today ... be in a very clear position to assure everyone that we have cracked it by this September, which will be a year earlier than the pledge we made at the General Election."

The government is also expected to point out that a number of five-year-olds start school in January each year and swell the figures accordingly.

Other age groups fared better in today's results, with the number of eight to 11-year-olds in classes of over 30 falling by 67,000 in the past year. Secondary class sizes have also fallen, with one teacher for every 17.1 children (down from 17.2 last year), and the average secondary class size remaining at 22.

Mr Blunkett denied that the emphasis on reducing class sizes for five to seven-year-olds had had a negative knock-on effect on junior class sizes. "Today's figures show that our critics were talking nonsense when they said that reduced class sizes 'could only be achieved' by increasing class sizes for older pupils," he said.

"People said it would have a knock-on effect on juniors and pupil-teacher ratios would go up there. I think we will find they haven't - they have in fact come down. The (junior) pupil-teacher ratio just nudged 0.1% down last year. We will see that, I am absolutely certain, accelerated."

But shadow education secretary Theresa May disagreed. "I don't think when in the 1997 election Tony Blair unveiled his posters saying class sizes will be smaller that parents thought that four years into a Labour government we were going to see secondary class sizes at their highest for 25 years." A Conservative government would not set limits on class sizes, she added.

"I hear many cases of primary schools where young children have been refused entry to their village primary because of the rigid limit on class sizes. In the past, the schools have been able to accept one or two extra and it has worked well," she said.

However, Mr Blunkett insisted the pledge was a "done deal". "It was an early pledge that we would act on it and that is why we did and why we got it down from 485,000 in the January 1998 count. We will be able to show today that we will crack it by September."

Mr Blunkett told the Today programme: "We had almost half a million in classes of over 30 three years ago. We will today ... be in a very clear position to assure everyone that we have cracked it by this September, which will be a year earlier than the pledge we made at the General Election." The government is also expected to point out that a number of five-year-olds start school in January each year and swell the figures accordingly. Other age groups fared better in today's results, with the number of eight to 11-year-olds in classes of over 30 falling by 67,000 in the past year. Secondary class sizes have also fallen, with one teacher for every 17.1 children (down from 17.2 last year), and the average secondary class size remaining at 22. Mr Blunkett denied that the emphasis on reducing class sizes for five to seven-year-olds had had a negative knock-on effect on junior class sizes. "Today's figures show that our critics were talking nonsense when they said that reduced class sizes 'could only be achieved' by increasing class sizes for older pupils," he said. "People said it would have a knock-on effect on juniors and pupil-teacher ratios would go up there. I think we will find they haven't - they have in fact come down. The (junior) pupil-teacher ratio just nudged 0.1% down last year. We will see that, I am absolutely certain, accelerated." But shadow education secretary Theresa May disagreed. "I don't think when in the 1997 election Tony Blair unveiled his posters saying class sizes will be smaller that parents thought that four years into a Labour government we were going to see secondary class sizes at their highest for 25 years." A Conservative government would not set limits on class sizes, she added. "I hear many cases of primary schools where young children have been refused entry to their village primary because of the rigid limit on class sizes. In the past, the schools have been able to accept one or two extra and it has worked well," she said. However, Mr Blunkett insisted the pledge was a "done deal". "It was an early pledge that we would act on it and that is why we did and why we got it down from 485,000 in the January 1998 count. We will be able to show today that we will crack it by September."

webTitle: Leader: The Human Rights Act is causing problems

fields.headline: Choice schools
fields.standfirst:
The Human Rights Act is causing problems

Guardian Unlimited Education
Special report: the Human Rights Act
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Twelve-year-old Nathan Mackay has found himself subject of a curious legal challenge brought under the Human Rights Act. His family is not Catholic, but his parents wanted him to attend a Catholic secondary school, St Margaret's Academy, which is only five minutes from his home in Livingston, West Lothian.
fields.body:
Twelve-year-old Nathan Mackay has found himself subject of a curious legal challenge brought under the Human Rights Act. His family is not Catholic, but his parents wanted him to attend a Catholic secondary school, St Margaret's Academy, which is only five minutes from his home in Livingston, West Lothian.

The school is heavily oversubscribed and Nathan is currently 37th on the waiting list. His parents are challenging the school's decision to restrict admission to baptised Catholics, arguing that Nathan has been discriminated against on the grounds of his religion. The controversial segregation of schooling on religious grounds has been part of Scots law since 1918: is it now tottering?

The answer is clearly no, the case is opportunistic. The convention and its interpretation in Strasbourg acknowledges that religious bodies have rights to "manifest" their faith. To reassure faith communities, this point was strengthened with an additional clause when the Human Rights Act was passed by the British parliament. Nathan has a right to an education under the convention, but not a particular kind of education.

The less clear-cut point is that if the education which Nathan is being offered at another school is significantly worse than that offered at St Margaret's (which does well in the school league tables), then perhaps he would have a discrimination case. This has implications for many areas of the country, particularly where there are inner-city Jewish and Catholic schools which maintain strict entry criteria and often have higher academic standards.

The courts would then have to adjudicate between the two conflicting rights. No prizes for guessing where the courts would come down, given how entrenched denominational schools are within the British educational system. Whatever the conclusion, this is exactly the kind of headache litigation which the faith communities feared from the Human Rights Act.

webTitle: Taking the sting out of student flat shares

fields.headline: Taking the sting out of student flat shares
fields.standfirst: Sharing a flat with fellow students can be an angst-ridden urban experience. But a new guide aims to transform your dwelling into the picture of domesticity. Rachel Gordon reports.
fields.trailText: Sharing a flat with fellow students can be an angst-ridden urban experience. But a new guide aims to transform your dwelling into the picture of domesticity. Rachel Gordon reports.
fields.body:
Sharing a property with friends is a typical part of student life, but arguments over money can make the whole experience less than enjoyable.

However, help is at hand. A new guide produced by the Abbey National student banking team is aimed at making sharing a home far less stressful.

The research was carried out for Abbey National by national opinion polls and involved interviews with about 1,000 people.

The Student Guide to Flatshares covers all the key areas that could cause potential problems. It also includes a section on how to choose flatmates with a guide on the main character types. Agony aunt Karen Krizanovich also offers some pointers on how to make sure everyone gets along.

Spending time to plan for a flatshare could bring huge benefits. Choosing the right mix of people, deciding how you will deal with bills and housework can make life a lot easier.

Many students do make mistakes and Abbey National found that almost a quarter of student flatmates found the experience so unpleasant that they would go out their way to avoid the people they shared with.

Money problems were one of the most common reasons for falling out and some 17% of students were still pursuing their ex-flatmates for unpaid debts.

Other areas of dispute were untidyness, lack of respect for privacy and stealing others' food and drink. A further 17% of those interviewed said they had a problem with the noise, smell and general offensive nature of their flatmates.

As far as finances are concerned, some pitfalls can be avoided. Here are the main areas the guide advises flatsharers to watch out for:

Tenancy agreements
Most students will be given an assured shorthold tenancy. This should not be for less than six months. Students should always insist on a written agreement, stating the tenancy period, the level of rent and the date it is payable.

You also have the right to your landlord's full name and address. Make sure all the names of the tenants are on the agreement. If one person leaves and owes money, the landlord can seek to recover this from the remaining tenants.

Deposits
A month's rent is standard. This is a safeguard against any damage. At the end of the tenancy this should be refunded in full unless there has been damage, or there are outstanding bills or rent owing.

Deductions should not be made for wear and tear. You should always obtain a receipt for the deposit, what it covers and when it will be returned. To avoid wrangles, make sure you have an inventory - a list of the contents and condition of the property - and have this witnessed by a third party. Don't redecorate or make alterations without the landlord's permission and take photographs or video of any areas you think may be a source of dispute, making sure these are dated.

Paying the bills
Where possible, all tenants names should be on the bills. This is not always possible, however. Clear agreement needs to be reached about when fellow sharers pay the bills, as if just one tenant has their name listed, they remain responsible for paying.

Telephone and Internet charges can be contentious, but even if someone does not use the phone, they are still likely to receive incoming calls or want the phone for use in emergencies. This means they should at least help with the line rental cost.

A copy of the guide can be obtained by calling 0800 731 7774 or visit the Abbey National website for further details.

http://www.abbeynational.co.uk/index_flash.html

webTitle: Sophie brushes with another fake sheikh

fields.headline: Sophie brushes with another fake sheikh
fields.trailText: The Sun sent a fake sheikh and its drug sniffer dog Charlie to greet Countess of Wessex at her very public engagement today, writes Ashley Davies
fields.body:
The Sun sent a fake sheikh and its drug sniffer dog Charlie to greet Countess of Wessex at her very public engagement today.

Stating his mission, Sun head of news Graham Dudman said Charlie's presence could have helped stand up the Mail on Sunday's cocaine allegations, and that 'Sophie likes talking to reporters dressed as sheikhs'.

Reporter Nick Fagge, dressed in Arab gear accessorised with a Sun sash, was allowed into the press area but was flanked by two policemen throughout.

His colleague, reporter Martin Wallace, accompanied Charlie. Neither he nor the hound was allowed anywhere near the royal couple. The police warned him he would be arrested if he went anywhere near them.

Dudman said: 'Why wasn't the sniffer dog allowed near the royals? We take this very seriously.'

Fagge asked the Countess how she was in Arabic but she did not respond. Dudman added: 'She was smiling at everyone but I think she was churning inside.'

This is not Fagge's first foray into the dressing up box. He dressed up as a pussy cat and a butler to deliver fish and chips to the queen when mice were found in Buckingham Palace's kitchen.

Dudman added: 'He's very versatile. I only employ people who can turn their hands to anything.'

fields.headline: The Gilletts
fields.standfirst: The school at the top of Jack's offer has 137 places going begging - not surprisingly after a wretched Ofsted which referred to problems with violence
fields.trailText: The school at the top of Jack's offer has 137 places going begging - not surprisingly after a wretched Ofsted which referred to problems with violence
fields.body:
Gary Gillett is a nurse. His wife, Jill, is a teacher. They live in Withington, south Manchester with their son Jack (left), 11 and Georgia, eight.

Jack Gillett's parents got him into nursery school in Withington at the age of four, with cast-iron guarantees that he would "feed" into Parrs Wood high school eight years later.

But the cast iron has shattered. The letter from the local education authority turned Jack down for the highly rated comprehensive in Didsbury and offered him more distant schools or ones with a struggling - at best - reputation. The shock is palpable in the voice of his mother, Jill, in spite of her long personal experience of the LEA and its workings. Now teaching at a special school in a Manchester education action zone (she is strongly committed to state education), she used to be in charge of transition arrangements to high schools in north Manchester.

"You do feel desperate, especially when everything has pointed to Parrs Wood for so long," she says. The family moved to be near one of the comprehensive's official feeder primaries, St Paul's, when Jack was tiny. Every assumption has been Parrs Wood.

"Jack plays his trombone in the orchestra there, he's done sports sessions in his holidays there, and he went on an Excellence in Cities course there last year," says Jill. "Most of his friends are going there. It's a wonderful school with beautiful new buildings, thanks to getting specialist technology status. It's got a great academic record and it would be just right for Jack."

The iron began to crack when Manchester decided to change its catchment policy two years ago, in an attempt to tackle a yawning imbalance between high school intakes. In place of "official feeder schools" with guaranteed places, each high school now runs a geographical catchment.

Now, Jack's house is just too far away from Parrs Wood, and the family cannot afford to move again to Didsbury - as many people in Withington have done in the past year. The school at the top of Jack's offer has 137 places going begging - not surprisingly after a wretched Ofsted which referred to problems with violence. Jill shudders. The answer for such schools may be parental faith, but it is very hard to be a pioneer. Jack would, she is sure, fail to thrive and would be bullied.

Jill's own instinct to appeal was strengthened by local anger; so many Withington parents have been affected by the new feeder scheme that two public meetings have been held and a telephone support network galvanises parents whose children are without a place. She also wrote to her MP, to Estelle Morris and even to Tony Blair.

Any private fears about upsetting the appeals panels by embarrassing the city council have been set aside in favour of airing the issue. Newspapers, radio and even TV have all been to Parrs Wood's gates, which are becoming a 2001 symbol of Manchester.

Like other parents, Jill is now concentrating on her case to put to the panel, probably at the end of May. Meanwhile, Jack is taking out the stress on his trombone and revision for the key stage 2 Sats.

fields.headline: The Trans
fields.standfirst: "I want to go to the mixed school because I know it is a good school, especially for a musician."
fields.trailText: "I want to go to the mixed school because I know it is a good school, especially for a musician."
fields.body:
Hung Tran was an architect in Vietnam until he and his family fled the country seven years ago. His wife, Tuyet, was a sales assistant. Both are now unemployed. They live in inner London with their three children, Duy, 17, Hoa, 14, and Thanh, 11 (pictured). When Thanh arrived from Vietnam as a refugee seven years ago he spoke no English, but has thrived in his cosmopolitan, inner-London primary school. He is also a keen musician, specialising in the oboe. Sadly, secondary provision in his home borough is uneven and Thanh lives too far from his first-choice school, an over-subscribed mixed county comprehensive, to have been offered a place there. Instead, he's been allotted to a boys' school nearer his home. Thanh's parents do not speak English well, which is why he must speak for himself.

"I want to go to the mixed school because I know it is a good school, especially for a musician. I was very upset when I didn't get a place there.

"I have an older brother who finished at the boys' school last year. He did well in his GCSEs and had some friends, but he was bullied. Because of that I am frightened. We have decided to appeal, and my teachers are helping all they can. They are going to fill in all the forms and someone is going to write a letter for us, explaining all the resaons why my parents think I should go to the school I like. If we don't win the appeal we hope for a place at our second-choice school where the waiting list is shorter. It is not a very good school, but it is still better for me than the boys' school. We don't know what else to do, so if the boys' school is the only one where I can get a place I will have to go there. We don't want to make a fuss."
