fields.headline: The Dixons
fields.trailText: Alan Dixon is a quality technician with a car parts firm. His wife Christine is a school helper. They live in Hertfordshire with their two children, Tony, nearly 11, and Steven, age nine.
fields.body:
Alan Dixon is a quality technician with a car parts firm. His wife Christine is a school helper. They live in Hertfordshire with their two children, Tony, nearly 11, and Steven, age nine.

"We live about 600 metres from our first-choice school, but Tony hasn't got a place there. Siblings get priority, and as it's a foundation school they also select up to 35% of its intake by entrance exam and 10% by proficiency in music.

"Then it's whoever lives the nearest. Tony took the entrance exam but obviously didn't do well enough, and there are so many siblings applying that even families living closer than us haven't been offered a place. It's frustrating, because we don't know how close Tony came in his exam, and we won't know where we are on the waiting list until the end of April. Our second choice was another foundation school a few miles away where they interview the pupils and pick the ones they want. I've written to David Blunkett saying I find it incredible that a school can choose its pupils in that way when it's supposed to be the other way round.

"We have been offered another school, a county comprehensive that's working hard to improve, but why should my child have to go on a long bus ride every day to a school that's not as good as any of the ones we wanted? We're hoping an acceptable place will eventually come up, and we'll go to appeal if we have to. But we're also thinking of moving, probably down to the Swindon area, where Christine's family comes from. Maybe Tony and Steven will have a better chance there."

fields.headline: The Worralls
fields.standfirst: "It's just never been this difficult before."
fields.trailText: "It's just never been this difficult before."
fields.body:
David Worrall is a plastics manufacturer. His wife, Lorraine, is a clerk at Asda. They live in Halifax with their three children, Lee, 13, Jamie, 11 and Katie, six. Lorraine and David spent ages leafing through school details, sports facilities and exam results before filling in their first three choices for Jamie, 11 in June and due to move up to high school next September. But when the buff envelope came back from Calderdale council this month, it was like a Lottery scratchcard gone wrong.

Four schools were offered, but not one of them was from the Worralls' own list. The couple were astonished, especially as one of the comprehensives was 12 miles away from their home in Halifax Ñ almost in a different county.

The other three were more predictable: schools that Calderdale is trying to rescue from the bottom of its strangely assorted heap. For sad historical reasons, the Yorkshire council has a mixture of grammars, former grant-maintained schools, strongly neighbourhood comps in outlying towns and what amount to secondary moderns, although everyone is trying to raise their game.

The squeeze on parental choice is such that the Worralls' ace Ñ a sibling already at their first-choice school for Jamie Ñ has been trumped. Their elder son Lee is 13 and flourishing at Holy Trinity, but the CofE high school had 242 applications for 180 places. Lorraine can do the sums. But she and David are also counting on strength in numbers. "There are five children in Jamie's class at the primary who now haven't got schools to go to Ñ who'll be staying behind when the others go off for the transition day at Holy Trinity or the other high schools," she says. Parents have been galvanised to tackle the appeals system, which involved writing three initial letters, fast.

First, Lorraine politely turned down the four Calderdale offers, in spite of approaches from one of the schools, which she knows from living nearby in the past. She says: "They said, Ôdon't worry Lorraine, Jamie will be in an express class' [part of reforms to attract back motivated parents and groom promising students]. But I don't want him segregated like that. We're a normal family and he's a normal boy who's bright enough but doesn't want Ôexpressing'. At that school, I'm scared that he'd either be segregated and maybe picked on, or dragged down with the rest Ñ which is why we moved away from there."

The second letter went off to Wakefield diocese to get an appeal form, and the third was the form itself, sent to Holy Trinity, which runs its own appeals; the Worralls are expecting a date at the end of this month. Lorraine and David kept their case simple and direct. "We had to," says Lorraine. "There wasn't that much room."

Lee's place at the school was one point; the other a strong and honest case for the family as active Church of England parents. In the squeeze on Holy Trinity, this is a key area of point-scoring; the family's initial application, refereed by their vicar whose own son is in Jamie's class and going to Holy Trinity, had to specify between types of church-going (the child alone, with family etc).

The Worralls want to go every week, and Jamie does Bible class on Monday evenings; but David's continental shifts at work rule out a lot of Sunday mornings for him, and then there's football. Lorraine says: "Jamie and Lee are really keen, but team practice is on Sunday morning at the same time as church." Like so many parents of three children (six-year-old Katie has all this to come) she is torn all ways.

That's another of her appeal points; sending Jamie somewhere else will mean that two hard-working parents have children at three separate schools Ñ "but I pride myself on having a very close family, and the children would benefit from being at the same school." She has tentatively approached the vicar about midweek worship, but it isn't yet a runner.

So all eyes are back on the letterbox at the family's home in Pellon, Halifax, waiting for the appeals appointment to drop through. Meanwhile, the Worralls draw strength from neighbours with the same problem, and sympathetic primary teachers who warn: "It's just never been this difficult before."
fields.bodyText: David Worrall is a plastics manufacturer. His wife, Lorraine, is a clerk at Asda. They live in Halifax with their three children, Lee, 13, Jamie, 11 and Katie, six. Lorraine and David spent ages leafing through school details, sports facilities and exam results before filling in their first three choices for Jamie, 11 in June and due to move up to high school next September. But when the buff envelope came back from Calderdale council this month, it was like a Lottery scratchcard gone wrong. Four schools were offered, but not one of them was from the Worralls' own list. The couple were astonished, especially as one of the comprehensives was 12 miles away from their home in Halifax Ñ almost in a different county. The other three were more predictable: schools that Calderdale is trying to rescue from the bottom of its strangely assorted heap. For sad historical reasons, the Yorkshire council has a mixture of grammars, former grant-maintained schools, strongly neighbourhood comps in outlying towns and what amount to secondary moderns, although everyone is trying to raise their game. The squeeze on parental choice is such that the Worralls' ace Ñ a sibling already at their first-choice school for Jamie Ñ has been trumped. Their elder son Lee is 13 and flourishing at Holy Trinity, but the CofE high school had 242 applications for 180 places. Lorraine can do the sums. But she and David are also counting on strength in numbers. "There are five children in Jamie's class at the primary who now haven't got schools to go to Ñ who'll be staying behind when the others go off for the transition day at Holy Trinity or the other high schools," she says. Parents have been galvanised to tackle the appeals system, which involved writing three initial letters, fast. First, Lorraine politely turned down the four Calderdale offers, in spite of approaches from one of the schools, which she knows from living nearby in the past. She says: "They said, Ôdon't worry Lorraine, Jamie will be in an express class' [part of reforms to attract back motivated parents and groom promising students]. But I don't want him segregated like that. We're a normal family and he's a normal boy who's bright enough but doesn't want Ôexpressing'. At that school, I'm scared that he'd either be segregated and maybe picked on, or dragged down with the rest Ñ which is why we moved away from there." The second letter went off to Wakefield diocese to get an appeal form, and the third was the form itself, sent to Holy Trinity, which runs its own appeals; the Worralls are expecting a date at the end of this month. Lorraine and David kept their case simple and direct. "We had to," says Lorraine. "There wasn't that much room." Lee's place at the school was one point; the other a strong and honest case for the family as active Church of England parents. In the squeeze on Holy Trinity, this is a key area of point-scoring; the family's initial application, refereed by their vicar whose own son is in Jamie's class and going to Holy Trinity, had to specify between types of church-going (the child alone, with family etc). The Worralls want to go every week, and Jamie does Bible class on Monday evenings; but David's continental shifts at work rule out a lot of Sunday mornings for him, and then there's football. Lorraine says: "Jamie and Lee are really keen, but team practice is on Sunday morning at the same time as church." Like so many parents of three children (six-year-old Katie has all this to come) she is torn all ways. That's another of her appeal points; sending Jamie somewhere else will mean that two hard-working parents have children at three separate schools Ñ "but I pride myself on having a very close family, and the children would benefit from being at the same school." She has tentatively approached the vicar about midweek worship, but it isn't yet a runner. So all eyes are back on the letterbox at the family's home in Pellon, Halifax, waiting for the appeals appointment to drop through. Meanwhile, the Worralls draw strength from neighbours with the same problem, and sympathetic primary teachers who warn: "It's just never been this difficult before."

webTitle: World Cup 2002 to be shown free in the UK

fields.headline: World Cup 2002 to be shown free in the UK
fields.trailText: Every World Cup Finals match of Korea Japan 2002 will be available free of charge on terrestrial TV, the Government has confirmed.
fields.body:
Every World Cup Finals match of Korea Japan 2002 will be available free of charge on terrestrial TV, the Government has confirmed.

Lord McIntosh of Haringey, a Government front-bench spokesman on culture issues in the Lords, today made it clear that all 64 matches would be free-to-air in the UK as they are classed as "listed events" under the 1996 Broadcasting Act.

The news has quashed fears in some quarters that the matches might be available only on subscriber or other non free-to-air TV.

Labour peer Lord Morris of Manchester, who tabled the original question about the 2002 World Cup broadcasting rights, said: "This means that all the matches will be available free-to-air in this country. Grave fears had been expressed in certain quarters that the matches might not be available to everybody, but only to those who can afford subscriber or digital TV.

"I am naturally extremely glad about the clarity and force of the minister's reply, making it crystal clear that everyone will have free access to these matches. It is very good news indeed and gives the green light."

A German media organisation, the Kirch Group, is planning to hold an open auction for the live rights of these matches.

In a written reply Lord McIntosh said: "We understand that the group intends to comply with the UK listed event legislation.

"Through correspondence and a meeting of officials, we have made the Kirch Group fully aware of the extent of this legislation: that the whole of the World Cup Finals tournament (all 64 matches) is a listed event and that any broadcaster purchasing live rights from Kirch would have to comply with the provisions of the 1996 Broadcasting Act.

"We expect that the ITC, the regulator responsible for ensuring compliance with the legislation, will take all proper steps to ensure that the law works in the way that it is intended, so that UK viewers have the opportunity of seeing the whole of the finals tournament on free-to-air television."

webTitle: FA Cup and Premiership team news

fields.headline: FA Cup and Premiership team news
fields.trailText: Arsenal v Tottenham (Sunday 1.30pm)
fields.body:
Arsenal v Tottenham (Sunday 1.30pm)

Striker Sylvain Wiltord is likely to get the nod to partner French colleague Thierry Henry as Arsenal go head to head with their north London rivals in the FA Cup semi-final at Old Trafford. Dennis Bergkamp is still out with injury while Giles Grimandi is suspended. Manager Arsene Wenger also has to choose between Lauren and Fredrik Ljungberg.

Sol Campbell may line up for Spurs even if he is not fully fit. The England defender is rated only 50-50 with an angle ligament strain, but is so crucial to Tottenham in Glenn Hoddle's first game as manager. Sergei Rebrov is fit with Ledley King and Stephen Clemence also expected to recover from injury in time. Stephen Carr, Tim Sherwood and Oyvind Leonhardsen are all free of injury, but short of match-fitness and Hoddle may be forced to take a gamble on at least one of them in his starting line-up.

Liverpool v Wycombe Wanderers (Sunday 4pm)

Robbie Fowler, Nick Barmby, Gary McAllister, Vladmir Smicer, Igor Biscan, Stephen Wright and Gregor Vignal are all likely to figure for the Reds as manager Gerard Houllier employs his rotation system following Thursday's goalless draw in the Uefa Cup against Barcelona in the Nou Camp.

Lawrie Sanchez will make a decision on the fitness of captain Keith Ryan before Wycombe go into the biggest match in their history. Jason Cousins will continue to lead the side if Ryan fails to make the starting line-up. Guy Whittingham, who joined from Portsmouth on deadline day, is likely to partner fellow veteran Andy Rammell up front, leaving goal-scoring hero at Leicester, Roy Essandoh, on the bench.

Aston Villa v West Ham United

Juan Pablo Angel may have to settle for a place on the Aston Villa bench. He is now fit after being sidelined for two matches with a knee injury picked up playing for Colombia. Villa have won both matches in his absence.

Harry Redknapp could turn to Bulgarian striker Svetoslav Todorov to solve his side's goalscoring problems. Todorov is in line for his first Hammers' start as the London outfit look to stop a slump that has seen them lose five successive matches and slip worryingly close to the relegation trap-door.

Derby County v Chelsea

Goalkeeper Mart Poom will return for the Rams in place of the injured Andy Oakes. Defenders Taribo West and Chris Riggott are also available having missed last Saturday's 2-0 defeat at Coventry but Scottish international midfielder Craig Burley is still sidelined with a hamstring injury.

French defender Frank Lebouef will not travel to Pride Park as he is still being troubled with a groin injury picked up while on international duty two weeks ago. The Blues, though, do include Albert Ferrer, Gus Poyet and Mario Melchiot in their squad.

Everton v Manchester City (Sunday 3pm)

Kevin Campbell and Richard Gough return to the Everton squad for this crunch relegation tussle while Francis Jeffers, who appears to be on his way out of Goodison Park in the summer, could also figure despite being troubled by an ankle injury.

Joe Royle, returning to Everton for the first time since he left the managerial post in March 1997, could offer a recall to striker Paulo Wanchope - the pair had a touchline row in January and the Costa Rican has not figured since. Steve Howey will have a late fitness test on his thigh strain, but should be available, and City's only definite absentees are the injured Kevin Horlock and Paul Ritchie.

Leeds United v Southampton

Dominic Matteo will partner Lucas Radebe at the centre of the Leeds defence following the news that skipper Lucas Radebe has been ruled out for the season. Striker Robbie Keane is also available having missed Wednesday's Champions League battering of Deportivo La Coruna due to his ineligibility.

The Saints should welcome captain Jason Dodd back into the fold for his first match since injuring his knee against Bradford on February 10. Striker Kevin Davies is also in contention for a recall having missed Monday night's 3-0 home reverse against Ipswich but Moroccan midfielder Hassan Kachloul (calf) is still a major doubt.

Leicester City v Coventry City

Leicester City will be without striker Dean Sturridge as they look to end a run of four league and cup defeats. Leading scorer Muzzy Izzet could return after a calf injury, but Foxes manager Peter Taylor will not risk the 11-goal midfielder if he is less than fully fit. Robbie Savage, Frank Sinclair, Matthew Jones and Darren Eadie are still all ruled out.

Coventry manager Gordon Strachan should field the same team that beat Derby last week.

fields.headline: £120m boost for tourism
fields.standfirst:
 Government loans for tourist industry
 Burial mound suggestion for carcasses
 Slaughterman dies after shooting incident

Election 2001: foot and mouth

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Government ministers were out in force today to promote British tourism in advance of the Easter holidays. The prime minister, Tony Blair, was in Yorkshire reassuring potential visitors that the foot and mouth outbreak would not interfere with their holiday plans.
fields.body:
Government ministers were out in force today to promote British tourism in advance of the Easter holidays. The prime minister, Tony Blair, was in Yorkshire reassuring potential visitors that the foot and mouth outbreak would not interfere with their holiday plans.

The government today pledged £120m of guaranteed loans to the tourist industry, after ministers confirmed yesterday that bookings are down 10% across the country and up to 80% in areas of Cumbria and Devon.

The initiative targets those businesses hit by cash-flow problems by offering loans of between £15,000 and £250,000.

Many rural businesses such as B&Bs are already eligible for loans under this scheme, but the move means that businesses such as garages, restaurants and souvenir shops can also now apply.

In addition, the maximum time for repayment will be increased by a year to 11 years, and capital repayment breaks will be increased from two to three years.

Meanwhile, the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, went sailing on the Norfolk Broads today in an attempt to persuade tourists to return to the countryside. Mr Prescott was in Brundall, near Norwich, to meet officials from the Broads authority to discuss the problems facing the tourist industry in East Anglia.

Many footpaths and mooring areas around the Broads are closed because of the disease, but Mr Prescott urged visitors to head to East Anglia this Easter, saying there was still lots of things to do.

"Even though some footpaths are closed there is still plenty to do and the countryside is still open," he said.

The cabinet minister, Mo Mowlam, was visiting Warwick castle today to deliver a similar message.

Cumbria county council was today removing road signs banning walkers from the countryside because the signs do not fit in with the "open for business image", the county council said.

A committee concluded that the signs are "absolutely necessary" in the areas already infected, as well as in the 3km culling zones, but said some would be removed in other areas.

While Britain struggles to convince the world that the countryside is not off limits, the Irish tourist industry today launched a promotion to win back visitors from the UK in the face of a forecast £417m shortfall resulting from the crisis.

The campaign coincided with similar moves by the holiday trade in Britain and Northern Ireland.

Newspaper advertisements will appear in Britain this weekend, assuring would-be visitors that Ireland is open for tourism business.

The development was welcomed by the Irish Tourist Industry Confederation, but a spokesman said similar tourism campaigns would be required in the US and other parts of Europe to salvage the approaching holiday season.

The Aer Lingus national airline has predicted that tourist numbers could be down by as much as 30% over the next three months, with advance bookings from the UK currently doing particularly badly. The ferries in Dublin said that they were experiencing a 35% drop in car and passenger services on services across the Irish sea.

Back in England, a clay mound the size of a football pitch to be filled with 30,000 decomposing sheep and cattle has been suggested for the west country to solve a crisis of unburied animals.

The Ministry of Agriculture is so desperate about carcasses lying in fields and barns that it refuses any longer to publish the figures, and is considering the mound plan, put forward by the National Farmers' Union.

 A slaughterman died in hospital last night after having been shot with a gun used to kill animals at a foot and mouth burial pit. Steven Smart, 28, from St Leonards in East Sussex, was culling healthy sheep on Wednesday at Great Orton airfield in Cumbria when a three-inch retractable rod was fired into his head from a bolt gun used to kill livestock.He died at Newcastle general hospital at 5pm yesterday.

fields.headline: Authorities seize 'corrupt' Bosnian bank
fields.trailText: Masked police, backed by soldiers from the Nato-led Stabilisation Force (S-For), today seized control of a bank in Mostar, Bosnia-Hercegovina, that is believed to be used by Bosnian Croat extremists pursuing the goal of an independent mini-state in Croat areas of Bosnia.
fields.body:
Masked police, backed by soldiers from the Nato-led Stabilisation Force (S-For), today seized control of a bank in Mostar, Bosnia-Hercegovina, that is believed to be used by Bosnian Croat extremists pursuing the goal of an independent mini-state in Croat areas of Bosnia.

Angry Bosnian Croats responded by stoning international officials, beating up employees of international organisations and ransacking a local office of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE). Nato spokesman lieutenant Lars Anderson said, "there have been injuries" among Nato-led peacekeepers but gave no further details. "The situation is still developing," he added.

As tension mounted, US and Nato forces bolstered their presence in a show of strength in areas with substantial Croat populations.

International authorities ordered the takeover of the Mostar headquarters and several branches of the Hercegovacka Banka because of "repeated concern over continued corruption", a statement from chief international administrator Wolfgang Petritsch's office said.

The bank is believed to be the financial base of the Bosnian wing of the Croatian Democratic Union (HDZ), which announced plans last month to break away from the Muslim-Croat Federation and establish a separate Croat state in south-western Bosnia.

Today Nato, UN international police and security forces of the Muslim-Croat Federation raided the bank and named a provisional administration, Mr Petritsch's spokesman, Chris Bird, said.

During the takeover, crowds stoned international officials and there were reports of shots fired outside the bank, UN spokesman Douglas Coffman said in Sarajevo.

Several people who work for Mr Petritsch were beaten, and the office of the OSCE in Siroki Brijeg was ransacked, he said.

"By doing this raid, the international community has hit a raw nerve, targeting this institution which allegedly is linked to illegal parallel institutions," Mr Coffman said.

The HDZ denounced the takeover as "armed robbery" and demanded an explanation from international administrators. In Mostar the bank's spokesman, Milan Sutalo, called the action "absolutely illegal because this is a private bank and not a public institution  There was no reason for armed people coming to the bank".

Troops and police also took over branches of the bank in the towns of Siroki Brijeg, Grude, Orasje, Tomislavgrad, Posusje and Medjugorje. In Orasje, about 500 Bosnian Croats gathered in front of the Hercegovacka Banka branch to protest against the takeover.

Tensions were already high in Orasje, located in northern Bosnia, because of efforts by hardliners and war veterans to convince Bosnian Croat soldiers to desert the federation army.

American military helicopters hovered over Orasje and armoured personnel carriers patrolled the streets as mediators tried to reduce the tension.

The raids took place a day after Bosnian Croat nationalists moved to take control of federation army barracks in the central Bosnian towns of Busovaca and Vitez.

German peacekeepers also increased their presence today around another central Bosnian garrison at Kiseljak to prevent any moves against the base there. Bosnia-Herzegovina was divided into a Bosnian Serb mini-state and the Muslim-Croat Federation as part of the 1995 Dayton peace agreement that ended the three-year Bosnian war.

After the war, the HDZ maintained parallel government institutions in south-western Bosnia, despite the objections of international administrators. In elections last November, the party lost support among Bosnian Croats nationally but remained deeply entrenched in the Croat heartland.

Last month, the HDZ announced it was pulling out of the federation with the Muslims, claiming the alliance worked against the interest of the Croat people. Mr Petritsch then fired the Bosnian Croat president, Ante Jelavic, and several top HDZ officials for violations of the Dayton accords.

Records show the Hercegovacka Banka was founded in 1997 by several private companies and the Franciscan order, which controls the religious shrine in Medjugorje, a major source of income, both from pilgrims and from donations by Croats living abroad.

fields.bodyText: Masked police, backed by soldiers from the Nato-led Stabilisation Force (S-For), today seized control of a bank in Mostar, Bosnia-Hercegovina, that is believed to be used by Bosnian Croat extremists pursuing the goal of an independent mini-state in Croat areas of Bosnia. Angry Bosnian Croats responded by stoning international officials, beating up employees of international organisations and ransacking a local office of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE). Nato spokesman lieutenant Lars Anderson said, "there have been injuries" among Nato-led peacekeepers but gave no further details. "The situation is still developing," he added. As tension mounted, US and Nato forces bolstered their presence in a show of strength in areas with substantial Croat populations. International authorities ordered the takeover of the Mostar headquarters and several branches of the Hercegovacka Banka because of "repeated concern over continued corruption", a statement from chief international administrator Wolfgang Petritsch's office said. The bank is believed to be the financial base of the Bosnian wing of the Croatian Democratic Union (HDZ), which announced plans last month to break away from the Muslim-Croat Federation and establish a separate Croat state in south-western Bosnia. Today Nato, UN international police and security forces of the Muslim-Croat Federation raided the bank and named a provisional administration, Mr Petritsch's spokesman, Chris Bird, said. During the takeover, crowds stoned international officials and there were reports of shots fired outside the bank, UN spokesman Douglas Coffman said in Sarajevo. Several people who work for Mr Petritsch were beaten, and the office of the OSCE in Siroki Brijeg was ransacked, he said. "By doing this raid, the international community has hit a raw nerve, targeting this institution which allegedly is linked to illegal parallel institutions," Mr Coffman said. The HDZ denounced the takeover as "armed robbery" and demanded an explanation from international administrators. In Mostar the bank's spokesman, Milan Sutalo, called the action "absolutely illegal because this is a private bank and not a public institution  There was no reason for armed people coming to the bank". Troops and police also took over branches of the bank in the towns of Siroki Brijeg, Grude, Orasje, Tomislavgrad, Posusje and Medjugorje. In Orasje, about 500 Bosnian Croats gathered in front of the Hercegovacka Banka branch to protest against the takeover. Tensions were already high in Orasje, located in northern Bosnia, because of efforts by hardliners and war veterans to convince Bosnian Croat soldiers to desert the federation army. American military helicopters hovered over Orasje and armoured personnel carriers patrolled the streets as mediators tried to reduce the tension. The raids took place a day after Bosnian Croat nationalists moved to take control of federation army barracks in the central Bosnian towns of Busovaca and Vitez. German peacekeepers also increased their presence today around another central Bosnian garrison at Kiseljak to prevent any moves against the base there. Bosnia-Herzegovina was divided into a Bosnian Serb mini-state and the Muslim-Croat Federation as part of the 1995 Dayton peace agreement that ended the three-year Bosnian war. After the war, the HDZ maintained parallel government institutions in south-western Bosnia, despite the objections of international administrators. In elections last November, the party lost support among Bosnian Croats nationally but remained deeply entrenched in the Croat heartland. Last month, the HDZ announced it was pulling out of the federation with the Muslims, claiming the alliance worked against the interest of the Croat people. Mr Petritsch then fired the Bosnian Croat president, Ante Jelavic, and several top HDZ officials for violations of the Dayton accords. Records show the Hercegovacka Banka was founded in 1997 by several private companies and the Franciscan order, which controls the religious shrine in Medjugorje, a major source of income, both from pilgrims and from donations by Croats living abroad. fields.headline: Advertising slump hits SMG
fields.trailText: 5.15pm: Scottish Media Group has become the latest victim of the advertising drought affecting ITV companies, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Scottish media group SMG has become the latest victim of the advertising drought affecting ITV companies.

The owner of the Scottish Television and Grampian TV franchises said television revenues for the first three months of the year were down 9% compared to the same period in 2001.

Donald Cruickshank, chairman of SMG, confirmed at the company's annual general meeting that a rapid recovery is unlikely, with analysts expecting the ITV advertising market to fall by up to 20% this month.

"While many commentators are predicting an upturn in the second half, a number of advertisers have been holding back on marketing budgets and only committing spend on a very short-term basis, thereby reducing our visibility on prospects over the coming months," he said.

Advertising revenues at ITV rivals Granada and Carlton are expected to fall by 5% for their financial year to September.

SMG has also been hit by the terms for its ITV licence renewals, which asked for an increased percentage of the group's advertising revenues.

Mr Cruickshank warned shareholders that these factors would make the first six months of the year "challenging."

However, Mr Cruickshank added that revenues at SMG's Virgin Radio operation were holding up well.

"Radio is achieving revenues around the level of this time last year, which is a good result given current trading conditions and the falling away of dot.com advertising," he said.

SMG's shares fell 7% to 187.5p on the news.

fields.headline: The Grand National
fields.standfirst: Tomorrow a huge TV audience will watch the world's most famous horse race. Here's our guide to the best of the Grand National on the net.
fields.trailText: It's the eve of the most famous horse race in the world. Here's our guide to the best of the Grand National on the net.
fields.body:
1. Tomorrow, a maximum field of 40 horses and riders will gather at the starting line for the world's most famous steeplechase, The Grand National. The race, which marks the end of a three-day jamboree at Liverpool's Aintree race course, will be watched by a massive TV audience of over 600m.

2. It's been possible to bet online for some time, but this year there's a special offer available for Guardian punters, and you can also watch the race on the web for the first time.

3. Betting, as always, will reach fever pitch, and there's plenty of information to help you pick your favoured nag.

4. After the misery of losing the Cheltenham Festival to the foot and mouth crisis, the sport of kings was given a big boost on Tuesday with the news that Irish trainers will travel to Liverpool for the race.

5. It's a brutal affair. Nearly two and a quarter miles long, with 16 fences, the horses have to complete almost two circuits, followed by a 494-yard finish. It's proved the downfall of many in the past. In 1999, the highly rated Eudip joined the list of fatalities when he fell at Becher's Brook.

6. Indeed, the race has long been controversial, with the notorious fences causing the deaths of many horses down the years. Animal welfare groups like Animal Aid continue to call for the end to the race.

7. But, this year, the fences have been adjusted to make things a little less dangerous.

8. The first official races at Aintree were in 1829, but, in 1839, Lottery became the winner of the first true Grand National, although it was hardly grand in those days. The horses had only to jump a stone wall (now the water jump), cross a stretch of plough land and finish over two hurdles.

9. In 1949, Lord Sefton sold the course to the Topham family, who appointed Mirabel Topham to manage it. The redoubtable Mrs Topham built a new track within the established course and opened it in 1953, the same year as the motor circuit that still encircles the track.

10. Past winners include L'Escargot, Party Politics and, most famously of all, Red Rum, but Bobbyjo, who won in 1999, won't be challenging for a second win in three years after sustaining an injury.

fields.headline: Freud has rival for Groucho
fields.trailText: 4pm: A company backed by IT girl Tara-Palmer Tomkinson is trying to scupper Matthew Freud's bid to take over the Groucho Club, writes Matthew Freud
fields.body:
A company backed by IT girl Tara-Palmer Tomkinson has submitted a formal attempt to scupper PR svengali Matthew Freud's bid to take over the Groucho Club, the Soho hangout favoured by media types.

Zoo Hotels, a boutique hotel group headed by 31-year-old Old Etonian Benjamin Fry and advised by Ms Tomkinson, offered a swap deal which would see Groucho shareholders given seven Zoo shares for every two shares that they own in the Groucho.

Mr Fry wants to build a 29.9% stake in the Groucho and then open a sister venue in Los Angeles and cinema in London's West End.

However it is understand that the Groucho is just days from closing a deal with Mr Freud.

Mr Fry's offer values each Groucho share at 358.75p and the club at £15.9m, compared to Mr Freud's cash offer of 266.75p per share. Groucho shares currently change hands at 225p.

Mr Freud last month tendered his offer for the Groucho through a newly formed company called Newco, which has the backing of investment banker Rupert Hambro and chocolates heir Joel Cadbury.

The Groucho board said that it prefers Mr Freud's offer because it is in cash. Mr Fry's offer is in shares and its value is therefore dependent on fluctuations of the stock market.

Groucho shareholders include Salman Rushdie, Lord Archer and Janet Street-Porter.

Zoo runs two London hotels, the Westbourne Hotel and the Sydney Hotel.

Ms Palmer-Tomkinson advises on interior decorations and furnishings. It has already had one attempt to buy the club rejected and faces an uphill battle to convince shareholders of the merits of its offer.

webTitle: Yahoo! joins team to combat Napster

fields.headline: Yahoo! joins team to combat Napster
fields.standfirst:
More net news
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The race to rival Napster took a step forward when Yahoo! joined Duet, the online music service created by Vivendi Universal and Sony Music Entertainment. By Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
The race to rival the controversial online music site Napster took another step forward yesterday when internet concern Yahoo! joined Duet, the online music service created by Vivendi Universal and Sony Music Entertainment, two of the world's largest recording groups.

The move comes days after AOL Time Warner, Bertelsmann, EMI and RealNetworks announced the formation of a digital music venture, MusicNet.

Napster is attempting to comply with a court order designed to stop the swapping of copyright music. It has set up filters to block access to disputed material . But the music industry claims the filter is not effective enough and is threatening further legal action.

Shares in Yahoo!, which have lost more than 90% of their value over the past year, rose 23% to $15 yesterday as analysts welcomed evidence that it would earn more revenue from regular subscribers. More than 80% of the company's revenues are derived from the cyclical advertising market.

Under the non-exclusive pact announced yesterday, Yahoo! will market Duet's online subscription service to its 185m monthly users. French-based Vivendi and Japan's Sony corporation represent two of the biggest music companies in the world with artists such as Jennifer Lopez and Elton John.

Music analysts believe that all five recording companies owned by the big media groups will eventually license their music to several subscriptionservices, allowing those services compete for users.

Eric Scheirer, an analyst at Forrester Research, said: "These announcement - all coming as a flurry on top of each other - legitimate the thought that the digital music market is taking shape in a fairly healthy way versus a single label service.

"The prospect that we see, in a year or two, is that of many different music services innovating and outcompeting each other, and that's a great music opportunity."

Jean-Marie Messier, chairman and chief executive of Vivendi, said: "The number of consumers seeking music online is large and growing, and we want consumers to have legitimate access to all their favourite artists and songs. We hope that other major music companies and independent music companies will join Duet."

The flurry of deals comes as Napster has struggled to block copyrighted work from its system following its defeat in a landmark legal ruling earlier this year. The company has also announced plans for a new subscription service with Bertelsmann this summer, infuriating many of its 50m-plus members who had downloaded songs free under the old service.

Both Duet and MusicNet hope to have introduced their new fee-paying services by this summer.

Duet's subscription service will let users compile personal playlists and share them with other Duet members. The service is expected to start with streaming music and plans downloads later.

Shares in the California-based group have plummeted amid concerns over the future of the internet in general and a management vacuum in particular. Yahoo! shook the market last month when it warned that its first-quarter results would fall well short of already lowered Wall Street estimates.

fields.headline: What went wrong at FTYourMoney.com?
fields.standfirst: When Pearson cut its losses with FTYourMoney, it effectively undid more than two years of work aimed at diversifying the FT's internet properties into a strong portfolio of brands
fields.trailText:
3.30pm: Comment: The closure of FTYourMoney signals an end to two years of diversification of FT online, reports Amy Vickers
Apr 6: FT cuts online jobs in quest to break even
Read the FT memo
fields.body:
When Pearson cut its losses with FTYourMoney, it effectively undid more than two years of work aimed at diversifying the FT's internet properties into a strong portfolio of brands.

FTYourMoney was arguably the first in a long list of expensive websites to be hived off from the core FT.com product.

During its year-long life span, FTYourMoney failed spectacularly to make any impact on the consumer personal finance market, despite a marketing budget of more than £7m.

What went wrong? Primarily, the website overstepped the confines of FT Group in that it took the company into the uneasy waters of the consumer market.

It soon became clear that this wasn't a natural fit with the rest of the FT's properties and found it difficult to find a strong differentiating foothold in what quickly became a very crowded marketplace.

But two years ago when the FT first called in the head-hunters to staff up for the generously paid executive positions at FTYourmoney, only a few within the industry questioned the FT's excursion into the consumer market.

Most thought it would be a natural extension of predecessor FTQuicken, which was closed down to make way for FTYourmoney.

After the initial 3m page impressions which followed a high-profile advertising campaign, traffic for FTYourmoney dropped off to insignificant levels.

Curiously, just a day after it was announced that the site - now a shadow of its former self - would be integrated into FT.com, emails from staff at the Financial Times still displayed this obligatory advert at the bottom of the mail: "For UK personal finance, please visit http://www.ftyourmoney.com".

Pearson, as expected, put a positive spin on Thursday's retrenchment. Of course, it did say back in August last year that it was now looking at an "integration strategy" and then last month it was reported to be halving investment in internet operations.

"It's not about what went wrong," said a spokesman from Pearson, "It's about how different the market is from last year. The sensible thing is to combine resources in order to make stronger returns."

The writing was on the wall, and staff working in the internet operations said there were very few surprises in the email memo from chief executive Stephen Hill was send round yesterday.

Investment in FT.com is now expected to be scaled back to around £50m this year as the company focuses heavily on premium subscription services, which are eventually expected to account for around half of all FT.com revenues.

The 10% cut in the number of online staff was also expected, especially since the FT had staffed up so heavily and expensively last year.

The only surprise, said one member of staff, was that there were editorial redundancies (around eight in total) because the FT always maintains it will try its hardest to protect editorial.

The rest of the job cuts were felt in areas such as technology, marketing, and product management.

fields.headline: Blair tours Yorkshire
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has spent the day taking part in a series of set piece visits to tourist attractions and farmers in Yorkshire in an attempt to persuade the nation that the countryside is, after all, open for business.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has spent the day taking part in a series of set piece visits to tourist attractions and farmers in Yorkshire in an attempt to persuade the nation that the countryside is, after all, open for business.

Wearing a suit and a light pink tie - in marked contrast to the protective clothing the prime minister wore on a visit to Cumbria a week earlier - Mr Blair and his wife Cherie began their day in York, where he toured the town's Viking centre.

They were greeted by school children and a group of museum staff dressed in Roman costumes.

"The most important thing to get across to people is that Britain is open there is no problem with people coming over," he said. "We have simply got to get across a proper sense of prospective."

The trip came after a government announcement today of £120m of guaranteed loans to the tourist industry. Ministers confirmed yesterday that bookings are down 10% across the country and up to 80% in areas of Cumbria and Devon.

Later Mr Blair and his wife visited the Bronte Parsonage in Howarth, West Yorkshire, the home of the famous literary family. Before entering the house Mrs Blair filled her husband in with details of the Bronte history, and agreed with waiting reporters that she was a fan of the writers.

Mr and Mrs Blair were due to walk through the cobbled streets of the moorland village later before visiting a steam railway.

Meanwhile, the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, went sailing on the Norfolk Broads today in an attempt to persuade tourists to return to the countryside.

However neither Mr Blair nor Mr Prescott would commit themselves to taking summer holiday in Britain.

"I do not yet know where I am going in the summer," said Mr Prescott, in Norfolk. "Like anyone else it is about having a balance between going abroad and staying in Britain. MPs are no different to anybody else."

The prime minister added that he would be delighted to visit the Yorkshire countryside for his holidays, if possible.

fields.headline: Hit and Miss Selfridge
fields.standfirst: New store, new ads, new look.  Charlie Porter finds out how the once-ignored high street store is fighting back
fields.trailText: New store, new ads, new look. Charlie Porter finds out how the once-ignored high street store is fighting back.
fields.body:
In fashion, there are a few standard phrases. Colours are always the New Black, and upcoming graduates are forever the New McQueen. So what do you call Miss Selfridge, the 35-year-old chain that's about to open a long-awaited new London flagship? Why, it's the New Topshop.

Which is more apt than you'd think, since the new site, which opens on Monday, neighbours onto Topshop's mammoth Oxford Circus megastore. Indeed, the two are linked by an always-open door, which is no surprise since both brands are owned by the sector-leading Arcadia Group. By joining the two stores together, the company is showing its commitment to the teenage shopper, hinted at by the announcement yesterday that it plans to sell off some of its more dowdier chains, such as Principles, Racing Green and Hawkshead.

But the differences between Topshop and Miss Selfridge could not be more stark - if you go to Topshop this weekend, head to the right hand side of the warehouse-style accessories floor and you can peek into Miss Selfridge's gaudy new palace, with its pink chandelier, loud grafitti walls and spinning, mirrored mosaic heart. The plan is for this new look to slowly influence the stores around the country.

While Topshop is a trend factory, usually on the mark, sometimes wide of it, Miss Selfridge is smaller, more personal, more fun. Sally Bailey, the store's brand director, has wanted to move out of their old shop for years. "For me, there are a lot of things people don't know about Miss Selfridge because we've never had a good flagship store," she says. "We're not going posher, we're not going younger. We're saying, 'This is Miss Selfridge, this is what we stand for.'"

A few years ago, the old store, over the road from the new site, was up with the times. But as the Oxford Circus area slowly regenerated into what is now the most important retail district in the country, the shop, hidden away near Superdrug, started to look clumsy and tired. The need for a good flagship on this patch, now also inhabited by Niketown, Hennes, Gap, French Connection, Mango and Zara, cannot be overstated. Not only do millions of shoppers pass through the area each week hungry for quick-fix trends, but the pavements also act as a fashion barometer - it's well known that model scouts find most of their new faces by standing outside Oxford Circus tube, waiting for the New Kate Moss to walk up the steps.

By moving a few feet across the road, Miss Selfridge goes from being that other store you might pop into after Topshop, and becomes a destination in itself. "Moving there is great for us," says Bailey. "We're the two biggest players on the market, so together we can only get stronger." Doesn't she worry that Topshop's formidable skill for spotting trends will dwarf its operation? "We just do what's right for our customers, but it's like all competitive labels, no matter how expensive. You'll always find black trousers, you don't say we can't do it just because someone else is. We'll do a trend in our own way, but we'll take it further than anyone else on the high street."

Which shows in its spring/summer collections - neon mesh vests, jersey T-shirts with Chloe-esque pineapples and blush pink ra-ra skirts will all be on the rails in its new store. It shows in its new edgy advertising campaign, where instead of the usual catalogue styling, the clothes look thrown on, as if they were cast in an edgy off-schedule show. One of the shots, with the models giggling in some teeny bikinis, has even been banned by London Underground for being too saucy.

But the campaign also had other aims - to help break fashions obsession with gaunt, ill-looking waifs. "When we chose the models, we didn't go for 'beautiful' ones," says Bailey, "they're more like normal girls. There aren't any really thin girls, and none that are really young - they're all over 18, and they're putting two fingers up to the world."

They need to be striking, because the other stores in the area are full of trends right now. Topshop has gone big on military, with a great take on Matthew Williamson's coloured camouflage and some very covetable neon belts (though these sit alongside some less desirable outfits - on one of the rails is a T-shirt with the slogan "It's Friday Night and I'm Going To Get Hammered"). Prada has influenced many of the shops - see the brilliant flower-shadow print skirt in black on white at Zara.

At French Connection, once you've got past the big-selling but Frustratingly Unfunny Comedy Klothing, there are some pretty candy colours, while Uth has some great Grecian billowing tops, and its rival Jigsaw has scored high with its Marc Jacobs-like 50s bad girl look. Amid all these key styles, it's easy to see why stores such as Gap are floundering. None of the shades is right for this season - dull oranges, blues and yellows without any hints of neon, and no thought has been put into the cut or shape of the clothes. "Blouson" and "assymetric" are clearly not part of its vocabulary.

Indeed, Bailey says that, although the high street is crowded, the wheat is starting to emerge from the chaff. "More people are leaving the market than coming into it. There are not that many getting it right for 15-24 year olds." And Arcadia's business-shedding strategy is proof that its core business are the late-teen, early 20s shoppers. For them, the restatement of the Miss Selfridge brand could not have come at a better time.

fields.headline: Israel attacks Palestinian police stations
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel launched a rocket attack on two Palestinian police stations today and knocked out power to thousands of homes after four Israeli communities were attacked by Palestinian mortar fire.
fields.body:
Israel launched a rocket attack on two Palestinian police stations today and knocked out power to thousands of homes after four Israeli communities were attacked by Palestinian mortar fire.

Meanwhile, a leading Islamic militant killed in an explosion attributed to Israeli forces was buried in the town of Jenin in the West Bank.

Eight men in white robes, meant to symbolise the death shrouds of suicide bombers, carried the flag-draped body of Iyad Hardan through the streets, followed by some 5,000 mourners.

Mr Hardan was killed yesterday when a public phone he used exploded and a thirst for revenge dominated the mood at his funeral today.

He was a follower of the Islamic Jihad group, which has carried out a series of attacks in Israel in recent months. Two other suspected Islamic militants held in the Jenin jail were released after his death, it has been reported.

The Israeli rocket attacks on northern Gaza early today came in response to mortar fire on three Jewish settlements and an Israeli communal farm on the border with the Gaza Strip. No one was hurt by the mortar shells.

In the past, Israel had only launched air strikes if Israelis were killed or wounded in Palestinian attacks.

The rockets knocked out large parts of the facade of a two-story building in a residential neighbourhood of the town of Beit Lahiya.

Palestinian police had moved out of the area when they heard the gunships approaching, although two bystanders were hit by shrapnel.

In several West Bank towns, including Hebron and Ramallah, Palestinians threw stones at Israeli soldiers. In Ramallah, troops fired rubber-coated bullets and tear gas, injuring 19 Palestinians, according to paramedics at the scene.

Israeli officials, meanwhile, said they would step up retaliation for Palestinian shootings, bombings and mortar attacks.

Israel will strike back "relentlessly" and Palestinian security installations will be considered targets as long as security forces fail to prevent attacks on Israelis, said Raanan Gissin, a top aide to the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon.

The internal security minister, Uzi Landau, said Israeli forces should hit Palestinian targets "every day, hour after hour". He told Israel radio that "the price we will exact from the Palestinian Authority will become intolerable."

fields.headline: Guinness unveils new advert
fields.trailText: 4.15pm: Guinness has unveiled the long-awaited follow-up to its 'Surfer' commercial, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
A stout-drinking squirrel and a giant curtain that reveals the meaning of life are the bizarre ingredients of the long-awaited follow-up to the Guinness "Surfer" commercial.

Surfer, in which a fanatical surfer crashes towards the shore on waves of white horses, was voted the best TV advert of all time in a national survey by the Sunday Times and Channel 4 last year.

The new commercial, entitled "Dream Club", reunites the team behind Surfer and forms part of a £5m campaign that breaks this weekend.

Following in the surreal tradition of Surfer, the new advert focuses on the members of a fictional elite club of adventurers who aim to find the meaning of life through their dreams.

Shot in the brewer's trademark black and white, the film shows a member of the group finally achieving his aim, fuelled, of course, by a pint of Guinness.

The commercial ends with the campaign line, "Good things come to those who wait".

Dream Club was created by Guinness's advertising agency Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO and directed by Jonathan Glazer.

The advert was shot in sub-zero temperatures in Budapest using 50 stuntmen and some 500 extras as well as a cast of local actors.

"We are confident that our advertising agency AMV and Jonathan Glazer have come up with the goods again," said Guinness marketing manager Wendy Darlington.

"We expect Dream Club to be one of our most successful campaigns to date."

The campaign is aimed at driving up sales among 18 to 35-year-old men and the commercial will premiere during Sky's coverage of the England v France rugby on Saturday.

fields.headline: Europe should now push Kyoto
fields.standfirst:
The United States' abandonment of the climate change pact gives the EU a chance to show its mettle, writes Andrew Osborn

Special report: global warming

Special report: George Bush's America

Special report: EU integration
fields.trailText: The United States' abandonment of the climate change pact gives the EU a chance to show its mettle, writes Andrew Osborn.
fields.body:
Appalling, provocative and depressing are all eminently suitable adjectives to describe George "Dubya" Bush's ill-considered forsaking of the crucial Kyoto climate change protocol. For without the participation of America, the world's biggest polluter, the accord looks shaky.

But America's idiocy could now be Europe's gain if the EU and its constituent member states honour their own commitments and marshall other countries to ensure that they do not follow President Bush's lamentable lead.

The hour of reckoning for Romano Prodi, the president of the European commission, and his able environment commissioner Margot Wallstrom, has now come.

Foreign policy experts and EU insiders are always complaining that the union in political terms punches way below its weight - in fact the phrase has become something of a mantra for Chris Patten, the EU's external relations commissioner.

The 300m-strong population of the eurozone - the 12 countries which have adopted the euro - outstrips that of the United States as does the area's share of world exports. But for a whole host of reasons, Washington is the only superpower on the block while the EU, thanks to conflicting views of what is should be, is simply not a power to be reckoned with. The fact that it manages the world's biggest humanitarian aid programme for example seems to count for nothing.

But America's increasingly vocal unilateralism and gradual retreat from the world stage - be it in the Balkans, North Korean policy and now environmental policy - creates a power vacuum just waiting to be exploited by the EU. This would not be a question of the EU as a superpower finally coming of age. On the contrary it would simply be a question of Brussels passing its own credibility test.

Where member states can agree on a common policy - be it on the environment or anything else - then surely it makes sense to act as one and start punching at the EU's mythical weight.

Judging from the fuss President Chirac of France and chancellor Schroeder of Germany have made in the last week, global warming and the issue of how it should be tackled is one policy area where Europe stands more or less united.

To her credit, the EU's Wallstrom is doing what she can to shore up the weakened Kyoto accord. A senior EU delegation wasted little time in racing to Washington to hear the bad news from the horse's mouth. And Mrs Wallstrom, a Swede, is now engaged on a whistlestop tour of Russia, Iran, China and Japan to see how the rest of the world can ratify Kyoto without the United States. That's a good start.

But what is needed now are concrete results - the pact was signed in 1997 and yet not one single EU member state, including Britain, has ratified it in their national parliaments since. The challenge - to cut 1990 greenhouse gas emissions levels in major industrialised countries by an average 5.2% by 2012 - is ambitious but achievable.

The fact is that Kyoto is not dead in the water if 55% of the original signatory countries press ahead and ratify the pact, provided that is that they also account for 55% of the world's greenhouse emissions.

With Japan in the middle of a massive economic downturn, this then is the chance the EU has been waiting for. But to pass the test the EU cannot be seen to be hypocritical and its member states need to ratify Kyoto themselves as soon as possible.

The shuttle diplomacy being practiced by the EU's Wallstrom must yield results.

Firm commitments from other key players such as Russia need to be extracted and Brussels needs to play the honest and responsible broker. If it succeeds, spiralling apathy about what the EU is actually for might start to dissipate and Brussels would have strengthened its diplomatic hand immeasurably.

fields.headline: Express columnist quits
fields.trailText:
12.30pm: Sunday Express columnist Peter Oborne has quit, leaving the Express group with yet another hole in its top team ahead of an election, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
Apr 5: Jobson joins Express exodus
Apr 5: Express and Star to merge news teams
Apr 4: Express loses core newsmen
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
Peter Oborne, political columnist of the Sunday Express has quit, leaving the Express group with yet another hole in its top team ahead of an election.

Mr Oborne confirmed he had accepted voluntary redundancy and would take stock before making his next move.

His departure brings the number of Express staff who have applied for redundancy to 100.

But 55 of those, including Mr Oborne, have asked to leave early and will not get the tax-free pay-off that comes with the redundancy programme instigated last month by the paper's new boss Richard Desmond.

Mr Desmond is seeking to axe 145 of the paper's 440 staff as part of a radical bid to turn the loss-making papers around.

"I loved the experience and wish the paper well. I have always been treated well but I feel the time has come to move on," said Mr Oborne.

"I leave with a measure of sadness because the Express is a great newspaper. There is nothing bigger about it and I do not wish to say anything more," he added.

Mr Oborne said he was looking forward to the time off.

"I have always wanted to be a a gentleman of leisure and not have to go back to the office after lunch.

"And I would like to play cricket and go to races. I have always just snatched Saturdays and Sunday here and there to play cricket.

"It is a funny feeling, but now I will be able to just pack my stuff into the car and go."

Mr Oborne has been on the paper for five years and served under six editors on both the Daily and Sunday papers.

The paper's election coverage will be overseen by the Daily Express political editor Patrick O'Flynn and Julia Hartley-Brewer, the newly appointed political editor of the Sunday Express.

webTitle: US diplomats visit spy plane crew

fields.headline: US diplomats visit spy plane crew
fields.standfirst: Special report: China
fields.trailText: US diplomats in China said this afternoon that a planned meeting with the crew of a downed American spy plane has taken place after a lengthy delay, and another meeting is scheduled for tomorrow.
fields.body:
US diplomats in China said this afternoon that a planned meeting with the crew of a downed American spy plane has taken place after a lengthy delay, and another meeting is scheduled for tomorrow.

The meeting with the 24 crew members, who have been held by Chinese authorities since making an emergency landing on Hainan island in the South China sea on Sunday, had been scheduled to take place at 4pm local time (8am GMT) today.

But the US embassy in Beijing was forced to retract an earlier report that the meeting had begun. Diplomats who had been scheduled to meet with the air crew at 4pm were kept waiting for nearly four hours.

Brigadier General Neal Sealock, the American military attache in China, said the crew members were in good spirits and had received the toiletries, books and other supplies that earlier had been turned over to Chinese officials.

The Chinese authorities today granted this second visit to the crew following a statement of regret from US president, George Bush, for the probable death of a Chinese pilot in the incident.

Beijing is still demanding a full apology for the collision between the US navy EP-3E surveillance plane and one of the two Chinese jets that were tailing it. The Chinese pilot has been missing in the South China sea since he parachuted from his plane after the collision.

In high level talks, the United States has been seeking the release of the crew and their aircraft. In their only meeting with the crew so far - on Tuesday in Hainan's capital, Haikou - US diplomats said the Americans appeared in good health and high spirits. Today's meeting was also expected to take place in Haikou.

In Washington the deputy secretary of state, Richard Armitage, met with Chinese ambassador Yang Jiechi. In Beijing the US ambassador to China, Joseph Prueher, met twice with assistant foreign minister Zhou Wenzhong.

"We're engaged with the Chinese at the appropriate levels, and we're working very hard. We're in intensive discussions, and we're all committed to trying to solve this," Mr Prueher said today. Despite the positive development, China still blames the US plane for the collision, which occurred about 60 miles south of Hainan.

China has welcomed US expressions of regret as a first step, but the US has refused China's demand for a formal apology, suggesting that the Chinese plane is to blame for the collision.

Echoing earlier comments by US secretary of state Colin Powell, Mr Bush said yesterday: "I regret that a Chinese pilot is missing and I regret one of their airplanes is lost," Bush said. webTitle: Sky One plans Temptation Island UK

fields.headline: Sky One to shoot 18 hours of Temptation Island UK
fields.trailText:
Sky One is lining up 18 hours of the UK version of US reality series Temptation Island for this autumn, reports Jason Deans.
Apr 4: Temptation Island comes to UK
Jan 12: Sky buys Temptation Island
fields.body:
Sky One is lining up 18 hours of the UK version of controversial US reality series Temptation Island for this autumn.

The BSkyB-owned cable and satellite entertainment channel is planning to make a 12-part series to air in a 9pm-10pm slot from late September.

The show has the working title Temptation Island UK.

In addition, the broadcaster is lining up six one-hour Temptation Island Uncut shows, which are expected to include raunchier material, to go out in a later slot.

Sky One has bought the UK rights to the format from US broadcaster Fox, which is also part of the News Corporation empire.

As part of the deal, it will make the UK version and show it first, but has sold the terrestrial rights to Channel 4, which will transmit Temptation Island UK six months later.

Sky One has just finished showing the seven-part US version of Temptation Island. It averaged more than 600,000 viewers and a 7.7% share of multi-channel viewing - impressive figures for a cable, satellite and digital channel.

"Temptation Island was massively popular with Sky One viewers," said Kate Marsh, BSkyB deputy director of broadcasting.

"There is little doubt that UK contestants will be more outrageous than their American counterparts so the new series looks set to be an even bigger hit."

Temptation Island UK is also expected to feature a number of interactive elements.

webTitle: Job losses put new EU pressure on Britain

fields.headline: Job losses put new EU pressure on Britain
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Britain came under fresh pressure from the European commission to sign up to compulsory management-employee consultation yesterday following mass redundancies at branches of Marks and Spencers across Europe and other big job losses in France.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and  Michael White  in London
fields.body:
Britain came under fresh pressure from the European commission to sign up to compulsory management-employee consultation yesterday following mass redundancies at branches of Marks and Spencers across Europe and other big job losses in France.

Anna Diamantopoulou, the commissioner for employment and social affairs, said she could not "remain silent" following the loss in the space of one week of a total of 6,000 jobs at M&S and the French-based food manufacturer, Danone. She urged the speedy adoption of a legally-binding directive on workers information and consultation, which is backed by the TUC, but opposed by Tony Blair and the CBI.

"It is unworthy of Europe that employers have to learn about their redundancy through the press or only few minutes before a public announcement," the Greek commissioner protested. "We cannot remain silent in the face of such decisions and their effect on employees and their families."

Britain, Ireland, Denmark and Germany all oppose the directive, which was proposed by the commission in 1998 to harmonise rules for consultation procedures between management and employers. But under EU rules the matter has to be decided by qualified majority voting (QMV) and if there is a change of position by Germany it could go through in June, shortly after Britain's expected general election.

If the directive was already in force it would have prevented cases like those of General Motors' Luton plant, where the media were first with news of 2,000 job losses, or Corus in South Wales in February, where management secrecy enraged British ministers. The CBI is vehemently opposed to the directive, which it says would make British business less competitive. The directive would apply to any firm with more than 50 employees.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, has rejected "flawed" EU proposals as not appropriate for Britain on the grounds that corporate structures are different in the UK from on the continent.

fields.headline: FT memo
fields.standfirst: Email sent to staff by FT Group chief executive Stephen Hill on April 5
fields.trailText: Financial Times Group Announcement 5th April 2001
fields.body:
Financial Times Group Announcement 5th April 2001

Dear colleagues,

FT.com: Next Steps to Profitability - an update

Over the last year, we have made a lot of progress transforming FT.com into the essential online tool for the international business executive. FT.com now attracts some 2 million unique monthly users - up over 50% on this time last year. But we don't just want to be the biggest online international business portal; we want to be one of the most profitable, too. We will break even by the end of next year and generate significant returns thereafter. This path to profitability involves us taking three steps of broadly equal significance:

Moving from start up to operational mode.
Last year, we had some hefty one-off start up costs - primarily in marketing FT.com in the UK and US and building our technology infrastructure. The marketing campaigns enabled us to make the big breakthrough in traffic growth that we recorded. Our focus is now to ensure we retain these customers and to sell them premium services and other FT Group products. This means we can focus our marketing efforts more tightly and will spend less. And, with the technology we now have in place, we can scale up our online operations - and develop new services - at little incremental cost. So, in this and future years, our marketing and technology costs will be much lower.

Integrating our operations.
Since August last year we have been carefully integrating our internet editorial and advertisement sales operations with those of the newspaper. And we have seen how we have become more efficient by doing so. The current economic climate has highlighted the need to continue to drive this process forward. Today we are announcing the next stage, integrating and restructuring our technology, marketing, product management and other operations. Unfortunately, as a result, we expect to lose around 40 positions across the FT Internet businesses. We have tried very hard to keep this number to a minimum. Over the next month we will be consulting as to how this can be best achieved. Of course we will also be doing all we can to help those of our colleagues affected by these changes to find new roles within Pearson or outside the company.

Growing revenues.
Last year, FT.com revenues increased threefold to £18 million and we are on track to achieve very strong revenue growth again this year. Although the economic climate is difficult, our online advertising revenues continue to increase. At the same time, we are generating new sources of revenues from licensing FT.com content and developing a range of new premium and subscription services (such as FT Mobile, Ask FT and FT Careerpoint). Next year, as the full benefit of these premium services start to kick in, we expect only around half our online revenues to be advertising driven.

Some four years ago we launched the most significant investment that the FT newspaper had ever had, to grow our international circulation. Today, we are seeing the return on that investment, not just in record copy sales and profitability but also in the enhanced reputation of the FT throughout the international business world. Likewise, we are confident that the investment we are making today in the digital expansion of the FT will bring similar rewards.

Michael Murphy and Olivier Fleurot will be presenting the FT newspaper/FT.com strategy to everyone at OSB on April 10th, but if you have any further questions or comments in the meantime, please contact myself or Michael Murphy.

Stephen Hill
Chief Executive
FT Group

fields.headline: Arsenal ruling could hit club profits
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: A high court judge has ruled against Arsenal in a trademark infringement case, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The future of football club merchandising has been thrown into doubt after a high court judge ruled against premiership side Arsenal in a trademark infringement case.

Arsenal failed to convince Mr Justice Laddie that a trader selling scarves and shirts bearing the club's names and logos constituted an infringement of the Arsenal trademark.

But the battle between the north London club and street trader Matthew Reed will go to extra time in the European court of justice after the judge said UK law was too "unsettled" to decide the issue.

The judge also threw out the club's allegation that Mr Reed was passing off his products as genuine Arsenal merchandise.

But Arsenal was given a last-minute reprieve when the judge queried Mr Reed's argument that the Arsenal logos were "badges of allegiance" and not an infringement of trademarks.

Mr Justice Laddie said the issue would have to be decided by the European court of justice because of the "current unsettled state of the law."

A further hearing on May 1 will decide whether the case goes to the court of appeal or straight to Europe.

If the case finally goes against Arsenal, it could cut premiership clubs off from a vital revenue stream which is becoming a bigger money-spinner than gate receipts.

The likes of Manchester United and Liverpool are hoping to capitalise on the size of their global following by selling replica kits to millions of fans.

fields.headline: Bigger than JR
fields.trailText:
1.12pm:It is set to go down in history as the most-watched 'whodunnit' ever - even bigger than the Who Shot JR? cliffhanger 21 years ago, write Lisa O'Carroll and Jason Deans.
From JR to Brookside: soap highs
fields.body:
It is set to go down in history as the most-watched "whodunnit" ever - even bigger than Who Shot JR? cliffhanger 21 years ago.

The question of who confronted Phil Mitchell on the steps of his house and left him for dead has been keeping EastEnders fans, bookies and the soap's cast on tenterhooks for five weeks.

Was it that multi-personality Mark Fowler, who after years of being nice was driven to attempted murder; was it dirty Dan; wimpish Ian; suave night-club owner Steve; or spurned girlfriend Lisa Shaw.

It wasn't quite the soap cliffhanger of summer 1980 when the whole of America, Britain and Ireland were left hanging in suspense.

For eight months viewers wondered whether it was half-mad quivering lip Sue-Ellen or her sister and mistress Kirsten who had shot evil oil tycoon JR.

But judging by the early ratings for last night's episode revealing Lisa as the culprit, it came pretty damn close.

By the time video-recording and Sunday night's omnibus edition are taken into account the ratings for Who Shot Phil? are expected to top 24m.

When Dallas returned in November 1980 to reveal Kirsten as JR's assailant show, 21m viewers watched. These, were however, pre-video days.

It means last night's episode will probably be the highest-watched programme of the year and one of EastEnders' all-time favourite episodes - with millions more viewers than other cliffhanger episodes such as Tiffany's death - 13.5m; Bianca giving birth in the Vic - 22.1m; or Grant Mitchell's disappearance into the Thames - 15m.

Indeed it looks like becoming the most watched instalment of the soap since the last time Phil was in a hospital intensive care unit bed more than six years ago.

Back in October 1994, 25.3m turned in to see Phil ending up in surgery when little brother Grant found out about his affair with wife Sharon.

As soap history goes Who Shot Phil? still can't compare with the nation's all-time favourite soap moment - Christmas 1986 when 30.1m tuned in to see Dirty Den serve divorce papers on Angie.

fields.headline: Japanese prime minister resigns
fields.standfirst: Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: Japan's prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, told his cabinet today that he would stand down after just a year in office, signalling the end of one of the country's most unpopular governments since the end of the second world war.
fields.body:
Japan's prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, told his cabinet today that he would stand down after just a year in office, signalling the end of one of the country's most unpopular governments since the end of the second world war.

Mr Mori, under fire for months over verbal gaffes and mistakes, had been long expected to quit. The ruling Liberal Democrat party (LDP) is planning to hold a leadership election on April 24 to choose a successor.

However, his resignation is unlikely to solve Japan's mounting problems. A long-awaited recovery from the lengthy economic downturn has stalled and banks are still crippled by a decade-long debt crisis.

"I made up my mind to resign because I think it is necessary to tackle mounting issues both at home and abroad under a new administration," Mr Mori was quoted as saying by the chief cabinet secretary, Yasuo Fukuda.

There is general agreement in Japan that Mr Mori leaves the country hungering for leadership, and that his mistakes have severely damaged the LDP, which has ruled nearly uninterrupted since 1955.

"Japan needs economic reforms no matter who the prime minister is," said Masumi Ishikawa, a political expert at Obirin university in Tokyo. "The year 2001 will be the year that made it clear that the LDP is finally falling apart."

The cabinet today announced an emergency economic package that set a two-year deadline for banks to dispose of their riskiest bad loans. One estimate has the level of debt at £73.5bn.

The apparent front runner to replace Mr Mori is the former prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, who served from 1996 to 1998. Mr Hashimoto heads the LDP's largest faction and reportedly has the support of two other factions.

Mr Hashimoto said today that he was flattered by the attention, but stopped short of declaring his candidacy.
