webTitle: Carlton chief challenges press on race

fields.headline: Carlton chief challenges press on race
fields.standfirst: Race in the Media Award winners
fields.trailText:
1.30pm: The newspaper industry has been urged to follow TV's lead and reflect cultural diversity, reports Ashley Davies.
Special report: Race in the Media Awards
Full list of winners
fields.body:
Carlton chief executive Clive Jones has called on the newspaper industry to do more to reflect cultural diversity.

Speaking at today's Race in the Media Awards, Mr Jones, who heads the TV industry's Cultural Diversity Network, said newspaper publishers should follow the lead set by broadcasters.

Mr Jones said the Cultural Diversity Network's manifesto, which pledges to increase diverse employment, was an initiative other media should follow.

"We have made a start. We have stopped talking about equality and started to do something about it," he said.

"I hope now that our colleagues in the rest of the media, particularly perhaps my former colleagues in the printed press, will want to follow our lead."

Mr Jones's comments came after Channel 4 was named best broadcaster at the awards for its "integrated and consistent portrayal of diversity".

Guardian journalist Vikram Dodd won the national news award.

All terrestrial broadcasters have signed up to CDN, which works on cross-industry initiatives and plans to share expertise, resources and models of good practice.

fields.headline: Q&A: nursing regulation
fields.trailText:
What is the UKCC?
The United Kingdom Central Council for Nursing, Midwifery and Health Visiting is the body that oversees nurses' behaviour and, in conjunction with the four national education boards, is responsible for post-registration training. It was set up as one of the last acts of the previous Labour government in 1979.
fields.body:
What is the UKCC?
The United Kingdom Central Council for Nursing, Midwifery and Health Visiting is the body that oversees nurses' behaviour and, in conjunction with the four national education boards, is responsible for post-registration training. It was set up as one of the last acts of the previous Labour government in 1979.

Why is it being replaced?
The need to streamline council procedures and speed up the disciplinary process has been recognised for some time. But there is no doubt the process has been given new urgency - and possibly a new direction - by the numerous scandals surrounding rogue doctors and the perceived failure of their professional body to act decisively.

What are the main changes?
The new council will consist of 23 members compared with the previous 60. Eleven of them will be lay members. There will be a broader definition of unfitness to practise, and a wider range of sanctions, meaning nurses who are incompetent or have health problems can be dealt with more appropriately. And the process from first accusation to final decision will be much faster.

Who will the new body cover?
All registered nurses, midwives and health visitors, working in the NHS and private and voluntary sectors - but not student nurses. At the moment there are 640,000 practitioners on the UKCC register.

Where will the lay representatives come from?
Lay members will be expected to represent the views of patients, carers, the public and, according to the national adverts for the shadow council, be good communicators and "able to see the big picture". But there is no further indication of what their background should be. It would also seem that the role, which is likely to involve 30-50 days a year at a daily attendance fee of £250, has struck a chord. More than 1,000 people have already inquired about the seven shadow council posts up for grabs.

Will the public be better protected?
It is hoped. The primary purpose of the new Nursing and Midwifery Council will be to protect the public. Patient and public representatives will be closely involved in both policy making and the disciplinary process. And it should be easier for members of the public to report a nurse to the council for unacceptable behaviour.

Do the public report nurses to the UKCC at the moment?
Very rarely. Anyone is entitled to complain to the UKCC about the behaviour of a nurse, but in fact the majority of cases are brought by other nurses. Evidence suggests that in disciplinary cases colleagues tend to be more severe than lay representatives in their judgments on erring nurses.

Will the new NMC root out every suspect nurse?
Probably not. It will still have to rely on someone complaining about a nurse's behaviour in the first place. But its powers will be considerably widened, allowing it to suspend a nurse's registration at any time or to impose conditions on practice. It will also be able to act not only over alleged misconduct but also ill health, "deficient performance" or criminal convictions and cautions. In addition it can apply a civil standard of proof in some circumstances rather than the criminal standard demanded at present.

Is this the end for self-regulation?
That seems unlikely. The government is happy to threaten the professions - especially the doctors -with external regulation if they don't get their house in order. But it would be costly and carry the danger that ministers would get the blame every time a doctor or nurse stepped out of line. However, it is clear that professionals will no longer have exclusive responsibility for regulating themselves - they will have to work more closely with both politicians and the public.

Which groups in the health service are regulated?
Doctors, dentists and the professions allied to medicine all have their own regulatory bodies. But there is no regulation of care assistants, ambulance staff (although paramedics, who account for around a third of ambulance staff, are regulated), domestics, ancillary workers - or managers. Social workers have no regulatory body either, although plans are afoot to set up one.

webTitle: Nurses to be scrutinised by new regulatory body

fields.headline: Nurses to be scrutinised by new regulatory body
fields.trailText: The government's plans to reform the regulation of nursing, published this week, are part of a wider strategy, precipitated by a catalogue of recent medical scandals, to clip the wings of the professionals and give the public and politicians a bigger say in how they are governed.
fields.body:
The government's long-awaited plans to reform the regulation of nursing, published this week, are likely to have reverberations well beyond the profession.

The move is part of a wider strategy, precipitated by a catalogue of recent medical scandals, to clip the wings of the professionals and give the public and politicians a bigger say in how they are governed.

The process began this week with the nurses and the professions allied to medicine.

Under the new plans - which follow a three-month consultation period with the profession - a new regulatory body, the Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC), will take over from the UK Central Council for Nursing, Midwifey and Health Visiting (UKCC), which has governed nurses for the past 22 years.

The new council, which will operate from next year, will be smaller than its predecessor and - more controversially - will have nearly as many lay members as professionals.

It will also have the power to impose a wider range of sanctions on erring nurses and to ensure decisions are reached more quickly and effectively.

Above all, the new proposals will make nurses more accountable to patients and the wider public. For the first time the NMC's primary function to protect the public will be enshrined in legislation. There will be a range of measures to encourage the public as well as the profession to make this a reality.

Claire Perry, who is heading the change management group overseeing the transition process, believes the changes should help employers by making training more relevant to service needs.

In addition, extra powers to check on a new recruit's health and character as well as professional aptitude should help root out rogue nurses.

"I'm not sure you will ever be able to stop a Shipman or Beverly Allitt, who were utterly determined to kill patients, but this should make a big difference with the more common examples of misconduct," she said.

The new plans will also seek to close one of the most worrying loopholes in the monitoring process - the failure of many health trusts to check on nurses' backgrounds before taking them on in the first place.

Employers are supposed to check with the UKCC to ensure a new nurse recruit is bona fide, but many simply rely on the nurse's pin card, which is little more than a receipt.

"The pin card is not intended to be used as a proof of registration," explained a spokesman for the new body. "The only 100% effective way of checking on someone's credentials is to use our confirmation service."

The service is free, easily accessible and should only take a few minutes, but unfortunately many employers - especially in the NHS - skip this process and the consequences can be disastrous.

"The spectrum of risk is everything from someone claiming qualifications they don't have to the nightmare scenario of a convicted paedophile slipping through the net and being allowed to work on a children's ward," said the spokesman.

The other related concern for many employers is the position of the estimated 100,000 nursing and health care assistants working in the NHS and private nursing homes.

This group is currently unregulated despite the fact that the public are arguably more open to abuse from them than from registered nurses since they provide much of the hands-on care. This means a nurse who is struck off the register could, theoretically, return to work as a care assistant without facing any scrutiny.

Ministers are considering setting up a care assistants' regulatory body - possibly under the auspices of the NMC. Unison, which represents most care assistants, strongly supports the idea, although it would favour a "one stop" regulatory body covering doctors, nurses, therapists and assistants - something favoured by most health care assistants as well.

Some employers are less certain, fearing it could simply add to bureaucracy. And there are concerns it could worsen the recruitment crisis if care assistants are put off working in health care altogether because of the new regulations.

Unison national officer Paul Chapman is undeterred: "At the end of the day we're talking about people giving hands-on care to vulnerable people.

"They have as much opportunity to physically, sexually or financially abuse patients as anyone. If some are put off because they feel their work will be more regulated then perhaps that won't be a bad thing."

webTitle: From JR to Eastenders: Soap highs

fields.headline: From JR to Eastenders: Soap highs
fields.trailText: Soap Highs
fields.body:
Soap Highs

Dallas - Who shot JR?, 1980

It was one of the most talked about mysteries in TV history and 21.6m viewers tuned in to discover it was ex-lover Kristin who pulled the trigger.

Dallas - Return of Bobby Ewing, 1986

After Bobby Ewing was killed off, ratings fell. At the end of the next series Bobby returned, his death and the ensuing 26 episodes explained as the dream of his wife, Pam.

EastEnders - Divorce papers, 1986

The highest rating for a soap episode was the 31m who saw Angie leave errant husband Den on Christmas Day.

EastEnders - The Murder of Dirty Den, 1989

Some 20m viewers watched as "Dirty" Den Watts was gunned down following a clandestine canal-side meeting with Michelle Fowler.

Brookside - Bad Barry Grant, 1991

Long-suffering Terry Sullivan lost wife Sue and baby Daniel when best pal Barry Grant pushed them from the top of scaffolding.

Coronation Street: Deirdre Rachid, 1998

The imprisonment of Deirdre Rachid for credit card fraud drew 19m viewers. As a Free the Weatherfield One campaign gathered strength, reality and fantasy blurred and Tony Blair called for her release.

Brookside: The Jordache saga, 1995

Abusive husband Trevor Jordache was murdered and buried under the patio by wife Mandy and daughter Beth. Beth, who featured in the first soap opera lesbian kiss, died in prison. Trevor was exhumed and 9m watched the subsequent murder trial.

webTitle: It was Lisa who shot EastEnder Phil

fields.headline: It was Lisa who shot EastEnder Phil
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Five weeks of mounting obsession ended last night as millions tuned in to EastEnders to find that Lisa Shaw was the one who shot Phil Mitchell. By Jeevan Vasagar and Laura Milne.
fields.body:
Five weeks of mounting obsession ended last night in a collective exhalation of breath as millions tuned in to EastEnders to find that Lisa Shaw was the one who shot Phil Mitchell.

Fans saw Phil, played by Steve McFadden, violently confront his embittered former partner, played by his real life girlfriend Lucy Benjamin. The two were sworn to silence by the producers and lied to fellow actors to stop the story line leaking out.

For even more security, all five of the soap's characters suspected of the shooting were called in individually to see executive producer John Yorke. Phil and Lisa were together told she would be pulling the trigger, but had to deny that this was the scenario to the rest of the cast.

Alternative scenes were filmed, in which Phil accused each of the five suspects, so even the crew were in the dark. The producers said they had considered switching the plot if the secret got out.

BBC executives have been delighted by the way the storyline has captured the nation's imagination. They plan to introduce a fourth weekly episode of the soap soon.

Last night's 40-minute special was screened before the Uefa Cup semi-final between Barcelona and Liverpool, a move calculated to obliterate ITV in the ratings war. The kick-off had been delayed 15 minutes so fans did not miss any of the action.

Bookmakers William Hill took bets amounting to six figures on the biggest TV whodunnit since JR Ewing was shot in Dallas. The final odds had Lisa Shaw as odds-on favourite at 8/11; Dan Sullivan, played by Craig Fairbrass, second favourite at 3/1.

The bookmakers insist they will only pay out on conviction, so those who bet on Lisa will have to wait and see whether justice catches up with her.

Before last night's broadcast, the two protagonists spoke of their relief that the suspense was over. Both were filming until 10pm last night, but they hoped to watch the programme during a break. Steve McFadden said he expected to continue with the soap for the "foreseeable future".

"I think we're all going to find it hard to top this one. I think it has got to be the best day of my career. EastEnders, when it's at its best, I can't think of anything that can better it."

Lucy Benjamin said she had been pleased to be given the shooting role, but had feared being written out of the soap if her character went to prison. Lisa is expected to reveal to Phil in future episodes that she is pregnant with his child. "I am so relieved. It's been hard keeping a secret. I was delighted for it to be me - she had every reason to do it.

"I've lied to my colleagues. They are going to kill me now they know. I think they all had their suspicions, but no one came up to me and said 'we know it's you'.

"Steve was told at the same time. That night we went home and screamed a bit."

webTitle: Comment: Madeleine Bunting on foot and mouth

fields.headline: Pig in the middle
fields.standfirst: Since her column last Saturday about the destruction of hundreds of thousands of animals Madeleine Bunting has been inundated with responses. Here is her reply
fields.trailText: Since her column last Saturday about the destruction of hundreds of thousands of animals Madeleine Bunting has been inundated with responses. Here is her reply.
fields.body:
Since I wrote my column last Saturday, angry at the destruction of hundreds of thousands of animals, I have been inundated with responses.

My inbox is brimming with dozens of readers' emails, the answerphone is full of messages and the letters are piling up.

I have never had a response like it to any column. About 80% of the emails were hugely grateful and congratulatory, though all of the phone messages were immensely critical, accusing me of shameless hypocrisy. How can a meat-eater quibble about how and why a cow is killed, they demanded to know.

What has characterised all of the responses is intense emotion. I am not sure that the mainstream media has managed to capture the degree of distress across the country over how the government is handling this disease.

Reader after reader spoke of their anger at this orgy of killing and of a terrible sense of frustration and impotence; again and again they asked me, what can we do, is there a petition, a demonstration or an opinion poll that we can sign up to show our anger?

I did not expect myself to become an information point for an incipient protest campaign - after all, I feel as helpless as my readers. Writing a column does not achieve anything: thousands of animals go on being killed every day. Much of the television reporting seems as heartless as ever.

So millions of people are probably dreaming horrific nightmares of this slaughter and are profoundly disturbed by it (I have received emails to this effect from all over the world). Yet they remain unconvinced by the vegetarian animal rights activists and find themselves uncomfortably caught in the middle in a sharply polarised debate - somewhere between the animal rights lobby and the utilitarians.

It seems a shame to me that, for us pigs in the middle, no help is on offer from the animal rights brigade. Why have they poured a stream of abuse in my direction, when I was lamenting this terrible destruction of animals?

Their charges of hypocrisy seem to me to indicate a kind of fundamentalist puritanism. webTitle: Lib Dems score triple byelection win

fields.headline: Lib Dems score triple byelection win
fields.standfirst: Special report: Devolved politics
fields.trailText: Liberal Democrats scored a hat-trick of gains in the latest council byelections, the first since Tony Blair postponed May's main contests - and effectively the general election.
fields.body:
Liberal Democrats scored a hat-trick of gains in the latest council byelections, the first since Tony Blair postponed May's main contests - and effectively the general election.

The latest results say little about the standing of the two major parties but much about morale with Labour throwing in the towel in half the polls including one seat at Cirencester Watermoor, Cotswold District, Gloucestershire which the party had previously held. Surprisingly, it also failed to fight at Hawkinge and Paddlesworth, Shepway District, Kent which is in the Folkestone and Hythe constituency of the Tory former home secretary Michael Howard.

He comfortably held off a Liberal Democrat challenge in the 1997 general election mainly because Labour strongly boosted its vote in third place.

But the latest result - a Liberal Democrat win from nowhere - following two gains from Labour in Shepway in January suggests Mr Howard could be at risk this time from tactical voting.

Liberal Democrats, as well as taking the Cotswold seat, also stormed Labour's Atherton stronghold in Wigan Borough, Greater Manchester.

There was better news for a Labour at Regent's Park, Westminster - the only comparable ward where the main fight was between it and Tories - with a 5% swing since 1998.

fields.headline: The indiscretion of Sophie Wessex
fields.standfirst:
Sophie Rhys-Jones has ignited a mighty press conflagration with her ill-judged remarks to a 'sheikh' who turned out to be a News of the World reporter. Derek Brown explains

Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Sophie Rhys-Jones has ignited a mighty press conflagration with her ill-judged remarks to a 'sheikh' who turned out to be a News of the World reporter. Derek Brown explains.
fields.body:
How did the story start?
An employee of the PR outfit she works for was unhappy about the way the company, RJH, was being run. Kishan Athulathmudali was allegedly unhappy that the firm was playing on its royal connections to drum up business. He approached PR guru Max Clifford, who peddled the story around the tabloids. It was taken up by the News of the World, which set up a bogus appointment for Sophie Wessex and her partner Murray Harkin to meet a "sheikh" - in fact, the paper's star reporter Mazher Mahmood.

What did she say?
All sorts of chitchat - none of it exactly explosively revealing, but wildly inappropriate from royal lips. She accused Tony Blair of being far too presidential; remarked that Cherie Blair was "horrid, horrid horrid" and suggested that William Hague looked "deformed".

And all this appeared in the News of the World?
No. A panic-stricken Buckingham Palace persuaded the News of the World to ditch the secretly tape recorded conversation, in exchange for an exclusive interview with Sophie, in which she blurted out further and more personal indiscretions about her marriage. The paper ceded editorial control to the palace, allowing it to vet the copy and headline in advance of publication. Astonishingly, it gave the go-ahead to publication.

Meanwhile, the Mail on Sunday had been investigating the the secret tapes, and got hold of some juicy bits. The result, last Sunday, was a gigantic royal double whammy, with the Mail's main headline "Queen's outrage at Sophie insults" accompanied by the News of the World's "Sophie: my Edward is not gay."

Was the Palace furious?
Not half. The Queen herself is said to be "supremely detached", but her courtiers are livid with the Countess. One minion has described her conduct as "naive at best". There is also great disquiet that both the Wessexes have been using their name to make cash: Sophie by attracting new clients to RJH, and Edward by spending time on official royal tours to secure the backing of foreign royals for programmes to be made by his loss-making TV company, Ardent.

Is it all likely to fade away?
Not a hope. The News of the World is said to have three or four hours of tapes in its possession, and other tabloids are hard at work on the story. Speculation is focused on a further set of indiscretions, this time by Sophie's business partner Murray Harkin.

Meanwhile, the News of the World's daily stablemate, the Sun, has been gleefully hinting all week that there is much, much more to come. Indeed, the story has been manna to the Sun in its new royal-bashing republican persona.

What does the Sun say today?
It praises trade secretary Stephen Byers for taking his own swipe at Sophie, and notes that he was not reprimanded for doing so by the prime minister. The comment column goes on to say of the Wessexes' latest royal tour: "The pictures of these two 'representing' us in Qatar were OFFENSIVE. They are not worthy to represent anything - let alone the British people. What an utter joke that these chancers were sent abroad as British ambassadors. We're sure Tony Blair won't let this happen again."

webTitle: Wall Street rally is short lived

fields.headline: Wall Street rally is short lived
fields.trailText: Following Wall Street's most successful day in recent months yesterday, stocks are trading lower again today as the US government unveiled higher than expected unemployment figures.
fields.body:
Following Wall Street's most successful day in recent months yesterday, stocks are trading lower again today as the US government unveiled higher than expected unemployment figures.

The short-lived rally in New York did not make much of an impression on other markets, and European stock markets today failed to recreate the excitement that sent the hi-tech Nasdaq to the third largest percentage gain in its history yesterday.

Uncertainty about yesterday's strong advance on Wall Street held investors back on several European exchanges. Although French and Swiss shares were trading somewhat higher at midday, stock exchanges in Britain and Germany slipped lower.

Good news from computer maker Dell sent the Dow Jones industrial average up yesterday by 4.2% and the Nasdaq composite index up by 8.9%. The rally on Wall Street reinvigorated New York investors, who were encouraged by positive corporate earnings news - something they had not seen much of recently.

"We were quite surprised it didn't have the impact we thought it would have," said Karl Boyce, an investment manager at London brokerage Williams de Broe. "It's the tech stocks leading the market down today."

However, the enthusiasm did not extend far overseas and did not even last long in New York. The US unemployment rate, at 4.3%, is the highest since the middle of 1999. The March figures showed that businesses had cut 86,000 jobs, the largest payroll reduction since the end of 1991.

One company that failed to gain from yesterday's rally was Cambridge-based software firm Autonomy, which saw half its market value wiped out today after it warned of lower sales. The company's chief executive, Mike Lynch, blamed the situation on the weakened US economy.

fields.headline: Bang out of order
fields.trailText: Who Shot Phil Mitchell? | EastEnders
fields.body:
"Miss Otis regrets she's unable to lunch today."

- Cole Porter

Dave Courtney was a gangster. He is a bald bloke with a lively line in jackets and patter. Unlike the other punters invited to back their fancy in Who Shot Phil Mitchell? (BBC1, Saturday), Dave had been there. He said, "There is nothing quite as scary as your missus with the 'ump." Wrenching your attention away from the thought of Mrs Courtney with a noise like velcro, you can only say, "Well done, my son!"

As almost everyone in EastEnders could hide at will behind a spiral staircase, almost anyone could have shot Phil. However, the main contenders were Mark, an honest barrow boy (no, really), Dan, who gets stuck in doorways, Ian, a busted flush, Steve, who is smoother than snakeskin shorts, and Lisa, a spurned woman. But as Dave suspected, it was Lisa, who took a gun and shot her lover down.

She is pregnant, and you consider with horror the frightful future fruit of Lisa's womb and Phil's loins. It will not, you suspect, be the nicer kind of child.

EastEnders (BBC 1) played this one so close to their chest, their nipples were not in the know. Various versions were filmed on closed sets with skeleton crews and strict security. False scripts were written which disturbed the tabloids' radar like metallic chaff. Editors' better nature was appealed to (good luck on that one). They managed to keep the secret while milking the story vigorously for its publicity; even the kick-off for the Barcelona v Liverpool football match was delayed to accommodate the programme.

The thunderous summons on every suspect's door at the end of Tuesday's EastEnders implied they were all due for a visit but, in fact, Phil went, like a missus-seeking missile, straight for Lisa. It was a strained encounter. "Woz ma'er, Lise? You don't seem pleased to see me." Lisa quickly offered him a cup of tea, which he declined like a vicar who has had an ample sufficiency of Lapsang Souchong. He was, for Phil, disturbingly affable. You wouldn't like him when he is affable. He had, he indicated, come to finger the guilty party as the Bill were baffled. "I have one teeny weeny advantage over them ... I know who did it ... I saw 'em."

"Oo?" asked Lisa.

"You!" said Phil.

This was an extraordinarily direct exchange for Albert Square, where a question is always answered with another question, presumably on the grounds that any information might incriminate the speaker. As in "Knock! Knock!" "Who's there?" "Who's arsking?" "Who's arsking who's arsking?"

EastEnders has a speciality it keeps for special occasions. In a double-header episode, two faces fill the screen as if they existed in their own soap bubble. It often has unusual intensity and intimacy. Phil (Steve McFadden) and Lisa (Lucy Benjamin) conducted something between a duet and a duel until two other suspects, Mark and Ian, arrived. Ian is the EastEnder most likely to burst into tears. He could give Lord Lundy lessons. Ian had seen Phil dying on the pavement. "I found him. I saw the blood. He was hardly breathing. I waited a minute and then I left. I panicked. You'd have done the same. Anyone would."

Dave, the ex-gangster, had a prescient comment on Ian. "He's pathetic ... I'd be embarrassed to live next door to him."

That left only two of the original suspects, Steve and Dan. Though they were innocent of the shooting, they have been blocking Phil's sunlight. Particularly, perhaps, Dan. When the room suddenly goes dark, you know it's Dan trying to get through the door again. Phil clutched the slight figure of his nephew, Jamie, and said, "From now on, we don't need anyone. We're gonna get rid of Steve. We're gonna get rid of Dan. From now on it's just you and me."

The Mitchells mutate in a very strange way. Phil used to be a nice young man, who tidied up after Grant like a street cleaner when the Household Cavalry have passed, but, the moment Grant went, Phil mutated into his brother. Jamie, a pretty lad clearly intended by nature to play Peaseblossom, has recently taken to scowling horribly in the hope of unnerving someone. I would value Dave's professional opinion of his chances as a hard man.

Phil used to be a nice young man, who tidied up after Grant like a street cleaner when the Household Cavalry have passed, but, the moment Grant went, Phil mutated into his brother. Jamie, a pretty lad clearly intended by nature to play Peaseblossom, has recently taken to scowling horribly in the hope of unnerving someone. I would value Dave's professional opinion of his chances as a hard man.

webTitle: Dynasty diva calls Oscar stars frocky-horrors

fields.headline: Collins criticises Oscar stars
fields.trailText: Joan Collins lived up to her most famous film role in The Bitch when she launched a catty attack on her fellow showbiz stars.
fields.body:
Joan Collins lived up to her most famous film role in The Bitch when she launched a catty attack on her fellow showbiz stars.

The actor said former Baywatch star Pamela Anderson appeared at the Oscars ceremony dressed like "a hooker on holiday".

Miss Collins said that what she called the "annual Oscar Frocky-Horror show" generally offered a taste of old time Hollywood glamour but, writing in The Spectator magazine, she said there were exceptions.

"The singer Bjork was persuaded to dress as a dying swan, complete with lolling head and beak, in a creation that wouldn't have looked out of place perched on a Skegness landlady's spare loo roll," the actor said.

"Juliette Binoche was being strangled by a surfeit of faux-pearl necklaces, cascading down her chest to her thighs, and hideous Toulouse-Lautrec laced-up boots.

She said: "The full horror was... Pamela Anderson. Revealing all the taste and refinement of a hooker on holiday, she chose to buck the system in denim hot pants and teeny weeny white shirt which struggled bravely to contain her..."

"Accompanied on one side by her camp, pink-shirted 'stylist' and on the other by our own dear Elizabeth Hurley, she brought trailer-trash fashion right into the 21st century," she added.
Press Association

webTitle: Taking action to fight racial harassment

fields.headline: Taking action to fight racial harassment
fields.standfirst: The Stephen Lawrence report rightly pointed out that housing providers can do more to tackle racial harassment. An independent race and housing inquiry is working to get the process started, writes Leroy Philips
fields.trailText: The Stephen Lawrence report rightly pointed out that housing providers can do more to tackle racial harassment. An independent race and housing inquiry is working to get the process started, writes Leroy Philips.
fields.body:
Last weekend, Shiblu Rahman was murdered yards from his council flat after returning late from work. Media reporting of this tragic incident in Bow has focused on the response by the police and emergency services.

Following the Stephen Lawrence inquiry, police actions have especially fallen under the spotlight. But what about housing?

A picture is emerging of an estate where Bangladeshi families are victims of severe harassment from young people. One local estate agent said the shops below Mr Rahman's flat are no-go areas for Asians.

"We were just waiting for something like this to happen," he said.

Some of Mr Rahman's neighbours have argued that things are so bad that they are too scared to go outside - and they are desperate to leave the area.

While no evidence has yet emerged of recent racists attacks before the murder, it seems that local Asian families have been the victims of persistent racist abuse.Their experiences are all too common for members of ethnic communities.

This makes the call by the independent race and housing inquiry for a revolution in race equality in housing all the more urgent.

The Stephen Lawrence inquiry rightly pointed out that housing providers can do more to tackle racial harassment.

"All too often housing departments were seen to be slow and bureaucratic in their response to racist behaviour," the report says.

It calls for housing organisations to work together with other local agencies and tenants to address racism and promote cultural diversity in their area.

It recommends setting up reporting centres to enable residents to report racist incidents, and that ethnic groups should be engaged in improving services for everyone.

The National Housing Federation has stressed that all social housing organisations have a duty to ask if they could improve performance to ensure that they are more sensitive to the needs of victims of racial harassment and their families.

The report emphasises the importance of adopting a victim-centred approach and proper monitoring to ensure information on the perpetrators of racist incidents is collected.

Many others have echoed these recommendations. But, ultimately, the problem is a lack of confidence. The under-reporting of racist crimes demonstrates this. The actual level of harassment is often far worse than that recorded by housing providers and other agencies.

The death of Mr Rahman shows this. Only after the murder and arising media attention is the true picture of the racial harassment on the estate coming to light.

Evidence is given of families scared to go out, employees giving up work because of the abuse and shopkeepers being harassed.

But if housing associations and other social housing providers really do become a beacon for race equality, we could begin to tackle these problems effectively.

We need to translate the goodwill of the 1980s and 90s into ongoing and accountable action. While nearly all housing associations have equality policies, the time has come to turn these into outcomes.

The race and housing inquiry was formed to begin this process. Its aim is to find what works in the real world, and to base its findings on the expertise and experience of everyone in the sector.

We are particularly keen to hear from tenants and staff groups. It is vital that we involve the expertise of tenants, get a true taste of their experience and find out how problems can be tackled.

We also need to hear from staff and discover how we can encourage and assist them in supporting our minority ethnic residents, especially those tenants who face harassment.

The race and housing inquiry's focus on race equality in housing associations is only one part of the picture. But it is an important one. If we are to seriously alter the experience of tenants on estates similar to Mr Rahman's, we have to get this right and take action now. That is why the race and housing inquiry is so vital.

 Leroy Philips is chairman of the race and housing inquiry.

fields.headline: Election 2001 up for grabs
fields.trailText: An internet entrepreneur, who registered election2001.co.uk as a domain name, is hoping to spark a bidding war to raise funds for farmers crippled by foot and mouth.
fields.body:
An internet entrepreneur, who registered election2001.co.uk as a domain name, is hoping to spark a bidding war to raise funds for farmers crippled by foot and mouth.

Michael Smith, a web designer from Littlehampton, Sussex, registered www.election2001.co.uk in November 1999.

He said: "I decided to register it on a whim but now I've had a lot of interest since the turn of the year."

Despite domain values falling in the past year, Mr Smith is optimistic election2001 will sell for a good price, with some of the proceeds going to farmers.

Mr Smith, 33, said: "One domain trading company offered me £1,000 but I think they were trying to get it on the cheap - it's worth more than that.

"I contacted all the political parties but they weren't interested - most of the interest has been from the media. Although the address has a short lifespan, it is a good site to have as it's a memorable."

Useful link
Election2001.co.uk

fields.headline: Tonkinson sacked from C4's Big Breakfast
fields.trailText:
12pm: Channel 4's Big Breakfast presenter Paul Tonkinson has been sacked after just two months, reports Claire Cozens.

Mar 30: New boss brought in for Big Breakfast
fields.body:
Big Breakfast presenter Paul Tonkinson has been sacked from the show after just two months, Channel 4 announced today.

Tonkinson, who joined the Big Breakfast in February, was told of the decision after yesterday's programme and was asked not to turn up for work today.

This morning's show was presented by the regular team including Amanda Byram, Donna Air and stand-in Mike McLean.

Makers of the show are now on the look-out for a new presenter to front the early morning programme, which has seen ratings plummet since Johnny Vaughan and Denise Van Outen left in January.

Producers have recently approached a number of potential hosts, including Radio 1 DJ Chris Moyles, in an effort to halt the ratings decline.

A number of guest presenters, yet to be confirmed, are being lined up for the next few weeks.

A statement from Planet 24, which makes the Big Breakfast for Channel 4, said: "Paul Tonkinson has been released from his contract as co-presenter of the Big Breakfast.

"The Big Breakfast will continue with its team of regular presenters, who will be joined by a number of guest presenters over the coming weeks."

Tonkinson also presents the Channel 4 quiz show, Dicing with Debt.

Related story

fields.standfirst: How do bookmakers like Blue Square make their money? Here's how!
fields.trailText:

fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £168.04
The Prince of Punts aka Paul MacInnes = £55.01
The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £43.46
Sean Ingle = £12.32

Scott Murray: Leeds v Southampton, away win - £5 @ 6/1

The Leeds babies (hold on, aren't they grown men?) are coming off the back of a European game, so they may be sleepy, bless them. Saints, meanwhile, have something to prove after making caretaker Stuart Gray look like a right arse against Ipswich.

OK, I'm hardly backing against a bad favourite - Leeds are a fine side, after all. But odds of 6/1 on a team in the top half of the table? Come on.

The Prince of Punts is still on holiday, we think

Nick Harper of the Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective: Liverpool v Wycombe, draw after 90 minutes ­ £5 @ 4/1

What do you mean the punt of a hapless romantic?

A few wins and Liverpool suddenly believe they¹re the new Manchester United; pre-occupied with Europe and squeezing the humble FA whatsitcalled in as an after thought. They'll opt out of the FA Cup to play a round robin in Ecuador next season, you mark my words.

Their well-lamented fixture overdose ­ I think Gerard said it¹s been 17 games in the last 6 days, or, for you maths fans, one game every eight hours and forty minutes ­ will also come into the equation.

Add the fact that they possess an unrivalled track record of underestimating underdogs ­ ask blubbing Trevor Francis for one ­ and all but the most myopic will come around to my way of thinking.

But if you¹re still not convinced, remember that Wycombe don¹t often (oh alright, ever) get to FA Cup semi finals. Underdogs of war on heat (a grizzly image if ever there was) playing as if their journeymen lives depended on it. Liverpool, methinks, won¹t fancy this one bit.

Sean Ingle: Arsenal v Spurs: Rebrov to score the first goal and Spurs to win 1-0 £2 @ 35-1

It's the Hail Mary pass of all Hail Mary passes. And I expect it to fail spectacularly. But with my once healthy bank balance now as vacant as my reasoning abilities, I need a miracle. So Holy Mary, mother of God, I pray for this bet. Now, and in the hour of my death. Amen.

Actually there is a modicum of logic behind my selection. Spurs, under new manager Glenn Hoddle, are bound to play this tight. And Arsenal, after their midweek exertions, could find Sol Campbell (if he plays) and co mighty difficult to break down.

So I reckon the no goalscorer bet at 8-1 probably represents decent value. But I'm desperate, and this is the FA Cup, so I'm starting to dream that anything is possible; even Sergei Rebrov scoring a late goal to give Spurs a famous victory.

webTitle: Jazz CD of the week: Gary Burton: For Hamp, Bags and Cal

fields.headline: How the blues got their vibes
fields.standfirst: Gary Burton's respect for the history of the vibraphone makes for an ideal counterpoint to his soft jazz-rock grooves, says  John Fordham
fields.trailText: Gary Burton's respect for the history of the vibraphone makes for an ideal counterpoint to his soft jazz-rock grooves, says John Fordham
fields.body:
Gary Burton For Hamp, Bags and Cal
(Concord Jazz) ****
£15.99

Gary Burton, the teenage vibraphone star of the 1960s who was one of the early explorers of a jazz touched by country-rock, came to London last year with the Japanese pianist Makoto Ozone. The shows could have been just for jazz buffs - for those with long memories of Burton's original emergence. They could have had an appeal only for those who don't find that the sometimes glutinous vibraphone sound sends them to sleep. But in the event, the duo's collaboration was a miniature tour de force.

It wasn't as if Burton - nowadays a man of scholarly dignity, and one of the Berklee Conservatoire's most respected teachers - went in for much theatricality of presentation, or groomed his show for those audience members who didn't know him from Richard Burton. But the breadth of his repertoire - from the 1930s swing style of vibes legends like Red Norvo and Lionel Hampton, to the softly grooving jazz-rock pieces that made him famous - and the sophistication of his melodic imagination and instrumental touch, were evidence of a class act at work.

This set does much of what Burton was doing then, but with a much wider roster of partners - including pianists Danilo Perez and Mulgrew Miller as well as Makoto Ozone, plus Christian McBride and John Pattitucci swapping bass roles.

Maybe it's his teacher's instincts, but Burton likes the world to know how the vibes got where they are today. The title of this disc accurately reflects the leader's showcasing of the contributions of several jazz-vibes giants, including Lionel Hampton, Red Norvo, Cal Tjader and Milt "Bags" Jackson. Norvo's fearsomely complicated, melodically treacherous swinger Hole in the Wall appears here as it did on the London gig - and it is Ozone, again, who supplies the appropriately high-stepping piano accompaniment.

Mongo Santamaria's Afro Blue represents Burton's tribute to Cal Tjader. An insistent percussion shuffle, and Danilo Perez's ebullient chording, sway in after the vibraphonist's typically glowing, graceful intro. Milt Jackson's Bags' Groove, one of the stealthiest jazz-blues tunes ever written, edges onstage after Mulgrew Miller's impassive statement of the bare-bones theme, and Burton - though he doesn't manage Jackson's trick of making the vibes sound earthy - rips through some startling melodic variations when the tempo cranks up.

Burton's glistening sound captures the aching melody of the late John Lewis's Django (long a feature for Milt Jackson with the Modern Jazz Quartet). Although the fiesta-noises that usher in the Latin shuffle Joao sound a shade self-conscious next to Burton's fastidious correctness, the leader's eerily tiptoeing marimba solo on Dance of the Octopus has an engagingly stately playfulness.

Idiomatically, a lot of this disc is as straight as jazz can get, with plenty of chunky, old-fashioned swing on it, and the vibes certainly isn't a sound that works for everybody. But within its own sphere, it's a very musicianly exercise.

fields.body:
Joe Locke Storytelling
(Sirocco Jazz) ***
£15.99

There's a good deal of Gary Burton's lyricism and subtlety of touch in the work of the younger American vibraphonist Joe Locke, who played in the UK last year with Tim Garland's American/British ensemble and who opens at Ronnie Scott's on Monday with his own band including Garland. It's likely that Locke's week-long residency will include much of the material from this CD, since vocalist Mark Ledford is there too.

The Gary Burton sound is in Locke's rich chords as much as in the dance of his single-line playing - but though Locke is a player who often keeps adventurous postbop company, both his approach and the dominant atmosphere of this session are surprisingly traditional. The set is aimed as much at a smooth-jazz audience and fans of such elegant contemporary/retro vocalists as Carmen Lundy as it is at the jazz hardcore. Mark Ledford, a staple feature of the Pat Metheny touring band for years and a fine vocal technician, is adept at a very superior Las Vegas singing style, and it's a sound that governs the impact of the set. Ledford's light, flexible voice curls around classics like The Thrill Is Gone (given a gentle funk groove) and Blame It on My Youth, and Locke reflects that easy-going lyricism in his sensitive interplay. Ledford's singing will be gracefully romantic to some and perhaps just plain cheesy to others. Despite the presence of Garland, Hammondist Henry Hey and drummer Jeff "Tain" Watts, this set doesn't quite ignite the way its elements suggest that it should.

Zoe Rahman The Cynic
(Manushi Records, www.zoerahman.com) ****

British pianist Zoe Rahman won the Perrier Young Jazz Musician of the Year award a couple of years ago, and has continued to evolve her vivacious, technically robust and expressive straightahead style. She toured on her own and with the David-Jean Baptiste band that included the formidable James Carter last year, revealing that she was both a powerful solo voice and a confidently creative group player. This self-marketed CD is Rahman's debut disc, featuring her regular trio with Jeremy Brown on bass and Winston Clifford on drums. All the pieces and the arrangements are Rahman originals, and the sustained quality of the writing suggests Rahman's career may well mature in more ways than at the keyboard alone. The uptempo feature Apple Pie, with its stalking, McCoy Tyner-like theme, is an emphatic, compelling piece that Rahman could well find quite a few of her contemporaries borrowing. The pianist's dewy, rippling-arpeggio delicacy with ballads is beautifully realised on the classical-sounding slow feature Monica. Meanwhile, the headlong title track has a quicksilver unpredictability of line that suggests Paul Bley, and Rahman's mingling of tumbling runs with ruggedly percussive chording and an alert rhythmic sense (shadowed everywhere by Clifford's restless percussion) suggests a musical mind as deft as her fingers.

New York Connexion Crossing the Bridge
(Sirocco Jazz) **
£15.99

It is a pity that this collection of pieces - by a New York ensemble including three members of the superb Dave Holland band that visited the UK recently - should begin with saxophonist Antonio Hart's rather diffuse, dolorous tone-poem Nine Weeks. It sets a tone for the music that isn't quite a fair reflection of its improvisors' strengths. But when you learn that the principal musical direction comes from a trombonist, the excellent Robin Eubanks, some questions about the prevailing mood of plush, slow-moving cloud-formations of chords and a lot of patiently interweaving counter-melody seem to get answered. The group doesn't have the nervous urgency of Dave Holland's band, despite their shared core of the extraordinary Billy Kilson's drumming. This is the second New York Connexion recording, with two pieces imported from other writers, while the rest have been generated by band-members. There is plenty of fine soloing from Antonio Hart (a once rather formulaic postbopper who is becoming increasingly quirky). Good work, too, from the jubilant swing and mellow, rounded sound of vibraharpist Joe Locke, the Herbie Hancockish harmonies of pianist Michael Cain, and the airily original Eubanks. Cain's contribution to Claire Fischer's Latin shuffler Morning is a good example of how to avoid the usual licks in the Lat-Am jazz idiom - it starts with a strange, inquisitive figure and drapes deceptively relaxed lines over it, but always returns to a slightly anxious insistence. But for a session populated by such pedigree sidemen, the overall impact is surprisingly becalmed.

fields.headline: Classical CD releases
fields.trailText: MacMillan | Elgar | Gluck | Mozart | Menotti | 18th Century British Symphonies
fields.byline: Reviews by Edward Greenfield and Tim Ashley
fields.body:
MacMillan: Mass; Christus vincit; Gaudeamus; Seinte Mari moder milde; A New Song; A Child's Prayer; Changed
Westminster Cathedral Choir/Baker
(Hyperion) *****
£13.99

It is hard to think of any recent music that conveys religious ecstasy as intensely as James MacMillan's Mass. It is a liturgical setting, with text (in English) expanded from the Ordinary of the Mass, which he wrote for the millennium celebrations at Westminster Cathedral. Closer in style to Britten than to Tavener, MacMillan is distinctive in his brilliant use of choral effects, with surging crescendos to stir the blood: it is music of high voltage from first to last. Equally, the shorter choral works on the disc, all written in the 1990s, have a rare concentration, often involving powerful slabs of sound. The singing of the Westminster Cathedral Choir is electrifying, with Martin Baker directing his first recording as choirmaster. (EG)

Elgar: Violin Sonata; Finzi: Elegy; Walton Violin Sonata
Hope/Mulligan
(Nimbus) ****
£11.99

Daniel Hope gives large-scale, virtuoso readings of the Elgar and Walton Violin Sonatas. They are both neglected, seemingly wayward works. But the warmth and thrust of Daniel Hope's performances underline the purposefulness of the writing, with the central slow movement of the Elgar treated not as a mere interlude but as a meditation. Similarly, Hope - with understanding support from a fellow Menuhin protégé, Simon Mulligan - brings tautness to the wide- ranging variation movement that rounds off the Walton Sonata. They make for an apt coupling, nicely supplemented by the lyrical Finzi Elegy. (EG)

Gluck / Mozart: Operatic Arias
Graham/Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment/ Bicket
(Erato) ***

This recital by American mezzo Susan Graham looks at operatic love and solitude as portrayed by Mozart and Gluck. Graham is an expert Mozartian - tenderly funny as Cherubino, intense and spectacular in Sesto's arias from La Clemenza di Tito, rapturous as Idamante - but one misses the tragic dignity essential to great Gluck interpretations. Her Orphée is less than harrowing; her Iphigénie suggests nostalgic wistfulness rather than desperation. Bicket, seemingly anxious to avoid stolidity, hectors her at times. Like Graham, he's more relaxed when it comes to Mozart, where he draws finely honed playing from the OAE. (TA)

Menotti: Apocalisse; Fantasia for Cello and Orch/Sebastian Suite
Wallfisch/Spoleto Festival Orchestra/Hickox
(Chandos) ****
£13.99

Richard Hickox here tackles three of Menotti's orchestral pieces: lyrical and colourful, yet till now neglected. The Sebastian ballet suite, a sequence of genre pieces, dates from 1944. The triptych Apocalisse, written for Victor de Sabata in 1951-2, builds on an ambitious first movement, Improperia, inspired by the conflict between the goodness of Christ and his suffering at the hands of man. Striking fanfare motifs bring echoes of Hollywood film music; and, as in the Sebastian Suite, the ostinatos echo Stravinsky. The Fantasia, dating from 1976, is similarly full of striking ideas, with echoes of Walton in the virtuoso cello part, played by Raphael Wallfisch. A full-bodied live recording. (EG)

18th Century British Symphonies - Arne; Collett; Kelly; Smethergell; Abel; Marsh
Hanover Band/Lea-Cox
(ASV) *****
£13.99

This collection of six British symphonies from the late 18th century is highly refreshing. Little is known of John Collett, but his four-movement Symphony Op 5 No 2, published in 1767, is a delight: in its energy it echoes the new Mannheim school, with brazen horn writing. Collett's patron, the Earl of Kelly, Thomas Erskine, studied for years in Mannheim, but his Periodical Overture No 17 is briefer and bluffer. It is in three movements, as are all the rest, including John Marsh's elegant Conversation Sinfonie for two orchestras (1778). With such bright and carefree inspiration in these works, the idea that Handel stifled British composers needs revising. (EG)

fields.headline: 18m tune in to EastEnders whodunnit
fields.standfirst: EastEnders top 20
fields.trailText:
11.30am: Nearly 18m viewers tuned in to EastEnders last night to find out Lisa Shaw shot Phil Mitchell, writes Jason Deans.
April 5: It was Lisa whodunnit
Apr 3: 13m tune in to EastEnders
Mar 2: 15m witness EastEnders shooting
Table: EastEnders top 20
fields.body:
Nearly 18m viewers tuned in to EastEnders last night to find out that Lisa Shaw shot Phil Mitchell.

But audience levels for the BBC1 soap are expected to rise to more than 22m when the omnibus edition on Sunday and video recordings are taken into account.

This puts it on a par with the Who Shot JR? episode of Dallas - the biggest cliffhanger in television history, back in 1980.

The audience for last night's EastEnders special peaked at nearly 20m just before 8pm, according to unofficial overnights.

Over 40 minutes from 7.30pm, EastEnders averaged 17.9m viewers and a whopping 69% audience share.

It will go down as one of the best performing episodes of EastEnders in recent years, providing a valuable boost to the soap when it goes four days a week this summer.

The number of viewers tuning in to the soap last night peaked between 7.45pm and 8pm, with 19.8m and three-quarters of the available audience.

The figures show the BBC managed to keep viewers' suspense even though the identity of the culprit had leaked out days before the broadcast.

An email revealing that Lisa shot Phil began doing the rounds last week. It also featured on MediaGuardian.co.uk's own Monkey diary.

For its last 10 minutes from 8pm, EastEnders was up against ITV's Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?.

But Millionaire proved no match, with just 8.4m and a 32% share over 60 minutes from 8pm.

Match of the Day - Live followed EastEnders on BBC1 from 8.10pm, with coverage of Liverpool's Uefa Cup semi-final against Barcelona.

Over nearly two hours 8.6m tuned in to watch Liverpool's goalless draw, equivalent to a 34% audience share.

Between 9pm and 10pm, Match of the Day was up against Peak Practice on ITV. The GP drama had 7.5m and a 31% share.

Overall, the strong performance by EastEnders helped BBC1 to a rare peaktime ratings victory over ITV between 7pm and 10.30pm.

BBC1 had a 40% audience share; while ITV had just 30%.

fields.headline: Amazonian journeys
fields.standfirst: It was dismissed in its time, but Janacek's first opera is a gem, says  Edward Greenfield
fields.trailText: It was dismissed in its time, but Janacek's first opera is a gem, says Edward Greenfield
fields.body:
Janacek: Sarka
Urbanova/Straka/Kusnjer/ Brezina/Prague Phil Choir/ Czech PO
(Supraphon) *****
£12.99

Fibich: Sarka
Urbanova/Kirilova/Lotric/ Jenis/Vienna Concert Chor/ Vienna RSO/Cambreling
(Orfeo, 2 CDs) ***
£28.99

The legend of Sarka and her fellow Amazons has inspired a sequence of Czech composers - notably Smetana, in one of the six symphonic poems of Ma Vlast. Janacek followed in 1887, writing this, his very first opera. Sadly, it was put aside when the author of the original play objected.

The score remained buried for almost 30 years, until Janacek revised it and got the piece produced in Brno in 1925. But in the mean time, Zdenek Fibich had written a Sarka in 1896-7, using the same story but with a more expansive libretto, and Janacek's effort was dismissed as inferior.

Now the two Sarka operas are issued simultaneously on disc. And though the Fibich is a confident work in a Wagnerian mould, the Janacek now emerges as much the more vital piece, with the drama compressed in a way that emerges as fresh and forward-looking.

Though the idiom has few anticipations of the mature Janacek, it is certainly distinctive, and its dramatic point comes over strongly. Having the story reduced to bare essentials gives it a dream-like quality, suggesting a Freudian fantasy before its time.

Though the three acts last little more than an hour, Janacek regarded this as his Wagnerian opera, ending as it does with the immolation of the formidable heroine, Sarka (as an Amazon sworn to revenge herself on man) on the funeral pyre of Ctirad, the hero-figure whom, against her will, she falls in love with. It is a Liebestod, or love-death.

This first stereo recording could hardly be finer. The text that has been newly revised and expanded, and conductor Charles Mackerras inspires his Czech singers and players to an incandescent performance. Eva Urbanova as Sarka and Peter Straka as Ctirad are ideally cast - both are characterfully slavonic and clean in attack. The sound is excellent, with atmospheric choral effects beautifully caught.

The Orfeo set of the Fibich opera offers a first-rate live recording made in Vienna, and it is a formidable rival for the fine 1978 Supraphon version. Again, Urbanova is outstanding as the heroine, opposite a clear-toned tenor, Janez Lotric, as Ctirad. Yet, more conventional in its idiom and less striking in its ideas, it now seems far less inspired than the Janacek.

fields.headline: Bedroom fluff
fields.standfirst: Shaggy discusses his sex life, 60 musicians try to upstage Cesaria Evora, and Stereophonics dream of running away in this week's releases
fields.trailText: Shaggy discusses his sex life, 60 musicians try to upstage Cesaria Evora, and Stereophonics dream of running away in this week's releases
fields.byline: Reviews by John Aizlewood, Robin Denselow, Alexis Petridis, Betty Clarke, Maddy Costa and Caroline Sullivan
fields.body:
Shaggy Hot Shot
(MCA) ***
£13.99

As Freaky Girl settles into its jogging groove, Orville "Shaggy" Burrell growls over The Kraft's Stakhanovite vocal legwork and lets slip a chuckle. In an instant, its good-natured lasciviousness encapsulates the unlikely but undisputed king of reggae. Shaggy's shtick is straightforward but appealing. His love songs - girl meets Shaggy, girl wants Shaggy, Shaggy obliges - are platforms to discuss his bedtime prowess ("Passion and ecstasy; you know the drill", he explains on Not Fair) or his life as a sexually active superstar. It is invariably harmless fluff, but Shaggy is often a spectator on his own album: Dance & Shout heavily samples Shake Your Body (Down to the Ground), while Hope is a close relation of Love of the Common People. Shaggy does not sing as such, so he gets others to do it. Yet, when he growls against a choir on Joy You Bring or duets with Samantha Cole on the naughty Luv Me Luv Me, he is impossible to dislike. In fact, he is a guilty delight. (JA)

Neil Finn One Nil
(Parlophone) ***
£15.99

Since disbanding Crowded House - effectively his solo project - in 1996, Neil Finn is not quite what he used to be. For all its careful crafting, One Nil offers no melody to eclipse his past, nor is there a phrase to compare with "Everywhere you go, always take the weather with you". Even so, Finn will never make a poor album, and One Nil grows in stature with each hearing. Wendy and Lisa, once of Prince's Revolution, are frequent collaborators: they supply lumpen beats to Rest of the Day and Don't Ask Why, but they also put a renewed spring in Finn's step on the inspired Elastic Heart and the feisty single Wherever You Are. More than many lesser talents, Finn is responsible for his career curve: married for more than 20 years, unwilling to uproot from Australia or New Zealand, he was never superstar material. One Nil - quality throughout, but with a lingering feeling of what might have been - suggests he has accepted his fate with dignity. (JA)

Antibalas' Afrobeat Orchestra Liberation Afrobeat Vol 1
(Ninja Tune) ***
£11.99

Martin Antibalas and his friends are a rousing curiosity: a Brooklyn-based band consisting of at least 14 members, determined to revive and update the tradition of Nigeria's greatest musical rebel, Fela Kuti. Fela's Afrobeat style was a mixture of traditional Yoruba music, funk and jazz, and involved lengthy instrumental passages and chanting vocal work-outs in which he could vent his fury at Nigeria's military rulers. There's not quite the same sense of danger in the US,but the Antibalas team strive hard for that tense Lagos feel. Their long songs have titles like Uprising and World War IV, and follow the Afrobeat format, though with a slick veneer. Like many US revivalist bands, they are strong on skill and technique, but less good at innovation; and, inevitably, they can't match Fela's sense of anger, excitement and musical bravery. That said, they are a lively, stylish band, with strong keyboards, brass and percussion. (RD)

Cesaria Evora Sao Vicente di Longe
(BMG/RCA Victor) ***
£13.99

Now rightly established as a best-selling international star, Cesaria Evora has moved on from exploring the music of her home (the Cape Verde Islands, off the coast of west Africa), which fuses African and Portuguese styles, to explore that music's links with other Afro-Latin styles across the Atlantic. She has been given the full superstar treatment, with recording sessions in Havana, Rio and Paris, and a supporting cast of nearly 60 musicians, arrangers and engineers. Was it worth it? Well, her intimate voice is as distinctive as ever, but those immaculately recorded orchestras of sweeping strings and guitars often sound out of place, and at times there's a clash between her thoughtful approach and that of the musicians, who sound desperate to get up and dance. Evora's singing may have a limited emotional range, but when it comes to languid melancholia she's in a class of her own. (MCA) **
£14.99

(Dusty Company) **
£8.99

(V2) ***
£14.99

From thoughts of suicide to musical travelogue, Stereophonics appear consumed with the notion of getting away from it all. (EMI) **
£14.99

The Swedish Eurythmics are still chipping away at the same power-pop coalface as they were in 1989, when The Look became the first of 21 fantastically unmemorable hits. As ever, singer Marie Fredriksson is the brittle focal point, compelling yet curiously unengaged as she tries to negotiate Per Gessle's lyrics. His attempt at a social conscience on Jefferson is scuppered by one of the worst first verses in history: "Jefferson was always out of luck/ I remember when we both grew up/ Jefferson got hit by a westbound truck/ I guess that didn't make him look like a million bucks." Yet a few tracks, such as the tinny Make My Head Go Pop and Real Sugar, are redeemed by choruses so insistent they quash all resistance. (CS)

(Go Beat) ***
£10.99

This introduction to oddbod singer-guitarist Russell Nash is reminiscent of Merz, who had a bewitchingly woozy hit with Many Weathers Apart. Nash and programmer Steve Ellington operate in similar R&B-based, anything-goes territory. The single 100 Million Ways is a happy accident of soul, reggae and (forgive them) Jamiroquai, bookended by the ambiguous query "Will I ever see the day that paints a picture and frees me of addiction?" It contrives to be irresistible, and is a hard act to follow for the other 13 songs, which never hit the same luscious peak. But if Black Box loses its lysergic marbles and Breakaway could be a Lighthouse Family outtake, Nash's fluid voice is consistently a thing of beauty. (CS)

fields.headline: The shooting of Phil Mitchell
fields.standfirst: After five weeks of anticipation, we now know that Lisa shot the hardman of Albert Square. Here's our guide to the best EastEnders sites.
fields.trailText: After five weeks of anticipation, we now know that Lisa shot the hardman of Albert Square. Here's our guide to the best EastEnders sites.
fields.body:
1. Last night EastEnders baddie Phil Mitchell finally contronted his would-be killer: his pregnant and embittered ex-girlfriend, Lisa Shaw.

2. Millions tuned in to last night's 40 minute episode, causing the third largest power surge on record. Impatient sport fans had to wait an extra 15 minutes for the kickoff of the Barcelona v Liverpool Uefa Cup semi-final, delayed to accomadate the nation's favourite soap.

3. Last month's gripping episode saw the shooting of relapsed alcoholic Phil but left 15m viewers wondering who did the dirty.

4. There were almost as many suspects as in the infamous shooting of Dallas nasty man JR.

5. Lisa was the prime suspect and the bookies' odds-on favourite, but even the show's crew did not know until the last minute.

6. Why did she do it? She was furious with him for his shabby treatment of her. But he should have seen it coming as she had already shown a tendency towards boyfriend battering when she smashed a plate over his head.

7. To keep the final outcome a secret, the BBC filmed alternative endings for each of the suspects.

8. Mark Fowler, Steve Owen, Dan Sullivan, and Ian Beale were all potential shooters.

9. The BBC's long-awaited answer to Coronation Street started on February 19, 1985 at 7pm. It was set in a "typical" east London square modelled on Fassett Square in the London borough of Hackney. The soap costs the BBC around £20m a year - sounds a lot but it is the equivalent of every viewer paying just £1.30 to watch the show for a year.

10. EastEnders is head and shoulders above the rest when it comes to the battle of the soaps. On Christmas Day in 1986 it broke all ratings records when 30.51m people tuned in to see Dirty Den serve Angie with divorce papers.

fields.headline: Radebe out for the season
fields.trailText: Leeds United have been dealt a massive blow with the news that captain Lucas Radebe has been ruled out for the rest of the season.
fields.body:
Leeds United have been dealt a massive blow with the news that captain Lucas Radebe has been ruled out for the rest of the season.

Radebe tore medial ligaments in his left knee during Leeds' 2-0 success at Sunderland last Saturday and the club have confirmed that he will now miss the remainder of a campaign that sees David O'Leary's men still battling for Champions League glory and making a late run to establish a top three finish in the FA Carling Premiership.

The influential South African has been plagued by injuries this season and his appearance at the Stadium Of Light last weekend was his first for three weeks after picking up a knee injury in a European tie against Real Madrid.

Leeds manager David O'Leary admitted: "It's a blow to lose the Chief for the run in to the season. But nobody can underestimate his powers of recovery and the determination he will show to bounce back."

webTitle: CD of the week: Laura Nyro: Angel in the Dark

fields.headline: Songs in the key of life
fields.standfirst: For fans of Laura Nyro's overlooked genius, here is a dream come true, says  Richard Williams
fields.trailText: For fans of Laura Nyro's overlooked genius, here is a dream come true, says Richard Williams
fields.body:
Laura Nyro Angel in the Dark
(Rounder) *****
£13.99

This album is incomplete, but so was Laura Nyro's life. It is the project on which she was working when she died of ovarian cancer four years ago this Sunday, aged 49, and it represents a precious addition to the luminous output of nine studio albums and two live recordings that attracted admiration and affection over the three decades of her career, even though she never truly fulfilled the music industry's early expectation that she would become one of the most popular performers of her generation.

She was in her teens when she wrote And When I Die, Wedding Bell Blues and Stoney End, big pop hits in the late 1960s for Blood, Sweat and Tears, the Fifth Dimension and Barbra Streisand respectively. Think about that - a 17-year-old composing And When I Die, with its tumbling structure and that blithely morbid lyric: "My troubles are many/ They're as deep as a well/ I swear there ain't no heaven/ And I pray there ain't no hell." And she was barely 20 when she wrote Eli and the Thirteenth Confession, her second album, a cycle of 13 songs full of astonishingly sophisticated musicianship and a young woman's wildheart poetry: "Silver was the colour/ Winter was a snowbell/ Mother of the windboys/ Living off the lovewell."

If her later work was often inconsistent and lacked the romantic gestures of those early street-corner arias, that only seemed to be a natural consequence of her involvement in motherhood, radical feminism and animal rights, to each of which she dedicated songs that veered away from poetry towards didacticism. Yet she never really lost her gift. The song Walk the Dog and Light the Light, the title track from the last album released during her lifetime, is a beauty, and so is the wonderful Companion, from her 1989 Live at the Bottom Line set. The concerts of her last years, whether in surroundings as appropriate as Islington's Union Chapel or in the indifferent setting of a hotel lounge in middle America, were always faithful, compelling representations of her uncompromising talent.

Angel in the Dark is just about everything her fans could wish for: almost an hour's worth of original songs and covers of old favourites, of voice-and-piano performances and pieces accompanied by a small band of crack musicians including the drummer Bernard "Pretty" Purdie, the guitarist John Tropea and the Brecker brothers, Randy and Michael, on trumpet and tenor saxophone. It finds Nyro fully engaged with life and love of all kinds.

Several songs on which she deploys the band - notably Sweet Dream Fade, Gardenia Talk, Don't Hurt Child and the title tune - have the informal feeling of very superior demos, and are all the better for the lack of sweetening. The arrangements are fresh and taut, close in style to Van Morrison's Moondance band, which means no messing about, no long solos - just a bunch of grooves placed right in the pocket, allowing the songs to speak.

Almost 30 years ago, in the collection called Gonna Take a Miracle, she reinterpreted the teen anthems of her subway adolescence. Here the mature woman reflects on the authentic poetry of Gerry Goffin's lyric to Will You Love Me Tomorrow, examines the naive loveliness of Thom Bell's La La Means I Love You, croons Smokey Robinson's ineffable Ooo Baby Baby, and finds a different and successful approach to Bacharach and David's Walk On By. Here and there you can sense where she would have added vocal harmonies, had there been time.

She was at her most intense when alone with the piano, as anyone whose memory goes back to her London debut at the Royal Festival Hall in 1971 will attest. In these performances of He Was Too Good to Me and Serious Playground there is no gap whatsoever between the performer and her material.

In musical and emotional terms, she was the mother of such adventuresses as Rickie Lee Jones and Mary Margaret O'Hara, although she cannot be blamed for the subsequent generation of show-offs and therapy queens, and her failure to find a larger audience of her own remains a bit of a mystery. Maybe there was something too naked about her voice, too uncomfortable about its pronounced break between registers. Perhaps the structures of her music were too grown-up, too well-crafted, too rooted in the cadences of Brill Building pop-soul songwriting, to satisfy the tastes of the broad rock audience. Possibly she suffered for wanting to write poetically about her acceptance of an ability to love both men and women without being interested in exploiting its publicity value. Her songs were drawn from her life, which should be all that we need to know. And it will be a big surprise if any singer-songwriter, of whatever gender or generation, releases anything this year remotely as accomplished and affecting as these last offerings from an artist of genuine and enduring originality.

Mortgage rates fell to their lowest level for 36 years yesterday after the Bank of England cut the cost of borrowing in an attempt to prevent the global economic slowdown spreading to Britain.

Amid signs that a combination of stock market falls and the foot and mouth outbreak are starting to have a negative impact on the economy, the bank announced that it was reducing base rates from 5.75% to 5.5%.

The move triggered an immediate response from banks and building societies, with the cost of a typical £60,000 loan trimmed by around £12.50 to £325 a month. Britain's biggest lender, the Halifax, said the reduction in its variable mortgage rate from 6.75% to 6.5% took it to a level not seen since February 1965, and its reduction prompted similar moves from the Nationwide, Cheltenham & Gloucester and HSBC. The Abbey National said it would review its rates today.

The bank said in a statement that while the domestic economy remained firm, there were "downside risks to UK activity from the slowdown in the global economy, the recent fall in equity markets and, in the short run, from foot and mouth disease.

"These developments could already have affected demand and output growth and may continue to do so, in particular through their impact on business and consumer confidence." It added that its nine-strong monetary policy committee (MPC) would "continue to monitor the downside risks carefully", an indication that further interest rate cuts may be on the way.

The bank's comments, together with confirmation from official figures yesterday that Britain's industrial sector is in recession, reinforced the government's decision not to countenance any further delay in polling day beyond June 7.

Unions and employers welcomed the bank's decision to cut rates for the second time this year. John Monks, TUC general secretary, said: "This was the prudent decision. With no great inflationary pressures in the UK, and real dangers from fall out from the US economic downturn, this was the only sensible decision."

Digby Jones, director general of the CBI, said: "We do not expect the UK to go into recession, but it is clear there are stormy waters ahead. Both manufacturing and service sectors are seeing the effects of the problems in America. With earnings still subdued, despite a fall in unemployment, this was a good time to take pre-emptive action."
