webTitle: Break the bonds of mental health

fields.headline: Break the bonds of mental health
fields.standfirst: As we celebrate world health day, mental health is once again hitting the headlines. But it's time to move on from the debate about services and address the question of civil liberties, writes Lynne Friedli
fields.trailText: Lynne Friedli: It's time to move on from the debate about services and address the question of civil liberties.
fields.body:
Tomorrow is world health day, which this year has a special focus on mental health.

There is little doubt mental health is moving rapidly up the agenda on several fronts. Media coverage of mental health grows apace, albeit oscillating between community care failures, "mad axeman on the loose" and sympathetic lifestyle features on stress and the middle classes. In policy terms, the NHS plan and the national service framework for mental health have reinforced mental health as a priority area.

World health day is likely to generate much hand wringing about the state of mental health services and negative public attitudes toward people with mental health problems. What we're unlikely to see is much debate about civil liberties and the extent to which discrimination against people with mental health problems is entrenched in almost every area of life.

People with mental health problems are hugely over-represented among the poor, the homeless, the prison population and the unemployed. They also have poor physical health and a lower life expectancy, partly because receiving a diagnosis frequently means health professionals neglect your physical health.

Although the Disability Discrimination Act covers mental disabilities, one in 10 people with a mental illness diagnosis is in work, compared with more than a third of people with physical disabilities. Within the public sector, the situation is, if anything, worse. Innumerable studies catalogue the consequences for nurses, doctors and other health professionals, of admitting to depression or bi-polar disorder.

Negative public attitudes are part of the problem, but are also a natural response to the way the whole debate about mental health has been framed. The reform of the Mental Health Act and the modernisation of mental health services were launched under the slogan "safe, sound supportive", with a ministerial emphasis on safe.

The focus on treatment and compliance with medication simply reinforced public fears and strengthened the view that mental illness equals incapacity, equals danger to others, equals relinquish any claim to basic human rights.

Of course, as any epidemiologist knows, failure to immunise your children poses a much greater threat to public health than non-compliance with anti-psychotic drugs. But we have yet to see compulsory treatment orders imposed on recalcitrant mothers.

It is undeniable that mental health services need to improve. But the best services in the world won't compensate for exclusion from society. Many people with mental health problems overcome unimagineable obstacles to live their lives and make a contribution. But in areas such as employment this is becoming increasingly difficult.

A survival of the fittest culture means having a social life, or any other form of human frailty, is an impediment to having a job. Smoking, hangovers, taking a lunch break and erotic emails are outlawed in the name of productivity and working environments are a significant cause of mental health problems.

Re-framing the debate in terms of civil liberties will mean recognising that people have rights, including the right to work. The case for employing people with a history of depression or schizophrenia does not rest on proving that they take fewer days sick leave than people with back problems.

In any event, bums on seats is not a reliable measure of productivity, as Britain's record shows. The experience of mental illness has a profound impact on people, but the goal is not the eradication of all the marks and signs of madness. The promotion of civil liberties is a precondition for valuing diversity and recognising that conformity is not an indicator of people's value - in the workplace or anywhere else.

Organisations like Mad Pride and Survivors Speak Out are building links with movements such as Gay Pride and Disability Rights, which have resisted attempts to medicalise and pathologise their experiences and have fought under a civil liberties banner.

Tomorrow sees the launch of Hats Off, a celebration of survival, resistance to labelling and the achievements of people with mental health problems. A Hats Off award has been established for the person who has done most to promote the civil liberties of people with mental health problems.

It's not too late to take action and receive a nomination more valuable than any Oscar.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.trailText: Black and White | Play It to the Bone | Breakfast of Champions
fields.body:
Black and White
Rental and DVD rental Columbia Tristar Cert 18
***

James Toback's view of life on both sides of the racial divide and the inbetweenies - white kids apeing black hip-hop culture - is ragged but always interesting. Toback's aim seems to be to slam together a mixed bag of white actors - Robert Downey Jr, Ben Stiller and Brooke Shields among them - and black rappers such as Power and Raekwon, mix up the sexual preferences and provocative plotlines and see what transpires. Amid the loose plot strands, the key development sees the ever-impressive Stiller entrap a young black basketball player into throwing a match for $50,000 for motives that turn out to be very twisted. The subtext seems to be whites exploiting blacks and getting away with it because society's set up that way. Black and White is best-known for the scene in which Downey, playing a gay film director comes on to Mike Tyson: "It's just that in the dream, you were holding me . . ." It's typical of writer- director-gambler Toback and the ultimate risk-taker Downey that this development in a largely improvised enterprise clearly comes as a surprise to the ex-champ, playing himself. Seconds out. It's notable too for Brooke Shields, unrecognisable as a dreadlocked documentary director, and for Claudia Schiffer, that most mainstream of models who, as an occasional actress, finds the edgiest parts imaginable - in Abel Ferrara's drugfest The Blackout and here, as a duplicitous girlfriend of two black guys. The soundtrack mixes Bach and Shostakovich with the Wu-Tang Clan and Raekwon. Yo, Johann.

Play It to the Bone
Rental and DVD (£15.99) Warner Cert 15
**

A tale of two boxers that is reminiscent of writer-director Ron Shelton's best films, Bull Durham (two sportsmen involved with a smarter woman) and White Men Can't Jump (Woody Harrelson with a joshing protagonist). Since the woman in question is Lolita Davidovitch, a fine actress as well as being Mrs Shelton, and the second boxer is the balletic Antonio Banderas, you settle back awaiting Shelton's punchy prose and Hawks-style sparky sparring. But, in what is mainly a road movie with the trio driving from LA to Las Vegas, it never really happens. The set-up is that Harrelson and Banderas are old friends and washed-up fighters who suddenly get to box each other on the undercard for Mike Tyson with the winner getting a title shot. Shelton throws in scene-stealing cameos from Lucy Liu as an amoral travelling companion and Robert Wagner as a smarmbag hotel boss, stacks the tape deck with Delbert McClinton and John Lee Hooker and films the long, bruising contest with hallucinogenic boxer's-eye views with some skill. But it's not nearly enough. Shelton has been great at creating real people - but here he just has cardboard cut-outs with a quirk each, boring scenery and a pat ending. Let's hope this shocking loss of form is a one-off. We need Shelton punching his weight.

Breakfast of Champions
Rental Warner Cert 15
*

I dimly remember Kurt Vonnegut's novel being a satire that worked, mainly through its author's eccentric writing style. Not a year has passed since without somebody announcing a film treatment and here is the finished article, 28 years after the book and minus any semblance of wit, humour or restraint. Bruce Willis, whose clout got the project made, plays a salesman undergoing a breakdown. But since everyone else in town appears equally deranged, you'd hardly notice. Director Alan Rudolph specialises in quiet, thoughtful literary adaptations, but here any satirical intent is drowned in a vat of loud overacting, plot incoherence and clumping pretensions to significance. Willis's town is surrounded by toxic swamp. Old reliables like Nick Nolte and Albert Finney must wish their contributions in this cataclysmically misconceived venture had been swallowed up in a poisonous dump of unreleased film stock.

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText:
Cheapskate ... Where to eat out for under £15: Pot of Beer
36 New Mount St, Manchester M4 4DE.
Tel 0161 834 8579.
fields.body:
Cheapskate ... Where to eat out for under £15: Pot of Beer
36 New Mount St, Manchester M4 4DE.
Tel 0161 834 8579.

Not all is as it seems. Tucked away on a back street just beyond the fringes of the city centre, towards the Boddingtons brewery and within sight of Strangeways, this apparently typical Manchester pub disguises a kitchen brimful of Polish goodies. Under the watchful eye of the Polish White Eagle, real ales rub shoulders with Zywiec beer and a selection of vodkas. Pass on the sandwiches, jacket potatoes and chips.

Go straight to mouth-filling, heart-warming barszcz (beetroot soup), sledzie (pickled herrings), bigos (pork and sauerkraut), kielbasa (grilled sausage), wedliny (cooked meats), placki (fried potato cakes), flaki (tripe), golabki (stuffed cabbage) and pierogi (large ravioli stuffed with cheese or meat) all for less than £5. Place your order by phone.

Quick bites ... Where to eat out in 15 minutes: The Armenian Taverna
3/5 Princess St, Manchester M2 4DF.
Tel 0161 834 9025.

Photos of 70s stars of stage and screen plastered over the walls, The Armenian Tavern is one of Manchester's first ethnic minority restaurants and makes for a rollicking retro experience. Armenian cooking has a touch of Turkey, North Africa, the Middle East and east Europe about it. So there's baba ganouge (grilled aubergine), yershig (spicy sausage) for starters (£2.50-£4). Main courses include koo koo (Iranian omelette), khash khash (minced lamb), a range of perfectly grilled kebabs, and four varieties of couscous (£7.25-£9.50). Banquets available.

On the menu: Argon oil

Not a petrochemical company, I take it. Very much the other end of the scale.

How so? It is made from the stones of the fruit of the argon tree ...

So what's all the fuss? ... that have passed through the digestive tract of a goat.

How very original. Whose goats? Moroccan goats. One tree produces two or three litres of oil.

And one goat produces? Figures aren't available.

And who's using this precious resource? Chic chefs in France on the look out for nifty novelty.

Any chance of it catching on over here? What do you think?

On the net: The Gluttonous Gardener

The Gluttonous Gardener is surely one of the loveliest sites on the whole of the world wide web. For a moderate fee they will deliver quality foodstuffs and an appropriate growing thing to the door of a lucky recipient. The fig tree plant, for example, is accompanied by a bottle of black fig vinegar; the sweet chestnut tree comes with a box of marrons glaces. Both are £35. Anyone after something stronger will be delighted by the Gin Drinker's Kit, containing a juniper tree, lemons and a bottle of Gloag's gin, and the tequila shooter kit boasts an Agave plant. The special christening kit is a gooseberry bush and a bottle of the fizzy stuff, and there's also a passion flower plant, passion fruits and a bottle of champagne for all you lovers out there.

Just out: Fauchon Marango

Form: chocolate mousse in the form of a Saxon burial urn with almond/honey ice cream and griotte cherries inside.

Flavour: terrific chocolate mousse, not too sweet, not too bitter; hefty almond hit from creamy ice; tart morello cherries.

Verdict: substantial offering from the House of Fauchon, the Parisian version of Fortnum & Mason, only more so; the mousse side of things is pretty convincing, and the almond/honey ice cream studded with suitably alcoholic and sharp griotte cherries, is pretty seductive too; but the chocolate macaroon base is a touch on the solid side for complete surrender.

Cost: £4.99 per 410g mousse from Waitrose.

The taste test: bolognese sauce

Spaghetti bolognese should be butter and oil, onion, carrot, celery, pork, beef, dry white wine, tomato puree stock and cream (or milk). None of those sent in were remotely authentic.

Sainsbury's

Price: £1.79/300g
What it's like: Refined; fresh flavoured; wine shines through
How it rates: ****

Waitrose

Price: £1.75/350g
What it's like: Beefo profindo; well put together; easy going and amiable
How it rates: ****

Safeway

Price: £1.49/350g
What it's like: Too much tomato by half, or three-quarters
How it rates: **

Tesco

Price: £1.49/330ml
What it's like: Tomato sauce with a bit of beef grit
How it rates: **

webTitle: Oscar won by Bette Davis to be auctioned

fields.headline: Oscar won by Bette Davis to be auctioned
fields.trailText: The Academy Award which the legendary star won for her performance in Jezebel in 1938 is the highlight of a collection of Hollywood memorabilia to be auctioned by Christie's in July
fields.body:
The Academy Award given to Bette Davis for her performance in Jezebel is to be sold. Reuters reports that Christie's is to sell the Oscar, which was awarded to the legendary star in 1938, at a Hollywood memorabilia auction in July.

Davis played Julie Morrison, a spoilt southern belle in the romantic melodrama, and the part is widely considered to have been a consolation for losing out on the role of Scarlett O'Hara in Gone With The Wind. The film brought her a second Academy Award to match the one she had received for 1935's Dangerous, but although she was nominated another eight times, she never won again.

The Oscar, which is expected to fetch between $150,000 and $250,000, is just one item of Davis memorabilia which is to be auctioned, other items include scripts, photographs, books and clothing. Part of the proceeds will benefit the Bette Davis Foundation which provides financial support for aspiring young actors.

The record price for an Oscar, or any piece of Hollywood memorabilia, is the $1.54m that Michael Jackson paid for Gone with the Wind's Best Picture Academy Award.

 More information about Bette Davis.

fields.headline: Shortcuts
fields.trailText: Oversubscribed: Adidas | Overexposed: Amusing ties | Overheard: Rules | Pretend you know all about: Hussein at Hakkasan
fields.byline: Charlie Porter, Jess Cartner-Morley and Rachel Garnett
fields.body:
Oversubscribed: Adidas

Whether it is through choice or coincidence, you can't get much hotter than Adidas. Through its catwalk collaborations, whether it be with John Galliano for spring/summer, or Yohji Yamamoto for autumn/winter, the sportswear brand has proven that it can keep pace with the quickest minds in fashion.

At Galliano, Adidas was behind the football boots and shinpads worn by his Jesus-as-soccer-star models. At Yamamoto, as well as providing the red-soled sneakers, Adidas's trademarked three stripes kept emerging through the entire collection, looking best on the arm of bomber jackets.

These clothes are for inspiration rather than purchase, but in the real world, Adidas is stepping up the pace with its heavily advertised Martina Hingis tennis tops with those famously lopsided sleeves.

When Hingis first wore the outfit at the Australian Open, the one sleeve to the elbow, the other to the wrist looked ridiculous as well as impractical (it apparently helped her out with her ball control, it didn't help us concentrate on her play). But during the recent round of catwalk collections, labels such as Helmut Lang and Versus started to play around with lop-sided sleeves, and suddenly this kind of off-kilter wasn't so offputting.

Overexposed: Amusing ties

The modern politico's penchant for image consultants gets a bad press. However, news of Bill Clinton's latest shopping spree suggests that we should be grateful to these people, for shielding us from the grisly horror that is the fashion sense of powerful, wealthy, confident men.

Now that he is off the presidential leash, Clinton has been flexing his style-muscles with a spot of shopping at Heathrow's terminal 3, picking up two silk ties, including a lime-green one with frogs on that he liked so much that he took off his own tie on the spot, wearing his purchase as he left the Hermès store.

Now, being Hermès, the tie is about as subtle and inoffensive as lime, frog ties get. And arguably, airport purchases shouldn't be held against you, even in cases of crimes against fashion. The yawning tedium of terminal time, the paucity of choice on offer, the possibility of spilling a pre take-off Bloody Mary down your front - the excuses for misguided purchases are endless. Nonetheless, making a beeline for a frog tie in a store of the calibre of Hermès is the fashion equivalent of ordering chips in Nobu. It doesn't exactly reek of good taste.

What's more, using novelty ties to express the wearer's fun-loving personality is a misguided and abhorrent form of deviance that has gone on too long and must be stopped. Is this man intent on setting a bad example to the world's impressionable youth?

 Tie, £65 from Hermès (or £58.73 tax-free from Heathrow). Enquiries 020-7823 1014.

Overheard: Rules

The rules being, "Follow, behave or get the hell out but I take the credit card". Surrendered wives are so last week: try the latest tactic for shopping trips with reluctant males. He will secretly love the new dominant you. Don't forget to make him carry the bags as well.

Pretend you know all about: Hussein at Hakkasan

Being a waitress has never been so fashionable, but we are not talking about donning a greasy apron for the local caff. Lucky table servers at Hakkasan, the new restaurant from the founder of Wagamama, will be clad in Husssein Chalayan.

Hussein, who has had a rough time of late with a dramatic plunge from the black into the red, shows that he might not be a financial whizz kid, but he can still bring glamour to the most unlikely places. The uniform has all the Hussein trademarks, a keyhole-collar blouse with three-quarter-length tulip-shaped sleeves, and a fantastically tailored skirt.

Staff will never have to worry about what to wear after work. All they need is a pair of cone heels and hey presto! - or should that be hey pesto - the perfect night-out-on-the-tiles look. Customers will have to look very cutting edge to compete with the waitresses in the fashion stakes.

 Hakkasan, 8 Hanway Place, London W1 (020-7927 0700).

webTitle: Sunshine state leans to the left

fields.headline: Sunshine state leans to the left
fields.standfirst: The words 'election' and 'Florida' might send you running, reports Martin Kettle, but you better get used to them
fields.trailText: The words 'election' and 'Florida' might send you running, reports Martin Kettle, but you better get used to them
fields.body:
It would be understandable if you never wanted to see the words Florida and election in the same sentence ever again.

But it is not a wish you are likely to see come true, though perhaps not for the reason you think, so you had better read on.

This week, the Miami Herald and USA Today newspapers produced the results of the latest - but by no means the last - of the many post-election surveys into what might have been on November 7.

In their survey, the two newspapers looked at more 61,000 uncounted Florida ballot papers, the so-called "undervotes" that never made it into the final disputed tally because of those hanging, dimpled or pregnant chads of infamous memory.

Puncturing one of the Democrats' most precious myths, the recount found that George Bush would have won a complete hand count in Florida if the counting standard advocated by Al Gore had been followed last year.

Instead of the officially certified 537-vote margin by which Bush won the state - and thus the presidency - Bush would have won by 1,665 votes, the survey concludes.

End of story? Game, set and match to Bush? Not so fast. For if the recount had taken place and had followed the counting standard favoured - if that's the word, which it isn't - by the Bush camp during the 36-day battle for Florida, then Gore would have won. By three votes. Talk about a squeaker.

That's not all, though. The Miami Herald/USA Today survey is far from being the last word on the disputed count, whichever of its findings you choose to believe. Right now, there is a further, bigger and still more painstaking survey under way, sponsored by such aristocrats of American journalism as the New York Times, the Washington Post and CNN.

The results of that survey are expected some time later this month. They will take into account not just the "undervotes" but also the "overvotes", in which - remember the Palm Beach 18,000? - lots of voters punched more than one name on the ballot paper. The word on the grapevine is that this survey will show a decisive Gore victory.

Well, perhaps it will and perhaps it won't. On one level, of course, it simply does not matter any longer. George Bush was declared the winner in Florida back in December, and nothing is going to undeclare his victory. In the view of a lot of people - mostly Republicans, for obvious reasons - it's time to accept the outcome and move on.

But this is where the inescapability of the Florida election issue takes the unexpected turn which I mentioned at the start. Last week, the United States Census Bureau published the results of the 2000 head count for Florida. Here, as in several other states - and, indeed, in the US as a whole - the big story was the dramatic increase in the Hispanic population, a change which is changing the face of America itself.

In Florida, the rise and rise of the Hispanic population is as pronounced as anywhere in the country. There is not a single county among Florida's 67 counties in which the Hispanic population rose by less than 30 per cent in the preceding decade. The increase was heavy in our old favourites Broward (up 151 per cent), Palm Beach (up 111 per cent) and Miami-Dade (up 35 per cent), but it was even heavier in the counties in the middle of the state, around Orlando and Tampa, like Orange county (up 159 per cent), Osceola (up 294 per cent) and De Soto (up 251 per cent).

These steep growth curves are set to continue for many years to come. The important thing to notice - and you can see it from the selection of counties mentioned above - is that the traditional Hispanic centres like Dade (where 57 per cent of the inhabitants are now Hispanic) are not the areas of fastest growth. Politically, that distinction is very important, because it underscores that the rapid transformation of Florida's population is coming not from the Cubans of Dade but from the non-Cubans elsewhere.

Boil it all down, and what you have is a state which is moving inexorably from the hands of the Republicans (who win among the non-Hispanic whites and among the Cubans) towards the Democrats (whose greatest strength lies among the blacks and the non-Cuban Hispanics). In each presidential election from 1972 to 1988, the Republican candidate held Florida with an average of 60 per cent of the vote. In 1992, George Bush Sr just held on against Bill Clinton, but in 1996 Clinton became the first Democrat in a generation to win Florida. Last year, the state was in effect a dead heat.

But the trend is clear. Florida is leaning to the left. It has become a swing state. And because it is a big state - don't forget those 25 electoral college votes - it is now the most important one. As Ronald Brownstein of the Los Angeles Times pointed out this week, "Florida is simply the state most likely to tilt the overall result toward the winner."

The 2000 election may have been a mess, but it didn't lie. Florida was the battleground state of the 2000 election because it is now the battleground state of any presidential election. So, you had better get used to it. You aren't going to hear less about Florida in elections to come. You are going to hear a lot lot more.

webTitle: Foot and mouth in the media

fields.headline: Day 46: foot and mouth in the media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk keeps you informed with a daily briefing on the press coverage of foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText:
Day 46: The Independent leads on the tourist crisis, with the headline 'Tourist income down 80% in worst-hit areas'.
Special report: foot and mouth in the media
fields.body:
The Independent
The Independent leads on the tourist crisis, with the headline "Tourist income down 80% in worst-hit areas". The crisis is said to be costing the industry at least £200m a week.

The Daily Telegraph
The crisis is back at the top of the news agenda. The paper splashes on the damage done by the government's week-long delay in tackling the crisis. A Telegraph investigation has shown there was a defeatist attitude within the Ministry of Agriculture.

The Times
Again a lead story. The epidemic will cost the British tourist industry at least £5bn by September.

The Guardian
The government hopes to rescue the tourist by handing over loans of £120m. Foot and mouth coverage is relegated to page eight of today's paper.

The Sun
A foot and mouth slaughterman was killed yesterday by the same bolt-gun used to cull the animals. Police are investigating the possibility of a disagreement with a colleague.

The Mirror
Tony Blair is ready to declare victory over the crisis within a week.

fields.headline: Russia's campaign for Milosevic
fields.standfirst: Kremlin officials seem to have a selective memory where the former Yugoslav president is concerned, says Ian Traynor
fields.trailText: Kremlin officials seem to have a selective memory where the former Yugoslav president is concerned, says Ian Traynor.
fields.body:
The arrest of Slobodan Milosevic in Belgrade has left Moscow tilting at windmills, a terminal blow to a decade-long policy of mollycoddling the architect of Yugoslavia's destruction in the name of preserving it. Moscow is finding it hard to take.

Just as the war crimes tribunal in The Hague goes from strength to strength, the Kremlin is stepping up a campaign, at least rhetorically, to have the trial closed down. If Milosevic is to be tried at all, then it should be by his own people, Russian politicians insist - just as the probability of the ex-president being handed over to the international court increases.

No outside interference in Yugoslavia, Moscow demands, just as international pressure is ratcheted up and, indeed, an American deadline triggers the raid on the Milosevic villa.

The knack for bad timing is uncanny. If Moscow's position during last October's Serbian revolution was divided and hesitant, its current policy towards Yugoslavia appears ambivalent, confused, and indignant, reflecting perhaps more broadly Russia's overall foreign policy under President Vladimir Putin.

Any figures in Belgrade exhibiting anti-westernism enjoy knee-jerk support in Moscow, just as much of Mr Putin's frantic global roadshow exhibits little purpose apart from getting up the noses of the Americans on the principle that my enemy's enemy is my friend - hence recent top-level talks between the Kremlin and, say, Cuba, North Korea, and Iran.

Russia might be a permanent UN security council member and party to the establishment of The Hague tribunal. But a senior foreign ministry official denounces it as ''illegal'', a political ''anti-Serb'' court that should be abolished. That Dario Kordic, the Bosnian Croat leader, gets 25 years in The Hague as the most senior political figure to be sentenced there is blithely ignored. That General Tihomir Blaskic, the Bosnian Croat military commander, gets 45 years for war crimes is similarly brushed aside.

If the wars in Yugoslavia began in 1991 and proceeded from Croatia to Bosnia to Kosovo, climaxing with Nato's 78-day bombardment of Serbia in 1999, it often seems, to listen to the Russian Duma, that the war started only with Nato in 1999.

The Hague tribunal, said Gennady Seleznev, the Duma speaker, should put Nato and not Milosevic in the dock. ''Then it will be clear who is the criminal and who is the hero.''

Belgrade would be making a serious mistake to hand Milosevic over to the tribunal, added Dmitry Rogozin, head of the parliament's foreign affairs committee, because such action would ''legalise the spring of 1999 and justify Nato's aggression against Yugoslavia''.

Bosnia's four-year war, its 200,000 dead, its two million uprooted civilians are conveniently forgotten, seen as somehow separate. In his defence plea to the investigating magistrate from his prison cell in Belgrade, Milosevic for the first time admitted secretly funding the wars in Croatia and Bosnia in 1991-95.

In other words, the resources facilitating the flattening of Vukovar, the 40-month siege of Sarajevo, the massacre of Srebrenica, and the gulag of the Banja Luka region came from Milosevic's secret war chest. And that's the case for the defence!

But Milosevic's thuggish son, Marko, fearful of returning home to a lynching party, continues to enjoy Russian hospitality, while the ex-president's brother, Borislav, till recently the Yugoslav ambassador in Moscow, is a regular on radio phone-ins here and a prized party guest for the political and diplomatic elite.

His farewell bash in Moscow as ambassador was attended by a roll-call of the great and the good from the foreign ministry, the parliament, the Kremlin, the Orthodox church hierarchy.

A liberal Moscow newspaper noted this week that the Kremlin had blown it in Belgrade, that with Serbia's realignment towards the West, Moscow was having difficulty accepting its growing loss of influence in the Balkans. Hence the indignation, the frequent sense of feeling affronted.

This assessment may be premature given Yugoslav president Vojislav Kostunica's visceral anti-westernism and the common grudges nursed both in Belgrade and Moscow towards the west. But the Segodnya newspaper's view is likely to prove correct.

Even Milosevic, especially Milosevic, through all the black years of his rule, hungrily craved the attention of the Americans, not the Russians. He may have cynically played on specious notions of pan-Slav brotherhood to flatter the Russians and to keep channels open when he was an international pariah. But it was Richard Holbrooke, not Viktor Chernomyrdin, with whom Milosevic wanted to negotiate.

webTitle: FT cuts online jobs in quest to break even

fields.headline: FT cuts online jobs in quest to break even
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
More net news
Read the FT memo
fields.trailText: The Financial Times yesterday announced plans for a 10% reduction in its online workforce, writes David Teather.
fields.body:
The Financial Times group yesterday announced plans for a 10% reduction in its online workforce as it struggles to make its internet business reach break even by the end of next year.

The 40 job losses are largely among back office staff including marketing and product development. There will be eight editorial job losses at FT Yourmoney, which will be merged with the personal finance operation of the Financial Times newspaper.

The group employs 350 online staff on websites including the flagship FT.com, FT Careerpoint, Economist.com and FT Marketwatch. Another, less quantifiable number work across print and online operations.

An internal memo from Stephen Hill, chief executive of the FT Group, said the economic climate highlighted the need to continue cutting costs by integrating the newspaper and online operations.

Consultation with staff will take place over the next month.

"Since August last year we have been carefully integrating our internet editorial and advertisement sales operations with those of the newspaper. And we have seen how we have become more efficient by doing so," the memo read.

Mr Hill said the company was still confident that FT.com would break even by the end of 2002. The memo said the company would also benefit from reduction in marketing and technology costs related to start-up of the online businesses.

Pearson, which owns the FT, recently said it invested £113m in the newspaper group's internet operations last year. The wider group invested £196m, with the remainder accounted for by Pearson's online education business.

FT.com achieved revenue of £18m last year, the majority of which was generated by advertising. The company expects licensing of content and new premium services such as FT mobile and FT Careerpoint to account for half of revenues by the end of next year.

FT.com attracts some 2m unique monthly users, up by 50% on this time last year.

webTitle: Man arrested over Lucie Blackman murder

fields.headline: Man arrested over Lucie Blackman murder
fields.trailText: Police in Japan have arrested their prime suspect over the death of British hostess Lucie Blackman, who disappeared on July 1 last year while working as a bar hostess in Kokyo's Roppongi entertainment district.
fields.body:
Police in Japan have arrested their prime suspect over the death of British hostess Lucie Blackman, who disappeared on July 1 last year while working as a bar hostess in Kokyo's Roppongi entertainment district.

Joji Obara, 48, was arrested on suspicion of kidnap, assault resulting in death, mutilation of a body, and abandoning a body, said police in Tokyo. Ms Blackman's dismembered body was discovered in February.

Mr Obara, a wealthy businessman, has been in police custody since October on charges of drugging and raping other Western women.

He was formally arrested at 9.30am local time (2.30am BST) today and is expected to be charged in the next few days.

Ms Blackman, 22, from Sevenoaks, Kent, was working in Japan to fund a trip around Asia. She was last seen by a friend as she set off for a drive to the ocean with a male client.

Police found her remains on February 8 in a cave on a beach at Miura, at the mouth of Tokyo Bay - near Mr Obara's seaside home.

Police first found feet, a hand and a section of leg in the cave. They then found Ms Blackman's head, encased in concrete.

Last week 300 family and friends attended her funeral at St Nicholas Parish Church in Chislehurst, Kent.

fields.headline: Media target small tracks
fields.trailText: The GG-Media group have launched a £67m media rights deal aimed at Britain's smaller independent racecourses.
fields.body:
The GG-Media group have launched a £67m media rights deal aimed at Britain's smaller independent racecourses.

Owned by investment house Fleming Family & Partners and Towcester chairman Lord Hesketh's family and associates, the group is offering a five-year scheme for the rights belonging to 26 tracks.

All but two of Britain's 59 racecourses have signed an exclusivity agreement with the Go Racing consortium.

However, some smaller courses believe that deal has been targeted at the major tracks and does not reflect the value of their media rights.

GG-Media Ltd chairman Tony Rice said: "GG-Media is offering much greater value for the independent racecourses' media rights than any other party."

webTitle: Religion and violence on Pakistan's streets

fields.headline: Religion and violence on Pakistan's streets
fields.standfirst: As Shia Muslims demonstrate their faith, Rory McCarthy looks at the growing sectarian violence in Pakistan
fields.trailText: As Shia Muslims demonstrate their faith, Rory McCarthy looks at the growing sectarian violence in Pakistan.
fields.body:
The crowd cleared and a group of men, naked from the waist up, stepped forward and began beating their chests. As the chanting grew louder, they unwrapped bundles of steel knives attached to chains and began beating themselves on their backs, shouting "Hussain, Hussain".

The blood-soaked ceremony is an annual ritual for Shia Muslims across the world, but in Pakistan this year it comes at a time of renewed sectarian tension.

In a string of violent outbreaks between the Sunni community and the minority Shias - who make up 20% of Pakistan's 140m population - more than 50 people have been killed in the past two months.

In Karachi on Wednesday, a bus driver found a bomb under his front seat and managed to defuse it. A Shia procession was due to pass by minutes later.

Just 24 hours earlier, a former leader of a Shia Muslim group was shot dead by gunmen on a motorbike, near Multan, in the centre of the country.

Reports say that there are up to 10,000 trained sectarian terrorists in Pakistan, supplied with arms from caches in mosques across the country.

Riot police and heavily armed soldiers are now patrolling Rawalpindi and other cities across the country in a bid to prevent further attacks. In Lahore alone, 10,000 soldiers were on duty for the Shia procession - the country's biggest.

The procession of mourners dressed in black shalwar kameez suits commemorates the martyrdom of Imam Hussain, the grandson of the prophet Mohammad, who died in 680AD in Karbala, in modern-day Iraq.

The Ashura ceremony is the culmination of 10 days of mourning in Muharram, the first month of the Muslim year.

But for all the recent upsurge in violence, most in the crowd at Rawalpindi appeared unconcerned by the threat.

"This day is most sacred for us. We are ready to die for this day," said Ahmed Ali, a 26-year-old web page designer from Islamabad.

"Things are becoming difficult now. The other sects are very organised and they think if they kill us they will go straight to heaven. But I don't think most people in Pakistan agree with them. For the past 50 years, we have lived peacefully in Pakistan. Why can't that continue?"

As the men beat deep cuts into their backs, women stood on the side of the road, dressed in black veils, beating their chests with the rest of the crowd.

At one point, a white horse - signifying that which Hussain rode in battle - was led into the centre of the crowd, and hands reached out to touch the animal.

Many of the men, already carrying scars on their backs from last year, came away with bloody wounds needing medical treatment. The knives ranged in size from just a few inches long to over a foot, and several young boys had joined in the self-flagellation.

Every few minutes, when a mourner's injuries appeared to become too serious, the crowd would push forward and wrestle the blades from his hand.

Across the border in Afghanistan, the hardline Sunni Muslim Taliban this week allowed Shias - again in the minority - to mark Ashura for the first time since they seized power nearly five years ago.

Many of Pakistan's most wanted Sunni sectarian terrorists are believed to be in hiding in Afghanistan, protected by their close links to the Taliban.

fields.headline: C5 boost for loss-making Civilian
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Channel 5 has given a boost to production outfit Civilian Content by recommissioning its Urban Gothic series, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Channel 5 has given a boost to the TV ambitions of production outfit Civilian Content by recommissioning its Urban Gothic series.

Civilian is better known for its film productions, but is keen to build up its presence in the more reliable TV programming business.

Today's announcement and recent appointment of former Channel 5 boss David Elstein to the board of the company are the first moves in Civilian's strategy of building "critical mass" in its TV operations.

"Our film activities are now fully integrated... We are now focusing management time on building critical mass in our television business," said Richard Holmes, managing director of Civilian.

The return of the Urban Gothic horror series was announced alongside full-year results which showed a pre-tax loss of £1.88m for 2000, against a deficit of £1.69m for the previous year.

Civilian's turnover soared from £626,000 to £4m thanks to last year's acquisitions of Gruber Films and the National Lottery-funded Film Consortium.

Over the next 12 months, Civilian will be releasing the eagerly awaited Madchester film 24 Hour Party People, Samuel L Jackson's vehicle 51st State and a snooker comedy featuring former EastEnders star Patsy Palmer.

webTitle: Leader: defeat illegal traffickers by liberalising immigration

fields.headline: How we can defeat illegal traffickers
fields.standfirst: Anyone with a romantic view of people smugglers would have had their illusions shattered by the shocking death of 58 illegal Chinese immigrants found in the back of a container lorry. The only way to avoid a repeat of this horrendous crime is to liberalise immigration
fields.trailText: Comment: Anyone with a romantic view of people smugglers would have had their illusions shattered by the shocking death of 58 illegal Chinese immigrants found in the back of a container lorry. The only way to avoid a repeat of this horrendous crime is to liberalise immigration.
fields.body:
Anyone with a romantic view of people smugglers would have had their illusions shattered by the shocking death of 58 illegal Chinese immigrants found in the back of a container lorry in Dover last year.

For the last six weeks, a Maidstone crown court jury has heard the callousness with which the lorry driver treated his human cargo. They were crammed so tightly into the truck that they each had only the space of an A4 sheet of paper in which to crouch. There were just four small containers of water for a nine-hour journey from Rotterdam. Their fate was sealed when the driver closed the one air vent in the back of his truck to ensure no ferry official heard their voices and caught him red-handed. But he knew the danger to which he was exposing them. A fellow gang driver had released his "cargo" on a similar run just two months earlier, when air in his truck ran out. Perry Wacker, the Dutch driver, was sentenced to 14 years in prison yesterday.

There are three lessons which can be drawn from this terrible event. First, there is nothing romantic about the organised gangs involved in the illegal immigrant trade. They are ruthless and extremely well-organised. The 60 Chinese immigrants came from a remote Chinese province by plane from Beijing to Belgrade, and then via road and air through Hungary, Austria, France, the Netherlands and Belgium. They paid up to £20,000 each for the journey - some up front and the rest promised over a period of years. In other words, slave labourers for the organised gang. The ruthlessness of such gangs knows no limits. In the last three years in Italy, at least 200 would-be immigrants have died at sea in collisions with custom boats or after being thrown overboard. Five years ago almost 300 died in a single incident.

A second lesson is that the heavy sentence handed down yesterday will not deter the trade. Tighter laws and heavier penalties introduced after Dover failed too. As David Wilson, head of intelligence for the immigration services, has noted: "The harder we make it, the more lucrative we make it for organised gangs." People smuggling is still not as profitable as drug smuggling, but an estimated 7m illegal immigrants are brought to Europe every year. Estimates of total turnover for the gangs worldwide ranges between £8bn and £20bn.

So what will reduce the illegal flow? That is the third lesson. Fifteen years ago there was no organised illegal trade. It emerged as Europe became ever more restrictive towards refugees and immigrants. Yet across Europe, ministers are complaining about labour shortages and the need for more economic migrants. Germany has just introduced a green card scheme, under which more economic migrants will be accepted. British ministers - Jack Straw and Barbara Roche - tried to start a grown up debate last year about the skills shortage in the UK. The one positive result of the Dover tragedy was the way in which it rallied tabloid support for an increase in controlled immigration. Even the Sun discovered "rich nations need immigrants if we are to prosper".

The emerging consensus is welcome. Awkward challenges remain. There are shortages of unskilled as well as skilled workers. Third world countries must not be robbed of their skilled labour - teachers, social workers, nurses, and doctors are in even shorter supply there. A common European approach is crucial. At least this last challenge is already agreed. The 1997 Amsterdam treaty conceded power to create a common immigration policy to the European parliament. It has already begun work on the challenge.

webTitle: £120m in loans offered as tourism lifeline

fields.headline: £120m in loans offered as tourism lifeline
fields.standfirst:
Drop of up to 80% in Cumbria and 10% across UK

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The government will today announce £120m of guaranteed loans to the hard pressed tourist industry. Ministers confirmed yesterday that bookings are down 10% across the country and up to 80% in the worst hit areas of Cumbria and Devon.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, John Vidal and Michael White
fields.body:
The government will today announce £120m of guaranteed loans to the hard pressed tourist industry. Ministers confirmed yesterday that bookings are down 10% across the country and up to 80% in the worst hit areas of Cumbria and Devon.

The loans package is designed to tide the industry over its growing cash crisis, but is unlikely to be seen as enough by the many small rural tourist businesses on the edge of collapse.

The English regional tourist boards estimate they are losing £200m a week in revenue, and the figure could be four times greater over Easter, which often represents as much as 10% of the industry's annual takings.

The loans will be announced by the culture secretary, Chris Smith, alongside £6m in subsidies to increase marketing by the English Tourism Council and the British Tourism Authority.

Mr Smith warned the cabinet yesterday that the danger of "significantly reduced" bookings for the summer was now serious. The package has been worked up in urgent talks between the Department of Culture, Downing Street and the Treasury. The money is on top of existing rate relief and VAT holidays.

The Conservatives are likely to claim that the package follows their own call for interest free loans of up to £10,000. The tourist industry will claim the assistance is dwarfed by the huge compensation payments being prepared for farmers.

But as President Bush told the Scottish first minister, Henry McLeish, in Washington that he "empathised with the UK" - and the European parliament snubbed Britain by voting overwhelmingly to call for a review of the non-vaccination policy - there were clear signs that government was becoming deeply frustrated at local councils in unaffected parts of the country.

Mr Blair has already met council leaders to urge them to take a common sense approach to footpath closures but large areas still have blanket bans.

The government found an unexpected ally in Sir Sean Connery, who was in Washington. "You will find our majestic countryside open," he said. Agriculture minister Nick Brown, who told cabinet members that he would be spending much of the Easter holidays at his ministry's headquarters, advised caution however, saying that the epidemic might be levelling off but no risks could be taken.

"This is a very serious outbreak which is likely to have a long tail," he told MPs as some pressed for faster cull-and-bury policies and others urged relaxation of restrictions on the movement of animals in unaffected areas.

The problem facing vets was multiplied by the fact that for every reported case of foot and mouth confirmed, there were two that turned out to be false alarms, Mr Brown said.

Compensation payments to farmers were now approaching £600 million, Downing Street said.

About 1,600 soldiers are working on foot and mouth in 14 areas of the country.

The tourist industry will claim the assistance is dwarfed by the huge compensation payments being prepared for farmers. But as President Bush told the Scottish first minister, Henry McLeish, in Washington that he "empathised with the UK" - and the European parliament snubbed Britain by voting overwhelmingly to call for a review of the non-vaccination policy - there were clear signs that government was becoming deeply frustrated at local councils in unaffected parts of the country. Mr Blair has already met council leaders to urge them to take a common sense approach to footpath closures but large areas still have blanket bans. The government found an unexpected ally in Sir Sean Connery, who was in Washington. "You will find our majestic countryside open," he said. Agriculture minister Nick Brown, who told cabinet members that he would be spending much of the Easter holidays at his ministry's headquarters, advised caution however, saying that the epidemic might be levelling off but no risks could be taken. "This is a very serious outbreak which is likely to have a long tail," he told MPs as some pressed for faster cull-and-bury policies and others urged relaxation of restrictions on the movement of animals in unaffected areas. The problem facing vets was multiplied by the fact that for every reported case of foot and mouth confirmed, there were two that turned out to be false alarms, Mr Brown said. Compensation payments to farmers were now approaching £600 million, Downing Street said. About 1,600 soldiers are working on foot and mouth in 14 areas of the country. fields.headline: Levi clashes with Tesco over court ruling
fields.trailText: Levi has hit out at Tesco claiming it 'misunderstood' a European court ruling about supermarket sales of its jeans. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Jeans giant Levi has hit out at Tesco claiming it had "misunderstood" a European court ruling about sales of its product in the supermarket chain.

The two companies were at loggerheads all day over who had won out in the battle over the sale of Levi jeans in Tesco stores.

Tesco director John Gildersleeve hailed as a victory for consumers the European court ruling that brand owners do not have unlimited rights over their brands.

"Brands like Levi have been given a clear message today that their policies to keep prices high will no longer be tolerated in Europe," he said.

But Alan Christie, head of public affairs at Levi Strauss, said Tesco had simply misunderstood the ruling.

"We think it was a good decision," he said. "The court ruled that the rights of the trader need to be taken into account, but that only applies if the brand owner gives up their right."

Mr Christie accused the supermarket giant of exploiting Levi's brand to build up its own business.

The jeans giant took Tesco to court in an attempt to stop it from importing cheaper Levis from outside the European Union to sell at lower prices. Levi claimed the practice was against EU law.

The decision marks a half-way stage in a four-year fight between Britain's biggest supermarket chain and the US jeans maker.

Today's ruling from a judge at the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg leaves the matter unresolved and the case will now return to the British courts in the summer.

But it represents a victory for Tesco, which can carry on selling the jeans until a final decision is reached.

Levi claims Tesco is debasing its brand by selling the jeans as a commodity.

But Tesco says it is just giving consumers what they want.

webTitle: Comment: World poor in sale of the 21st century

fields.headline: World poor in sale of the 21st century
fields.standfirst:
Democratic rights are a high price to pay for western free trade

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: Democratic rights are a high price to pay for western free trade.
fields.body:
Trade ministers from the 34 countries negotiating the Free Trade Area of the Americas will today meet in Buenos Aires. Many in Latin America predict that the ministers will be greeted with protests much larger than the ones that exploded in Seattle in 1999.

The FTAA's cheerleaders like to pretend that their only critics are white college kids from Harvard and McGill who just don't understand how much "the poor" are "clamouring" for the FTAA. Will this public display of Latin American opposition to the trade deal change all that?

Don't be silly.

Mass protests in the developing world don't register in our discussions about trade here in the west. No matter how many people take to the streets of Buenos Aires, Mexico City or Sao Paulo, defenders of corporate-driven globalisation just keep on insisting that every possible objection lobbed their way was dreamed up in Seattle, by somebody with newly matted dreadlocks slurping a latte.

When we talk about trade, we often focus on who is getting richer and who is getting poorer. But there is another divide at play: which countries are presented as diverse, complicated political landscapes where citizens have a range of divergent views, and which countries seem to speak on the world stage in an ideological monotone.

In western Europe, the foot and mouth inferno puts the entire model of export-oriented industrial agriculture on trial. In North America, we are finally hearing the debates about whether or not more of the same model of deregulation, privatisation and liberalisation will protect their heath and education and water systems.

And yet such diversity of public opinion is rarely attributed to citizens of third world countries. Instead, they are lumped into one homogenous voice, channelled by dubiously elected politicians or better yet, ousted ones like Mexico's Ernesto Zedillo, now calling for a global campaign against "globophobes".

The truth is that no one can speak on behalf of Latin America's 500m inhabitants, least of all Mr Zedillo, whose defeat was in part a repudiation of Nafta's record. All over the Americas, market liberalisation is a subject of extreme dispute.

The debate is not over whether foreign investment and trade are desirable - Latin America and the Caribbean are already organised into regional trading groups such as Mercosur. The debate is about democracy: what terms and conditions will poor countries be told they must meet to qualify for trade and investment?

For the past two decades, these terms and conditions have been negotiated and enforced by the IMF and the World Bank in exchange for loans. Social services have been privatised, user fees introduced, agricultural subsidies cut (while richer countries kept theirs), hard-won land redistribution programs abandoned, and the minimum wage has been controlled - all in the name of becoming "investment ready".

Argentina, the host of the current FTAA ministers' meeting, is currently in open revolt over massive cuts to social spending - almost $8bn over three years - that have been introduced to qualify for an IMF loan package. Three cabinet ministers have resigned, unions staged a general strike, and university instructors moved their classes to the streets.

Though anger at wrenching austerity measures has focused primarily on the IMF, it is rapidly expanding to encompass trade deals such as the proposed FTAA. The Zapatistas began their uprising on January 1 1994 - the day the North American Free Trade Agreement came into force.

Seven years later, 75% of the population of Mexico lives in poverty, real wages are lower than they were in 1994, and unemployment is rising.

No wonder the Zapatistas were able to draw 150,000 supporters to the streets of Mexico City last month. And despite the claims that the rest of Latin America is clamouring for a Nafta to call its own, the central labour associations of Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay - representing 20m workers - have come out against the plan. They are now calling for nationwide referendums on membership in the FTAA.

Brazil, meanwhile, has threatened to boycott the summit altogether, furious at Canada's dirty trade war and wary that the FTAA will contain protections for drug companies that will threaten its visionary public health policy of providing free generic Aids drugs to anyone who needs them.

Defenders of free trade would have us believe in a facile equation of Trade = Democracy. The people who will greet American trade ministers on the streets of Buenos Aires next week are posing a more complex and challenging calculation: how much democracy should they be asked to give up in exchange for trade?

 Naomi Klein writes a fortnightly column

webTitle: Man shot in head with bolt gun dies

fields.headline: Man shot in head with bolt gun dies
fields.trailText: A slaughterman died in hospital last night after having been shot with a gun used to kill animals at a foot and mouth burial pit.
fields.body:
A slaughterman died in hospital last night after having been shot with a gun used to kill animals at a foot and mouth burial pit.

Steven Smart, 28, from St Leonards in East Sussex, was culling healthy sheep on Wednesday at Great Orton airfield in Cumbria, when a three-inch retractable rod was fired into his head from a bolt gun used to kill livestock.

He died at Newcastle general hospital at 5pm yesterday.

A former butcher, he was understood to have taken the culling job after being made redundant a month ago as a result of the foot and mouth crisis.

Police have arrested a slaughterman aged 37 from Warwickshire on suspicion of grievous bodily harm with intent. A third man, who witnessed the incident, has been treated for shock.

Cumbria police said last night that their investigation was continuing; nothing had been ruled out, including the possibility of a prank gone wrong. A spokesman said: "There are people we have yet to speak to. It would be wrong to pre-judge what they are going to say. I can confirm that we are examining weapons involved in the slaughter of animals."

The three men were working under army direction at Great Orton airfield. Wearing regulation white suits and supervised by Maff vets, they were in the centre of the slaughter line where sheep are herded into pens before being led to a tent to be killed.

Hours before Mr Smart was shot, Brigadier Alex Birtwistle, head of the army operation in Cumbria, and Jane Brown, regional head of Maff, had visited the sited had concluded that safety and competence levels were excellent.

webTitle: GPs told to boycott form-filling chores

fields.headline: GPs told to boycott form-filling chores
fields.standfirst: Doctors' first work to rule protest 'within law'
fields.trailText: The first work to rule by family doctors was agreed yesterday by the British Medical Association in protest against an "unsustainable" burden of administrative work that is taking time away from patient care.
fields.body:
The first work to rule by family doctors was agreed yesterday by the British Medical Association in protest against an "unsustainable" burden of administrative work that is taking time away from patient care.

The association's GPs committee told its 32,000 members in England and Wales to boycott the form filling needed to comply with national strategies for cancer, heart disease and care of older people.

Simon Fradd, the committee's deputy chairman, said the move amounted to "non-compliance" with government directions, and it was likely to be the first of a series of actions in protest at excessive workload.

The boycott did not count as industrial action because at least 95% of GPs did not have these administrative duties in their contracts, he said. About 1,000 GPs on personal contracts would be exempted if the boycott required them to breach their conditions. There was therefore no requirement for a ballot under industrial relations law.

"We have reached the stage where we believe it is in the public interest to cut out work that is not essential to make sure the job can be done safely in terms of clinical care," Dr Fradd said.

GPs would be told to stop writing reports for health authorities and primary care trusts, as the government required to demonstrate improvements in programmes to combat killer diseases and raise the standard of care for older people.

For example, they would follow government guidelines for screening patients for high blood pressure but would not collate the data to provide ministers with the evidence to score political points.

The move was a further embarrassment for ministers, who are braced for a BMA offensive during the general election campaign.

The association is preparing a patients' dossier showing the suffering caused in the NHS when doctors are forced to cut corners.

The BMA said the "national service frameworks" for priority NHS work were "laudable in their intention to raise the standards of care for patients" but gave rise to an unsustainable burden on GPs to monitor and report on the delivery of that care.

GPs should do their utmost to fulfil the clinical aspects of the government's plan but stop taking time away from patient care to meet the associated requests for information.

"When patients are ill, they want to be able to see their doctors, not to find that their GP is having to undertake administrative tasks to satisfy a government that has steadfastly refused to listen," the BMA said.

Dr Fradd said the government's NHS plan was raising patients' expectations about what GPs could deliver. "We are seeking ways to reduce workload to give a better deal to the public.

"Nobody can give consistently safe care in consultations lasting a national average of eight minutes. You can't do a proper job for patients in that time. We have to find ways to reduce hours spent on work that is not relevant to patient care."

The GPs' action follows a warning from Ian Bogle, the BMA chairman, that patients' safety was being put at risk because doctors did not have enough time for consultations.

"Consulting times are getting lower. Therefore, patients are not getting the quality of service they need and deserve and, from the doctors' point of view, if they are cutting corners - and they may well be in short consultations - they are putting their careers at risk," he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, said: "I am increasingly concerned that doctors are being forced into unsafe medical practices in order to meet arbitrary government targets.

"I agree with Dr Bogle that rushed consultations and less time with patients increases the risk of mistakes being made."

fields.headline: One-year deal suits Sheringham
fields.trailText: The sportswear company Nike has denied that it interferes in the selection of the Brazilian national team, which it sponsors, writes Daniel Taylor.
fields.body:
Teddy Sheringham has become the latest Manchester United player to commit his future to Old Trafford after indicating that he is willing to accept the club's offer of a new one-year contract.

After emerging as United's leading scorer this season Sheringham was thought to have been holding out for a two-year deal, but the 35-year-old said yesterday that he is happy with a short-term deal.

"There are things the club need to sort out but a one-year deal suits me. That would keep me quite happy because if I am not in the team, I would not want to stay," he said.

"You have to take these things as they come at my age. A year-on-year situation is quite right and I am happy with things on that score."

Sheringham, who has been linked with moves to Tottenham, West Ham and Fulham, is expected to conclude negotiations within a few weeks, joining Jaap Stam, Ryan Giggs and Andy Cole in tying himself to the champions.

The sportswear company Nike has denied before a Brazilian parliament's commission of inquiry that it interferes in the selection of the national team, which it sponsors. The commission, which is investigating how much influence Nike holds over Brazil's national side, also heard that the company was happy with its investment in the team, even though it has caused controversy in the past.

Many Brazilians see the US$369m 10-year deal as an incursion into national sovereignty. The issue came to a head at the 1998 World Cup final when the striker Ronaldo, who has a personal contract with Nike, was picked to play for Brazil against France despite suffering a reported convulsive fit only hours earlier.

Ronaldo looked dazed and lethargic throughout the match, which the Brazilians lost 3-0. "The picking of players is under the exclusive control of the coach," Ingo Ostrowisky, Nike's communications manager in Brazil, told the commission.

webTitle: Motor racing: Teams force Kirch to crumble on pay TV

fields.headline: Teams force Kirch to crumble on pay TV
fields.trailText: The Kirch media group has moved quickly to head off the car makers' plan for a new formula one championship, writes Alan Henry.
fields.body:
The Kirch media group has moved quickly to head off the car makers' plan for a new formula one championship. Kirch has offered a 25% stake in the formula one side of its business to the car manufacturers, although the price has not been revealed. It has also offered veto rights to prevent the broadcasting of grands prix moving to pay TV.

Kirch has assured the manufacturers that it will continue its commitment to terrestrial television coverage beyond the expiry of the current Concorde agreement, which governs the sport, at the end of 2007.

Kirch's spokesman Hartmut Schultz said: "There are no plans to let formula one slip into pay TV." He said that Kirch wanted to keep formula one attractive to a large audience.

On Wednesday Paolo Cantarella, the chief executive officer of FIA, the world governing body, had indicated that the European car manufacturers would organise their own series as they were worried about the commercial implications of Kirch's recent acquisition of a controlling interest in Bernie Ecclestone's SLEC empire, which holds the commercial rights to the current world championship series.

The car makers were concerned that Kirch's commitment to pay-to-view broad-casting would undermine the global appeal of formula one by depriving terrestrial viewers of free access which is regarded as crucial in promoting their products. Kirch owns 75% of SLEC.

The current Concorde agreement contains a key requirement from the sport's governing body committing the commercial-rights holder - currently Ecclestone - to provide free television access. However, such assurances seem to offer only a limited solution.

The manufacturers are now determined to exact as much as possible in terms of concessions. For example, they will seek an increase in the 51% of commercial-rights income currently shared by the 11 teams. Ecclestone received the other 49%.

Cantarella elaborated on the decision to start an independent series, explaining that the manufacturers also wanted more control over the sport and saw it essential to keep it in the public eye.

"It is quite simple really," he told a meeting of the confederation of Italian industrialists in Rome. "The constructors are the protagonists in formula one, they provide the material for the sporting event and the spectacle. And so they would like to be able to run everything more directly with greater overall guarantees.

"We want formula one, together with its entire heritage, to continue with order, technological development, clarity of rules and maximum visibility. As you can see, the guarantees also involve the general public."

This speech echoed the sentiments of the Ferrari president Luca di Montezemolo who said just before last month's Australian grand prix: "We, the teams, are the players. And it is only right that we want a bigger slice of the commercial cake."

The teams refused to comment. That comes as no surprise. In the rain-swept paddock at Silverstone yesterday, where three of them were attempting to test, the notion of an independent, breakaway formula one series was being treated with a scepticism bordering on indulgent amusement.

Kirch has assured the manufacturers that it will continue its commitment to terrestrial television coverage beyond the expiry of the current Concorde agreement, which governs the sport, at the end of 2007. Kirch's spokesman Hartmut Schultz said: "There are no plans to let formula one slip into pay TV." He said that Kirch wanted to keep formula one attractive to a large audience. On Wednesday Paolo Cantarella, the chief executive officer of FIA, the world governing body, had indicated that the European car manufacturers would organise their own series as they were worried about the commercial implications of Kirch's recent acquisition of a controlling interest in Bernie Ecclestone's SLEC empire, which holds the commercial rights to the current world championship series. The car makers were concerned that Kirch's commitment to pay-to-view broad-casting would undermine the global appeal of formula one by depriving terrestrial viewers of free access which is regarded as crucial in promoting their products. Kirch owns 75% of SLEC. The current Concorde agreement contains a key requirement from the sport's governing body committing the commercial-rights holder - currently Ecclestone - to provide free television access. However, such assurances seem to offer only a limited solution. The manufacturers are now determined to exact as much as possible in terms of concessions. For example, they will seek an increase in the 51% of commercial-rights income currently shared by the 11 teams. Ecclestone received the other 49%. Cantarella elaborated on the decision to start an independent series, explaining that the manufacturers also wanted more control over the sport and saw it essential to keep it in the public eye. "It is quite simple really," he told a meeting of the confederation of Italian industrialists in Rome. "The constructors are the protagonists in formula one, they provide the material for the sporting event and the spectacle. And so they would like to be able to run everything more directly with greater overall guarantees. "We want formula one, together with its entire heritage, to continue with order, technological development, clarity of rules and maximum visibility. As you can see, the guarantees also involve the general public." This speech echoed the sentiments of the Ferrari president Luca di Montezemolo who said just before last month's Australian grand prix: "We, the teams, are the players. And it is only right that we want a bigger slice of the commercial cake." The teams refused to comment. That comes as no surprise. In the rain-swept paddock at Silverstone yesterday, where three of them were attempting to test, the notion of an independent, breakaway formula one series was being treated with a scepticism bordering on indulgent amusement.

fields.headline: Whimpering nation
fields.standfirst:
We see every mishap as a portent of doom. The message we are sending out is that we are as sick as our cows

Special report: what is Britain?
fields.trailText: We see every mishap as a portent of doom. The message we are sending out is that we are as sick as our cows.
fields.body:
This is a country on the verge of a nervous breakdown. The stiff upper lip is wobbling, hysteria is in the air. What are the symptoms? A national nervous reflex, an involuntary panic spasm that greets every event. Any minor setback sets off a crise de nerfs, a fit of the vapours turning any mishap into a crisis.

So it came to pass that a law was rushed through parliament this week postponing local elections never before cancelled in peace time. Why? Because 1.8% of the national herd has caught a disease lethal to neither man nor beast, while the whole of agriculture represents just 0.8% of GDP. A neurotic over-reaction caused filthy pyres which closed the countryside down, destroying tourism which has created a genuine calamity.

So it was with the Hatfield rail crash. A broken rail shattering into 300 fragments of steel came to symbolise the parlous 20-year decay of public services everywhere. Four people dead was a tragedy, sacrificed to the wanton privatisation of railways. That political disgrace has turned a sad episode into a genuine national disaster. Neurotic response brought national transport to its knees. Grotesque exaggeration of danger closed the railways forcing commuters to resort to the roads instead. (Some 3,400 are killed a year on roads.) Worse, it immobilised the country. A curious fatalism fell upon the passengers who ought to have rebelled far more vociferously than the fuel protesters.

Diana tears were bizarre, but since then national neurosis has seen twitchy sensation take over from reason and statistic time and again. Unfortunate incidents become omens and signs from the stars, signifying some bigger, scarier malaise. Every piece of bad luck or bad news is rolled up together as certain proof that the elements are against us. Protests by a handful of rogue dairy farmers and hauliers sent the country into paralysis, and now each crisis escalates. When things go wrong, as they do, it now has symbolic meaning. The doctor has no appointment for a week, the roads are gridlocked this morning, the circle line stopped. TB stalks school corridors and now half Beachy Head has fallen into the sea. Each one becomes more than a personal or national event - it is a portent.

Nations, like people, live in their heads and their imaginations as much as in the real world. Ideas and symbols matter. This Margaret Thatcher instinctively understood, it was her greatest political talent. Now Britain's self-image is flagging even as times are better than ever before for almost everyone, far better than in her day. Our clinical depression has no root in real facts and figures, only in a diseased imagination. But the psychosis is infectious, radiating out a message to the rest of the world: we are as sick as our cows.

An email, one among many, (some unprintable, catchlined "Eat shit, euro-scum", "Lady, you are a total moron" and the like) zaps across the Atlantic in response to my article on George Bush this week. Here's how we look to them: "Your whole infrastructure is decaying around you. Your crime is higher than ours. Your football hooligans are the recognised gold standard, the most loutish yobs this side of the Taliban. The British have lost their collective wits. Your whole country ground to a halt because a bubble-headed ditz of a princess committed involuntary suicide in a careening automobile with a man who was not her husband. Your tree and bunny huggers are out of control and Luddism is running riot. Until foot and mouth your national priority seemed to be banning of fox hunting... You get the idea?" Yes, alas, we do. There were many others in this vein.

From the other end of the political spectrum, add in a session I had in Glasgow this week with Tommy Sheridan MSP for the Scottish Socialist party, who follows in the rhetorical footsteps of many a red Clydesider. His eloquent tongue left no New Labour achievement untrashed, no sign of progress, all doom and calamity in a land of galloping inequality and social disease. Then a Dutch TV journalist calls to ask if there is any food left in the shops.

But even more unnerving, an email arrives from the London correspondent of the German Financial Times: "It seems to me that it really is five to 12 for Britain and that it will, in all probability, become a second-world country, sidelined in Europe, run down internally, insignificant politically and economically, a slum in which a few very rich people still lead a good life oblivious of the conditions of the rest..." It takes the breath away, leaves gasping paroxysms of panic. Time to take up your children and emigrate?

No, take a deep breath, calm down and realise that this is just what we are saying to ourselves, reverberating and exaggerating itself around the globe in distorting Chinese whispers. This is our own unreasonable neurosis and our worst midnight fears reflected back to us. Jitters and jumpiness combine with deep "nothing works" cynicism to paint a portrait of a nation in crisis. We are suffering from clinical political depression.

How did we fall into this melancholia? The Tory party may be in unelectable decay, but in its death throes its inordinately powerful press still has the capacity to poison the national air. If it can't win, it can still spoil, sour and frighten. By any objective measure, things are getting better with more money in almost every pocket, including benefits and pensions. This has been the most golden economic moment in living memory. What's more, at last serious money is there on the table for health, education and transport. But it has all taken too long, big numbers announced with scant change to be seen yet, results slow in coming. In public services, this is a fertile time to believe superstitiously that nothing makes any difference, nothing works. Things fall apart...

But does the centre hold? Up to a point. Tony Blair the touchy feely is a man of these times: his nose to the wind, he feels our hysteria. Whatever his rational cabinet might say, he knows by the pricking of his thumbs that the election must be postponed, not for good reasons but bowing to the national sentiment. And he was quite right, for these mood swings sweep all before them. Resis tance is useless. The question is, does he stop to ask himself why we are in this neurotic and irrational state? Or if there is anything he might do to stiffen the sinews, summon up the blood?

His third way is partly to blame for all this drift and wobble, leaving public sentiment to be blown about like dandelion seed. There is too little political rootedness, no clear markers of where we are headed and why. Clinton's woeful lack of legacy shows a golden economy is never enough without strong ideological leadership too. What is needed now is clarity of purpose and message, no more appeasement, but a manifesto of sufficient boldness to fill a political void that has turned us into a nation of hysterics.

The PCC has severed claims with the QueenÕs most senior media adviser as the row over the Sophie Wessex affair escalates. P1

Sophie Wessex's business partner, Murray Harkin may be forced to resign. P3

Millions tuned into EastEnders to discover it was Lisa who shot Phil. P7

Tesco claimed to have struck a blow for consumers yesterday when a court appeared to sanction its policy of selling cheap branded goods. P9

Business leaders discuss how Britain and its brands should be portrayed. P24

Yahoo! has joined the new online music service Duet. P26

President Mugabe has charged the editor of a national newspaper with criminal defamation. P21

Rupert Murdoch forecast yesterday that online betting revenues would generate nearly £700m for BSkyB by 2005. P33

Ray Snoddy asks whether advertising revenues will give the first indication of an economic downturn. P24

Falling standards at the BBC. P26

The media industry isn't converging quickly enough to need a single regulator. P27
