Sophie Wessex has said her business partner will not resign from the firm. P1

Relations between Buckingham Palace and the PCC are frosty despite attempts at a reconciliation. P5

Actress Ashley Judd has received substantial damages from Now magazine after its publishers admitted they published an article based on an interview that never took place. P6

The mystery of who shot EastEnders' Phil Mitchell is solved. P7

Russia's only remaining national independent TV station NTV yesterday broadcast live coverage of the Kremlin's attempts to take it over. P19

Ted Turner is considering cutting his ties with Time Warner. P33

THE INDEPENDENT

The National Grid's third-largest power surge took place last night as viewers tuned in to EastEnders. P5

The Guardian has ditched a column by comedian Jeremy Hardy because it was too left-wing. P5

Pearson is to cut 10% of the staff on its FT.com internet operation. P16

THE FINANCIAL TIMES

Levi Strauss won qualified legal backing yesterday in its bid to prevent Tesco selling cheap jeans. P1

Outdoor advertising company JC Decaux could be hampering its profits in its pursuit of growth. P14

Shares in Yahoo! leapt after the web portal said it was joining Vivendi Universal and Sony in a new internet music operation. P21

The Industry Standard Europe has been put up for sale. P22

THE WALL STREET JOURNAL

Coca-Cola is to advertise its products in the tunnels of a major US subway. P23

DAILY MAIL

Sophie Wessex is facing pressure to quit her PR job. P1

The actress who plays Lisa in EastEnders told her mum she shot Phil Mitchell, even though the show's producers had sworn her to secrecy. P7

The teenager plucked from a crowd to join Geri Halliwell at the premiere of Bridget Jones was spurned by her PR firm Freuds only a day later. P22

The Ministry of Defence has spent £1.7m on a new logo for its military research organisation. P45

DAILY EXPRESS

Prices of branded goods are set to drop after a court victory by Tesco. P1

Lisa Shaw, the woman behind the shooting of EastEnders' Phil Mitchell, gives her defence. P3

Lenny Henry has signed a deal for his first BBC comedy series in three years. P22

THE SUN

Big Breakfast presenter Paul Tonkinson has quit after it emerged the show's bosses had offered his job to DJ Chris Moyles. P3

Last night's EastEnders was watched by 22m people. P9

THE MIRROR

EastEnders' Lisa on why she shot Phil. P12

Sophie Wessex is now ready to quit her job. P17

DAILY STAR

The actress behind EastEnders' Lisa Shaw says the last two months have been the worst of her life as she struggled to keep her identity as the killer secret. P1

Crimewatch presenter Nick Ross has become embroiled in a row after he accepted a £5,000 fee to speak at the launch of a crime-fighting scheme. P4

AND FINALLY...

NBC has produced publicity shots of Anne Robinson to promote the US version of The Weakest Link. But the stern presenter has been so heavily airbrushed as to make her virtually unrecognisable. "Like Doris DayÕs younger sister" is how the Mail describes Ms Robinson's wholesome new look. P3

webTitle: Comment: Macedonia will be a problem for years to come

fields.headline: Macedonia will be Europe's problem for years to come
fields.standfirst:
The EU is embracing a country far from overcoming its divisions

Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: The EU is embracing a country far from overcoming its divisions.
fields.body:
It is only 40 minutes by EU-financed motorway from Skopje to Tetovo. One city has a Macedonian majority, the other is almost entirely Albanian. The road goes through wondrously beautiful forested hills, the paler colours of cypress and birch in feathery contrast to the general greenery. The scenes at each end are uglier, but not notably different from each other.

A warm spring sun shines down on graffiti-mottled council estates, their rubbish-filled courtyards haunted by despondent dogs. They open out on to vistas dominated by the overblown public buildings of the socialist era, rebadged with new national symbols. Here and there a fine old villa or commercial building, a church, mosque, or Ottoman market survives.

Layered over this are the banks, offices and often already tatty shopping malls of the new capitalism, with their Arizona Fast Food places, quick English language courses, cyber cafes, and Kalifornia video shops. Through them mooch handsome adolescents in platform shoes, searching for tapes, nail polish and each other. In the restaurants their elders consume, with slight religious variations, the standard Balkan suicide diet of too much tobacco, alcohol, coffee, meat, gossip and jokes.

People are almost uniformly good natured and courteous. It is difficult to imagine that two cities so apparently similar could go to war with each other, or that the mixed city of Skopje could go to war with itself. Yet that is, unhappily, a possibility, if still a remote one.

When the EU drafted an association agreement with Macedonia last year, wise heads in Brussels believed they were taking in a country that was overcoming its divisions, not one in danger of being overwhelmed by them. But, as next Monday's final signing ceremony in Luxembourg approaches, it is evident that Europe is embracing a society which may be a problem for years to come, even if it avoids another bout of violence in the near future.

Could ethnic harmony be assured by sheer weight of political celebrity, it would already be established in Macedonia. Since the little war of Tetovo, Macedonians have been subjected to repeated visits by European chieftains. They are well accustomed to the schoolmasterly tones of Chris Patten, the rolling periods of Lord Robertson, the kindly uncle persona of Javier Solana, and the sharp footwork of Robin Cook.

All hold up the prospect of a closer and closer relationship with the EU and Nato, with its benefits in terms of trade, aid and security. All threaten, obliquely, that this is in jeopardy unless ethnic Macedonians and Albanians swiftly reach a compact and thus outflank the fighters in the hills. The likely immediate result will be some kind of framework agreement in the next few days. Then the much desired "dialogue" can begin, with the EU monitoring progress although not, its representatives insist, mediating.

It sounds rational, even promising. But it is difficult to express how truly elusive is this goal of a hard and fast agreement. Issues matter much less than attitudes. Both sides are aggrieved, both are divided, both react with neuralgic intensity to certain words, and both are almost tearful in their view that they have been slandered in the eyes of the world.

Macedonians feel that, after all their efforts to accommodate the Albanian minority, in contrast to what happened in Serbia, they are being branded as oppressors. Albanians feel that after years of waiting for their rights to be granted in practice as well as on paper, they are being labelled as criminals and wreckers because some impatient young men made an armed demonstration.

As that last phrase suggests, the two sides differ above all on the facts. according to Macedonians, a heavily armed force composed of a majority of Kosovans, and including criminal elements, came into Macedonia with the barely concealed objective of encouraging secession, and was repulsed by a government offensive which was militarily effective but spared Albanian civilians through exemplary restraint. According to Albanians, a small body of lightly armed men, most from Macedonia, staged a show of force to draw attention to grievances and withdrew before the government offensive.

The EU and Nato seem to be sending out three hard signals. One, to the Macedonians, is that, as part of a range of reforms, the constitution should be altered so that it does not give symbolic primacy to their ethnicity. The second, to the Albanians, is that all thought of federal or cantonal arrangements should be abandoned and they should demonstrate an enhanced fealty to the Macedonian state. The third is that further armed activity will be treated as terrorist, a word Robin Cook used at least half a dozen times during his visit here yesterday, and that Nato countries help Macedonia deal with it.

It is understandable how international officials, rightly alarmed at the prospect of an insurgency in Macedonia, arrived at such a programme. But, on the ground, there is a yawning feeling that it hardly touches on the central problem, which is one of two communities that have little understanding of each other, and which stand at different moments in their histories.

The difference is well put by Eran Fraenkel, the American head of the Skopje office of Search for Common Ground, an international non-governmental organisation specialising in conflict prevention. "Macedonians," he says, "don't know who they are, but they know what they want. Albanians in Macedonia know who they are, but they don't know what they want."

In the wreckage of Yugoslavia, Macedonians have achieved their state and want to be masters of it, while remaining uncertain about their status among closely related fellow Slavs, like Bulgarians and Serbs. The Albanians of Macedonia have no such uncertainties about their ethnic identity. But, if union with other Albanian-speaking regions like Kosovo and Albania is ruled out, they do not find it easy to say exactly what would satisfy them.

That does not mean that changes like those proposed to the constitution, or those giving more autonomy and money to local authorities, or more status for the Albanian language, would not be acceptable. The Albanian leader Arben Xhaferi, whose party is in government, says the first is vital. But it may mean that the discontents of Albanians can only be allayed, never extinguished, at least for a long time to come. And time, as is usually the case in these threatening situations, is the commodity in shortest supply.

"This is the internet generation," says the Albanian writer Kim Mehmeti of the young men who took up arms. "They want to live now and immediately." Add to that widespread unemployment and the unsettling impact of events across the border in Kosovo, and it is evident how much tinder is around. In Mehmeti's view, "the men on the Sar mountain are forcing the country to look at itself in the mirror". The trouble is that Macedonians and Albanians, so far, see two different images in the glass.
fields.bodyText: It is only 40 minutes by EU-financed motorway from Skopje to Tetovo. One city has a Macedonian majority, the other is almost entirely Albanian. The road goes through wondrously beautiful forested hills, the paler colours of cypress and birch in feathery contrast to the general greenery. The scenes at each end are uglier, but not notably different from each other. A warm spring sun shines down on graffiti-mottled council estates, their rubbish-filled courtyards haunted by despondent dogs. They open out on to vistas dominated by the overblown public buildings of the socialist era, rebadged with new national symbols. Here and there a fine old villa or commercial building, a church, mosque, or Ottoman market survives. Layered over this are the banks, offices and often already tatty shopping malls of the new capitalism, with their Arizona Fast Food places, quick English language courses, cyber cafes, and Kalifornia video shops. Through them mooch handsome adolescents in platform shoes, searching for tapes, nail polish and each other. In the restaurants their elders consume, with slight religious variations, the standard Balkan suicide diet of too much tobacco, alcohol, coffee, meat, gossip and jokes. People are almost uniformly good natured and courteous. It is difficult to imagine that two cities so apparently similar could go to war with each other, or that the mixed city of Skopje could go to war with itself. Yet that is, unhappily, a possibility, if still a remote one. When the EU drafted an association agreement with Macedonia last year, wise heads in Brussels believed they were taking in a country that was overcoming its divisions, not one in danger of being overwhelmed by them. But, as next Monday's final signing ceremony in Luxembourg approaches, it is evident that Europe is embracing a society which may be a problem for years to come, even if it avoids another bout of violence in the near future. Could ethnic harmony be assured by sheer weight of political celebrity, it would already be established in Macedonia. Since the little war of Tetovo, Macedonians have been subjected to repeated visits by European chieftains. They are well accustomed to the schoolmasterly tones of Chris Patten, the rolling periods of Lord Robertson, the kindly uncle persona of Javier Solana, and the sharp footwork of Robin Cook. All hold up the prospect of a closer and closer relationship with the EU and Nato, with its benefits in terms of trade, aid and security. All threaten, obliquely, that this is in jeopardy unless ethnic Macedonians and Albanians swiftly reach a compact and thus outflank the fighters in the hills. The likely immediate result will be some kind of framework agreement in the next few days. Then the much desired "dialogue" can begin, with the EU monitoring progress although not, its representatives insist, mediating. It sounds rational, even promising. But it is difficult to express how truly elusive is this goal of a hard and fast agreement. Issues matter much less than attitudes. Both sides are aggrieved, both are divided, both react with neuralgic intensity to certain words, and both are almost tearful in their view that they have been slandered in the eyes of the world. Macedonians feel that, after all their efforts to accommodate the Albanian minority, in contrast to what happened in Serbia, they are being branded as oppressors. Albanians feel that after years of waiting for their rights to be granted in practice as well as on paper, they are being labelled as criminals and wreckers because some impatient young men made an armed demonstration. As that last phrase suggests, the two sides differ above all on the facts. according to Macedonians, a heavily armed force composed of a majority of Kosovans, and including criminal elements, came into Macedonia with the barely concealed objective of encouraging secession, and was repulsed by a government offensive which was militarily effective but spared Albanian civilians through exemplary restraint. According to Albanians, a small body of lightly armed men, most from Macedonia, staged a show of force to draw attention to grievances and withdrew before the government offensive. The EU and Nato seem to be sending out three hard signals. One, to the Macedonians, is that, as part of a range of reforms, the constitution should be altered so that it does not give symbolic primacy to their ethnicity. The second, to the Albanians, is that all thought of federal or cantonal arrangements should be abandoned and they should demonstrate an enhanced fealty to the Macedonian state. The third is that further armed activity will be treated as terrorist, a word Robin Cook used at least half a dozen times during his visit here yesterday, and that Nato countries help Macedonia deal with it. It is understandable how international officials, rightly alarmed at the prospect of an insurgency in Macedonia, arrived at such a programme. But, on the ground, there is a yawning feeling that it hardly touches on the central problem, which is one of two communities that have little understanding of each other, and which stand at different moments in their histories. The difference is well put by Eran Fraenkel, the American head of the Skopje office of Search for Common Ground, an international non-governmental organisation specialising in conflict prevention. "Macedonians," he says, "don't know who they are, but they know what they want. Albanians in Macedonia know who they are, but they don't know what they want." In the wreckage of Yugoslavia, Macedonians have achieved their state and want to be masters of it, while remaining uncertain about their status among closely related fellow Slavs, like Bulgarians and Serbs. The Albanians of Macedonia have no such uncertainties about their ethnic identity. But, if union with other Albanian-speaking regions like Kosovo and Albania is ruled out, they do not find it easy to say exactly what would satisfy them. That does not mean that changes like those proposed to the constitution, or those giving more autonomy and money to local authorities, or more status for the Albanian language, would not be acceptable. The Albanian leader Arben Xhaferi, whose party is in government, says the first is vital. But it may mean that the discontents of Albanians can only be allayed, never extinguished, at least for a long time to come. And time, as is usually the case in these threatening situations, is the commodity in shortest supply. "This is the internet generation," says the Albanian writer Kim Mehmeti of the young men who took up arms. "They want to live now and immediately." Add to that widespread unemployment and the unsettling impact of events across the border in Kosovo, and it is evident how much tinder is around. In Mehmeti's view, "the men on the Sar mountain are forcing the country to look at itself in the mirror". The trouble is that Macedonians and Albanians, so far, see two different images in the glass.

webTitle: No aid for Virgin to keep lid on fares

fields.headline: No aid for Virgin to keep lid on fares
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Virgin Trains is to be told by the government that it will not be bailed out with increased subsidies to head off fare increases of almost 10% from May 21.
fields.body:
Virgin Trains is to be told by the government that it will not be bailed out with increased subsidies to head off fare increases of almost 10% from May 21.

Ministers were last night said to be angry that Virgin had used the aftermath of the Hatfield rail disaster to justify putting up fares. The company was accused of "acting perversely".

The strategic rail authority has agreed to meet Virgin shareholders next week to hear their concerns about the company's profitability over the next 12 months, at a time when it is getting ready to introduce high speed trains on its intercity and cross country routes.

The SRA is likely to tell Virgin that the industry is in the private sector and that companies such as Virgin must accept that there will always be good times and bad.

Even so, some government sources pointed out that if the rail companies acted together and presented their post-Hatfield case it might be possible to cushion them with extra money.

This could lead Virgin to freeze its fares, if not from May 21 then in the future.

A spokesman for the prime minister said the rail companies had to make judgments about getting the necessary investment and how they could best attract people back to train travel.

News of Virgin's proposed fare increases was received with widespread hostility. Stewart Francis, chairman of the rail passengers' council, said they were unacceptable and called on the industry to "stop fleecing passengers".

He said: "The ping pong battle between Railtrack and the train companies post-Hatfield should never have been alllowed to spill into the fares box. We were told that Railtrack's shareholders would bear the cost of Hatfield, not passengers."

Michael Moore, Liberal Democrat transport spokesman, said Virgin was making "cheap excuses" and exhibiting the "unacceptable face of privatisation".

Vernon Hince, assistant general secretary of the Rail, Maritime and Transport Union, said: "This is a slap in the face to passengers and railway staff. After months of disruption and delay, they are having to pay yet again for bungling and mismanagement on our railways."

webTitle: GPs told to boycott form-filling chores

fields.headline: GPs told to boycott form-filling chores
fields.standfirst: Doctors' first work to rule protest 'within law'
fields.trailText: Doctors' first work to rule protest 'within law'.
fields.body:
The first work to rule by family doctors was agreed yesterday by the British Medical Association in protest against an "unsustainable" burden of administrative work that is taking time away from patient care.

The association's GPs committee told its 32,000 members in England and Wales to boycott the form filling needed to comply with national strategies for cancer, heart disease and care of older people.

Simon Fradd, the committee's deputy chairman, said the move amounted to "non-compliance" with government directions, and it was likely to be the first of a series of actions in protest at excessive workload.

The boycott did not count as industrial action because at least 95% of GPs did not have these administrative duties in their contracts, he said. About 1,000 GPs on personal contracts would be exempted if the boycott required them to breach their conditions. There was therefore no requirement for a ballot under industrial relations law.

"We have reached the stage where we believe it is in the public interest to cut out work that is not essential to make sure the job can be done safely in terms of clinical care," Dr Fradd said.

GPs would be told to stop writing reports for health authorities and primary care trusts, as the government required to demonstrate improvements in programmes to combat killer diseases and raise the standard of care for older people.

For example, they would follow government guidelines for screening patients for high blood pressure but would not collate the data to provide ministers with the evidence to score political points.

The move was a further embarrassment for ministers, who are braced for a BMA offensive during the general election campaign.

The association is preparing a patients' dossier showing the suffering caused in the NHS when doctors are forced to cut corners.

The BMA said the "national service frameworks" for priority NHS work were "laudable in their intention to raise the standards of care for patients" but gave rise to an unsustainable burden on GPs to monitor and report on the delivery of that care.

GPs should do their utmost to fulfil the clinical aspects of the government's plan but stop taking time away from patient care to meet the associated requests for information.

"When patients are ill, they want to be able to see their doctors, not to find that their GP is having to undertake administrative tasks to satisfy a government that has steadfastly refused to listen," the BMA said.

Dr Fradd said the government's NHS plan was raising patients' expectations about what GPs could deliver. "We are seeking ways to reduce workload to give a better deal to the public.

"Nobody can give consistently safe care in consultations lasting a national average of eight minutes. You can't do a proper job for patients in that time. We have to find ways to reduce hours spent on work that is not relevant to patient care."

The GPs' action follows a warning from Ian Bogle, the BMA chairman, that patients' safety was being put at risk because doctors did not have enough time for consultations.

"Consulting times are getting lower. Therefore, patients are not getting the quality of service they need and deserve and, from the doctors' point of view, if they are cutting corners - and they may well be in short consultations - they are putting their careers at risk," he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, said: "I am increasingly concerned that doctors are being forced into unsafe medical practices in order to meet arbitrary government targets.

"I agree with Dr Bogle that rushed consultations and less time with patients increases the risk of mistakes being made."

webTitle: Shock appointment for NHS head of HR

fields.headline: Shock appointment for NHS head of HR
fields.trailText: A trust chairman who has never had a full-time job in the health service but who emerged last year as a key architect of the NHS plan has been appointed as the £100,000 a year NHS head of human resources.
fields.body:
A trust chairman who has never had a full-time job in the health service but who emerged last year as a key architect of the NHS plan has been appointed as the £100,000 a year NHS head of human resources.

Property company director Andrew Foster, who has been involved in NHS HR policy - mostly on a part-time basis - for just five years, and the NHS - also on a part-time basis - for just nine years, will take up the job in May.

He and the NHS confederation are credited with an influential role in the development of HR policy in the NHS plan, which promises more investment in nurses and doctors, and improved pay and training for staff.

Mr Foster is in many ways an astonishing appointment - it is believed to be unprecedented for a trust chairman to be appointed to a senior NHS executive management position.

It is also rare for someone with no track record in the civil service or as a career NHS manager to take up such a key post at the Department of Health - although ministers have been reportedly keen to attract private sector talent to the NHS.

It seems likely that Mr Foster's work with the confederation on the HR policy work that fed into the NHS plan impressed ministers and senior civil servants.

NHS chief executive Nigel Crisp admitted as much when he said: "Andrew's work at the NHS confederation has shown that he is an excellent candidate for the job."

Mr Foster, 46, will have responsibility for solving the health service's chronic staff recruitment and retention problem, redesigning the NHS pay system and developing staff skills.

For the past year he has worked for the NHS confederation as human resources policy director and has chaired its human resources committee since 1996.

Mr Foster has been a director of a family property company, Worldcrest, based in Wigan, since 1981, although it is understood that much of his time over the past five years has been devoted to his NHS work.

Previous to that he worked in a series of jobs for Rowntrees, the confectionery manufacturer, as a graduate trainee.

He was appointed as chairman of the then West Lancashire NHS trust by the Conservative government in 1992 - now the Wrightington, Wigan and Leigh NHS trust - and is a member of the NHS workforce task force set up to implement the NHS plan.

webTitle: Sketch: Mr Flabby fails to fizz at Commons house party

fields.headline: Mr Flabby fails to fizz at Commons house party
fields.trailText: Agriculture questions in the House of Commons, and poor Nick Brown, the minister, had to face MPs for the second time since the foot and mouth crisis began.
fields.body:
Agriculture questions in the House of Commons, and poor Nick Brown, the minister, had to face MPs for the second time since the foot and mouth crisis began.

He does not inspire great confidence. Mr Brown is flabby. Flabby, flabby, flabby. If Noel Edmonds heard about him he would invent a character called Mr Flabby - not that the BBC would dream of taking it up.

Mr Brown sits flabbily. He gets to his feet in a flabby fashion, then stands flabbily at the despatch box. When he wants to make a point, he lets a flabby hand descend flabbily on to his folder, which is the only thing about him which isn't flabby.

I feel bad writing about him in this way. It must be ghastly having to cope with a crisis where not getting much worse is the closest you can get to getting better.

Or as Colin Breed, the aptly named LibDem agriculture spokesman put it: "Are there grounds for guarded optimism that we are beginning to see some beginning to the end?" This line was almost Churchillian in its majestic obfuscation.

But there is nothing Churchillian about Mr Brown. If the British foot and mouth crisis lasts for a thousand years, men will still say: "This was his flabbiest hour."

You'd imagine that the monthly question time would be the opportunity to say something stirring, something hopeful, anything to give the impression that Mr Brown wasn't merely standing there flabbily, flabbing on about the figures.

But no. He doesn't want to inspire or encourage. He just wants to flab, and in jargon if at all possible. Agriculture generates plenty of jargon these days. One Labour MP asked Mr Brown about people who work in food processing. They are in danger of losing their livelihoods too, and there are lots more of them than farmers.

"There are a large number of people employed in downstream activities," Mr Brown mused. What did he mean? Salmon netting? Apparently not. Downstream activities is just the flabmeister's term for jobs that depend on other jobs.

Julia Drown rose to ask when the disease would begin to decline. Ms Drown has a dangerous name for someone engaged in a downstream activity, and nobody is more downstream than a backbench Labour MP.

Mr Brown warned us that the outbreak might be declining, but it was "still a very serious outbreak with a very long tail".

As opposed to a pig, which is a very serious animal with a short, curly tail.

We moved on to Brigadier Birtwhistle, the army supremo in charge of the great slaughter, the General Haig of this war. If Haig had had to face 10,000 cows, the Somme would have been a very different place.

Mr Brown was full of flabby praise. "My congratulations go out to everybody, both civilian and military personnel, working so hard right across the country..."

Congratulations is always the first refuge of the flabby. Nobody disagrees with praise, especially if it's showered over the military.

A protester in the public gallery shouted: "There's a conspiracy!" twice, until burly attendants picked him up and threw him out, presumably on the grounds that MPs know that already.

The Tory spokesman, Tim Yeo, was cheered by his own side. Mr Yeo is thought to have had a good war. Someone talked about "the overstretch of vets".

Mr Brown was still flabbing onward. Vets were going to farms, he said, and culling out animals. "Cohorts are culled out with the same team," he added. It means, "the same people kill all the animals that live nearby."

It doesn't sound better, but it is a lot flabbier.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Complacency, so Mr Tony Blair is wont to insist when warning of the dangers of voter apathy, is something up with which he will not put.
fields.body:
 Complacency, so Mr Tony Blair is wont to insist when warning of the dangers of voter apathy, is something up with which he will not put.

If so, perhaps Mr T might have a quiet word with my old friend Paul Boateng, the dandyish minister who likes to describe himself by the previously non-existent title of deputy home secretary. Paul, currently a 16-1 shot for Turncoat of Turncoats, has been heard offering counsel about the rehabilitation of Keith Vaz's image. Paul says that, with New Labour guaranteed "another five to 10 years" in power, there is ample time for Mr Vaz to recover from his recent Hinduja-related difficulties.

In the short term, meanwhile, he advises Mr Vaz to spend his time now that he is home again after a brief stay in St Thomas's hospital, putting any newly discovered insights and empathies with patients into practice by visiting other hospitals in the run-up to the election. It's a brilliant and remarkably sophisticated plan, of course, but will it work? We shall see, we shall see.

 Speaking of Mr Vaz, I am saddened to learn that civil servants who visited him in St Thomas's last week were exhibiting signs of the sort of rudeness for which the Diary has all too often been obliged to rebuke Alastair Campbell and other members of the apparat. One, for example, imperiously ordered a nurse "Fetch this man a cup of tea". Nothing remotely civil about that. Poor show.

 The appeal for entirely bald people, or those with latex bald wigs, to join the David Yelland Appreciation Society (DYAS) has not gone well. Bulge our postbag does not. Perhaps if I outline the stunt, the floodgates will open. The plan is to collect about 20 DYAS members at the News International gates in Wapping. Each will attempt to persuade the guards that he or she is David Yelland but has left their security pass at home. Eventually, a Spartacus-style cry of "I'm David Yelland", "No, I'm David Yelland", etc, will go up, at which point security will be called to drive them off the premises. Lest that not be enticement enough, a snap of Marina Hyde and myself in bald wig and round glasses will appear here early next week.

 The spirit of the Algonquin continues to pervade Tory central office, where the anti-Hague axis of Francis Maude-Michael Portillo is now known to Hague loyalists as "St Francis and a cissy". The side stapler, matron, the side stapler...

 The Diary must add its own sense of distress to the correction opposite to yesterday's error about Prince Edward. It's all well and good being marauding republicans, but we must never be sloppy about titles. We also wish to make it clear that this reference to Edward as a "count" was not, as some suspect, a cunning taster for a new Graham Rawle regular cartoon, Added Vowels.

 A lesson in filial piety comes from Janet Levene, who drove her 91-year-old mother Mildred Wooten 1,000 miles from Colorado to Oregon. Nothing odd there, except that Mildred Wooten was dead. Eager to cut costs on taking Mildred to an Oregon mortuary to join her late husband, she waited an hour after becoming an orphan before dressing the cadaver in clean pyjamas, plonking it on the front passenger seat, and hitting the interstate highway. Mortuary officials called police when asked to fetch the body, but no charges will be brought. "Death can make people behave in strange ways," says Sgt Mike Julian of Jefferson County charitably, "even crazy ones."

Paul says that, with New Labour guaranteed "another five to 10 years" in power, there is ample time for Mr Vaz to recover from his recent Hinduja-related difficulties. In the short term, meanwhile, he advises Mr Vaz to spend his time now that he is home again after a brief stay in St Thomas's hospital, putting any newly discovered insights and empathies with patients into practice by visiting other hospitals in the run-up to the election. It's a brilliant and remarkably sophisticated plan, of course, but will it work? We shall see, we shall see.  Speaking of Mr Vaz, I am saddened to learn that civil servants who visited him in St Thomas's last week were exhibiting signs of the sort of rudeness for which the Diary has all too often been obliged to rebuke Alastair Campbell and other members of the apparat. One, for example, imperiously ordered a nurse "Fetch this man a cup of tea". Nothing remotely civil about that. Poor show.  The appeal for entirely bald people, or those with latex bald wigs, to join the David Yelland Appreciation Society (DYAS) has not gone well. Bulge our postbag does not. Perhaps if I outline the stunt, the floodgates will open. The plan is to collect about 20 DYAS members at the News International gates in Wapping. Each will attempt to persuade the guards that he or she is David Yelland but has left their security pass at home. Eventually, a Spartacus-style cry of "I'm David Yelland", "No, I'm David Yelland", etc, will go up, at which point security will be called to drive them off the premises. Lest that not be enticement enough, a snap of Marina Hyde and myself in bald wig and round glasses will appear here early next week.  The spirit of the Algonquin continues to pervade Tory central office, where the anti-Hague axis of Francis Maude-Michael Portillo is now known to Hague loyalists as "St Francis and a cissy". The side stapler, matron, the side stapler...  The Diary must add its own sense of distress to the correction opposite to yesterday's error about Prince Edward. It's all well and good being marauding republicans, but we must never be sloppy about titles. We also wish to make it clear that this reference to Edward as a "count" was not, as some suspect, a cunning taster for a new Graham Rawle regular cartoon, Added Vowels.  A lesson in filial piety comes from Janet Levene, who drove her 91-year-old mother Mildred Wooten 1,000 miles from Colorado to Oregon. Nothing odd there, except that Mildred Wooten was dead. Eager to cut costs on taking Mildred to an Oregon mortuary to join her late husband, she waited an hour after becoming an orphan before dressing the cadaver in clean pyjamas, plonking it on the front passenger seat, and hitting the interstate highway. Mortuary officials called police when asked to fetch the body, but no charges will be brought. "Death can make people behave in strange ways," says Sgt Mike Julian of Jefferson County charitably, "even crazy ones." diary@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Burial mound suggested to cut west's surplus of carcasses
fields.standfirst:
'Desperate' farmers fear ministry is overwhelmed

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: A clay mound the size of a football pitch to be filled with 30,000 decomposing sheep and cattle has been suggested for the west country to solve a crisis of unburied animals.
fields.body:
A clay mound the size of a football pitch to be filled with 30,000 decomposing sheep and cattle has been suggested for the west country to solve a crisis of unburied animals.

The Ministry of Agriculture is so desperate about carcasses lying in fields and barns that it refuses any longer to publish the figures, and is considering the mound plan, put forward by the National Farmers' Union.

It was suggested to the farmers by Ian White, regional waste manager for the environment agency until he retired last year. He said that the clay lined mass grave would allow rapid mass burial.

The mound would be drained at the bottom to prevent pollution getting into the water table - the main risk with burying carcasses.

Dr White said that, because of continuous heavy rain, it was proving very difficult to find suitable burial sites. Although rendering carcasses was the best option, there was not enough capacity.

He described his idea as being a simple engineering technique. "We need a large flat field, which would be covered in a thick layer of impermeable clay, of which we have plenty in this area.

"Then the field would be surrounded by high banks, or bunds."

He said these banks would need to be five to 10 metres high depending on the volume of animals to be buried, but either way would provide a large space to pile sheep and cattle carcasses.

Dr White calculated that an area 60 metres by 30 metres by five metres high could take up to 30,000 sheep, but if cattle were buried as well it would need to be larger. Once filled, it would be sealed with a layer of clay on top. Gradually, as the carcasses decomposed, the mound would sink.

"It would be ike a very large stone age barrow by that stage," he said.

Ian Johnson for the NFU in Devon said: "We think this is a very good idea.

"Our members are desperate. It is very upsetting and unsavory, to put it mildly, to have your animals lying about for up to a week. The ministry has been concentrating on killing infected animals, but then the army has nowhere to take them."

Over much of the country yesterday the ministry was clearly falling behind its targets of catching up.

Although the disposal of animals has speeded up in Cumbria with the giant pit at Great Orton airfield, it has slowed elsewhere.

There were 1,150,000 animals hit by foot and mouth, of which 385,000 were awaiting slaughter. An unknown number had been killed but were unburied.

The ministry had published a daily figure until two days ago, but stopped doing so when the figure passed 192,000.

Signs of the system breaking down were showing yesterday in the north east, acknowledged by the government chief scientist, David King, as a new hot spot.

Among the 33 new cases yesterday, bringing the total to 1,058, was a farm at High Whinholme in Northallerton in North Yorkshire where there are 1,110 pigs and 670 sheep.

This is the first case among pigs for some days - and a serious development, because pigs spread the virus much faster than other farm animals.

North of England NFU leaders were warning that things could get "10 times worse", and felt they were losing the battle against foot and mouth disease because of too much "bureaucracy".

The stark warning was issued following a meeting on Tyneside between farming union leaders and Pat Sellers, from the department of science and technology, a division of the Department of Trade and Industry.

Despite her assurances that she was "cautiously optimistic" that the government's policy of culling infected animals within 24 hours, and those on neighbouring farms within 48 hours, would help beat the outbreak, NFU leaders said the Tyneside operation was not working quickly enough.

Malcolm Corbett, chairman of the Northumberland NFU, said after the meeting: "It was a depressing meeting from my point of view. Things are going from bad to worse.

"Having had this situation for six weeks now, you would think reasonably intelligent people would have learned lessons - but they have not. While they are fiddling in Cumbria, this problem is going to get 10 times worse in Northumberland.

"There does not seem to be the will or the common sense to grasp that, or to cut through bureaucratic nonsense and red tape to give people the resources they need to beat this disease."

A mass incineration of carcasses at an airfield in Shropshire has been put on hold after protesters threatened legal action.

Residents and businesses close to Tern Hill airfield, near Market Drayton, have expressed their concern at possible contamination from the pyre and its implications for health. An alternative site is being found.

fields.headline: BBC admits digital mistakes
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The BBC's director of television admits 'not enough thought or money' went into the development of its digital channels, writes Ashley Davies.
fields.body:
BBC director of television Mark Thompson has admitted "not enough thought or money" went into the development of digital channels BBC Choice and BBC Knowledge.

And he has admitted the corporation does not cover arts as well as it should.

Mr Thompson vowed to learn from the experience of the corporation's first forays into digital broadcasting as he reiterated plans for BBC3, BBC4 and the two proposed children's channels.

He said the BBC had would rather repeat more expensive programmes on these new channels than produce low-budget shows like those on BBC Choice.

Speaking at the Voice of the Listener and Viewer spring conference, director general Greg Dyke's chief lieutenant admitted: "Choice and Knowledge weren't properly thought out and crucially, were not properly funded."

He also said if the corporation got the go ahead to launch BBC4, a channel devoted to arts programming, it would go towards filling an existing cultural gap.

"We recognise our existing channels don't offer the widest range of the most serious arts programming," said Mr Thompson.

He added that he wanted BBC4 to have a nightly world news programme, providing coverage from a global perspective. Some programmes for the channel would be co-commissioned by BBC2.

Explaining to delegates that BBC3 would be entertainment-focused and target younger viewers, he promised to keep the two children's channels free of commercials.

"We are not changing the philosophy about children's programmes. In most multi-channel homes children find their programmes on dedicated channels," he said.

The government is expected to greenlight the new channel plans after the election.

BBC Radio is also waiting for ratification of its three proposed digital channels. These are provisionally titled Network X, a black urban music station with a bespoke news service; Network Y, for music lovers who feel too old for Radio 1 and too young for Radio 3; and Network Z, which would air plays, books, programmes for children and night-time comedy classics.

fields.headline: Granada's Red Heart packs up
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The Sydney-based joint venture set up by Granada and led by former BBC entertainment chief Paul Jackson has collapsed, writes Jason Deans.

Oct 10 2000: Jackson quits BBC for Granada Media Australia

Oct 11: Been there, done that, going down under
fields.body:
The Sydney-based joint venture company set up by Granada and headed up by former BBC entertainment chief Paul Jackson has collapsed.

Red Heart is understood to have foundered because of the differing aims of its two backers - Granada Media and the Seven Network.

But Mr Jackson will be staying in Sydney to run a new standalone company set up by Granada.

Granada and Seven are putting the finishing touches to an agreement to break up their 50/50 Red Heart joint venture, which was heralded as Australia's biggest production company when it was established just over a year ago.

Mr Jackson will run a new Granada Australian production unit which will pitch ideas to other broadcasters in the country.

It will still develop shows for Seven, but not have the first-look output deal Red Heart enjoyed.

Meanwhile the Seven production staff and shows, including long-running soap Home and Away, that became part of Red Heart when it was set up in February last year are expected to return in-house.

"The Australian networks are very, very internally focused on what their schedules need," said Andrea Wonfor, executive chair of Granada Media International.

"Paul has gone down there and brought a huge energy to things. But there was a tension between supplying Seven and Red Heart's other activities.

"We've had a very constructive meeting with Seven and we are going to pull the two operations apart."

Granada was looking to invest in programming that would sell internationally; while Seven was interested in shows tailored to its Australian audience.

And because of Red Heart's first-look output deal with Seven, other Australian networks were reluctant to commission ideas that could have been rejected by their commercial rival.

"Australia is a very competitive market and it's much more difficult to establish relationships with all the channels in the way you can in the UK," said Ms Wonfor.

"We've now got to focus on building up those relationships and trust and get Paul working with the other channels."

She added that the new Granada Australian outfit would still continue to work with Seven on particular formats and drama with international sales potential.

Granada also still owns a stake of around 10% in Seven.

Mr Jackson is expected to be involved in the shooting of the final episode of the next series of Cold Feet, which is to be shot in Australia.

fields.headline: Piat D'Or ends French love affair
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The wine brand will distance itself from France when it relaunches in the summer, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
For years it managed to convince us the French adored le Piat D'Or.

Now the owner of the infamous wine brand is dropping the slogan from its advertising because the British no longer want to drink French wine.

Piat D'Or is to be relaunched this summer with an advertising campaign that repositions it as the easy-drinking choice.

The £500,000 campaign will introduce a new theme - "Relax. It's Piat D'Or" - and make no mention of the brand's French roots.

"France and the French are no longer as aspirational as they once were," said Emma Chamberlain, marketing manager for Piat D'Or.

"We're still a French wine but we've dropped 'Les Francais adorent le Piat D'Or' from our advertising and we're dropping the 'le' in the brand name. There will be less of an emphasis on France."

Throughout the 1980s, le Piat D'Or was Britain's biggest-selling branded wine.

Its opulent-looking red and gold labels and pseudo-French origins made it the wine of choice for the masses.

The success of the brand owed much to the adverts, in which a beautiful young French woman introduces her English boyfriend to her father.

The father reacts with disdain until the Englishman hands over a bottle of le Piat D'Or and all is resolved.

In recent years the brand has slipped as new world wine brands such as Jacob's Creek and E&J Gallo have become more popular.

The relaunched Piat D'Or will hit the shelves in July and will have understated labels and a new flavour

The advertising agency behind the new campaign is Dow Delaney Potter.

fields.headline: UK succumbs to television Temptation
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The reality TV show Temptation Island, branded immoral, sadistic and a cynical attempt to cash in on emotional trauma when it was screened in the US, is to be made for Britain.
fields.byline: Jason Deans  in Cannes and  Dan Milmo
fields.body:
The reality TV show Temptation Island, branded immoral, sadistic and a cynical attempt to cash in on emotional trauma when it was screened in the US, is to be made for Britain.

Sky One and Channel 4 have linked up to broadcast a programme that tempts committed, but unmarried, couples to be unfaithful.

The plot will see four couples marooned on a tropical island with 26 beachwear-clad singletons. In the US the six week series had on average 17m viewers per episode.

It is believed that Sky One will screen the series first, and Channel 4 the repeats. Reports of the deal circulated at the MipTV festival in Cannes.

fields.headline: Industry Standard Europe seeks buyer
fields.standfirst:
More net news
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The Industry Standard Europe, favourite newsletter of the dot.com community, has put itself up for sale six months after it opened.
fields.body:
The Industry Standard Europe, favourite newsletter of the dot.com community, has put itself up for sale six months after it opened.

Neil Thackray, chief executive of the European magazine and website, said negotiations were taking place with a number of potential investors or buyers. It is owned by Standard Media International, the Silicon Valley-based company that publishes the US version.

Mr Thackray said it would make more sense to have a European able to offer strategic help as well as cash.

"My judgment was that we could increase our rate of growth if we worked with someone who had infrastruc ture in place such as distribution which would help our route to market."

The decision had not been forced by the US parent, which has shed large numbers of staff since the start of the year.

Chroniclers of the internet economy have not been immune from the downturn. Red Herring has also made job cuts while Business 2.0, the new economy magazine owned by Future Network, is up for sale.

Pearson, owner of the Financial Times, has a 2.5% stake in Standard Media International but is understood to have ruled out making a bid for the European version.

Mr Thackray said he was confident Industry Standard Europe would reach break even at the end of next year.

Sophie and Edward have to choose

Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Even the most steel-hearted republican must feel some sympathy for Sophie Rhys-Jones, the "Countess of Wessex". Not for the first time, she has embarrassed herself royally.
fields.body:
Even the most steel-hearted republican must feel some sympathy for Sophie Rhys-Jones, the "Countess of Wessex". Not for the first time, she has embarrassed herself royally. Yesterday she returned to Britain to face a full-dress carpeting from Buckingham Palace, doubtless delivered by the silky personage of the Queen's private secretary, Sir Robin Janvrin. Her crime was to have opened her heart to a make-believe Arab sheikh who turned out to be a reporter for the News of the World.

Sympathy is due because, once again, a newspaper has resorted to dodgy, intrusive means to pursue a story whose claim to be in the public interest is slim. Trickery and deception are tools which journalists can use in only the most exceptional circumstances - and exposing the private thoughts of a minor royal hardly count as those.

It is telling, however, that the NoW did not have to work hard to lure Ms Rhys-Jones into its trap. On the contrary, she was only too eager to meet their bogus sheikh, believing he would be a valuable client for her PR firm. And this gets us to the heart of the matter. For this latest episode illustrates the conflict of interest that exists between membership of a family obliged to stand outside politics, entirely free of taint, and commercial work as an image-maker for hire. Her firm cannot help but trade on her royal status: it is her proximity to the palace that her clients think they are buying. Her readiness to speak so freely about royal life to a potential client suggests the glimpse of majesty was a routine part of her pitch.

This conflict of interest should end. Trade secretary Stephen Byers is surely right that the confusion of "public and private" roles is untenable. Ms Rhys-Jones should wind up her firm immediately; her husband should do the same with Ardent, the TV company whose entire existence is parasitical on its royal provenance. It operates from a country estate provided by the Queen (which means us). He pays for it from the £141,000 pocket money given him each year by the Queen, which comes from the allocation we give to her. In other words, Ardent is a publicly subsidised company.

The Wessexes are right to want to work, but they cannot both be in private business and retain their royal status. They will have to choose. Once again we are seeing the anomalies that arise when a country tries to maintain an ancient, hereditary institution in a modern age.

fields.headline: Press row envelops Queen
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of the monarchy
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The Press Complaints Commission has severed relations with the Queen's most senior media adviser as the row over the Earl of Wessex and his wife Sophie's alleged exploitation of their royal connections for business purposes threatened to spin further out of control. By Matt Wells, Stephen Bates and <B<Steven Morris.
fields.byline: Matt Wells, Stephen Bates  and Steven Morris
fields.body:
The Press Complaints Commission has severed relations with the Queen's most senior media adviser as the row over the Earl of Wessex and his wife Sophie's alleged exploitation of their royal connections for business purposes threatened to spin further out of control.

The PCC will in future deal directly with Sir Robin Janvrin, the Queen's private secretary, bypassing Simon Walker, the public relations executive seconded from British Airways to update the royal family's public image.

Lord Wakeham, the PCC chairman, was furious that palace sources suggested he came up with the idea of a News of the World interview with Sophie, granted in exchange for the paper's tapes of her indiscreet comments.

The strategy backfired when the countess's unguarded comments on political leaders and members of the royal family appeared in other papers. The interview with the News of the World was also a disaster: in it, she insisted that her husband was not gay and that she was able to have children.

Amid mounting exasperation, a senior palace official described her conduct as "naive at best".

Officials are bracing themselves for further damaging revelations about the business practices of Prince Edward and his wife this weekend. It is understood that the News of the World has three to four hours of tapes still in its possession, and revelations are expected to focus on Sophie's business partner, Murray Harkin.

Sir Robin was meeting Prince Edward and Sophie following their return from an official visit to the Gulf yesterday, ostensibly to talk about security arrangements at their Surrey mansion, Bagshot Park, but undoubtedly also to raise mounting concerns about the crisis.

The palace has been desperately promoting a "business as usual" approach, playing down anxieties about what has become the most disastrous week for the royal family in years.

The "firm" has watched as its carefully constructed media strategy to recast the royals as a modern institution was blown apart by a ferocious media hunt.

There are fears that new revelations throwing more light on the couple's exploitation of their royal connections for commercial purposes will bring the whole family into renewed disrepute.

Although outwardly supportive, the countess was privately being censured by officials for allowing herself to be trapped into making disparaging comments by the News of the World's investigative reporter disguised as a sheikh, supposedly anxious to do lucrative business with her public relations company RJH.

The countess, 36, who married the Queen's youngest son two years ago and who was supposed to instil a new business and media acumen into the royal family, found herself trapped into making disparaging comments about Tony and Cherie Blair, William Hague, the Queen and Queen Mother.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, told BBC viewers sardonically: "If a sheikh came to me with a glass of champagne, I would make my excuses and leave."

The future of Mr Harkin was in doubt last night as he came under the spotlight. He was allegedly the original target for the Sunday paper's investigation after an RJH employee, Kishan Athulathmudali, raised his concerns about how the company was playing on its royal connections to attract possible clients.

The potential for further revelations this weekend is strong with reports of a second taped interview, this time between Mr Harkin and the reporter Mazher Mahmood. The News of the World's editor, Rebekah Wade, is reconsidering the paper's decision last week not to publish the countess's comments.

It is feared that the newspaper may publish the full transcripts and that revelations about Mr Harkin's business and personal life will inevitably bring the countess's judgment further into question.

Yesterday RJH refused to comment. The company has barred access to the sections of its website giving details about the business which boasts JCB Sales, Teletext and the high-class jewellers Boodle and Dunthorne among its clients.

Officials insisted that reports of the Queen's annoyance were overplayed. "She doesn't do furious - she is supremely detached," said one.

webTitle: Palace in a spin over Sophie and the sheikh

fields.headline: Palace in a spin over Sophie and the sheikh
fields.standfirst:
More revelations likely as attempts to draw line under affair go wrong

Special report: the future of the monarchy
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: More revelations are likely as attempts to draw line under affair go wrong, writes Matt Wells.
fields.byline: Matt Wells, Stephen Bates  and Steven Morris
fields.body:
Simon Walker, the public relations supremo seconded from British Airways to Buckingham Palace to devise a modern media strategy for the royal family, reckoned without the fake sheikh fiasco when he fixed his holiday plans. Instead of jetting off to an exotic destination today the prospect of further catastrophic revelations may keep him at his desk for some time yet.

Attempts by the palace to prevent the Sophie and Edward story from spinning out of control have proved more disastrous by the day. And with the Sunday tabloids circling, the royal family may be about enter the most damaging period since Andrew Morton's biography of Princess Diana in 1992 exposed the fiction of a happy and united family devoted to the service of the nation. There may need to be a scapegoat, and the handsomely-paid Mr Walker is first in the firing line.

The Countess of Wessex's remarks to the "middle Eastern businessman" from the News of the World were bad enough, but the strategy of containment has been an unmitigated disaster. The palace's efforts to paint her as a victim of entrapment got nowhere, as did the original strategy of pretending she had not said what she was quoted as saying about senior politicians and fellow members of the royal family.

Her decision to send letters of apology to the figures she insulted was another spectacular error of judgment: it enabled other newspapers to verify the story independently. (It was not as if political sources were reticent - a royal disaster story conveniently took the heat off Tony Blair at the height of the foot and mouth crisis.) That episode led to the News of the World proclaiming: 'Sophie: My Edward is not gay,' and the Mail on Sunday shouting: 'Queen's outrage at Sophie insults.' This was the real story - how Sophie allegedly described Cherie Booth as 'horrid, horrid, horrid', said: 'The public put me on the plinth vacated by Diana,' and called William Hague 'deformed'.

The panic-stricken palace's attempts to shift the blame onto the press complaints commission have only resulted in a damaging rift with the watchdog. The PCC, called in to advise the palace after Sophie realised that she had been set up, enjoys a close relationship with the Prince of Wales's camp at St James's Palace - the prince's deputy private secretary, Mark Bolland, is the partner and flatmate of Guy Black, the PCC director. But now the watchdog has fallen out spectacularly with Simon Walker down the road at the Queen's communications office.

Internal royal communications have been disastrous too: the Prince of Wales knew nothing about the looming disaster until Sophie's letter of apology arrived last Friday afternoon. Since then he has been quietly seething in Balmoral, angry that Sophie had talked presumptuously of Diana and Camilla Parker Bowles, and decidedly unimpressed at Buckingham Palace's ineptitude.

Attention has also again focused on the Earl of Wessex's much criticised television production company Ardent, which has made losses of £1.9m since it was formed in 1993. It was claimed that on a six-day official tour of Malaysia and Brunei Prince Edward planned a programme on royal gardens which would feature the monarchs of both nations.

Even the News of the World is in turmoil: reporters and some executives are furious that material it gathered ended up on the pages of its principal rivals.

As revelations about the interview and hostile stories about Sophie and Edward's business arrangements have multiplied, the palace has grown increasingly defensive, trying to insist it is business as usual and frantic to draw a line under the affair.

While denying that there had been any crisis meetings between the Queen and Sir Robin Janvrin, her private secretary and closest adviser, it was said: "She sees the press cuttings like everyone else here." It is certain that the demolition of the royal family's strategy of transforming itself in the wake of the furore at the time of Diana's death will cause anguished reappraisal. A scheduled meeting between Edward and Sophie and Sir Robin yesterday, ostensibly to discuss security arrangements at Bagshot Park, their enormous mansion in Surrey, will certainly have been fraught.

One Buckingham Palace insider, who said that Sophie had been "at best naive" in her dealings with the tabloid press, mused: "We want her to work and to have a professional career rather than be depicted as a freeloader on the state. But it seems she is damned if she does and damned if she doesn't."

There is little chance that it will get any better sometime soon: the NoW is thought to be ready to publish the full transcript of the meetings with the countess and her business partner Murray Harkin, after being embarrassingly scooped by the Mail on Sunday and the Sunday Mirror. Some royal sources believe that the explosive material contained in the tapes will make the events of this week pale into insignificance.

The seeds of the current crisis were sown when a dissatisfied employee of RJH, Sophie's PR firm, went to the public relations expert Max Clifford on February 12, saying he was unhappy with how the firm was being run. Kishan Athulathmudali had told his bosses of his concerns but wanted to tell his story to a newspaper.

It is understood he was unhappy about how the firm was playing on its royal connections. He claimed clients were told they could get invites for royal events and even engineer photo opportunities with royals. He also claimed that Murray Harkin, Sophie's business partner, believed the company could become so strong it would not have to pitch for business (a boast often made by Mr Clifford).

Mr Clifford says he first spoke to the Mail on Sunday about his client's story, but the paper decided not to buy it. He then offered it to the News of the World, which dreamt up the idea of the sting. But Mr Clifford believes that there was a leak: someone "marked the card" of Sophie and Mr Harkin.

So although Mr Athulathmudali had agreed to go on the record with his allegations, on March 27 RJH won an injunction against him, banning him from speaking about his former bosses.

The second part of the palace containment plan was engaged when the News of the World was offered an exclusive interview in return for the embarrassing tapes. The palace's choice of reporter was dispatched by the newspaper, along with a photographer who was admitted clandestinely by another gate to deflect attention. At the same time the tapes were handed over for the palace's safe-keeping. Mr Walker sat in on the subsequent interview.

The News of the World gave the palace editorial control in vetting the interview in advance of publication - which makes Sophie's assertions about her fertility and her husband's heterosexuality - possibly the most intrusively demeaning comments ever made by a member of the royal family - even more extraordinary. Her claim that her husband was not gay was apparently volunteered and not the result of questioning.

Last Friday Rebekah Wade is understood to have rung Mr Clifford to tell him that she would be carrying an interview with Sophie rather than a story based on the allegations made by Athulathmudali. Clifford has branded the subsequent interview as "nothing more than a PR puff".

Meanwhile, although the Mail on Sunday had not picked up Mr Clifford's story, it had continued to investigate the allegations independently. Clifford may have told the Mail of the News of the World's plans to bury the tale of the countess's indiscretion in favour of the exclusive interview, and - boosted by learning of the material that the NoW had held back - splashed the story.

Since then the Sunday tabloids have been working hard to find former employees of RJH and friends and associates of Harkin.

The News of the World is thought to have three or four hours of tapes still in its possession: it looks as if the palace spin doctors are going to have a busy weekend.

Perhaps the best advice for all involved in the farcical episode came from the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers. He told BBC1's Question Time: "If a sheikh came to me with a glass of champagne, I would make my excuses and leave."

webTitle: Controversy may force co-founder of PR firm to quit

fields.headline: Partnership under pressure
fields.standfirst:
Controversy may force co-founder of PR firm to quit

MediaGuardian.co.uk
Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Murray Harkin was in defiant mood last night, vowing that he would not quit the public relations firm he founded with the Countess of Wessex, writes Steven Morris.
fields.body:
Murray Harkin was in defiant mood last night, vowing that he would not quit the public relations firm he founded with the Countess of Wessex.

However, if fresh revelations about his role in the controversy emerge over the next few days the pair's fruitful partnership could become untenable.

It is believed that Harkin, 36, was the original target of the sting engineered by the News of the World and could be the subject of subsequent tabloid stories.

Any new damaging allegations against Harkin will come as a bitter blow to the countess who sets great store by his business sense and his friendship.

The pair met while Harkin was promoting Good Morning with Anne and Nick for the BBC. At the time, the countess was working with the likes of Chris Tarrant and Noel Edmonds, though beginning to attract the attentions of the press because of her romance with Prince Edward.

They became friends and when they wanted to branch out by themselves founded RJH four years ago. The company was originally based at her flat but is now run from smart Mayfair offices.

Unlike Prince Edward's much-criticised television production company, Ardent, RJH has done well. Harkin recently boasted: "We're heading towards the first million ... it's just going from strength to strength." Customers include the jewellers Boodle and Dunthorne and Teletext.

But the countess's dual role as businesswoman and royal has caused friction. In an interview given to his hometown paper, the Bournemouth Daily Echo, before the controversy, Harkin recalled how in the days of her courtship with Prince Edward, the press became more interested in her relationship than in the products which she was then promoting. "In PR, that's bad" he said.

But he claimed the royal family was "100% behind her."

Harkin was born in London but his family moved to Dorset when he was six. He went to a comprehensive school and completed his A-levels at Bournemouth College. He began a teacher training course but only lasted six months and signed up for media studies at Goldsmiths College in London.

For a while he was a DJ and worked with the likes of Vic Reeves and Bob Mortimer and Julian Clary. But he was not going to make it as a showbusiness star in his own right and began working for the London office of a Hollywood-based PR firm, which was involved in the handling of stars such as Paul McCartney and Tina Turner.

His first brush with the tabloid press came when he was put in charge of the PR for a Beach Boys comeback tour. "It was a baptism of fire," he said. He moved into media PR and met the countess.

Harkin told the Daily Echo how, at her wedding day, the countess had grasped his hand through the car window as it drove away. "The car was moving. I said: 'I'm going to have to let go, Sophie, or I'll hit the wall.'"

Depending on the next few days, the countess might now have to let go of her friend and business partner.

His first brush with the tabloid press came when he was put in charge of the PR for a Beach Boys comeback tour. "It was a baptism of fire," he said. He moved into media PR and met the countess. Harkin told the Daily Echo how, at her wedding day, the countess had grasped his hand through the car window as it drove away. "The car was moving. I said: 'I'm going to have to let go, Sophie, or I'll hit the wall.'" Depending on the next few days, the countess might now have to let go of her friend and business partner.

fields.headline: Murdoch shrugs off DirecTV blow
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch said yesterday acquiring US-based satellite pay service DirecTV - which his News Corporation has been striving to do for months - was not really important. By Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch said yesterday that acquiring US-based satellite pay service DirecTV - which his News Corporation has been striving to do for months - was not really important.

His comments came as the satellite operation, which is owned by Hughes Electronics, was given more time to find financial backers for a spin-off alternative to merger with Mr Murdoch's Sky Global.

News Corp has characterised its discussions with Hughes as "extremely difficult". When asked whether they had stalled, Mr Murdoch showed his frustration yesterday by saying: "I really don't know."

In an earlier speech to an industry conference, he said: "Is Sky Global viable without a US presence? Of course. It's a bit like asking if the Louvre would exist without the Mona Lisa."

"We, like the Louvre, have plenty of other treasures to show off."

Although its satellite empire reaches 80m homes in 60 countries, News Corp has a limited presence in the US. Mr Mur doch has said that a tie-up with Hughes would be ideal.

But the talks have been halted by disagreement over valuations and conflict with the Hughes management.

Michael Smith, the head of Hughes, has publicly said that the Murdoch offer undervalues his company. General Motors, Hughes' parent, has given him several weeks to find financial backers for a full spin-off.

Yet sources familiar with the situation at Hughes said that the Murdoch offer was still on the table. "We are stuck in neutral," one said.

Mr Murdoch has called Hughes an "undermanaged" company.

There have been further complicating factors during the standoff. Last week's acquisition of GE's satellite unit by Luxembourg's Société Européenne des Satellites removed an obvious buyer of Panamsat, the private communications satellite operator owned by Hughes.

Mr Murdoch's offer for Hughes was predicated on his ability to sell this division for several billion dollars.

fields.headline: Lord Hartwell
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Former Daily Telegraph editor Lord Hartwell.
fields.body:
To be appointed as a journalist at the Daily Telegraph of Lord Hartwell (Obituary, April 4), in the last days of Fleet Street in the mid-1980s, before the sell-out to Conrad Black, was to enter a world removed in detail, but scarcely in time, from Evelyn Waugh's classic tale of newspapers, Scoop, of 50 years before.

High above the roar of London's traffic, concealed behind the elegant art-deco facade of the Telegraph building, with its motif of two winged messengers setting off across the world in opposite directions - their feet unfortunately tied together - there lurked, up on the fifth floor, a shadowy, unknown proprietor, peering out from his panelled office over his roof garden with its neatly trimmed rectangular lawn.

Painfully shy, he appeared oblivious of the fact that, down below, his employees were rooking the company on a grand scale. As the journalists cheerfully headed for lunch, waving advances slips at the cashier's office, handily placed in the foyer on the route to the wine bars and the Cheshire Cheese, the printers and maintenance men balefully patrolled the warren of printing presses around the back. When the time for redundancies eventually came, it was the printers and septuagenarian messenger boys who were more lavishly rewarded than the journalists.

Few of us had ever seen Lord Hartwell, and those who had encountered him, by chance ascending in the staff lift, had endured an age of anguished silence before he, or they, could make an embarrassed escape.

He appeared to leave all editorial decision-making to the managing editor, Peter Eastwood, who ruthlessly controlled the news agenda, or to the editor Bill Deedes, whose empire extended little further than the slender comment and leader pages. Both were men almost as old as the proprietor, which was to say in their 70s.

There seemed to be only one item in the paper that really interested Hartwell, the half-page Peterborough diary column. At about 5.30pm, a call would be put through to the Peterborough editor, asking whether the column was ready - and it would be borne aloft to the fifth floor.

Coming out of the lift, you turned sharp left, and there, at the glass doors, a butler wearing white gloves would be waiting to bear the copy away for his lordship's approval. A few minutes later, the call would come down that the column was acceptable - or, occasionally, that its diet of second world war gossip, interesting old buildings and PR events was too racy, and required toning down.

When Hartwell's business acumen slipped, and he overstretched the company with lavish plans for a new printing works, he gave the first - and only - press conference of his career to explain how the Telegraph would be passing into the hands of Mr Black.

Naturally, the conference, such as it was, was confined to a reporter from the Daily Telegraph, ushered into the proprietor's office, where he was confronted by Hartwell, sitting in front of one of the newspaper's maps of the world, c1930, and largely coloured red. On the walls of his dining room next door hung framed copies of famous billboards: Mafeking Relieved and Titanic Sunk. There was a sense of timeless integrity, out of place in a more ruthless modern world.

It seems appropriate that his old paper reported that he died with a copy of the Daily Telegraph on his lap.
