fields.headline: Flirting with Redwood
fields.standfirst:
Special report: House of Commons
Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: It was, admittedly, a weird coupling. My friends and family were appalled. Perhaps that was the appeal - a bit of Tory rough trade to get me going after so liberal and cultured an upbringing.
fields.body:
It was, admittedly, a weird coupling. My friends and family were appalled. Perhaps that was the appeal - a bit of Tory rough trade to get me going after so liberal and cultured an upbringing.

Mind you, John Redwood didn't look that rough when our eyes met across an empty room. He just looked gauche and sounded lonely with his stiff body and dead language The solipsist as politician touched me.

He later gave an interview with BBC Radio Wales and said that he'd never wanted me anyway. To begin with he certainly saw me as part of the general conspiracy. My appointment as a cabinet adviser had been forced on him. I was there, he thought, to spy, to report back to Downing Street on his doings, to frustrate from within the grand plan for Redwoodian domination.

It was the pathos that got to me. I had never come across anyone so enclosed. He had impure suburban prejudices allied to a fine administrative mind. It was a dangerous combination and he lacked charity towards his opponents.

But when he started to respond to treatment it was gratifying. He frightened everybody else. Civil servants clammed up in his presence. Grand schemes for reform came and went because he couldn't get them through. He was the original non-team player and I liked that for its own sake. Immature, I know.

The best thing about him was his hatred for the government of which he was a part. And our joint plan to subvert John Major, to tease his dreadful circle of bullies, was worth doing.

The worst thing about him was all that morality. He could - and did - preach for England. But the coldness was a personal tragedy, of which he was aware and could do nothing about. "My wife works for British Airways," he once said to me, "so she's good at spotting gays."

Trolly-dollies apart, he was light years away from normal tolerant England and Gail's gay psychic powers never seemed that strong to me. And when he told me that he didn't like wearing pink shirts because of the colour's gay association I really should have got in a muscle mary friend to beat him up.

He did a good and brave thing when he resigned from the Major cabinet. I resigned too as a jape and it was his eyes that filled with tears when he said that there was no need. He showed grace and resilience.

What followed was less beautiful. He convinced himself that the Tory leadership was his by indefeasible moral right. And this offended his colleagues.

He said in his interview that I was good at creating "chaos and confusion". Apparently I'd created mayhem when working with him and carried on doing so afterwards. Admittedly, I do have an anarcho-syndicalist temperament. I flirted with Tories simply because I disliked what the Welsh Labour party had done in a one-party, big-boss, intolerant country.

Now I see Conservatives as simply an English version of the same condition. I hate the collectivity and its lies. Those years as a cabinet adviser were the end of my long adolescence. They forced me into thinking more positively about what freedom meant.

In John Redwood's case freedom was economic - the liberty to sell and buy, to make money and to be private. It wasn't about exploration of the self, the discovery of potential, or voyaging through strange seas of thought. In that sense a less intellectual person never lived. A powerful mind constructed sophisticated bulwarks for the truisms he was born into and was happy with.

So the Queen (keen he thought to keep in touch after he resigned) was a very wise woman, Britain was semi-detached England and abroad was unutterably bloody.

I was glad to cause chaos in government because that was what he wanted and endorsed. I ignored serious consideration of his anti- Europeanism and concentrated on exposing the mess in health and education whose plight he rightly saw as pitiful.

It was distressing to see someone who took so high -if sanctimonious - a view of truth grinning and crawling through the hoops set up for him by William Hague. The advice I'm proudest of offering him was actually an instruction to stop his colleagues doing anti-gay briefing against William Hague's circle during the last leadership campaign.

I regard Mr Hague as an outrage to English liberalism and his own stance on clause 28 combines repugnance with irony. But it was John Redwood's association with such ugly obscurantism that ended his career as a front-line politician. The Redwood version of England is as dead as Arthur Bryant's history. The Thames valley Malvolio sleeps an unquiet rest.

 Hywel Williams was a former adviser to John Redwood, Conservative Welsh secretary

fields.headline: Lord Shepherd of Spalding
fields.standfirst: Labour hereditary peer who combined business success with ministerial efficiency
fields.trailText: Labour hereditary peer who combined business success with ministerial efficiency.
fields.body:
Grumpy, balding Lord Shepherd of Spalding, who has died aged 82, was Labour leader in the House of Lords from 1974 to 1976, but began and ended his political career in the upper house in near-obscurity. When his appointment was being finalised, Harold Wilson's press secretary, Joe Haines, told journalists: "I cannot let you have the name because it is not yet ready for release. But I can give you a hint: Psalm 23." When the Guardian and Financial Times disclosed Shepherd's identity next morning, even their knowledgeable readers asked: "Lord who?"

Although, by then, he had been both Labour chief whip and deputy speaker in the Lords, his impenetrable personality had made little impact on the political world. Only in Bishops' Bar, deep within the palace of Westminster, did he become jovial and convivial, the complete extrovert to those few peers with whom he drank.

There was no doubting Shepherd's shrewdness, however, particularly in the business field, for he had spent 18 years in south-east Asia, trying to outwit Chinese entrepreneurs. So canny was he that Lord Plurenden, better known as Rudi Sternberg, made him a director, and then deputy chairman, of his Sterling Group, notorious for trading with the East Germans.

Despite this background, Shepherd was deeply rooted in Labour traditions - he was the son of George Shepherd, the party's national agent between 1926 and 1946, a period that included the crisis year of Ramsay Macdonald's betrayal in 1931. By then, young Shepherd was a pupil at the Friends' school in Saffron Walden, Essex.

During the second world war, he served in the Royal Army Service Corps, seeing service in the western desert, Sicily and Italy, and being commissioned in 1941. Those who knew him best thought his most important wartime experience was his marriage, also in 1941, to Edinburgh-born Allison Redmond, a socially-conscious Scot.

After the war, Shepherd went to south-east Asia as a partner in a textile firm, becoming the chairman of another. Although, on the surface, just another successful businessman, he mixed with local people better than most - probably because of his Quaker education and Labour background. In this, he was like Malcolm Macdonald, Ramsay's son, who was then Britain's commissioner-general for south-east Asia.

Few knew locally that Shepherd's father had become the first Baron Shepherd, having been elevated by Clement Attlee in 1946 as thanks for having organised Labour's landmark election victory 1945. He too became chief whip in the Lords. When his father died in 1954, young Shepherd took six months' leave to settle the family affairs, take his seat in the Lords, make a maiden speech and return to south-east Asia for another four years.

In 1958, his company's headquarters moved to London, and his family returned home with it. After Labour lost the 1959 election, he took a job as a whip in the Lords, showing cunning if not brilliance. He devised a complex and inexpicable procedure known as "Shepherd's pie". When Labour won in 1964, Harold Wilson made him chief whip, or captain of the gentleman-at-arms. When Labour lost in 1970, he had to go to work for Sternberg, a fact he did not advertise.

Labour's unexpected return to power in March 1974 enabled Shepherd to become leader of the Lords and Lord Privy Seal and, in October 1974, also minister for the civil service. He was a very good minister, getting to the office at 8am and not speaking too much in cabinet. He was also not very forthcoming in his weekly, off-the-record briefing for journalists, as I can attest.

He left the Wilson government in 1976 because Sternberg, by then Lord Plurenden and in poor health, urgently wanted him back in the firm, and offered him recompense beyond his government salary. He remained deputy chairman of the Sterling Group until 1986.

In the following years, Shepherd mixed his political life with a continuing business career. Crucially, he was chairman of the mammoth National Bus Company from 1979-84. In 1989, he became chairman of Chequepoint International. When most hereditaries lost their right to sit and vote in 1999, he was made a life peer.

His wife predeceased him in 1998. He leaves two sons, with the elder, Graeme, inheriting the title.

 Malcom Newton Shepherd, Baron Shepherd of Spalding, businessman and politician, born September 27 1918; died April 5 2001

webTitle: Gene watchdog attacks Straw's DNA crackdown

fields.headline: Gene watchdog attacks Straw's DNA crackdown
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Jack Straw's plans to keep the personal DNA samples of millions of British citizens acquitted of any offence have been attacked by the government's own human genetics commission.
fields.body:
Jack Straw's plans to keep the personal DNA samples of millions of British citizens acquitted of any offence have been attacked by the government's own human genetics commission.

The commission, which was set up to advise on genetics policy but was not formally consulted about the proposals by the home secretary, is seeking changes before the radical measures become law.

The commission's chairwoman, Lady Kennedy, a Labour peer and lawyer, warned that plans for the police to keep samples of suspects found innocent is "a frightening move to a national database".

She said: "Being on a database of potential offenders which might be regularly trawled by the police means that, in a very important sense, one is on a list of suspects and that surely very subtly alters the way in which the state sees and the way in which we see our fellow citizens."

She suggested such a course would be seen as "a major erosion of presumption of trust which which exists between us and the state". She also warned the plan may be in breach of the European convention on human rights.

Members of the commission believe that an independent body, as opposed to the police, should oversee the samples.

The plan to keep DNA samples of anyone picked up by the police on suspicion of an offence is contained in the criminal justice and police bill, which has still to be considered by the Lords. The measure has the strong support of Tony Blair, and will be a key plank of Labour's manifesto if the measure does not reach the statue book before the election.

Police regard DNA samples as the biggest technological breakthrough of recent years in their battle to identify criminals. But some commission board members fear that the database could be used to predict a tendency towards criminality.

The commission, which is undertaking a wider review on the storage of genetic information, has found that Mr Straw's plans go much further than most European countries.

Lady Kennedy would personally like to see only those convicted of a serious crime included on the database. She said suspects found innocent should be entitled to apply for their sample to be removed after a period of time.

She added: "If there is one thing which the Alder Hey inquiry and its counterpart in Scotland have shown it is that people have very strong feelings about their own tissue and members of their family."

A Mori survey for the commission found 98% supported DNA samples being kept of anyone found guilty of murder. The figure dropped to 46% support for keeping DNA samples of someone acquitted of a crime.

The police DNA database already contains profiles of 900,000 individuals and 100,000 scenes of crime, with the numbers are growing at between 25,000 and 30,000 a month.

 A £90m boost was announced yesterday for law enforcement agencies to break up the networks of illegal people smugglers and drug traffickers over the next three years.

The extra money will be used to improve the "strategic and tactical" intelligence capabilities of the agencies which include MI5 and MI6, the national crime squad and customs and excise.

She added: "If there is one thing which the Alder Hey inquiry and its counterpart in Scotland have shown it is that people have very strong feelings about their own tissue and members of their family." A Mori survey for the commission found 98% supported DNA samples being kept of anyone found guilty of murder. The figure dropped to 46% support for keeping DNA samples of someone acquitted of a crime. The police DNA database already contains profiles of 900,000 individuals and 100,000 scenes of crime, with the numbers are growing at between 25,000 and 30,000 a month.  A £90m boost was announced yesterday for law enforcement agencies to break up the networks of illegal people smugglers and drug traffickers over the next three years. The extra money will be used to improve the "strategic and tactical" intelligence capabilities of the agencies which include MI5 and MI6, the national crime squad and customs and excise.

webTitle: Protest over Tory poll cash switch

fields.headline: Protest over Tory poll cash switch
fields.trailText: Labour last night challenged the newly created electoral commission to prevent the Conservatives diverting some of the £3m a year they get as the main Opposition party at Westminster into campaign funds for the coming election.
fields.body:
Labour last night challenged the newly created electoral commission to prevent the Conservatives diverting some of the £3m a year they get as the main Opposition party at Westminster into campaign funds for the coming election.

In the wake of Tory admissions that some of the so-called Short money is used to support shadow cabinet members "in the war room" at party HQ, Labour protested that such spending should be confined to "research associated with frontbench duties, developing and communicating alternative policies".

In a letter to the commission's chairman, Sam Younger, Labour MP Fraser Kemp said there was "a need for transparency on what exactly the Conservative party spends" the annual £3m on.

The move comes as the Conservatives faced another complaint from Labour, that they breached Commons rules by using parliament's banqueting rooms to raise party funds.

The Conservative frontbench club was allowed to go ahead with a lunch yesterday in the Commons due to be addressed by Andrew Lansley, the shadow cabinet office minister. Members of the club give more than £5,000 a year in return for access to frontbench politicians. The club advertises itself by saying that members are invited to several exclusive shadow cabinet lunches throughout the year and that the majority are held in the houses of parliament.

Commons rules state "private dining rooms are not be used for direct financial or material gain by a sponsor, political party or any other person".

The Commons catering committee chairman, George Turner, said future Tory club events would not be allowed. "It is using entertainment in the Commons banqueting facilities to entice people to give money and that is against the rules."

fields.headline: Yeo scraps animals plan
fields.trailText: William Hague has been forced to perform another U-turn and abandon a Tory policy on animal experiments amid fears that it could leave scientists vulnerable to terrorist attack.
fields.body:
William Hague has been forced to perform another U-turn and abandon a Tory policy on animal experiments amid fears that it could leave scientists vulnerable to terrorist attack.

In the face of a campaign from some leading scientists, the shadow agriculture minister, Tim Yeo, has quietly shelved his plan to end "secrecy" over animal experiments. His move marks the 12th policy U-turn performed by the Tory leadership.

Mr Yeo pledged in February that a Tory government would introduce legislation to force the government's animal procedures committee, which monitors animal experiments, to publish details of tests by scientists. Under the reforms, government inspectors would also be given powers to make surprise inspections of animal testing laboratories and the monitoring committee would have to explain why non-animal methods were unsuitable before licences for experiments would be granted.

Mr Yeo's plans prompted protests led by Colin Blakemore, professor of physiology at Oxford University, whose vivisection work has resulted in letter bombs and death threats from animal rights extremists. Prof Blakemore, who accused the Tories of "making policy on the hoof", said that Mr Yeo's plans "would guarantee the leakage of information to terrorist organisations".

Mr Yeo initially dismissed Prof Blakemore's criticisms. However, after meeting the Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry last month he decided to shelve his controversial policy. A source at the association said last night: "It is our understanding that the Tories are revising their policy. We were not consulted on the policy, but we found Mr Yeo very amenable at our meeting."

fields.headline: Bad language
fields.standfirst: Poor English murders clear-thinking - and academics, politicians and journalists are the culprits
fields.trailText: Poor English murders clear-thinking - and academics, politicians and journalists are the culprits.
fields.body:
It was in April 1946 that George Orwell's essay Politics and the English Language appeared in Horizon magazine with the memorable description of much political writing as stale phrases "tucked together like the sections of a prefabricated hen-house". His was the definitive demonstration of the connection between bad writing and bad politics.

Orwell helps us to identify dangers which, if not attended to, threaten the future of that progressive tradition of which he was such a distinguished representative. In drawing attention to these dangers, I want briefly to bite the three hands that have kept me moderately well fed for most of my life.

First, the academy. In particular, that section of it represented by the so-called social sciences. This is now giving us entire fields full of nothing but prefabricated hen-houses. When I became an editor of the Political Quarterly, a journal whose credo is clear argument in plain English, I started collecting particularly fine examples of such prefabrication from articles that were sent to us.

Here is one example, typical of many others, from a political scientist: "It is possible to offer a discussion of the 'Pacific Asian model' in terms which gesture to an ideal-typical political-economic configuration, related to social-institutional structures, and associated cultural forms."

Is anybody supposed to read this kind of stuff?

Academics are writing more and more about less and less, and in a mutilated language that cuts them off from the public arena. Is it because they really have nothing to say, or because - even if they had - they have forgotten how to say it? Where are the social science equivalents of those science writers who have looked for and found a huge public audience for their intelligently accessible books?

Where are the successors to public intellectuals like Bernard Crick and David Marquand, who repudiate narrow academic boundary lines in pursuit of the big picture that can make sense of the details?

Where, in other words, is the commitment to public philosophy that was the academic contribution to that old progressive tradition with its well-trodden path from the university common room to the Manchester Guardian? Its absence is today's trahison des clercs.

Second, the political class. The entire energies of today's political managers (in all parties) are devoted to closing down, or sealing off, free-range political argument. These are our thought police, the on-messengers of yet more prefabricated hen-houses.

This is the world of verbless vacuities, of mindless "modernisations", of "level playing fields" and "rolling outs", of robotic repetition of words and phrases that have long lost any connection with meanings. They glaze the eyes not only of the receivers but of the deliverers. They are, in Orwell's words, the stale tea leaves that block up the drain, preventing any fresh thoughts or arguments getting through.

Now the practitioners of this kind of politics, the thought policemen armed with their shiny, modern toolkits, these destroyers of political language, are not bad people. In fact they are usually good people, who want to do good things. But they are killing politics. And they have to be stopped.

Third, the media class. My charge here is that the media class has become the accomplice of the political class in closing down serious political argument.

The old distinction between fact and opinion has entirely disappeared, in the broadsheets no less than in the tabloids and with the broadcasters not far behind. News is routinely spun, by journalists as much as by politicians (and often in collusion). Stories are no longer expected to be true, even by those who write them. Speculation and suggestion is all. What matters is what sells.

In this environment, a sensible politician keeps his head down. If he is asked for his views, it is not because they might be thought interesting but because they might provide a journalistic opportunity to insert a cigarette paper of difference between these views and those of someone else.

The story becomes the difference, not the issue. Faced with this, the politician naturally comes to prefer a protected life inside the prefabricated hen-houses. The result is that, together, journalists and politicians are squeezing the life out of serious political debate.

So that is my charge sheet: academic abdication, political suffocation, and journalistic collaboration. It would be bad enough if only one of these was happening, but together and in combination they are threatening the basis upon which a serious public life can be conducted, and on which the progressive tradition was built.

We are not yet in Orwell's Room 101 (except as a television show, and it is rather alarming to find an O'Brien in the Home Office), but there is a sense in which we are now in the building. The only remedy is resistance. Orwell demands no less of us.

 Tony Wright is Labour MP for Cannock Chase and joint editor of the Political Quarterly.

webTitle: MIT to put its courses free on the internet

fields.headline: MIT to put its courses free on the internet
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited Education
More net news
fields.trailText: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology, one of the world's foremost universities, is pushing back the boundaries of education by making nearly all its courses freely available through the internet.
fields.body:
The Massachusetts Institute of Technology, one of the world's foremost universities, is pushing back the boundaries of education by making nearly all its courses freely available through the internet.

Over the next 10 years it will offer assignments, reading lists, outlines and notes on 2,000 courses on its website.

The venture is intended to counter what it calls the "privatisation of knowledge".

It will not give degrees to those using using the material on the MIT OpenCourseWare site. But the innovation could revolutionise e-learning and threaten the plans of universities which have seen internet courses as a source of revenue.

The MIT president, Charles Vest, said: "It will provide an extraordinary resource, free of charge, which others can adapt to their own needs."

About 500 courses are likely to be made available within two years at a cost of $7.5m-10m. The ultimate cost is expected to be about $100m.

William Jennings, vice-provost for professional and distance education at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, New York, said MIT's decision "may make all of us rethink the way we do things and encourage us all to be more open".

fields.trailText: "What's he doing?" asked Lauren.
fields.body:
"What's he doing?" asked Lauren.

Tom watched as the young man fumbled some pills into his mouth and dived into the canal. Shit. This is how people die, he thought, as he followed the boy into the water.

Lauren got undressed as Tom recovered in a hot bath. "It's not working out, is it?" she said, a little later. Tom had been impotent ever since Lauren had been trying to get pregnant.

"I'd better go to the hospital," he answered. "The ambulance crew picked up my coat by mistake."

The patient's name tag of Ian Wilkinson registered nothing, but Tom still felt a gnawing sense of recognition. "You're..." "That's right, I'm Danny Miller," the patient interrupted. "What a coincidence," said Tom.

Tom thought back 13 years to when Danny was 10. They had met when Tom had been asked to provide a psychological assessment on whether Danny was adult enough to stand trial for the murder of a pensioner.

"I need to talk," said Danny. "It's been tough since I got out from the secure unit." "I can see that," Tom answered. "I'll have to check with Martha, your probation officer."

"It was your fault I was convicted," said Danny, a few days later. "I didn't do it, you know." Tom felt uneasy. "Let's take it slowly," he dead batted. "Do you mind if I talk to some of your other case workers?"

"He was one of the most brilliant boys we've ever had here," said Bernard Greene, the head of the secure unit. "He was the most dangerous person I've ever met," confided his wife, when her husband was out of earshot.

"I want a divorce," said Lauren. Tom felt another boundary slip away.

"I'm terrified people will recognise me," whispered Danny.

"Let's go back to the murder."

"I'm lying under the bed and she comes back early and I push her down the stairs. Then I put a cushion over her head as I don't want her looking at me." "As you kill her."

Tom heard noises outside. "Is Danny Miller there?" shouted a crowd of journalists. He called Martha and Danny was taken to a safe house. But as he and Martha settled down to their new life together, Tom often wondered just what kind of recovery Danny had made.

And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested: Child psychologist and 10-year-old killer reconnect 13 years later and come up with precious few answers

webTitle: Mark Sevi: The king of film sequels

fields.headline: The king of sequels
fields.standfirst: Perhaps you saw his   landmark puppet movie, Ghoulies IV. Or his thought-provoking sci-fi chiller, Scanners: the Showdown. What about Fast Getaway II? No? Neither did anyone else. Hollywood scriptwriter  Mark Sevi  explains how he became the king of sequels
fields.trailText: Perhaps you saw his landmark puppet movie, Ghoulies IV. Or his thought-provoking sci-fi chiller, Scanners: the Showdown. What about Fast Getaway II? No? Neither did anyone else. Hollywood scriptwriter Mark Sevi explains how he became the king of sequels
fields.body:
My agent, David Saunders at Agency for the Performing Arts, called me on a Sunday afternoon and he loved my script. Hell, I didn't even know David existed at the weekend. I figured that on Monday they just took him out of the casket and he went directly to his dark office in that big building on Sunset. But, yes, that was his voice on the phone and he was saying all those things a writer dies to hear. First thing in the morning, he enthused, I would be on the Yellow Brick Road - a golden path only slightly stained by my seven years of hacking scripts that were made into bad movies by even worse directors, producers and actors.

The script went out, the responses came in, it was good. Very good. So good that super-producer John Davis (Predator, Grumpy Old Men, Grace Under Fire) wanted Fox studios to purchase it for him.

Davis's offices are in the really nice section of Los Angeles. As soon as I parked my car, I knew this was the bigs. The underground lot was studded with BMWs, Benzes and other expensive German and Italian iron. Most people were in casual clothes, a sure sign that they were players - they didn't give a rat's ass what you thought of them.

Standing at the portal to the Underworld, I glanced up at this imposing structure and couldn't help but reminisce on the whacked path that had led me here.

Wavy-line SFX as we flashback to...

Producer's office: young writer meets professional producer. Some illusions are shattered.

My first ever industry meeting, filled with glorious anticipation, lasted all of five minutes - and went something like this: "Mark, I read your script. You're a great writer. We can get dozens of writers like you. Get a better concept next time. A high concept." A what concept?

Let's define terms.

Spec script: Something you write on your own impetus that you hope someone will buy.

High concept: A story concept that you can describe in 10 words or less (since most studio execs have the attention span of a Halloween pumpkin but aren't nearly as bright). Example: "I see dead people."

Producer: An entity (not necessarily human) who makes it possible for your spec script to be purchased by the studios.

Studio exec: Another entity (see Producer) who takes your script up the studio's corporate ladder to the people who may ultimately make it into a movie.

Here's how it should work. I write a script on spec, a producer receives it from my agent, reads it, loves it and takes it to the studio with which they are affiliated. The studio buys it, makes it into a successful film and continues to pay me obscene amounts of money to write what I like.

Now, forget all that and you've got my career.

It was 1990. I wasn't all that young but I was fairly naive. I still believed in Santa Claus and reasonable Hollywood men and women. I was taking writing classes at a community college and had finished three scripts, two of which were science fiction. My goal was to bring better science fiction to the big screen. I wasn't having much luck. Seven out of the top 10 grossing films of all time have been sci-fi - you'd think it would be an easy sale. Not so. Any producer who read my work liked the writing and hated the concepts. If it wasn't ET, it wasn't really sci-fi, one producer maintained.

Fortunately, one of my rejected science fiction scripts, Nemesis, caught the attention of a company that was looking for new writers (new = non-union = cheaper than Writers' Guild). As a result, the company asked me to be part of a cattle call and pitch a concept for the sequel to Relentless, a low-budget film about a guilt-ridden serial killer who wants to be murdered by the police. The sequel was supposed to be a variation on the original, but it had to be clever enough to catch the attention of the film company, Cinetel, a very successful low-budget company that makes five or six money-producing films a year, year after year, mostly by selling them to cable networks or going direct to video.

My idea for Cinetel's sequel: a serial killer who is not a serial killer is killing people who are already dead.

They bought it almost instantly.

I was contracted to write the script and for what seemed like a lot of money ($38,000 in various increments). They wiggled out of the last $10,000 payment by declaring that they hadn't achieved a certain contractual production goal. Were they lying? Don't know. Did I care? Hell, no. I made $28,000 for three months' work. Do that a few times a year and you're living large.

The man who had directed the first Relentless was also going to direct the sequel. I saw him at an Academy awards party hosted by Cinetel. Never having met a director, I was full of the promise of the future, having already mentally bonded with this man, professional to professional. When I introduced myself to this (former porn-video) director, he told me flat-out that the script would never work - this without reading a single word of something that I had barely started. He would give me four films by the famed Italian horror director Dario Argento. I wasn't clear what he wanted me to learn from them, but I was nevertheless supposed to watch them and call him so we could change the script - even though he knew that I was contractually obligated to write only the concept that I had pitched to Cinetel.

Despite his intervention, I wrote the story I had pitched. Ultimately, he didn't end up directing the movie. Michael Schroeder, the replacement director, helped polish my script and make it visually stunning. Everyone lived happily ever after, right?

That could have happened.

The actor, Ray Sharkey (Idol Maker, Wiseguy), who they pulled in at the last minute to play the bad guy, was someone who I respected and admired. The first words out of his mouth were less than reassuring: "This is some of the worst shit writing I have ever seen. Who fucking talks like this?"

As our relationship progressed from bad to worse, I soon understood why Sharkey was such a convincing bad guy: he was an asshole. He turned the filming of Relentless II into a nightmare of petulant rants. I also learned a hard lesson. In the low-budget world, you only work with actors like Sharkey when they are on the downside of their career. By then, they are usually pretty grumpy fucks who hate the fact that they are doing a $2.5m genre flick instead of a $100m studio film. There are a lot of them.

Montage of scenes

Cinetel and I proved to be a good match. Around town its creative director, Catalaine Knell, was called the Queen of Bs. I was emerging as the King of Roman Numerals. After Relentless II, Cat and I collaborated on six more films, five of which were sequels. I was so busy at one time that I was working for two companies on three scripts, finishing one, starting another and polishing a third.

The movies were fast, fun and financially rewarding. Plus, the B-movie- makers would take chances that studios would never dare. It was hard, sometimes frustrating work, and I was always proud - until I saw the finished product, which most times made me cringe. Most times the movies I wrote made me cringe. There was always an excuse: bad director, alcoholic actors, no budget. But in the back of my mind, I thought maybe I'm just not a very good writer. Still, I had a good time, I made money and I didn't think about the future much. Eventually, I developed a sense of humour and a fatalism about the whole process. How else do you cope with the following experiences . . .

I was commissioned to write the fourth in a series of Ghoulies pictures, but (a rather big but) Cinetel couldn't afford the actual Ghoulie puppets. That meant I couldn't use any of the scenery-chewing title characters in the script. Imagine doing Jurassic Park without dinosaurs. ("Did you see that giant lizard?" "Where?" "Right there!" "Where?") I actually produced a pretty good script for G4 that was then brutally rewritten by the lead actor and director into the biggest mess I have ever seen - and, unfortunately, my name was the only one to make it to the credits.

Corey Haim and Corey Feldman are probably nice, normal guys now (or not). Back in the late 1980s the teen heartthrobs did a few films together, including Dream a Little Dream. Cinetel bought the rights to Dream a Little Dream 2 and asked me for a storyline. At the time, both boys were turning into, shall I say, adventurous young men. I was told by Cinetel to keep one of the Coreys (I don't remember which) "in jail" throughout the film because his personal habits were a little wild and Cinetel needed to maintain control over his performances. Then the other Corey got into even more trouble and I was asked to make him the one who had to spend time in jail. Why, exactly, was I working my ass off again?

Image Organization, another successful low-budget film house known for doing all the Scanners films, Deep Cover and other slick and professionally crafted B-movies, bought one script from me and hired me to write a sequel. For Scanners: The Showdown, I wrote what I considered a moody, thoughtful science fiction-horror film - my tribute to David Cronenberg, who years before had written and directed the first Scanners, a sci-fi classic. My script was enthusiastically embraced by all the executives at Image except, unfortunately, the man who was paying me. I was told to write an entirely new script in one week or I would be fired. I apparently didn't understand the rules of this sub-genre: each Scanner film (four at last count) must include two heads blowing up. I slammed out a new script in only five days and it was, of course, monstrously inadequate. But it was approved: it featured two exploding heads.

Mistress is a funny and sad film about a writer who has to continually rework his film to accommodate a revolving cadre of "film producers" who are porking empty-headed and talentless actresses with big tits. I thought it was fiction until I was put into the same position on not one, but four different projects. I don't want to name names here because some of those involved are nice people (and they might sue me). But for example: a film company I worked for purchased one of my scripts specifically to feature the producer's girlfriend, whom he hoped to turn into an action star. To be fair, she did the fighting shit well and was very attractive in all those skintight, cleavage-enhancing outfits. Unfortunately, there were actually portions of the script where she had to, you know, talk.

And so on for seven years with dozens of assignments, hundreds of story meetings and 12 produced films. I was getting just a little burned out and beginning to think that I was relegated to writing sub-par, genre scripts that paid the bills but in no way helped move me forward either careerwise or, more important, creatively.

Cut to: real-time

With my agent's blessing, I took a gamble and stopped taking low-budget assignments to write what I wanted to write. Arachnid was a labour of love - my passionate homage to the creature flicks of the 1950s, the kind of movie where a man/insect/alien grows to epic proportions because of exposure to radiation/virus/convenient substance and takes over whatever town/island/ planet the small-time production company could afford. These movies, like Them! and The Blob, were canonical masterpieces of B-movie-making. I knew, in this revisionist mood of Hollywood, that anything from 40 years ago was being given a new cloak of respectability. Throw enough money at something and you make it legitimate: old television, old movies or old actors. With studio-funding and the right creative urge, Arachnid could be a sci-fi classic.

Actually, not many - but the constant promise of this moment had kept me working hard. That meant hundreds of thousands of dollars for me - financial freedom. Plus, I would have the chance to work with consummately professional actors, directors and producers who understood what I was trying to do. You already know where this is going, don't you?

"Could the girl fall in love with the alien spider?" I figured that if he could get dates, then a giant, pus-dripping, alien spider could too.

I knew to keep the spider hidden for the majority of the film; keep people wanting to see what's behind that bush, how the spider will kill its victim. I only showed its legs, fangs, hairy armpits - until it was time for the big payoff. I've been reading, watching and studying sci-fi horror for decades; I love writing it. The suggestions (demands) they piled on me wouldn't have passed my 11-year-old niece's bullshit alarm.

I struggled for a futile month on synopsis rewrites, all for free, hopelessly trying to find the focus of these ludicrous ideas. The result was reams of vacuous crap that pleased neither me nor anyone at the studio. I was stunned. Where were the creative minds that propelled this movie business? Is the payday the only difference between the idiots at the bottom and the idiots at the top? "What did you expect?" my Cinetel friend Catalaine asked me. And maybe I wasn't a very good writer.

In the end they - Davis Productions, Fox studios - wouldn't return my phone calls, and all the remaining steam seemed to go out of my agent regarding my once-hot/now-not career. It took longer and longer for David to return my calls.

I never heard from him again on a Sunday.

Epilogue

I call it ESP, Endless Self-Promotion. You learn that no matter who you talk to, or about what subject, you always mention: 1) Your latest project; 2) Your last project; 3) Five ideas for your next project; 4) All of the above - twice.

Two years after Fox, having used my ESP, Arachnid ended up in the hands of an independent producer who needed scripts. Brian Yuzna (Re-Animator, The Dentist) had a three-picture deal with a Spanish film company that wanted to break into the American horror market. He pitched Arachnid as one of the 50 scripts that he could get. Those Spanish boys loved it. How can you go wrong with a giant alien spider? Then they read the script and loved it more. We began negotiating. Suddenly they didn't love it as much. In the end, they screwed me and I thanked them for it. I mean, who else is going to give me $45,000 for anything besides one of my kidneys?

I was actually happy at this turn of events. Even if Arachnid wasn't going to a studio, it was going to a group of people who had some low-budget chops. The producers, Sheri Bryant and Yuzna, are well known and well thought of in the horror world - the director they hired, Jack Sholder, equally so. The company that would do the spider effects and mockups, Steve Johnson's XFX, is one of the best in the world. Had I somehow slipped out of Fox, into a bucket of shit and come out smelling, well, if not like a rose then perhaps like one of those pine tree things you hang on your car mirror?

As of this writing, Arachnid is well into post-production, which means it has been filmed and it is in the editing room being cut together. Is it, will it be, any good? Last I heard, the actors, competent professionals who no one was screwing on the side, did a good job. The Spanish film company had even at one point grudgingly approved some extra money. The spider puppets and animatronics had performed as promised.

All good signs.

Unfortunately, one of the producers has also recently informed me that the director is missing shots. This happens occasionally in the mad rush of a low- budget shoot, and most times it's nothing to panic about - unless the missing scenes happen in the climax of the film and they feature (or don't feature, actually) the star of the movie, the king-size spider.

I don't know if the producers are willing to invest the money to fix the problem or if it's even possible at this late stage - all the sets were struck. Maybe spooky hand shadows will take the place of the alien arachnid in the missing scenes.

"Did you see that giant fucking spider?"

"Where?"

"Right there!"

But, yes, that was his voice on the phone and he was saying all those things a writer dies to hear. Davis's offices are in the really nice section of Los Angeles. As soon as I parked my car, I knew this was the bigs. fields.headline: Box clever?
fields.standfirst: A new, hi-tech 'concept' cinema opens in Greenwich today. But could it be bad news for arthouse films?  Brian Logan  finds out
fields.trailText: A new, hi-tech 'concept' cinema opens in Greenwich today. But could it be bad news for arthouse films? Brian Logan finds out
fields.body:
'We're running a bit close to the wire," says the man who greets me when I arrive at TheFilmWorks, Greenwich's new, all-singing, all-dancing 14-screen cinema. Can this really be the future of British movie-watching? A JCB lurches by the entrance, whipping up clouds of dust. The popcorn counter is enveloped in clingfilm. Two days' hence, Atomic Kitten will open TheFilmWorks, and they're used to plusher conditions than this.

TheFilmWorks is apparently "next-generation cinema". Its pilot branch opened in Manchester in the autumn; mark two launches today on the Greenwich peninsula. It's a colourless, drum-shaped construction, next to Sainsbury's and a flyover. But the view is more impressive from inside. The foyer is at the centre of an atrium, defined by circular balconies rising four levels up to a battleship-grey cupola. "I think it was inspired by the Dome," says my host, Lindsey. Which makes it unique in one way at least.

The Big Idea is as follows. According to Dave Harris, UCI's vice president in the UK: "Most people decide which cinema to visit based on film and location. The cinema brand has not really been pivotal in the decision process. This was where our opportunity lay. Brand differentiation has to occur." In the (less Dalek-like) words of head of marketing Janet Smith: "The multiplexes that we'd been building since the mid-1980s were boxes that had screens and showed films. We feel that we need to offer a place in which people have the opportunity to spend a whole night as part of a social event."

So what kind of "social event" might the Greenwich FilmWorks - and the others to follow - offer? Its foyer is a branding theme park: to your left, Ben & Jerry's, to your right, Café Nescafe; McDonald's next door. There's a bar, Hollywood and Vine, that flogs wines from Francis Ford Coppola's vineyard - we can only hope they're better than his recent movies. And then there's the design. Smith claims that UCI wishes "to create a more contemporary feel".

So the aesthetic here, as in Manchester, is post-industrial: the inner walls of the drum snake with fat, foil-clad piping. But that aside, TheFilmWorks makes no dramatic breach with the usual airport-lounge-in-Technicolor multiplex décor. I wouldn't choose to spend a whole evening here.

My pre-opening tour seems to imply a more maverick, design concept: labyrinthine confusion. Navigating the building's Escher-like recursions, TheFilmWorks' brainwave becomes clear: audiences will stay and watch all 14 movies only if they're denied any visible means of escape. It'll be easier by Friday, says my guide, seeking the foyer and stumbling through a fire exit into the street.

The cinema's chief innovation, however, is social - it will segregate audiences into first- and second-class. Those paying £15 a ticket gain access to an exclusive top-floor bar. In the auditorium, they're treated to the comfiest, body-sculpted armchairs - I felt like Jimmy Saville when I tried one out - and waited on throughout the movie by "cast members" (many recruited from the Dome) toting drinks and nibbles.

The auditoria are all "black box", which is to say, in Smith's words, "black seats, black walls, black carpet, and very low level lighting, so there are no distractions while you're watching the film". The cinema's audio and visual technology is state-of-the-art, judging by the length of the acronyms. The effect, it appears from one sample reel, is to render film viewing an experience neither of the heart nor the mind, but of the viscera: this is the point at which the movies meet the fairground. I watch a trailer for The Mummy Returns, and it's practically an out-of-body experience.

Is this, then, a reflection of audience priorities at the start of the 21st century? Richard Gray strongly doubts it. The chairman of the Cinema Theatre Association is a campaigner against multiplexes and in favour of "the wonderful cinemas that were built in the past". It's not news to him that audiences might select a night out by venue rather than film, and the fact that UCI are thinking along these lines he finds encouraging. But he can't believe anyone would actively prefer the new Greenwich megaplex, which "looks like a biscuit tin". And on hearing of the "black box" concept, he splutters with derision: "That's so boring and dreary it's not true. We've all done that, been there. That is the decorative cop-out to end them all."

A more telling cop-out on TheFilmWorks' part relates not to its upholstery but to its entertainment. For, while digital pyrotechnics in the screening rooms may greatly embellish the blockbuster experience, what of films made in a lower key? Janet Smith can't guarantee that arthouse films will feature on any of Greenwich's 14 screens. With two smaller auditoria of only 46 seats apiece, she claims, "you do have the opportunity to try other things, and we will be trying other things" - as if exhibiting non-Hollywood fare were a curious fetish. "We'll see," she concludes ominously, "what the people want."

This is the context from which Harris's hankering for "brand differentiation" springs: the homogenising effect of multiplexes on cine-culture. UCI are now "branding" the idea that a cinema might do more than show movies, might offer an environment amenable to pre- and post-show socialising. But that "idea" is nothing new. A poll this week of London audiences was won hands-down by picture-houses offering just such environments. They weren't multiplexes, but independent cinemas: the Curzon Soho, the Ritzy in Brixton, the NFT. For all its much-trumpeted radicalism, UCI's scheme is about appropriating the indies' innovations - save for the one that might actually engender audience loyalty, which is quality programming.

According to Dave Harris, UCI's vice president in the UK: "Most people decide which cinema to visit based on film and location. The cinema brand has not really been pivotal in the decision process. This was where our opportunity lay. Brand differentiation has to occur." In the (less Dalek-like) words of head of marketing Janet Smith: "The multiplexes that we'd been building since the mid-1980s were boxes that had screens and showed films. We feel that we need to offer a place in which people have the opportunity to spend a whole night as part of a social event." So what kind of "social event" might the Greenwich FilmWorks - and the others to follow - offer? Its foyer is a branding theme park: to your left, Ben & Jerry's, to your right, Café Nescafe; McDonald's next door. There's a bar, Hollywood and Vine, that flogs wines from Francis Ford Coppola's vineyard - we can only hope they're better than his recent movies. And then there's the design. Smith claims that UCI wishes "to create a more contemporary feel". So the aesthetic here, as in Manchester, is post-industrial: the inner walls of the drum snake with fat, foil-clad piping. But that aside, TheFilmWorks makes no dramatic breach with the usual airport-lounge-in-Technicolor multiplex décor. I wouldn't choose to spend a whole evening here. My pre-opening tour seems to imply a more maverick, design concept: labyrinthine confusion. Navigating the building's Escher-like recursions, TheFilmWorks' brainwave becomes clear: audiences will stay and watch all 14 movies only if they're denied any visible means of escape. It'll be easier by Friday, says my guide, seeking the foyer and stumbling through a fire exit into the street. The cinema's chief innovation, however, is social - it will segregate audiences into first- and second-class. Those paying £15 a ticket gain access to an exclusive top-floor bar. In the auditorium, they're treated to the comfiest, body-sculpted armchairs - I felt like Jimmy Saville when I tried one out - and waited on throughout the movie by "cast members" (many recruited from the Dome) toting drinks and nibbles. The auditoria are all "black box", which is to say, in Smith's words, "black seats, black walls, black carpet, and very low level lighting, so there are no distractions while you're watching the film". The cinema's audio and visual technology is state-of-the-art, judging by the length of the acronyms. The effect, it appears from one sample reel, is to render film viewing an experience neither of the heart nor the mind, but of the viscera: this is the point at which the movies meet the fairground. I watch a trailer for The Mummy Returns, and it's practically an out-of-body experience. Is this, then, a reflection of audience priorities at the start of the 21st century? Richard Gray strongly doubts it. The chairman of the Cinema Theatre Association is a campaigner against multiplexes and in favour of "the wonderful cinemas that were built in the past". It's not news to him that audiences might select a night out by venue rather than film, and the fact that UCI are thinking along these lines he finds encouraging. But he can't believe anyone would actively prefer the new Greenwich megaplex, which "looks like a biscuit tin". And on hearing of the "black box" concept, he splutters with derision: "That's so boring and dreary it's not true. We've all done that, been there. That is the decorative cop-out to end them all." A more telling cop-out on TheFilmWorks' part relates not to its upholstery but to its entertainment. For, while digital pyrotechnics in the screening rooms may greatly embellish the blockbuster experience, what of films made in a lower key? Janet Smith can't guarantee that arthouse films will feature on any of Greenwich's 14 screens. With two smaller auditoria of only 46 seats apiece, she claims, "you do have the opportunity to try other things, and we will be trying other things" - as if exhibiting non-Hollywood fare were a curious fetish. "We'll see," she concludes ominously, "what the people want." This is the context from which Harris's hankering for "brand differentiation" springs: the homogenising effect of multiplexes on cine-culture. UCI are now "branding" the idea that a cinema might do more than show movies, might offer an environment amenable to pre- and post-show socialising. But that "idea" is nothing new. A poll this week of London audiences was won hands-down by picture-houses offering just such environments. They weren't multiplexes, but independent cinemas: the Curzon Soho, the Ritzy in Brixton, the NFT. For all its much-trumpeted radicalism, UCI's scheme is about appropriating the indies' innovations - save for the one that might actually engender audience loyalty, which is quality programming.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Black and White | Play It to the Bone | Breakfast of Champions
fields.trailText: Black and White | Play It to the Bone | Breakfast of Champions
fields.body:
Black and White
Rental and DVD rental Columbia Tristar Cert 18

James Toback's view of life on both sides of the racial divide and the inbetweenies - white kids apeing black hip-hop culture - is ragged but always interesting. Toback's aim seems to be to slam together a mixed bag of white actors - Robert Downey Jr, Ben Stiller and Brooke Shields among them - and black rappers such as Power and Raekwon, mix up the sexual preferences and provocative plotlines and see what transpires. Amid the loose plot strands, the key development sees the ever-impressive Stiller entrap a young black basketball player into throwing a match for $50,000 for motives that turn out to be very twisted.

The subtext seems to be whites exploiting blacks and getting away with it because society's set up that way. Black and White is best-known for the scene in which Downey, playing a gay film director comes on to Mike Tyson: "It's just that in the dream, you were holding me . . ." It's typical of writer- director-gambler Toback and the ultimate risk-taker Downey that this development in a largely improvised enterprise clearly comes as a surprise to the ex-champ, playing himself. Seconds out. It's notable too for Brooke Shields, unrecognisable as a dreadlocked documentary director, and for Claudia Schiffer, that most mainstream of models who, as an occasional actress, finds the edgiest parts imaginable - in Abel Ferrara's drugfest The Blackout and here, as a duplicitous girlfriend of two black guys. The soundtrack mixes Bach and Shostakovich with the Wu-Tang Clan and Raekwon. Yo, Johann.

Play It to the Bone

Rental and DVD (£15.99) Warner Cert 15

A tale of two boxers that is reminiscent of writer-director Ron Shelton's best films, Bull Durham (two sportsmen involved with a smarter woman) and White Men Can't Jump (Woody Harrelson with a joshing protagonist). Since the woman in question is Lolita Davidovitch, a fine actress as well as being Mrs Shelton, and the second boxer is the balletic Antonio Banderas, you settle back awaiting Shelton's punchy prose and Hawks-style sparky sparring. But, in what is mainly a road movie with the trio driving from LA to Las Vegas, it never really happens.

The set-up is that Harrelson and Banderas are old friends and washed-up fighters who suddenly get to box each other on the undercard for Mike Tyson with the winner getting a title shot. Shelton throws in scene-stealing cameos from Lucy Liu as an amoral travelling companion and Robert Wagner as a smarmbag hotel boss, stacks the tape deck with Delbert McClinton and John Lee Hooker and films the long, bruising contest with hallucinogenic boxer's-eye views with some skill. But it's not nearly enough. Shelton has been great at creating real people - but here he just has cardboard cut-outs with a quirk each, boring scenery and a pat ending. Let's hope this shocking loss of form is a one-off. We need Shelton punching his weight.

Breakfast of Champions
Rental Warner Cert 15

I dimly remember Kurt Vonnegut's novel being a satire that worked, mainly through its author's eccentric writing style. Not a year has passed since without somebody announcing a film treatment and here is the finished article, 28 years after the book and minus any semblance of wit, humour or restraint. Bruce Willis, whose clout got the project made, plays a salesman undergoing a breakdown. But since everyone else in town appears equally deranged, you'd hardly notice. Director Alan Rudolph specialises in quiet, thoughtful literary adaptations, but here any satirical intent is drowned in a vat of loud overacting, plot incoherence and clumping pretensions to significance. Willis's town is surrounded by toxic swamp. Old reliables like Nick Nolte and Albert Finney must wish their contributions in this cataclysmically misconceived venture had been swallowed up in a poisonous dump of unreleased film stock.

fields.headline: Better than Sex
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Very slight and derivative sex comedy.
fields.body: The Seventh London Australian film festival kicks off with this very slight and derivative sex comedy. It stars the likable, talented Susie Porter as Cin, a designer who has a raunchy fling with Josh (David Wenham) and, like him, is scared by the thought that it could be getting serious. Porter was sexier and more interesting in her recent erotic thriller with Kelly McGillis, The Monkey's Mask, and this is tiresomely intersected with monologue pieces-to-camera from Cin, Josh and their buddies about Sex, Relationships, etc - a pretty tired-looking gimmick.

fields.headline: Rugrats in Paris: the Movie
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Toy Story it ain't.
fields.body: The appeal of these little baby moppets with their potty humour passes me by with a mile or two to spare, and their jokey references to The Godfather do not approach, say, the sophisticated fun of The Emperor's New Groove. But anyway - here they are in a sequel that takes them to Paris, France, where they find themselves in a Japanese-themed family fun park, where the climactic showstopper is the rugrats working the controls of a giant dinosaur creature, lumbering through the streets of the French capital. It ends with that most hilarious of things - a food fight. Toy Story it ain't.

fields.headline: Les Enfants du Siècle
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: This breast-beating, breast-baring affair has a certain entertaining forth rightness, but there are too many romantic and period cliches.
fields.body:
Director Diane Kurys offers a fervent, emotionally grandiloquent account of the affair between the 19th-century novelist George Sand, played by Juliette Binoche, and her younger lover, the poet and libertine Alfred de Musset (Benot Magimel), elevating their tangled, on-off relationship to the status of tragic romance.

The movie avowedly takes as its starting point Musset's autobiographical La Confession d'un Enfant du Siècle, which makes much of his tempestuous history with Sand; the resulting film makes it seem that he was the love of her life, whereas he was just one of a number of significant lovers and romantic allies. (For example, the story of Sand's seven-year liaison with Chopin became the film Impromptu a few years back, with Judy Davis and Hugh Grant.)

This breast-beating, breast-baring affair has a certain entertaining forth rightness, but there are too many romantic and period cliches, including some very cheesy "whoring" sequences in which the dissolute poet laughs lustily with the tarts in the stews while scribbling and sketching in an adorably bohemian way. And the scenes in Venice, in which Sand falls in love with the doctor tending the opium-raddled Musset, have a touch of the school play about them.

fields.headline: The Wedding Planner
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: As for McConaughey, well, whatever presence or charisma he ever had has been surgically extracted, loaded into some sort of supergun and fired off into outer space.
fields.body:
You could take a 90-year-old donkey with four broken legs and still have something less lame than this dire "comedy". It's got Jennifer Lopez as the uptight wedding planner who falls in love with Matthew McConaughey, one of her grooms, naturally. A zero-brainer from first to last, it's a lazy mish-mash of feelgood comedies like The Wedding Singer, My Best Friend's Wedding or Runaway Bride, in which the makers are hoping to hitch a free ride from the (assumed) emotional intensity, drama and happiness of a wedding.

McConaughey is a paediatrician (for which read: gonna be a great dad, as well as swoon-inducingly rich) and his wronged fiancee is an internet millionaire - that will give you some idea of how clued-up and cutting edge this is. Cute, comic dialogue has to rise like a souffle, but this souffle is made of lead shot. As a performer, J-Lo has immaculate lip gloss. And as for McConaughey, well, whatever presence or charisma he ever had has been surgically extracted, loaded into some sort of supergun and fired off into outer space, leaving behind the dullest leading man in the movies. The Wedding Planner is a film to leave at the altar.

fields.headline: Bamboozled
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A muddled, exasperating movie, but with undeniably powerful moments and its own bull-in-a-china-shop energy.
fields.body:
What a bizarre, sulphuric, directionless satire from Spike Lee this is. The title is from a speech by Malcolm X ("You've been led astray, led amok. You've been bamboozled") and Lee quotes it by unblushingly showing a clip of his own movie with Denzel Washington addressing a crowd. Damon Wayans plays Pierre Delacroix, an upwardly mobile black TV executive with the strangulated pseudo-white voice Eddie Murphy famously sent up in his stand-up act. Pierre's trying to get aspirational black middle-class sitcoms on the air. But his neurotic white boss Dunwitty (Michael Rapaport - recently one of Woody Allen's Small Time Crooks) continuously demands edgy, street, gangsta-style stuff from the ghetto.

Goaded beyond endurance, Pierre cooks up a mad, defiant flourish - part radical-situationist stunt, part career suicide - designed to get himself fired with a pay-off. His new programme is a grotesque minstrel show set on an Alabamy plantation with black people actually blacking up with burnt cork - and of course, it's a huge postmodern ratings smash.

Like many movies, Bamboozled implies that TV is the big villain, and repeatedly alludes to Peter Finch being "mad as hell" in Network. But the obvious precursor, Mel Brooks's The Producers, is not mentioned - I suspect because the director does not care to make common cause with Jewish victimhood, however comically invoked.

The satire gets sprayed everywhere: on the radical black group that finally abducts the minstrel show's star, on the corporate executives promoting ghetto chic (the programme is sponsored by "Tommy Hillnigger" with an Ali G chorus of "white niggas"), and of course on the horrific minstrel show itself. This last target would appear to be a bafflingly obvious Aunt Sally - though admittedly in this country, black licence-payers were required to subsidise the BBC's Black and White Minstrel Show until 1978.

Evidently Lee is saying that the attitude of white corporate America to black identity simply makes for a 21st century minstrel show. But this is a strangely indirect and heavy-handed way of making the point, as well as arguably regressive and defeatist. Finally Lee gives us a long montage of clips from "minstrel" movies, implying a perverse connoisseurship of this lost culture and a desire to reclaim and contextualise it in some way.

It's a muddled, exasperating movie, but with undeniably powerful moments and its own bull-in-a-china-shop energy. Modern Hollywood clearly thinks that invoking racial tension without a happy ending shows a want of taste. So maybe Lee's sheer tactlessness is refreshing.

fields.headline: A One and a Two
fields.standfirst:
The main character's life is falling to pieces,
but Edward Yang's family drama is still vastly
entertaining, says Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A feat of storytelling which is carried off with tremendous poise and unobtrusive artistic integrity.
fields.body:
The film of the week could be the film of the year. This spacious family drama, written and directed by Edward Yang, is exquisitely considered, richly textured, beautifully acted, moving, funny and wise. Encountering this movie after the dreck and dross of most of the globalised Hollywood product sloshing about at the moment is like being allowed to drink Dom Perignon after being force-fed gallons of flat Vimto. It was a deserved hit at Cannes last year, winning the best director prize, and a second viewing deepens and enriches the impression that this outstanding movie leaves.

Much has already been made critically of the "novelistic" quality of A One and a Two, a film about the interconnecting tribulations of one extended family in contemporary Taipei. It revolves around a man whose computer firm is failing, whose wife is deeply depressed, whose mother-in-law is gravely ill, whose children are beset with problems, whose dodgy brother-in-law owes him cash. To top it all off, he has just met the person he jilted when she was a schoolgirl 30 years before: now a beautiful and elegant woman who, in a blaze of passion, reveals that her teenage angst and vulnerability are still as fresh as a daisy and demands to know why he left her all those years ago.

A One and a Two's literary quality resides in the easy yet thoughtful way Yang manages all the narrative strands, while having the confidence to go off on tangents and intriguing byways. Yang succeeds in inserting all sorts of footnotes and diverting appendices about the human condition - and modern Taiwan's relationship with Japan and the US - and yet never loses his thread, or allows us to lose the desire to know what happens to everyone in the end.

From these elements, Yang conjures the effect of what in a novel would be a narrative voice: a humorous, if sad and shrewdly careworn voice, in whose presence we gain access to the mind of Yang's reticent hero, NJ Jian. He is splendidly played by Nien-Jen Wu, an actor who is also a distinguished screenwriter and director in his own right.

Even the title, based as it is on an idiosyncratic allusion, sounds bookish. The karmic oneness of the universe divided in two, maybe? The paradox of two lovers and one love? No - all it means is how jazz musicians count themselves in for a live number: it's a happy introduction to the laid-back ensemble style of which Yang shows such mastery, and which acts as a solvent to the intensity, and occasionally the melodrama that his movie acts out.

It starts at a raucous, rowdy wedding reception: that of the corpulent, giggling A-Di (Hsi-Sheng Chen) and the heavily pregnant Xiao Yan (Shu-shen Hsiao). The event is immediately poisoned by the sudden, hysterical appearance of the groom's old girlfriend Yun-Yun (Hsin-Yi Tseng), who behaves like the spectre at the feast. Her calculated malice is of a piece with her unwelcome arrival some months later at a small party to celebrate the birth of Xiao Yan's baby, which she appraises with cool detachment before saying sweetly, "It looks more like the mother than the father!" - a deliciously subtle, vicious stab at Xiao Yan's sexual continence.

It's all part of the headache for NJ, who is thunderstruck by an accidental meeting at the hotel where the reception is taking place with Sherry (Su-Yun Ko), his first love and, as he and we are to realise in the course of the film, very probably his only love. They exchange halting pleasantries, laden with a Brief Encounters poignancy, and Sherry walks away. Then she turns on her heel, comes back, and demands to know why NJ stood her up for what was to be their final, non-existent date. It is the beginning of an unsentimental journey into the past for both of them, bringing revelations about the terrible choices that life and love force on us all.

Yang and his cinematographer Wei-han Yang capture the interlocking human dramas coolly and unassumingly, often filming the principals in long shot, as if noticed from a high window, as they stroll together through the streets or chat in cafes. The director has a particular feel for the daylit interiors of apartments: either the chintzy and rather cramped haute-bourgeois home of NJ, or A-Di's glossy, flashy pad. It creates an overwhelmingly plausible habitat for real lives and real emotions: a stunningly empathetic transcription of so many feelings - those of an eight-year-old boy, a teenage girl and a dying old woman. It is a feat of storytelling which is carried off with tremendous poise and unobtrusive artistic integrity.

When people talk about today's new golden age of "arthouse cinema", this is the kind of film they mean, and Edward Yang is the kind of director they mean - although confining A One and a Two to the ghetto of "arthouse" is obtuse. It is unmistakably the work of an artist, but it is still vastly entertaining. It demands to be seen.

From these elements, Yang conjures the effect of what in a novel would be a narrative voice: a humorous, if sad and shrewdly careworn voice, in whose presence we gain access to the mind of Yang's reticent hero, NJ Jian. He is splendidly played by Nien-Jen Wu, an actor who is also a distinguished screenwriter and director in his own right. Even the title, based as it is on an idiosyncratic allusion, sounds bookish. The karmic oneness of the universe divided in two, maybe? The paradox of two lovers and one love? No - all it means is how jazz musicians count themselves in for a live number: it's a happy introduction to the laid-back ensemble style of which Yang shows such mastery, and which acts as a solvent to the intensity, and occasionally the melodrama that his movie acts out. It starts at a raucous, rowdy wedding reception: that of the corpulent, giggling A-Di (Hsi-Sheng Chen) and the heavily pregnant Xiao Yan (Shu-shen Hsiao). The event is immediately poisoned by the sudden, hysterical appearance of the groom's old girlfriend Yun-Yun (Hsin-Yi Tseng), who behaves like the spectre at the feast. Her calculated malice is of a piece with her unwelcome arrival some months later at a small party to celebrate the birth of Xiao Yan's baby, which she appraises with cool detachment before saying sweetly, "It looks more like the mother than the father!" - a deliciously subtle, vicious stab at Xiao Yan's sexual continence. It's all part of the headache for NJ, who is thunderstruck by an accidental meeting at the hotel where the reception is taking place with Sherry (Su-Yun Ko), his first love and, as he and we are to realise in the course of the film, very probably his only love. They exchange halting pleasantries, laden with a Brief Encounters poignancy, and Sherry walks away. Then she turns on her heel, comes back, and demands to know why NJ stood her up for what was to be their final, non-existent date. It is the beginning of an unsentimental journey into the past for both of them, bringing revelations about the terrible choices that life and love force on us all. Yang and his cinematographer Wei-han Yang capture the interlocking human dramas coolly and unassumingly, often filming the principals in long shot, as if noticed from a high window, as they stroll together through the streets or chat in cafes. The director has a particular feel for the daylit interiors of apartments: either the chintzy and rather cramped haute-bourgeois home of NJ, or A-Di's glossy, flashy pad. It creates an overwhelmingly plausible habitat for real lives and real emotions: a stunningly empathetic transcription of so many feelings - those of an eight-year-old boy, a teenage girl and a dying old woman. It is a feat of storytelling which is carried off with tremendous poise and unobtrusive artistic integrity. When people talk about today's new golden age of "arthouse cinema", this is the kind of film they mean, and Edward Yang is the kind of director they mean - although confining A One and a Two to the ghetto of "arthouse" is obtuse. It is unmistakably the work of an artist, but it is still vastly entertaining. It demands to be seen.

webTitle: MoD may use old RAF pipeline to confound fuel protests

fields.headline: Enemy within
fields.standfirst:
Wartime RAF pipeline may be used to beat future fuel protesters

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence is considering converting a secret military pipeline to push motor fuel around the country to beat any future fuel bockade.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence is considering converting a secret military pipeline to push motor fuel around the country to beat any future fuel bockade.

Ministers were startled last year by the speed with which British industry ground to a halt as a result of the relatively small number of pickets of key oil refineries. The blockade was lifted after the pickets realised the extent of the damage they were causing to Britain's hospitals and civil life.

The government had at the time of the crisis considered activating a little-known government pipeline system, which was originally built to link wartime airfields, above, and to refuel emergency vehicles as part of defences against a Nazi invasion. There are altogether 1,500 miles of pipelines across the country, many serving RAF air bases dotted around the country.

The system was built in 1938. During the cold war it was linked to civilian airports including Heathrow, Gatwick, Stansted and Manchester. It now runs through major cities including Bristol, London, Liverpool and Humberside, connecting RAF Strike Command bases, US Air Force bases and the airports.

A daily aerial survey is carried out along the pipeline to check for damage. Ministers now want to see if it should be expanded and converted.

The defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, has ordered a feasibility study to see if the costs of the conversion would be prohibitive. Outside industry experts claim the scheme could cost as much as £50m, but civil defence chiefs believe conversion could make a substantial contribution to beating future fuel protest blockades. The Ministry of Defence said last night no decision had been made yet on the future of the pipeline, but an assessment was being made of the cost of converting it to cary fuel for motor vehicles.
