Ke Su Di and Ke Shi Guang were cheated. Both men thought they would be flying to the UK, travelling on their own legitimate passports. For at least part of the journey this was the case. They flew from Beijing to Belgrade, the gateway for illegal immigration into the EU. Close ties between Beijing and an increasingly isolated Milosevic regime made access easy for Chinese citizens, and tens of thousands of Chinese took advantage. At any one time around 50,000 of the 200,000 Chinese in Yugoslavia are preparing to leave Belgrade for the west, a senior immigration intelligence source told the Guardian. Codewords Wearing their "uniform" of grey T-shirts and black trousers and armed with codewords issued by the snakeheads to prevent rival gangs picking them up in error, the pair, by now part of a larger group of around 15 immigrants, moved by road and on foot towards Hungary. Here the journey met its first hitch. Hungarian border police kicked open the doors of the van in which they were travelling and discovered the immigrants, turning them back towards Yugoslavia. No matter. Within days they tried again and this time succeeded. At this point both men had their Chinese passports confiscated by their snakehead minder, and were given fake Korean documents. With these they passed quickly through Hungary before crossing into Austria in a van with darkened windows, crouching in silence as torches probed the cab. Here the group had their first brush with disaster. They were left in the back of the van for more than three hours, during which time it became harder to breathe and three people fell unconscious. The others, realising the danger they were in, kicked out the windows and revived their colleagues. This was the group's last attempt at concealment until the fatal journey to Dover. They proceeded to Vienna where, on their forged Korean passports, they caught a plane to Charles de Gaulle airport in Paris. From here they took a train to Belgium and then on to Rotterdam, arriving on June 15 to find the station platform a sea of Dutch football fans. As the Dover 60 were making their way north in small groups, preparations were being made in Rotterdam and London for the final leg. In Rotterdam a local Turkish mafia gang, under the leadership of Gurbel Ozcan, 36, had been sub-contracted to take responsibility for the snakeheads' assets. Ozcan, who cruised Rotterdam in a black Mercedes with darkened windows, was a hardened people smuggler. In 1998 he served six months for people trafficking offences and in the months preceding the fatal June shipment he sent two other lorries laden with Chinese immigrants across the Channel. Ozcan and his co-conspirators met to discuss the operation in the bar of the New York hotel, Rotterdam, on Monday June 12, six days before the transport. Unknown to Ozcan, however, his car had been bugged by Dutch police, and his every move was monitored. Inexplicably, the police lifted their surveillance of the gang leader just before the weekend on which the Dover transport was made, convinced that Ozcan had no imminent operations planned. The opposite was the case. Leo Nijveen, an old friend of Perry Wacker's and a sometime driver for Ozcan's lorries, told police a backlog of migrants was building up in Rotterdam and Ozcan was concerned at the cost of housing and feeding them. He ordered the overloading of lorries heading for England. On April 5 Nijveen himself had been in charge of one of these lorries with 50 Chinese on board along with the token pallet of legitimate cargo, in this case yoghurt. Halfway through the 3.30am Zeebrugge-Dover crossing Nijveen heard screaming and banging from the lorry as its human cargo began to run out of oxygen. Nijveen, unlike Wacker, threw open the doors and let the Chinese out. They were processed at the Dover immigration centre, and Nijveen was fined £2,000 per head, then allowed to return to Holland. Police later said there was insufficient evidence to show he knew they were on board. Despite the April 5 incident, Ozcan was determined to clear the backlog. A number of petty crooks were hired to do the dirty work, thus shielding Ozcan from any investigation. Hubertus van Keulen, 50, was paid £1,200 to rent the warehouse at Waalhaven, while Willem Jansen, 49, was paid £2,000 to buy the tomatoes, the dummy cargo, which Nijveen and Wacker later collected. The pair also bought the tractor unit of the truck from a garage near Wacker's home, and later purchased the trailer. Nijveen had been retained as an advisor and it was he who recruited Wacker, a lorry driver from Rotterdam's eastern suburbs. The pair had worked together as drivers for a transport firm run by Ronald Wacker, Perry's uncle, and Nijveen knew his friend was desperate for cash. Wacker was due to be married in Rotterdam on July 17, a month after the transport, to a Moroccan girl called Nora he had met in Spain the previous year. Wacker was desperate for money. His fiancee was not an EU national and he had to satisfy Dutch authorities that he could support both of them. Nijveen was keen to offload the driving work to someone else and introduced Wacker to the conspiracy, telling him he stood to make at least £30,000 at £500 per person. Wacker agreed. With a driver engaged, the final stage in the preparations was to set up a cover company to protect Ozcan and the snakeheads in the event that the consignment was discovered by customs. For this they needed a front man, a "katvanger", someone paid to provide a cover identity for criminal operations. For the ill-fated transport the gang engaged Arien van der Speck, a punchy petty criminal from the eastern suburb of Terbregge. Days before the transport, Van der Speck visited the Rotterdam chamber of commerce and founded a haulage firm, Van Der Speck Transport. He took his money and left, hearing nothing more until the Rotterdam police knocked on his door on June 19. He has since been charged with false certification. The final stage in the journey was organised by snakeheads living among London's 60,000-strong Chinatown community. To them fell the task of organising asylum applications, and more importantly making arrangements for final fees to be paid. The Dover 60's first point of contact in the UK was to be a young Chinese interpreter, Ying Guo, 29, known to many who worked with her as Jenny. Twenty-seven of those that died had her mobile phone number on them, either on a scrap of paper or stitched into their clothing. A Mandarin speaker from north-eastern China, Guo who arrived in England in late August 1996, travelling legally on a student visa to study English, accounting and computing at Edgware College, north London. She had worked in a car factory in China earning around £500 a month but hoped to qualify as an accountant during her time in the UK. Within three years, however, Jenny Guo had built herself a successful and relatively lucrative career on the margins of the legal profession, thanks to a chance encounter with a friend who needed an interpreter to help him at a meeting at the Home Office immigration centre in Croydon, south London. Guo went along, and soon she was spending around 40 hours a week interpreting for asylum applicants at home office screenings and interviews with solicitors. More importantly, she began introducing clients to a network of solicitors across London, clients for whom she then acted. In 18 months, from January 1999, she had dealings with more than 366 asylum applicants, mostly Chinese, 7% of all Chinese applicants dealt with by the Home Office during that period. One solicitor spoke of paying her £10,000 in legal aid claimed for translation work for around 80 clients, another of £5,000 for 40. At the going rate Perry Wacker's lorry was worth £7,500 to Jenny. Four years after entering the country she was able to afford an £83,000 mortgage on a flat in South Woodford, east London. Between March 3 2000 and June 20 she also sent £37,000 back to China using the account of her boyfriend, You Yi. Guo was the first point of contact in the UK for the Dover 60 and on the morning of their expected arrival she was busy finalising arrangements. Clients On the morning of Monday June 19, seven hours after the bodies had been discovered, Guo telephoned Chandika Wolpita, a solicitor at Ratna & Co, in Walworth Road, London. She had referred around 80 clients to him between December 1999 and February 2000, and now asked if he could deal with some asylum matters on behalf of 60 Chinese people. According to his evidence in court, Mr Wolpita called his supervisor who advised him they could take on about 30. Wolpita took the request to mean they had already arrived. Shortly afterwards Gou called again and said she had not heard from the Chinese, and that she would call again later. Around midnight she finally called and said the police had been and removed her computer. In the intervening period Guo had learned of the deaths and panicked, destroying her mobile and deleting files. Many of them were recovered, including draft letters of application for asylum, and a number of invoices to solicitors. The next day, Guo and her boyfriend You Yi, a chef, turned themselves in to Kent police at Canterbury police station. Yi was released without charge and is working in Chinatown. For her part, Guo, who protested her innocence throughout the trial, was last night beginning a six-year sentence for her part in the deaths of 58 Chinese innocents in search of a better life. webTitle: 'My brother paid £4,000 to come here. Now he's dead'

fields.headline: 'My brother paid £4,000 to come here. Now he's dead'
fields.standfirst:
Snakeheads 'paint false picture of UK'

Special report: refugees
fields.trailText: He Chang Ming's brother experienced first-hand the human toll of Perry Wacker's tragic cargo. He Chang Ming died in the back of Perry Wacker's lorry; at 45 he was the oldest of the 58 victims.
fields.body:
He Chang Ming's brother experienced first-hand the human toll of Perry Wacker's tragic cargo. He Chang Ming died in the back of Perry Wacker's lorry; at 45 he was the oldest of the 58 victims.

"When he left China I didn't know he was coming," said his brother, who did not want his name disclosed. "It was only when I heard that people had died in the lorry that I suspected he might be on board. I rang home to Fujian and was told that he was on his way.

"Following the discovery pictures of the dead bodies were sent back to China and the local police station published them. My family in China saw him and knew first he was on that trip. Next time I called home I found out he was dead.

"It was heartbreaking, beyond words. I said goodbye to my brother five years ago. I never thought my reunion with him would be with a dead body."

The dead man's brother, a kitchen porter at a Chinese restaurant in Kent, believes He Chang Ming was tempted to leave his wife and three children in Fujian by false promises and coercion from the snakeheads.

"I think my brother was tricked into coming to Britain. The snakeheads tell people that life is wonderful, that you can earn big money, and as long as you pay they can get you there no problem. My brother paid £4,000 to come here, just a part of the full cost. That money will never be returned to his family even though he is dead.

"I tried to persuade my brother not to come, I told him life is not nearly as good as you think over here. In China though life is even harder and the snakeheads paint such a rosy picture. Many people in our home town have built bigger houses with money they received from overseas. This was why he ignored my advice - he thought 'me and my family can have a life like that'.

"With the breadwinner dead my sister-in-law has three children to raise on her own. It will be hell for her. Relatives will help where they can but so many are poor. Chinese peasants do not have a welfare state to care for them so if you have no work or you are ill you have had it."

His own journey to the west began in 1996 when he left Fujian for Thailand on a snakehead transport. After passing through Malaysia he flew to Britain and claimed political asylum. He has temporary resident's status, but his application for a passport has been turned down. Life in the west has left him disillusioned.

"Life is not good here," he says. "We earn more money than we did in China but it is only from our sweat and blood. One of my friends died here and nobody knew, not even his family.

"I have a job but I do not have enough money to send some home to my family. Sometimes I have jobs, sometimes not. If a restaurant is doing badly then I am the first out of the door. I earn around £100 a week which with rent and food does not leave much."

He says he is trapped in Britain, desperate to leave but too poor and too scared to do so. "I want to go back to China but I can't. If I return I will face a huge fine or imprisonment for leaving the country.

"Once you pass a day there is another one to get through. I cannot go home, and life is always a struggle. I am trapped. This life is a kind of prison."

webTitle: Villagers grieve for victims but more plan trip to make fortunes

fields.headline: Villagers grieve for victims but more plan trip to make fortunes
fields.standfirst:
Western wealth still a lure to poor families

Special report: refugees
fields.trailText: As so often in Chinese villages, everyone in Sayu has the same surname. There is only one Yang from Changle county on the British police list: he was Yang Jiaohua, who died aged 33 and four months.
fields.byline: John Gittings in Changle county, Fujian
fields.body:
As so often in Chinese villages, everyone in Sayu has the same surname. There is only one Yang from Changle county on the British police list: he was Yang Jiaohua, who died aged 33 and four months.

Of the 58 found dead in the Dover-bound container, 23 came from Changle county and another 28 from neighbouring Fuqing county. The disaster has brought unwelcome publicity for the area and local officials have been told to deter outside inquirers.

Changle police say they have cracked down on the snakeheads. Last November a group of them were sentenced at a public rally to jail terms ranging from eight to 10 years. The police claim 26 snakeheads "surrendered voluntarily" last year.

Yet the clampdown has had little effect on those who decide to "toudu" (steal across the frontiers).

"It was a terrible tragedy which shook the world," says a Changle taxi driver. They were all such young people too. But my son still wants to go to Britain. Of course, he will fix it through the snakeheads - there's no other way."

Despite the post-Dover crackdown, information for future would-be migrants is still not hard to obtain.

The Lion Belly temple at Houyu looks out on the widening Min river estuary down which millions of Fujianese have sailed abroad to sell their labour over the past 150 years.

Houyu villagers about to venture abroad have for generations visited the temple to pray for a peaceful journey and future wealth.

Now they can get more immediate help from a small advertisement on the temple wall "Good news!", it proclaims. "I can solve your problem of getting emigration documents."

Jiang Diandong, if that is his real name, offers a complete service for the hopeful migrant. Mr Jiang claims a success rate of 95% and says he will abide by the principle of "no payment [needed] if no success [in reaching the destination]."

Mr Jiang will deal with all consular formalities, prepare all necessary documents, purchase air tickets, and make all appropriate arrangements. He is happy to arrange a "financial guarantor" for those without the money or who have a family to support.

This former fishing village, squeezed into a small bay between the rocks and the sea, has been transformed by wealth from previous generations of migrants abroad. It is claimed that 80% of its able-bodied men work overseas.

New four-storey houses, gleamingly tiled, crowd together where there were once wooden shacks. Two young boys lead the visitor proudly to another, even more special, temple. It is the ancestral hall of the Zhang clan (here everyone is surnamed Zhang).

On both walls, contributions of Zhang members abroad are posted with a photograph of each benefactor. The sums range from $1,000 (£700) to $22,000 (£15,500). Visitors inspect the list and cry out an admiring "that's fantastic" at the highest figure.

It is possible that Mr Jiang only deals with those who are entitled to emigrate legally: most do not. Even in Shanghai and Beijing, the authorities say they are having huge problems with visa brokers who use their legitimate business as cover for illegal people-smuggling.

Not everyone is keen on the enterprise. "It's a question of living standards," says Changle resident Ning Jianhua. "Those who go abroad are the ones without prospects at home."

But for those willing to take a chance, migration has seemed in recent years like a wager with the odds in favour of success.

No one could have guessed last year that the terms of the bet in the Dover tragedy would involve risking not money, but life.

webTitle: Driver of lorry in which 58 Chinese died gets 14 years

fields.headline: Driver of lorry in which 58 Chinese died gets 14 years
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: A Dutch lorry driver was yesterday jailed for one of the largest mass killings in British criminal history when he was convicted of the manslaughter of 58 Chinese illegal immigrants, who suffocated in the back of his lorry en route to Dover.
fields.body:
A Dutch lorry driver was yesterday jailed for one of the largest mass killings in British criminal history when he was convicted of the manslaughter of 58 Chinese illegal immigrants, who suffocated in the back of his lorry en route to Dover.

Perry Wacker, 33, of Rotterdam, was sentenced to 14 years for his part in an organised people smuggling operation, coordinated by a Chinese snakehead gang. He was also found guilty of conspiracy to facilitate the entry of illegal immigrants.

Ying Guo, 30, a translator from South Woodford, Essex, was jailed for six years for conspiracy. She was to be the immigrants' contact in Britain.

Sentencing the pair, Mr Justice Moses said that human trafficking of this kind added to the climate of hostility against asylum seekers and encouraged government to take ever more draconian measures.

"As signatories to the Geneva Convention, the UK must... exercise fair and effective systems of immigration control. Those like you two, who traffic in illegal entrants out of greed, undermine that system.

"Undermining that system creates the risk of oppression and prejudice against those who come to this country seeking protection as calls for more rigorous controls grow louder."

Wacker received six years for each of the 58 dead, to run concurrently, and a further eight years for conspiracy. He showed no emotion as he was sent down.

Mr Justice Moses said Wacker had been central to organising the fatal transport and was guilty of criminal negligence. "You took no care for the safety of those people [in the lorry] and you share responsibility for the decision to carry so many in such a confined place."

During the six-week trial Maidstone crown court heard how on June 18, one of the hottest days of last year, Wacker drove from Rotterdam to Zeebrugge, Belgium, with the 60 Chinese illegal immigrants from the province of Fujian in his lorry trailer.

A dummy load of tomatoes had been placed at the rear of the trailer to disguise the true cargo, leaving each of the immigrants a space the size of this newspaper page in which to crouch. At Zeebrugge Wacker closed the air vent on the side of the lorry, the passengers' only source of oxygen, to stop them being overheard by port officials. Within three hours all but two of the 60 were dead, suffocated in sweltering temperatures.

"Once you closed the vent you deprived them of the air they needed to stay alive. Each one of those [58 people] was a human being who relied on you - you treated them as cargo," said the judge.

Two months before the fatal shipment Leo Nijveen, a close friend of Wacker's, was arrested by Kent Police after arriving at Dover with 50 Chinese in his lorry. They had almost suffocated en route and had been released by Nijveen on the crossing. Nijveen was released without charge and returned to the Netherlands.

The National Crime Squad, which coordinates operations against organised crime, said details of Nijveen's arrest should have been passed to the Dutch authorities, but the Guardian understands this was not the case.

The court heard that Wacker and Nijveen were part of an established gang based in Rotterdam and run by a Turk, Gurzel Ozcan, a convicted people smuggler. Police believe Wacker was to be paid about £17,500 for the shipment.

Ozcan, Nijveen and seven others are in custody in the Netherlands awaiting trial, seven of them on manslaughter charges in relation to the deaths. The two survivors, Su Di Ke, 20, and Ke Shi Guang, 22, have conditional leave to remain in Britain for four years.

fields.headline: The snakeheads
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees
fields.trailText: Chinese snakehead gangs are at the forefront of the global traffic in people, a hugely profitable industry worth $30bn worldwide last year, according to US government estimates.
fields.body:
Chinese snakehead gangs are at the forefront of the global traffic in people, a hugely profitable industry worth $30bn worldwide last year, according to US government estimates.

Europe accounts for a sizeable chunk of that trade with 6-7m illegal immigrants entering the EU annually, increasingly shepherded by organised criminals.

The snakeheads are seen as the most secretive and ruthless gangs in a growing market; it is estimated that of every 20 illegal entrants to the UK between five and 10 are Chinese.

Chinese communities in Europe provide support and cover along the road. The gangs rely on technology such as pay-as-you-go mobile phones to function, but they also use the close-knit nature of the Chinese communities as cover.

The smugglers are also increasingly ingenious. New routes are opening and snakeheads are developing links with gangs such as the Turkish mafia. fields.headline: Rail boss receives £86,000 bonus
fields.standfirst:
Performance-related package paid to Hatfield line contractor's board

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Jim Cohen, head of rail operations at Balfour Beatty, the firm that maintained the rail line where the Hatfield crash occurred, received a performance-related bonus last year.
fields.body:
Jim Cohen, head of rail operations at Balfour Beatty, the firm that maintained the rail line where the Hatfield crash occurred, received a performance-related bonus last year.

The total pay of Mr Cohen, who took over the running of the rail business four years ago, reached almost £300,000, including the £86,020 bonus, according to the annual report published yesterday.

The chief executive, Michael Welton, was the highest paid director on the board, receiving a total of £477,335, including a bonus of £124,816.

The bonus payments to Mr Cohen and his fellow board directors follow the report by the health and safety executive into the fatal crash. It is yet to be announced what charges, if any, will be brought against any of the companies mentioned in the HSE report published earlier this year.

While the report said that cracks on the line at Hatfield were at a certain angle and depth that were "unlikely to be detected" by Railtrack's ultrasound machine, it concluded that the line was in such a poor condition that inspection alone should have been enough to spot the state of the track. The bonus was paid to Mr Cohen even though profits at the rail division fell from £18m to £6m during the financial year.

A Balfour Beatty spokesman said: "This is a well established bonus scheme which has been fully approved and delivers bonus payments against performance.

The performance of the company overall is very satisfactory and exceeded the expectations of the City. The [bonuses] were set against the corporate results."

This means that the performance of each board director's division was not taken into account when setting the bonus payments - which can rise to a maximum of 40% of a directors' basic salary. Last year they averaged 30%.

Overall, the company's profits rose by 69% to £86m.

It is not possible to compare Mr Cohen's pay rate with that during the previous year as he only joined the board of the company in February last year - and it was not necessary for his renumeration package to be disclosed.

webTitle: Leader: defeat illegal traffickers by liberalising immigration

fields.headline: Illegal traffickers
fields.standfirst: Defeat them by liberalising immigration
fields.trailText: Anyone with a romantic view of people smugglers would have had their illusions shattered by the shocking death of 58 illegal Chinese immigrants found in the back of a container lorry in Dover last year.
fields.body:
Anyone with a romantic view of people smugglers would have had their illusions shattered by the shocking death of 58 illegal Chinese immigrants found in the back of a container lorry in Dover last year.

For the last six weeks, a Maidstone crown court jury has heard the callousness with which the lorry driver treated his human cargo. They were crammed so tightly into the truck that they each had only the space of an A4 sheet of paper in which to crouch. There were just four small containers of water for a nine-hour journey from Rotterdam. Their fate was sealed when the driver closed the one air vent in the back of his truck to ensure no ferry official heard their voices and caught him red-handed. But he knew the danger to which he was exposing them. A fellow gang driver had released his "cargo" on a similar run just two months earlier, when air in his truck ran out. Perry Wacker, the Dutch driver, was sentenced to 14 years in prison yesterday.

There are three lessons which can be drawn from this terrible event. First, there is nothing romantic about the organised gangs involved in the illegal immigrant trade. They are ruthless and extremely well-organised. The 60 Chinese immigrants came from a remote Chinese province by plane from Beijing to Belgrade, and then via road and air through Hungary, Austria, France, the Netherlands and Belgium. They paid up to £20,000 each for the journey - some up front and the rest promised over a period of years. In other words, slave labourers for the organised gang. The ruthlessness of such gangs knows no limits. In the last three years in Italy, at least 200 would-be immigrants have died at sea in collisions with custom boats or after being thrown overboard. Five years ago almost 300 died in a single incident.

A second lesson is that the heavy sentence handed down yesterday will not deter the trade. Tighter laws and heavier penalties introduced after Dover failed too. As David Wilson, head of intelligence for the immigration services, has noted: "The harder we make it, the more lucrative we make it for organised gangs." People smuggling is still not as profitable as drug smuggling, but an estimated 7m illegal immigrants are brought to Europe every year. Estimates of total turnover for the gangs worldwide ranges between £8bn and £20bn.

So what will reduce the illegal flow? That is the third lesson. Fifteen years ago there was no organised illegal trade. It emerged as Europe became ever more restrictive towards refugees and immigrants. Yet across Europe, ministers are complaining about labour shortages and the need for more economic migrants. Germany has just introduced a green card scheme, under which more economic migrants will be accepted. British ministers - Jack Straw and Barbara Roche - tried to start a grown up debate last year about the skills shortage in the UK. The one positive result of the Dover tragedy was the way in which it rallied tabloid support for an increase in controlled immigration. Even the Sun discovered "rich nations need immigrants if we are to prosper".

The emerging consensus is welcome. Awkward challenges remain. There are shortages of unskilled as well as skilled workers. Third world countries must not be robbed of their skilled labour - teachers, social workers, nurses, and doctors are in even shorter supply there. A common European approach is crucial. At least this last challenge is already agreed. The 1997 Amsterdam treaty conceded power to create a common immigration policy to the European parliament. It has already begun work on the challenge.

webTitle: $500m human map to trump DNA project

fields.headline: $500m human map to trump DNA project
fields.standfirst:
Software and genetics firms team up to analyse how proteins work

Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: A private consortium of genetics and computer firms has announced plans to trump the deciphering of the human "book of life" by mapping and selling a molecule by molecule blueprint of the human body's deepest workings.
fields.body:
A private consortium of genetics and computer firms has announced plans to trump the deciphering of the human "book of life" by mapping and selling a molecule by molecule blueprint of the human body's deepest workings.

In an undertaking which may cost as much as US$500m, [£350m] the Japanese electronics giant Hitachi and the US computer database firm Oracle have teamed up with Utah-based Myriad Genetics to analyse virtually every protein in the human body, and how they interact, by 2004.

The move comes less than a year after rival teams of private and publicly funded scientists announced they had decoded the billions of letters of the human genome, the sum of the roughly 30,000 genes which contain the instructions to build and maintain the human body.

But what they had not done was analyse the chemicals, or proteins, which actually carry out these instructions - sending messages between cells, building bones and so on. The full set of proteins is called the proteome.

The Myriad consortium has now stolen a march on its commercial, government and academic rivals, who have spoken only vaguely about the need for a publicly funded Human Proteome Project, along the lines of the successful Human Genome Project.

Myriad and its partners argue that its human proteome map once created will lead to breakthroughs in disease research which the genome information by itself cannot provide.

Myriad Genetics, which will own 50% of a new subsidiary called Myriad Proteomics, has been criticised in recent years for its patent claims on two genes which predispose women to get breast cancer. The company has used the patents to restrict competing tests for the gene in favour of its own.

Myriad spokesman Bill Hockett said private firms would have to pay to get access to the future human proteome database, although there would be special terms for academic users.

Myriad would also have first look at the data, and would patent any proteins it thought valuable for developing new drugs and therapies.

Initially, the three firms will invest $185m in the venture. Up to $500m will be needed to finish the job.

"This ambitious project to map the human proteome within three years will enable us to make a great leap forward in our understanding of the causes of human disease," said the head of Myriad, Peter Meldrum.

"The human proteome has become the next frontier of modern biology."

The consortium's announcement was greeted with scepticism by some scientists, who called their ambitious plan too broad. Some of those detractors, however - such as Craig Venter of Celera, who told the New York Times newspaper that the project had little value - are rivals.

"Whenever you undertake an ambitious project, people will say it can't be done, be cause they're not doing it," said Mr Hockett.

The consortium's announcement coincided with a meeting in the US of a loose group of academic and private sector scientists calling itself the Human Proteome Organisation (Hupo), which seeks to mobilise governments and business to collaborate on a human proteome map.

But tackling the proteome is so much more complex and diffuse than the genome that there is little support for a government-backed effort to make the data freely available in the public domain.

Asked what he thought the Myriad group's chances of success were, one of the members of Hupo's council, Ian Tomlinson of the Medical Research Council's laboratories in Cambridge, said: "The three partners in that consortium are all serious about proteomics, so who knows?

"It depends what financial resources they are committing to it."

webTitle: Now for cooperation, hard work and the really big money

fields.headline: Now for cooperation, hard work and the really big money
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: No superlatives were too great last year when scientists announced that the human genome had been read and the first draft made available to all.
fields.body:
No superlatives were too great last year when scientists announced that the human genome had been read and the first draft made available to all.

It was more important than the splitting of the atom or putting man on the moon; it was on a par with the works of Shakespeare, Rembrandt and Wagner.

Yet even as the champagne corks were popping in London and Washington, there were murmurings behind the scenes that the human genome project was not enough.

To understand the nature of the human machine, some scientists argued, there needed to be another mass international effort: mapping the human proteome.

If the mind is our software, and the genes our operating system, proteins are the hardware. They are the chemicals - the hormones, the enzymes, the building blocks of skin and bone and muscle - which the body synthesises according to the template the gene provides.

"The genes are what might happen. The proteins actually do the work. We call them the molecular work horses," said Ian Humphery-Smith, a proteomics researcher at Utrecht University in the Netherlands.

Despite the razzmatazz over the genome, scientists always understood that genes would not yield the secrets of disease until they understood the proteins associated with those genes.

The Wellcome Trust, for instance - which provided much of the money for the British end of the Human Genome Project - is channelling tens of millions of pounds into proteomics research.

But studying small groups of proteins is a world away from what Myriad Genetics, Hitachi and Oracle announced they were going to do this week - construct a map of the entire human proteome, showing how each protein interacts.

No one even knows how many different kinds of proteins there are in the human body. All that is certain is that there are far more than there are genes. There are now thought to be around 30,000 genes; estimates for the number of proteins range from 100,000 to 3m.

"It is true today that we don't know how many proteins there are, but that doesn't mean the mapping can't be done, it just means we are going to be learning as we go along," said Bill Hockett of Myriad.

"I have seen the estimates of 3m but we favour the lower end of that scale - 300,000 to 500,000.

Another problem of mapping the proteome is that whereas the genome never changes, from birth to death, from cell to cell, the set of proteins swimming around differs widely according to time and place. The set of proteins in the cell of a baby's toe will be quite different from the set in the brain cell of an 80-year-old man.

Despite these obstacles, and many other huge technological barriers to mapping the proteome, the Myriad consortium has thrown down the gauntlet to a scientific community which has so far been reluctant to contemplate another biology project on the scale of the genome.

The recently established Human Proteome Organisation is little more than an ad hoc assembly of interested scientists from academia and industry. Although governments in the US, Europe and Asian countries such as Korea are putting money into proteomics research, and firms are investing heavily, there is little coordination.

So far there has not been an appetite for a repeat of the bitter war over public access to data between the Human Genome Project and the US corporation Celera which continued right up to publication of the two rival groups' results in Science and Nature earlier this year.

Dr Humphery-Smith, one of the founders of Hupo said governments and private consortiums like the Myriad group would have to work together. Myriad's approach could only give broad information about the proteome, he added.

He said one way forward was for governments to help fund private research in exchange for a stake in the outcomes. "Global sentiment is that many countries do not wish to miss out on proteomics like they missed out on genomics."

webTitle: Police failed to protect man killed in cell, says report

fields.headline: Police failed to protect man killed in cell, says report
fields.standfirst: Special report: deaths in custody
fields.trailText: A report into the killing of a 30-year-old man who was savagely beaten by a mentally ill cellmate has made sweeping criticism of police officers for their conduct before and after the death.
fields.body:
A report into the killing of a 30-year-old man who was savagely beaten by a mentally ill cellmate has made sweeping criticism of police officers for their conduct before and after the death.

The failures of Essex police contributed to Christopher Edwards, who had been arrested for a minor breach of the peace, being placed in a cell at Chelmsford prison with Richard Linford, 37, who had a history of mental disorder, hallucinations and violence, the report said.

Mr Edwards, described by friends as a gentle academic, was so badly disfigured by the attack that he could only be identified by dental records. One of his ears was missing, presumed eaten.

Published yesterday, a police complaints authority investigation into the death on November 29, 1994, upheld 15 allegations made by Mr Edwards's parents, Paul and Audrey.

The report said Christopher, who also had a history of mental illness, should have been examined by a police surgeon when he was first arrested.

It said officers failed to complete forms which would have warned the prison service that the two men were inmates of "exceptionally high risk."

Police also failed to ensure the examination of the scene was properly recorded and lost other documents, the report concluded.

PCA officer Ian Bynoe wrote: "Detective officers leading the investigation into Christopher's death failed to interview and take statements from several witnesses with information highly relevant to Mr Edwards's allegation that his son's death resulted from gross negligence by those responsible for his health and safety."

After the killing, the treatment of Mr Edwards's family was, "totally inadequate", the report concluded.

Mr Edwards's parents were informed of the death by telephone, rather than face to face, and they were kept in the dark about Linford's court appearances - he was convicted of manslaughter due to diminished responsibility.

The inquiry dismissed 13 other allegations made by Mr and Mrs Edwards. Paul Edwards said yesterday's report was "good as far as it goes", but was disappointed the PCA had not been able to prove "beyond reasonable doubt" that an attempted cover-up had taken place.

"All but one of nearly 20 officers declined to answer questions during interview for this investigation," Mr Edwards said.

No officers have been disciplined and Essex police is not planning to start proceedings. Many of those involved have retired.

A public inquiry, chaired by Kieran Coonan, made 85 recommendations and criticised the prison service, police, care workers and the courts, when it was published three years ago.

Essex police said yesterday the force had already acted to ensure a similar tragedy could never happen again.

Mr and Mrs Edwards will be consulting their lawyers over possible civil action.

The couple were awarded £4,500 by the criminal injuries compensation board for their son's death.

"The amount we received diminishes the value of someone we have loved and lost," said Mr Edwards.

fields.headline: Hague tribunal delivers Milosevic warrant
fields.standfirst:
Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The international arrest warrant for Slobodan Milosevic and his formal indictment for war crimes will be handed to Yugoslavia's justice minister, Momcilo Grubac, by Hague tribunal officials today with the request that they be immediately served on the former president.
fields.body:
The international arrest warrant for Slobodan Milosevic and his formal indictment for war crimes will be handed to Yugoslavia's justice minister, Momcilo Grubac, by Hague tribunal officials today with the request that they be immediately served on the former president.

"Milosevic is now in their custody, he is under their control, so they will be obliged to present the warrant to him with due diligence and without delay," said Jim Landale, the tribunal's spokesman, after Hans Holthuis, its registrar, arrived in Belgrade.

"We are here for three reasons: to give the arrest warrant to the competent authorities and try to ensure it is served on Milosevic; to clarify legal steps to be followed now by Yugoslav authorities to fulfil their obligations under international law, and gather as much information as possible on the domestic charges brought so we can co-ordinate further action with Belgrade," Mr Landale said.

Several of Mr Milosevic's key associates are being questioned by Serbian investigators, and some are reported to have started to turn against their former boss and to give damning evidence.

One of those being questioned for corruption is Nikola Sainovic, who was a deputy prime minister in charge of police operations in Kosovo, who is also indicted for war crimes. The Hague team will want to know whether he has started to give details which they can use for their own prosecution.

Another war crimes indictee, Milan Milutinovic, the current president of Serbia, is to be investigated in Serbia on suspicion that he helped to issue Milosevic cronies with diplomatic passports.

Criminal charges were filed against Mr Milosevic's daughter Marija, 32, yesterday for shooting at government officials who negotiated the former president's surrender in his Belgrade villa on Sunday. Police charged her with "endangering public safety and illegal possession of arms". Legal experts said she could face up to five years in jail for attempted murder.

After Mr Milosevic's arrest on Sunday, Carla del Ponte, the international tribunal's chief prosecutor, indicated that she would be willing to wait a few months before his transfer to the Hague. In any case this cannot happen until a Yugoslav law on co-operation with the tribunal comes into force, probably at the end of next month.

Although Jean-Jacques Joris, her political adviser, insisted this week that the Hague team were "trial-ready" for Mr Milosevic and he should be sent there immediately, the emerging western political consensus is that governments will allow the Serb authorities to put him on trial for corruption and abuse of power in Belgrade first.

Britain's foreign secretary, Robin Cook, told President Vojislav Kostunica on Wednesday that he was keen to see the former president put on trial in Serbia first, so that Serbs would see for themselves the extent of his abuses of power.

The initial sense of national pride which led most Serbs to resist a trial in the Hague has been evaporating fast.

 Naser Oric, the Bosnian Muslim wartime military chief of Srebrenica, yesterday appealed to protesters worried that he would be arrested to let him tell the Hague tribunal the truth about his role during the 1992-95 war.

Mr Oric, who led the defence of Srebrenica before thousands of Muslim men were massacred, was being interviewed by UN investigators in Sarajevo.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: • An article published on page 34 (Sport), February 2, under the heading Highbury hits the pocket hardest, which claimed Arsenal was the most expensive club from a supporter's point of view, was based on information gathered on behalf of Nationwide Building Society, which Nationwide has since admitted was flawed and for which it has apologised.
fields.body:
 An article published on page 34 (Sport), February 2, under the heading Highbury hits the pocket hardest, which claimed Arsenal was the most expensive club from a supporter's point of view, was based on information gathered on behalf of Nationwide Building Society, which Nationwide has since admitted was flawed and for which it has apologised.

It withdrew the report very shortly after its publication. In particular, Nationwide acknowledged that the ticket prices used in calculating costs at Arsenal should have been lower. It also acknowledged the importance to the club of its reputation in providing value for money to its supporters.

The article in the Guardian was published in good faith, but the paper failed to take account of Nationwide's retraction, which it does now with an apology to Arsenal for not doing so immediately.

 Geoff Mulgan, the head of the Downing Street performance and innovation unit, points out that, contrary to our report, Ministers defend Whitehall empires, page 11, yesterday, he is not a political appointee, but went through civil service selection procedures. Nor is he drawing up options for reorganising Whitehall departments (though others are).

 In an article headed Cocktail of problems as drinks firms zero in on youngsters, page 9, March 27, we referred to The Drinks Company as the importer of a product called Mad Dog. The importer is in fact an entirely separate company called The Drinks Group. Apologies for the mistake.

 The husband of the Countess of Wessex, page 1, yesterday, is not the Count of Wessex. he is the Earl of Wessex.

 In our G2 lead feature, headed Battle of the birders, yesterday we wrongly located Sandy (home of the headquarters of the RSPB) in Northamptonshire. It is in Bedfordshire.

fields.headline: Dell comforts bear victims
fields.trailText: Although the decision by the Bank of England to cut interest rates by 25 basis points provided support, it was a comforting trading statement from the American computer manufacturer, Dell, that really got the London market going yesterday.
fields.body:
Although the decision by the Bank of England to cut interest rates by 25 basis points provided support, it was a comforting trading statement from the American computer manufacturer, Dell, that really got the London market going yesterday.

Dell said it was prepared to stick by its first quarter earnings forecasts, sparking hopes among investors that the worst of the bear market might be over. History has shown that when the rate of earnings disappointments slow, equity markets start to recover.

As the Dow Jones and Nasdaq blazed ahead in early trading, the FTSE 100 came to rest 86.1 points higher at 5,621.8, extending its two-day winning streak to 160 points.

All the other main indices ended in positive territory, and with a handful of tech stocks posting double-digit percentage gains some traders were wondering if the dot.com bubble had ever burst. The FTSE Techmark 100 ended 72.53 points stronger at 1,836.97.

The bombed-out tech and telecom sectors spearheaded the advance as short sellers rushed to cover their positions.

Cable company Telewest, up 11.75p to 110.75p, topped the blue chip leader board, closely followed by software specialist Sage, 22p stronger at 250p, and chip designer ARM Holdings, 26p better at 290p.

Mid-cap tech issues also had a good day. Baltimore advanced 11p to 75p after a large sell order was completed and Bookham Technology gained 38.5p to 317p on renewed Alcatel bid speculation.

The gains were by no means confined to the new economy - even Railtrack joined in the fun. Ending a three-day losing streak that had seen 36% wiped off its market value, the shares rallied 27p to 475p.

Oil stocks BP, up 12p to 575.5p, and Shell, 9p higher at 549p, also lent support on the back of positive US statistics, which showed a large draw down in oil reserves.

Senior market men re mained cautious, noting that turnover remained low and there was, as yet, little sign of institutional buying. "It is a classic bear squeeze, nothing more. The market has been caught short of stock and forced to buy," said one senior dealer.

Other traders remarked on the cuts analysts were still making in profits forecasts. Software group Autonomy underperformed its peers, rising just 3p to 570p as Goldman Sachs reduced its 2001 earnings estimate to 13p from 25p. Goldman cited the slowdown in demand recently reported by other software companies as the reason for the downgrade.

United Business Media, up 3.5p to 633.5p, came in for the same treatment, with Merrill Lynch lowering its 2001 profits estimate by 15% after adopting a more pessimistic view of the magazine division's prospects.

Lower down the market, the race for a place in the FTSE 100 was warming up, after reports that EU regulators had approved Schlumberger's bid for current constituent Sema, 1p better at 557p.

If true, the reports mean the deal is close to being declared wholly unconditional. When this happens, Sema will be replaced with the highest-ranking stock by market capitalisation on the reserve list.

At the close of play last night that was grocer Wm Morrison (market value £3.053bn) but things are very tight and could change before the deal is completed.

Healthcare group Smith & Nephew (market value £3.043bn) and clothing retailer Next (market value £3.016bn) are not far behind. Yesterday, Morrison shares rose 0.5p to 200p; Smith & Nephew gained 0.5p to 332p; and Next was unchanged at 895p.

In the small cap world, concrete products firm Alexander Russell added 20.5p to 195.5p after being approached by industry heavyweight and 22% shareholder RMC, down 3p to 645p.

fields.headline: Spoiling for a counterbid
fields.trailText: Is Billiton's merger with Australian group BHP about to go the same way as the Prudential's deal with American General?
fields.body:
Is Billiton's merger with Australian group BHP about to go the same way as the Prudential's deal with American General?

With 36m Billiton shares changing hands in yesterday's session some dealers were clearly betting on it. According to market tittle-tattle, a counter bidder is poised to torpedo the £20bn deal that aims to create the world's second biggest natural resources company.

No one seems able to name a viable counter bidder. Canadian group Alcan has ruled itself out, while Anglo American has its hands full with the acquisition of diamond specialist De Beers.

That does not preclude Anglo from making a move - after all it does have a 7% stake in Billiton. Would fund managers back a merged company that had the majority of its assets in unstable African economies?

Billiton shares closed up 4.5p at 319p.

fields.headline: At this price?  Kewill
fields.trailText: The outlook would appear to be good for Kewill - the business-to-business supply chain software specialist which yesterday delivered a trading statement.
fields.body:
The outlook would appear to be good for Kewill - the business-to-business supply chain software specialist which yesterday delivered a trading statement.

After all, the firm has been hit by the US economic downturn but managed to avoid issuing a profits warning - something many of its rivals have failed to achieve.

How did it manage such a trick? The answer lies in the strict control of development costs and a successful integration of recently acquired US firm Evcor.

Here lies the danger. Although the company has maintained profits by cutting costs, can it make further cuts if sales fail to meet expectations? On yesterday's evidence this is happening.

While Kewill deserves credit for protecting its margins through tight control of costs, there must be concern that revenues will be marginally below the consensus when it reports for the year to the end of March. For a company selling efficiency-enhancing software that promises to save corporates lots of money this is not a good sign.

Its ERP division in the US has experienced lower than forecast sales in the final quarter, as smaller US manufacturers have responded to the uncertain economic climate by delaying IT investments, according to Kewill.

The acquisition of Evcor has caused some disruption in the US sales channel in the first half and overall the division will be slightly below its revenue target for the full year. On the positive side, its key e-commerce division has performed broadly in line with expectations and it is not experiencing any real slowdown.

Actions taken to reorganise the sales channels following the acquisition of Evcor have both improved effectiveness and lowered costs.

Yesterday's news was welcomed by the market which was fearing something far more grim, according to one analyst. Shares were pushed 13p higher to 108p, which seems far enough for now.

webTitle: BT in talks to sell directories business

fields.headline: Yellow goodbye
fields.standfirst: BT in talks to sell directories business
fields.trailText: BT has entered into exclusive talks with a consortium of private equity firms for the sale of Yell, the directories business that includes the Yellow Pages.
fields.body:
BT has entered into exclusive talks with a consortium of private equity firms for the sale of Yell, the directories business that includes the Yellow Pages.

Discussions with the consortium, which is made up of Apax Partners and Hicks, Muse Tate & Furst, are said to be reasonably advanced, although an announcement is not thought imminent. The talks are expected to value Yell, which made pre-tax profits of £220m last year, at around £3bn.

The consortium approached BT shortly after the company said at the end of January that it was considering a demerger of Yell instead of the original plan to float up to 25% of the business on the stock market. The change of heart was driven by deteriorating market conditions.

BT's shares yesterday rose 15p to 529p on expectations of a deal being agreed. One investor said: "It's important they do something with Yell because the market needs to see tangible evidence that they can sell a stake for cash."

BT is under intense pressure to reduce its debt level, now at £30bn. Chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield, pictured above, pledged in November to repay £10bn by the end of this year, principally through the partial float of Yell and BT Wireless, the mobile division which includes BT Cellnet. The floation of BT Wireless also seems increasingly unlikely.

There is speculation that BT is preparing to launch a rights issue of up to £5bn to raise cash. Reports suggest at least three parties approached BT with offers for Yell, including Seat Pagine Gialle, the Italian Yellow Pages business, and another private equity consortium led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts. Yell also publishes in the US and runs an online operation.

But a deal to sell the directories business will not happen before the DTI is sues its verdict on whether Yell has unfair dominance of the UK directories market. The OFT passed a report to the DTI in February and a judgment is expected within weeks.

Apax in February closed a €4bn European fund, and if it acquires Yell it will be its second foray into the directories market. BT and Apax both declined to comment.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Shell marks up litre another 1p
fields.body:
Shell marks up litre another 1p

Shell raised petrol prices by up to 1p per litre to an average of 75.9p a litre at 400 of its 1,100 UK service station yesterday.

The rise, which came into effect on Wednesday, was in response to a 6-7% leap in wholesale prices on the Rotterdam market this week, a spokesman said.

The increase resulted from soaring prices in the US ahead of the peak summer driving season. Diesel prices are unchanged at 76-77p a litre.

RMC bids for Russell

Scottish concrete products firm Alexander Russell said it had been approached by RMC with a possible takeover offer worth about £60.

Announcing the latest move in the consolidating building sector, Russell said the approach was priced at 206p per share, an 18% premium to Wednesday's closing price.

RMC already owns 22.2% of Russell and its play for the company two years ago was rejected as too low.

Private buyers fuel car sales

New car sales powered ahead in the new Y-number plate month of March.

Boosted by a 17.2% rise in private purchases, the number of new cars sold last month reached a record 408,024, a 1.5% rise on the March 2000 total, said the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders.

Since 1999, registration plates have changed twice a year, in March and September, succeeding the annual change in August that lasted more than 30 years.

The number of new cars sold in the first three months of 2001 stands at 675,083, a 2.2% increase on January-March 2000.

The latest report from the Consumers' Association claims leading car companies are "dodging" moves to cut new car prices and that consumers are still paying more for nearly all models than buyers on the Continent.

Newcastle Utd in the black

Newcastle United reported a small pretax profit for the six months to February despite a disastrous spell on the playing field in recent weeks. Chairman John Fender admitted this owed a lot to the club's 41,000 season ticket holders and fans who continue to pack St James' Park near to capacity.

Sales for the six months rose 15% to £32.2m. The club made a pretax profit £5,000, compared with a loss of £1.3m in the same period last year.

QinetiQ energy costs £400,000

Whitehall officials spent more than £400,000 finding a name for the new commercial arm of Britain's defence technology agency, QinetiQ.

The defence evaluation and research agency has been split into two bodies specialising in sensitive military technology and commercial applications. QinetiQ, derived from the scientific term "kinetic," was devised by communications expert Radical and design consultancy The Partners, which were paid £407,000 to come up with a title and logo.

fields.headline:
The £7,000 City
slimming diet
fields.trailText: It is the City's way of drawing in the purse strings - keeping dinner expenses down to £7,000 a night.
fields.body:
It is the City's way of drawing in the purse strings - keeping dinner expenses down to £7,000 a night.

The plea for restraint came direct from the New York headquarters of investment bank Credit Suisse First Boston and is one of the first cases of cost-cutting that is expected to spread through the City as fears of a slump in profits grow.

The dinners being slimmed down are those held in celebration of big corporate deals, such as takeovers or share sales, where it is more usually a case of no expense spared. They are held in some of the most exquisite London private dining rooms. The Savoy is a favourite for the traditionalists while the trendily up-market St Martin's in Covent Garden is a more recent favourite for the younger generation of deal doers.

webTitle: Change of image can land you in the alphabet soup

fields.headline: Change of image can land you in the alphabet soup
fields.trailText: Many of Britain's former state-run monopolies have attempted to shake off their national colours in response to global market pressures but success has been variable.
fields.body:
Many of Britain's former state-run monopolies have attempted to shake off their national colours in response to global market pressures but success has been variable.

A £60m makeover went particularly badly for British Airways in 1997 when Lady Thatcher drew a handkerchief over the tailfin of a model aircraft not carrying the airline's union flag livery. She also gave chief executive Bob Ayling a public dressing down but more recent rebrandings have fared better.

Last year, British Aerospace ditched its national affiliation during a merger with defence business Marconi Electronic Systems. The new group became BAe Systems, abandoning its distinctive arrow-shaped union flag logo. The move caused a fuss, but later was grudgingly accepted as necessary given the changed nature of business.

For similar reasons, British Steel restyled itself as Corus in 1999 after merging with Dutch competitor Koninklijke Hoogovens. "It was not easy to leave behind our former names, as we are proud of our heritage," the new group said.

In 1997, British Gas began shedding its national identity after it decided to demerge operations - twice. The result included three businesses - BG, Lattice and Centrica - recast as dynamic private sector firms with global ambitions the old "gas board" image could not begin to encapsulate.

British Petroleum - born out of Britain's imperial links with Persia - has long since branded itself under initials alone, and more recently as BP Amoco. However, the group came under fire in July last year, when chief executive Sir John Browne said BP stood for "beyond petroleum" - something the group has since vehemently denied.

Last month, the Post Office was also subject to a media drubbing after changing the name of its holding company to Consignia, following its transformation into a government-owned public company. Union leaders said management could have made more of the nation's historic role in pioneering mail delivery in the title.

Chief executive John Roberts said: "To consign means to entrust to the care of, which is what each of our customers does every day. The new name describes what the Post Office does in a way that the words post and office do not."

Others to have shed national and regional colours for an alphabet soup of initials or fabricated names include British Telecom (BT), Scottish Telecom (Thus), Welsh Water/South Wales Electricity (Hyder), Yorkshire Water (Kelda) and British Midland (bmi).

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: Nonsense On Stilts (special edition) Department: Some things are so ludicrous they don't need to be touched by human hands.
fields.body:
Nonsense On Stilts (special edition) Department: Some things are so ludicrous they don't need to be touched by human hands.

Like this press release from the government's Defence, Evaluation and Research Agency (Dera), part of which is to be renamed under a public-private partnership. I swear it's real. "New Dera will be named QinetiQ when it begins trading as a new company," it reads. "The name... was carefully chosen as the outright winner from an original list of 400 which resulted from extensive analysis of all our capabilities and strengths." 400?!? "QinetiQ was seen as particularly distinctive and reflects the organisation's spirit of innovation and creativity but also energy, motion and progress. It is a positive name, with expansive, bold, and assertive overtones, underpinned by a good, solid, technical ring." Shoot me. Please.

 In this job there is great comfort to be taken from the old saying, "a stopped clock is right twice a day". So it proved yesterday, with the announcement that DeAnne Julius is to step down from the Bank of England's monetary policy committee, to be replaced by another "dove from above" - an event predicted in this column as long ago as March 20. I'm sorry to make the most of this, but I have a strong premonition it's not going to happen often. If ever.

 Stuart Rose, the modest, shy and retiring chief executive at Arcadia, was holding forth at the retail group's annual results yesterday about what a strong brand Arcadia had in the Burton menswear chain. Until he was asked if he was wearing clothes from Burton - whereupon he went a bit quiet. "Ahhhh, well..." Stuart stammered, before confessing that his suit had been made by Richard James, the posh Saville Row tailor to the stars.

 Celebrating the decision of an American court to award $65m worth of damages to the original owner of the highly profitable sex.com website address, lawyer James Wagstaffe said: "The substantial size of this damage award sends a message that the internet is not a lawless wasteland."

Oh yeah? The background is that Stephen Michael Cohen used forged documents to convince the domain name registrars to transfer ownership of the name to himself from the original owner, Gary Kremen of San Francisco. That was in 1995, and it has taken six years for the decision on damages to be reached, during which time Cohen made considerable profits from advertising. True, $65m is a lot, but Cohen's holdings in offshore accounts in Liechtenstein, Luxembourg and the British Virgin Islands means the money may be difficult to recover. Cohen couldn't make it to the trial: his lawyers claimed he was under house arrest in Mexico.

 The final Dog of the Day award for this week must go to Tony James and Chuck Ward, the fun loving co-heads of investment banking at CSFB, for their memo cracking down on celebrations for successful share floats. As we note elsewhere, CSFB hasn't lead-managed a single IPO this year anyway. Woof.

fields.headline: Amcor unwrapped
fields.trailText: Australian packaging group Amcor was forced into the embarrassing position yesterday of having to retract an offer to the media to attend the launch of a potential three-way European merger after admitting that it had unwrapped the news too soon.
fields.body:
Australian packaging group Amcor was forced into the embarrassing position yesterday of having to retract an offer to the media to attend the launch of a potential three-way European merger after admitting that it had unwrapped the news too soon.

The initial invitation stated: "Following an announcement by Amcor today regarding the three-way merger in Europe, you or another representative of your department are invited to a news conference."

But as the company's shares were suspended on the Sydney stock exchange, Amcor was forced to cancel its invitation. "The email was sent mistakenly - but the company will make an announcement tomorrow," said a spokesman for Amcor. The company declined to reveal any further details on its proposed tie-up - leaving analysts to speculate that it could involve the packaging businesses of companies such as Britain's Rexam, Canada's Alcan and France's Pechiney.

Other names in the frame were Bemis of the US and Swiss drink cartons manufacturer SIG Holding, which asked the Zurich stock exchange to suspend trading of its shares.

The merger is expected to leave Amcor as the biggest shareholder in the producer of packaging for confectionery, snack foods, frozen foods, soups and pharmaceuticals.

Speculation about a possible merger has been increasing since Amcor announced earlier this year that it was targeting acquisition opportuni ties in flexible packaging, PET plastic bottles and folding cartons.

Amcor's managing director, Mr Russell Jones, has said the company was planning to spend as much as $500m on acquisitions throughout Europe and North America during the next year.

The fragmented packaging sector is under severe pressure from an increasingly large group of food and other manufacturing clients who have driven down suppliers' prices while energy costs soared.

Amcor spun off the paper operations from its packaging business last year, and said it aimed to build one of the five biggest packaging businesses in the world.

Amcor shares were suspended at A$5.76, valuing the company at £1.3bn.

webTitle: Our Price disappears in Virgin remix

fields.headline: Our Price disappears in Virgin remix
fields.trailText: The Our Price record chain is set to disappear next year - 30 years after it was founded.
fields.body:
The Our Price record chain is set to disappear next year - 30 years after it was founded.

The group, which is owned by Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Our Price Holdings, is to be converted to the entrepreneur's new V.Shops format, which stock only a limited selection of chart music alongside DVDs, videos and Virgin mobile phones.

Customers wanting to buy anything other than chart music - like back catalogue albums - will have to order them from internet terminals at the back of the store and wait for them to be delivered. Only the 90 Virgin Megastores will carry a wide selection of music.

Some 100 of the 220-store chain have already been converted to V.Shops and the bulk of the rest will disappear in the coming year. A spokesman for Virgin said: "2002 may see a move towards all V.Shops. We are committed to them".

He dismissed suggestions that V.Shops were being rolled out just as the mobile phone market was becoming saturated: "We are not seeing that. Virgin mobile is the fastest growing mobile company in Europe. Unlike mobile phone shops, in V.Shops mobile telephony is only 30% of the business".

Our Price began life in 1971 as a single Tape Revolution store on London's Finchley Road. In 1976 the six-strong Tape Revolution chain was renamed Our Price Records, to reflect the popularity of vinyl. In 1984 it was the first specialist music store to float on the stock exchange and two years later it was bought for £43m by WH Smith.

By 1993 there were more than 300 stores and, as CDs took over from vinyl, they were redesigned again. A year later they were merged with Virgin megastores in a joint venture between WH Smith and Virgin.

Three years ago Virgin paid £145m to gain full control of the business, but Virgin Our Price Holdings recorded a £127m loss last year. The Virgin spokesman said the group was now trading profitably.

The group has undergone a substantial restructuring under new chief executive Simon Wright. VOP's bank debt has been assumed by another Branson company, Ivanco. In its first full year under Branson's full control VOP incurred one-off costs of nearly £80m, including some £20m set aside to cover unsold stock.

Some 30 stores have been closed in the past two year, but the spokesman said no further slimming down was planned : "We are not in closing mode."

fields.headline: Rose revives Arcadia group
fields.standfirst: Fashion chain becomes best performing retail stock in Europe
fields.trailText: The Arcadia fashion group, on its knees until six months ago, yesterday announced a huge improvement in profits and a clear-out of high-street brands to keep up the recovery.
fields.body:
The Arcadia fashion group, on its knees until six months ago, yesterday announced a huge improvement in profits and a clear-out of high-street brands to keep up the recovery.

The group, whose fascias include Top Shop, Wallis and Burton, returned a half-year profit of £29.1m after a loss of £8.6m last year. Like-for-like sales climbed 5.5% in the six months to the end of February and they are 6.5% ahead of last year's levels in the past five weeks. The shares shot up 46p to 239p, 200p higher than they were 12 months ago.

The 350% rise in the price in the past six months has made Arcadia the best performing retail stock in Europe and has generated a potential fortune for chief executive Stuart Rose.

When he joined the company last November from supermarket chain Iceland, which has seen its share price halve over the half-year, he was awarded options over 6.4m shares. He was also given £600,000 to compensate for losing his Iceland options, which would now have been worthless, and dipped into his own pocket to buy another £100,000 worth of Arcadia stock.

Although the bulk of the shares cannot be accessed for three to five years, they are now valued at more than £6m.

Some analysts have expressed doubts about the sudden reversal of Arcadia's fortunes but Mr Rose said: "The company is now valued at £400m and I think it is pretty good value".

The country's second largest clothing retailer is to slim down to six retail brands by the summer. The "sub-scale" Warehouse and Principles chains, together with Racing Green, Hawkshead and designer outlet Wade Smith, are to be sold to managements.

The group is also scaling back investment in its Zoom.co.uk internet joint venture with Associated Newspapers and is to take full control of its loss-making Dial home-shopping joint venture with Littlewoods, for £7.5m.

Arcadia will concentrate on Burton, Top Shop/Top Man, Wallis, Dorothy Perkins ,Miss Selfridge and Evans, which Mr Rose believes will cater for the entire middle-market fashion buyer "from ages 18 to 81".

He described Dorothy Perkins as "Arcadia's best kept secret", and accused City analysts and the financial press of undervaluing it because of snobbery: "If it was called Next you'd all be raving about it."

Mr Rose insisted he was unconcerned about the tough competition in the fashion market. "There has been competition in retail since the first shops opened on the Nile. The market is as good now as it has ever been. M&S is not where we want to be. Next is full of M&S refugees and Bhs is a value retailer."

Improved trading and the proceeds from disposals meant there was no longer any need for a rights issue and the group's £195m debt would be "sharply reduced" by the end of the year.

Mr Rose took over when John Hoerner retired early. Mr Horner had presided over the decline of the group but also masterminded a restructuring, called BrandMax, to close 450 shops, shed 3,500 jobs and get brands to share stores to save on rent costs.

This is responsible for some of the glory that Mr Rose is now basking in. "I can't take the credit for BrandMax," he confessed. After the disposals, Arcadia will have 1,300 shops and a £1.6bn turnover.
