webTitle: Brown takes an industrial weight decision

fields.headline: Brown takes an industrial weight decision
fields.trailText: Positive switch at the MPC
fields.body:
Positive switch at the MPC

Gordon Brown chose his moment well. On the day the doveish faction on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee tasted victory in the battle over interest rates, he announced that one woman with close links to industry, DeAnne Julius, formally of British Airways, should be replaced by another, Kate Barker of the CBI.

Despite the inevitable criticism that the decision is motivated by the need to have a woman on the MPC, it was the right decision. Ms Julius left the MPC of her own volition, and a balanced com mittee needed an economist of similar views to succeed her. Ms Barker is eminently suited to the job. End of story.

She joins at an intriguing time. The statement issued by the MPC following the quarter-point cut yesterday underlined the ascendancy of Ms Julius and her brother in arms on the MPC, Sushil Wadhwani. Yes, it said, the domestic economy has remained robust, but the gloomy picture abroad has affected business and consumer confidence, and may yet do more damage. Yes, the labour market is tight, but price and cost pressures remain muted. There is no sign of inflation picking up - on the contrary it will remain below its 2.5% target unless rates are cut. The fact that the statement concludes that the MPC will continue to monitor the downside risks carefully suggests both that further rate cuts are in the pipeline, and that Ms Julius and Mr Wadhwani were pressing for a cut of 50 basis points this month.

All this supports the City view that interest rates are coming down to 5% over the next few months, and may go lower. Looking further ahead, it is possible that cost pressures will start to push up inflation, necessitating a rise in rates in 2002.

But the fact that underlying inflation is still below 2% should tell the MPC that something fundamental has happened to the relationship between growth, inflation and unemployment.

It was to Ms Julius's credit that she spotted the trend early, and was often a lone voice on the MPC before the arrival of Mr Wadhwani. She will be a tough act to follow.

Retail diversity

In one week we have seen two retail recovery plans from M&S and Arcadia, the UK's number one and two purveyors of clothing. Their plans are not dissimilar - get out of peripheral businesses, concentrate on the core middle market operations, bring some flair and inspiration to the shops, improve customer service and so on - basic retailing, really.

Twelve months ago, they were both in deep trouble. Debt-laden Arcadia's problems appeared terminal.

In recent months, both of the companies' share prices have undoubtedly benefited from the interest of a foreign investor - the US Brandes group now holds 12% of M&S and the Icelandic Baugur group has built a 20% stake in Arcadia. Both companies insist they are friendly holdings based on value investing.

But the TopShop group has performed a Lazarus-style recovery and City analysts, by and large, are mad for it. Its shares have increased sixfold, and yesterday's recovery strategy produced another flurry of excitement and the belief that the company can deliver on its promises.

One week on, any excitement that M&S generated has disappeared.

The diverse responses are the result of some crucial differences. There are tangible signs of improvement at Arcadia - little things like increasing sales from less space and higher margins - that are still missing at M&S.

On basic measures such as the price to earnings ratio, M&S is rated more highly than Arcadia.

M&S is run by a Belgian supermarket chief and a McKinsey man who probably wouldn't recognise a fashion trend if it slapped them in the face. The pair are cool management operators with no detectable trace of passion for their product. Arcadia, meanwhile, is run by Stuart Rose, a serial retailer with 17 years of M&S experience, who talks at the pace of Peter O'Sullevan on speed. He is a snappy dresser with a sense of urgency, and the City loves him. What a difference a Top Man makes.

Lex reader

Here's a cheap rhetorical: what might the venerable Lex column make of news that the Financial Times is trimming 10% of the workforce at FT.com? This is mere cheese-paring, given the scale of spending on the business news site last year - upwards of £100m - and the severity of the downturn in advertising.

FT.com is a great brand. It must be doing intangible wonders for the newspaper's name internationally.

But as Lex told its readers yesterday, as it berated the big investment banks for failing to cut staff numbers aggressively in the wake of the bull market blowout, "business stinks and profits are plunging". This first cut should have been much deeper.
fields.bodyText: Positive switch at the MPC Gordon Brown chose his moment well. On the day the doveish faction on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee tasted victory in the battle over interest rates, he announced that one woman with close links to industry, DeAnne Julius, formally of British Airways, should be replaced by another, Kate Barker of the CBI. Despite the inevitable criticism that the decision is motivated by the need to have a woman on the MPC, it was the right decision. Ms Julius left the MPC of her own volition, and a balanced com mittee needed an economist of similar views to succeed her. Ms Barker is eminently suited to the job. End of story. She joins at an intriguing time. The statement issued by the MPC following the quarter-point cut yesterday underlined the ascendancy of Ms Julius and her brother in arms on the MPC, Sushil Wadhwani. Yes, it said, the domestic economy has remained robust, but the gloomy picture abroad has affected business and consumer confidence, and may yet do more damage. Yes, the labour market is tight, but price and cost pressures remain muted. There is no sign of inflation picking up - on the contrary it will remain below its 2.5% target unless rates are cut. The fact that the statement concludes that the MPC will continue to monitor the downside risks carefully suggests both that further rate cuts are in the pipeline, and that Ms Julius and Mr Wadhwani were pressing for a cut of 50 basis points this month. All this supports the City view that interest rates are coming down to 5% over the next few months, and may go lower. Looking further ahead, it is possible that cost pressures will start to push up inflation, necessitating a rise in rates in 2002. But the fact that underlying inflation is still below 2% should tell the MPC that something fundamental has happened to the relationship between growth, inflation and unemployment. It was to Ms Julius's credit that she spotted the trend early, and was often a lone voice on the MPC before the arrival of Mr Wadhwani. She will be a tough act to follow. Retail diversity In one week we have seen two retail recovery plans from M&S and Arcadia, the UK's number one and two purveyors of clothing. Their plans are not dissimilar - get out of peripheral businesses, concentrate on the core middle market operations, bring some flair and inspiration to the shops, improve customer service and so on - basic retailing, really. Twelve months ago, they were both in deep trouble. Debt-laden Arcadia's problems appeared terminal. In recent months, both of the companies' share prices have undoubtedly benefited from the interest of a foreign investor - the US Brandes group now holds 12% of M&S and the Icelandic Baugur group has built a 20% stake in Arcadia. Both companies insist they are friendly holdings based on value investing. But the TopShop group has performed a Lazarus-style recovery and City analysts, by and large, are mad for it. Its shares have increased sixfold, and yesterday's recovery strategy produced another flurry of excitement and the belief that the company can deliver on its promises. One week on, any excitement that M&S generated has disappeared. The diverse responses are the result of some crucial differences. There are tangible signs of improvement at Arcadia - little things like increasing sales from less space and higher margins - that are still missing at M&S. On basic measures such as the price to earnings ratio, M&S is rated more highly than Arcadia. M&S is run by a Belgian supermarket chief and a McKinsey man who probably wouldn't recognise a fashion trend if it slapped them in the face. The pair are cool management operators with no detectable trace of passion for their product. Arcadia, meanwhile, is run by Stuart Rose, a serial retailer with 17 years of M&S experience, who talks at the pace of Peter O'Sullevan on speed. He is a snappy dresser with a sense of urgency, and the City loves him. What a difference a Top Man makes. Lex reader Here's a cheap rhetorical: what might the venerable Lex column make of news that the Financial Times is trimming 10% of the workforce at FT.com? This is mere cheese-paring, given the scale of spending on the business news site last year - upwards of £100m - and the severity of the downturn in advertising. FT.com is a great brand. It must be doing intangible wonders for the newspaper's name internationally. But as Lex told its readers yesterday, as it berated the big investment banks for failing to cut staff numbers aggressively in the wake of the bull market blowout, "business stinks and profits are plunging". This first cut should have been much deeper.

fields.headline: S&N sizes up Peroni
fields.standfirst: Acquisitive brewer turns to Italy and Spain
fields.trailText: Scottish & Newcastle is considering plans to spend more than £500m taking over Peroni of Italy, maker of Nastro Azzurro, and buying into Mahou/San Miguel of Spain.
fields.body:
Scottish & Newcastle is considering plans to spend more than £500m taking over Peroni of Italy, maker of Nastro Azzurro, and buying into Mahou/San Miguel of Spain.

S&N still owes £1.2bn from its purchase of Kronenbourg from Danone of France so would need to raise additional money. It might be tempted to do this through disposal or sale and leaseback of its pubs estate, analysts say. S&N has already outlined plans to sell 740 pubs as part of a cost-cutting programme agreed at the start of the year.

S&N is running the slide rule over Peroni, which could cost £300m. The two companies al ready have a close relationship through the Italian brewer licensing Kronenbourg.

S&N had signalled a desire to buy a 24% stake in Peroni that was held by Danone but was prevented from doing so by Italian family shareholders who exercised pre-emption rights last December.

Now the controlling Peroni shareholders are considering the sale of the whole business and S&N has registered its interest.

A spokesman for the Edinburgh-based brewer said yesterday: "We wanted the 24% stake that Danone had and if the whole business comes up for sale 'yes' we are interested."

But industry experts say S&N might face tough competition for Peroni from Danish brewer Carlsberg and Dutch rival Heineken.

S&N has also confirmed interest in buying the 33% stake in Spain's second-largest brewer which is held by Danone.

Two Spanish family shareholders have an option to buy the stake, estimated to be worth £200m.

S&N has 24 months to pay the amount owed on its £1.7bn takeover of Kronenbourg in March 2000.

The purchase of Kronenbourg has already made S&N the second biggest brewer in Europe, behind Heineken and ahead of Carlsberg.

S&N shares ended the day up 1p at 515p.

fields.headline: Mobile numbers create conflict
fields.trailText: Vodafone and BT Cellnet, Britain's two largest mobile phone networks, yesterday sent conflicting messages about the rate of market growth.
fields.body:
Vodafone and BT Cellnet, Britain's two largest mobile phone networks, yesterday sent conflicting messages about the rate of market growth.

Like One2One, which reported its customer numbers on Wednesday, Vodafone figures showed the market has begun to slow significantly. Vodafone signed 616,000 new customers during the first three months of the year, compared with 851,000 in the same period last year.

Chris Gent, Vodafone chief executive, said the figures "reflect the slowdown in customer growth post the buoyant Christmas and the initial effects of the adoption of our new commercial policies".

BT Cellnet outstripped analysts' forecasts by acquiring 918,000 customers between January and March. That was double the number of customers signed in the same period last year and took its customer base to 11.2m, behind Vodafone's 12.3m.

Orange is due to announce its results on Monday and analysts expect it to have added more than 1m customers. That would not be enough to dislodge BT Cellnet as number two in the domestic market.

Worldwide, Vodafone added 4.4m customers during the quarter bringing its base to 83.4m.

All four networks have shifted focus to improving revenues and margins and away from customer acquisition. BT Cellnet became the last of the four yesterday to reduce the subsidies on handsets for pre-pay services, raising the price of its cheapest phone to £70.

The focus on revenue growth has been sharpened by outlays on licences and infrastructure for next-generation networks.

One2One added 657,000 customers, taking the expected total across the four networks in the first three months of 2001 to 3.2m new users.

fields.headline: On message
fields.trailText: e-briefs
fields.body:
 Hype unspun: The take-up of e-business in the UK is slow, and much heralded fundamental changes to how businesses operate have not materialised, according to a report jointly commissioned by the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply, the Institute of Management and the Institute of Transport and Logistics . The survey of more than 1,000 companies, and central and local government departments, found 61% of respondents had seen no increase in revenue from implemented e-business strategies.

 Calibre of growth: UK software firm DCS Group said yesterday it had appointed Stephen Yapp as finance director.

 Unwound: Leading US wireless phone company Verizon Wireless reported first-quarter subscriber growth short of expectations amid a slowing economy and a shift away from less attractive prepaid customers. Verizon's second-quarter subscriber growth also may be poor - in the range of 600,000 new customers compared with 800,000 a year ago, said a source familiar with the company.

webTitle: Bin Laden suspects seized in Europe

fields.headline: Bin Laden suspects seized in Europe
fields.trailText: Police in Italy and Germany have broken up a suspected terrorist cell whose members are alleged by investigating magistrates to have plotted bomb attacks across Europe on behalf of the Islamic militant Osama bin Laden.
fields.body:
Police in Italy and Germany have broken up a suspected terrorist cell whose members are alleged by investigating magistrates to have plotted bomb attacks across Europe on behalf of the Islamic militant Osama bin Laden.

But the raids that ran into the early hours yesterday failed to net five suspects who were still being hunted in Italy last night.

The six men who were seized are accused of targeting Strasbourg's Gothic cathedral. In Milan and the nearby town of Busto Arsizio, five Tunisians were arrested on suspicion of supplying arms and false documents. The sixth man was arrested in Germany.

"For the first time, we believe we can determine a direct link between Islamic terrorist cells and training camps in Afghanistan," said Stefano Dambruoso, one of two investigating magistrates in the case.

Investigators said that Lombardy, the region where the arrests took place, was being used to supply the operational needs - weapons and paperwork - of extremists trained in Afghanistan and now operating in Britain, Germany, France and Belgium.

Italy's interior minister, Enzo Bianco, hailed police forces in Europe and the United States, plus Italy's two main intelligence agencies, Sismi and Sisde, for pooling information and acting on it.

"The nerve centre of an organisation which could carry out attacks in Europe has been exposed. Police have uncovered a very dangerous unit ready [to carry out] terrorist acts. We are convinced we have defeated a mastermind of Islamic terrorism."

Two of the suspects arrested in Italy were said to be on the run after serving time in Jordan and Tunisia.

All five are being held in Milan's San Vittore prison while charges of belonging to a criminal organisation, trafficking in arms and falsifying documents are prepared.

They were named as Essid Sami Ben Khemais, 32, Charaabi Tarek, 30, Bouchoucha Moktar, 31, Kammon Medhi, 32, and Ben Soltane Adel, 30. They shared houses in Viale Bligny in Milan, and Via Dubini in Busto Arsizio.

The man arrested in Germany, believed to be Algerian, was accused of helping them to prepare a Christmas atrocity in the French city of Strasbourg, where the European parliament sits.

The attack was allegedly aborted on December 26 after police in Frankfurt seized two Iraqis, an Algerian, and a Frenchman, along with arms and explosives. An amateur video film of the route to the cathedral was also found.

Italian investigators said the men were working for Bin Laden, a wealthy Saudi exile hiding in Afghanistan.

Sought by the US for the 1998 bombing of its embassies in Nairobi and Dar es Salaam, which killed 224 people - all but a few of them African residents, not the target Americans - he is suspected of providing training camps and funding for the men now in detention, who are said to include mercenaries.

webTitle: Time for truth as Rwanda strives for reconciliation

fields.headline: Time for truth as Rwanda strives for reconciliation
fields.standfirst: On the genocide's seventh anniversary a unique experiment in village-level justice is under way to try to end a culture of impunity
fields.trailText: Margaritte Salome Uwamaliya lives in a newly built village for widows on the outskirts of the Rwandan capital, Kigali - neat, square earthen houses with concrete floors and iron roofs. In her living room there are wooden chairs and a sofa, a radio and crocheted covers on the sideboard which hint at her former life as the wife of a civil servant.
fields.body:
Margaritte Salome Uwamaliya lives in a newly built village for widows on the outskirts of the Rwandan capital, Kigali - neat, square earthen houses with concrete floors and iron roofs. In her living room there are wooden chairs and a sofa, a radio and crocheted covers on the sideboard which hint at her former life as the wife of a civil servant.

Her husband and two of her six children were killed in the genocide seven years ago, as were her siblings and every other relation except two of her brother's children who now live with her.

From behind her house she looks up the hill to Kigali's biggest prison, Kimironko, where prisoners in their pink pyjama uniform come and go. "We see these people, we are forced to forgive them, but they don't recognise what they've done... they ignore us, even if we offer them a drink of water," she says.

"Foreigners can never understand the void we widows live in, we have lost the whole of our large families, our husband's families, everyone is gone."

Margaritte says the pain of poverty is with her every day; when her children want something for school they lament the lack of a father to provide it for them.

Rwanda, in a unique experiment in local justice, is starting to try many of its 120,000 prisoners in informal people's courts in an attempt to foster national reconciliation.

Survivors such as Margaritte now face the challenge of confronting the killers of her family. She speaks for many survivors when she says, "It will not be easy to live with them again, it will be very, very hard to welcome them."

The survivors know who killed their families, though many would be too afraid to testify against them in public.

The gacaca system of justice - once a traditional community court used for banal village disputes - will try prisoners before open meetings in towns and villages in which their former neighbours and friends will detail exactly what each of the accused did during the genocide. Rape, which was extremely prevalent during the genocide, will not be tried by gacaca , the memories too painful for the victims to recall in open court.

"We are asked why we didn't take the South African approach of amnesty," says Gerald Gahima, the government's chief prosecutor. "Ours is a different case and you can only do what is politically possible in your own society. Of course, we cannot kill all those who deserve to die, it would not stabilise our society. But in the aftermath of genocide there was an over whelming feeling that there must be accountability, people must be punished so it will not happen again."

Gacaca promises that those found not guilty by the community in which they lived, or those who have confessed to a minor part in the killings, will go free.

"Establishing the truth is as important as justice, and if everyone participates it will create the environment for reconciliation," says Mr Gahima.

The justice minister, Jean de Dieu Mucyo, says: "There can be no reconciliation here without justice. We have to break a system of impunity which stretches back to the 1960s when people were told that the more they joined in the killings, the less they would be punished."

But gacaca is a risk, a judicial experiment that needs enormous resources to equip 10,000 courts, and elect and train 280,000 lay judges.

No one can be sure that the instinct to protect friends and relatives will not weigh heavier than the truth. Many survivors oppose gacaca which they know will inevitably return killers to communities where the survivors, often widows and children, are desperately poor, marginalised and fearful.

As one government official put it, "For most of us the genocide ended in 1994, but in the villages survivors feel threatened every day of their lives. If you visit villages and speak to them they are immediately afraid they will be noticed, that they will be killed."

Judges murdered

However, Mr Gahima and other justice officials say there is absolutely no alternative, given the overwhelming numbers involved in the three months of killing in 1994, when about 800,000 people were butchered. "The bottom line is that the courts cannot do this job - gacaca is the only chance," Mr Gahima says.

The justice system itself was decimated in the genocide with many officials and judges murdered. But since 1994 it has been rebuilt, staffed with 800 judges trained with help, in particular, from Canada, the US, and Germany.

In the last five years 5,000 people have been tried. Tens of thousands of the old, the sick, and those against whom the evidence was too flimsy, have been released. But 120,000 remain in prison, and, even with the International Committee of the Red Cross paying half the prison food bill, the prison system still takes 4% of the national budget (5% of the budget is set aside for a survivors' fund).

Philip Munyurwo is an early beneficiary of a gacaca trial. He spent four years in prison in the south-east of the country and wrote three times to the authorities pleading his innocence.

"When they started gacaca in the prison they asked those who had confessed to the killings whether I had been with them... and they said 'no'. Then they asked the people of my village and no one accused me, so I went free," Mr Munyurwo says.

Mr Munyurwo is an anxious-looking man; responsible for his own family and the children of his brother who was killed in the genocide. While in prison he worried about how hard things were for his family.

He shakes his head, remembering those four long years. But at the sudden sight of a large group of prisoners in pink pyjamas being escorted up the road he breaks into a broad smile and waves to his former companions.

Ready to confess

As talk of gacaca started in many jails, spontaneous groups sprang up and divided those ready to confess from those who maintained their innocence.

"We started gacaca in the prisons, taking a truckload at a time back to the village they all came from. People came out in their thousands and were very clear who did what, who should go free and who deserved prison," said the justice minister.

He believes that once gacaca has started in earnest, Rwanda can return to normal in about three to five years, without its massive prison population distorting the family life of everyone in society.

webTitle: Diego Garcia exiles say Britain owes passports

fields.headline: Diego Garcia exiles say Britain owes passports
fields.trailText: Indian Ocean islanders are going to demand compensation today from Britain for its illegal eviction of them 30 years ago to make way for a US base on the island of Diego Garcia, a British territory.
fields.body:
Indian Ocean islanders are going to demand compensation today from Britain for its illegal eviction of them 30 years ago to make way for a US base on the island of Diego Garcia, a British territory.

The High Court called "the wholesale removal" of the islanders an "abject legal failure" when it ruled on the affair in November. Official papers showed that the British and US governments lied to parliament and Congress at the time.

The islanders are suing the American government for $6bn (£4bn) in compensation.

A delegation of the islanders, who now live in Mauritius, most of them in poverty, will present their demands today to John White, head of the overseas territories department of the Foreign Office.

They also want British citizenship for the 7,818 islanders and direct descendants living in Mauritius.

The Foreign Office says it paid Mauritius £650,000 in 1973 for the benefit of the islanders and in 1982 put £4m in a trust fund which was accepted in "full and final settlement". It says it will consider the issue of citizenship.

It is studying whether two other islands would be livable for those wanting to return - Peros Banhos and Salomon - but not Diego Garcia.
fields.bodyText: Indian Ocean islanders are going to demand compensation today from Britain for its illegal eviction of them 30 years ago to make way for a US base on the island of Diego Garcia, a British territory. The High Court called "the wholesale removal" of the islanders an "abject legal failure" when it ruled on the affair in November. Official papers showed that the British and US governments lied to parliament and Congress at the time. The islanders are suing the American government for $6bn (£4bn) in compensation. A delegation of the islanders, who now live in Mauritius, most of them in poverty, will present their demands today to John White, head of the overseas territories department of the Foreign Office. They also want British citizenship for the 7,818 islanders and direct descendants living in Mauritius. The Foreign Office says it paid Mauritius £650,000 in 1973 for the benefit of the islanders and in 1982 put £4m in a trust fund which was accepted in "full and final settlement". It says it will consider the issue of citizenship. It is studying whether two other islands would be livable for those wanting to return - Peros Banhos and Salomon - but not Diego Garcia.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Filipino rebels delay execution
fields.body:
Filipino rebels delay execution

With minutes to go before the deadline, Abu Sayyaf guerrillas in the southern Philippines backed down from their threat to behead hostage Jeffrey Schilling, 25, following an emotional plea by his mother on local radio yesterday. The American was kidnapped by the Muslim rebels seven months ago.
AFP, Manila

Thousands flee Liberia fighting

Thousands are fleeing renewed heavy fighting between Liberian forces and dissidents in the northern Lofa region. Hundreds of thousands of Liberian and Sierra Leonean refugees have been stranded in Guinea by the conflict which has cost at least 1,000 lives since September.
Reuters, Monrovia

Guard guilty of paint assault

A black security guard has been convicted of assault and fined 1,500 rand (£130) for painting white a 14-year-old black girl accused of shoplifting in Louis Trichardt, 250 miles northeast of Johannesburg. The store's white manager allegedly ordered the girl to be painted but was found not guilty due to lack of evidence.
AP, Louis Trichardt

fields.headline: Berlusconi may face extradition
fields.standfirst: Special report: European parliament
fields.trailText: The Italian opposition leader and former prime minister Silvio Berlusconi, who is preparing for a general election on May 13, has been put a step closer to extradition to Spain on tax fraud charges by a European parliament committee ruling yesterday that his immunity as an MEP can be challenged
fields.byline: Rory Carroll in Rome and Andrew Osborn in Brussels
fields.body:
The Italian opposition leader and former prime minister Silvio Berlusconi, who is preparing for a general election on May 13, has been put a step closer to extradition to Spain on tax fraud charges by a European parliament committee ruling yesterday that his immunity as an MEP can be challenged

Theruling, overturning a previous decision to safeguard his immunity, infuriated his political allies. But the MEPs did not give a date for deciding whether his immunity should be lifted, and even if it is he will probably remain protected as a member of the Italian chamber of deputies.

Nevertheless, another legal wrangle is the last thing he wants as the opinion polls make his centre-right coalition the likely victors in May.

Mr Berlusconi fell from power in 1994 in a welter of corruption allegations, but he has clawed his way back to respectability, casting himself as the victim of a leftwing witch hunt.

Many Italians are now bored rather than shocked by his legal travails. Trials, convictions and appeals in connection with corruption, bribery, illegal party financing and fraud have ground through the courts, but none of them has stuck.

Spain wants to prosecute the media tycoon in connection with his acquisition of the Spanish station Tele 5. The inquiry is led by Baltasar Garzon, the investigating magistrate who sought the former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet's extradition from Britain.

In February Mr Garzon accused the parliament of delaying his request for Mr Berlusconi's immunity to be lifted.

Socialist MEPs asked for an inquiry into the delay and threatened to take legal action against the conservative parliamentary president, Nicole Fontaine.

Yesterday's decision means that the rules preventing MEPs looking at documents relating to other members' personal and financial interests will have to be lifted allow a thorough investigation.

Mr Berlusconi, 64, said the Spanish accusations were baseless.

fields.headline: Israeli phone bomb kills militant
fields.standfirst:
Violence and new settlement fuel tension in West Bank

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel stepped up reprisals against the Palestinians yesterday by assassinating a commander of the militant Islamic Jihad group with an explosive device planted in a public phone box.
fields.body:
Israel stepped up reprisals against the Palestinians yesterday by assassinating a commander of the militant Islamic Jihad group with an explosive device planted in a public phone box.

Islamic Jihad, which has been responsible for many bombings in Israel, threatened to avenge his death. A similar Israeli booby trap in 1996 was followed by a wave of suicide bombings.

The killing in the West Bank town of Jenin came only hours after Israeli soldiers shot up a convoy carrying a senior Palestinian negotiator, Mohammed Dahlan, back from peace talks. He escaped injury, but one of his bodyguards was shot in the leg and two others were injured when their vehicle overturned.

Mr Dahlan, a member of the inner circle of the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, is the most senior Palestinian yet to be on the receiving end of Israeli fire.

The Palestinians claimed it was a botched assassination attempt while the Israelis insisted the Palestinians opened fire first. The Israeli army promised an investigation.

After a relatively quiet Wednesday that saw political initiatives from both sides, the hardline Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, resorted to the iron fist yesterday.

In addition to the violence that also saw the Israelis kill Ahmed Mahmoud al-Atar, a 15-year-old Palestinian who was throwing stones, the Israeli government threatened to add to the already deteriorating situation by inviting tenders for 700 new houses for Jewish settlers in the predominantly Palestinian West Bank.

Israeli peace campaigners condemned the announcement, while the United States called the move provocative and inflammatory. Using language much stronger than in previous statements on Jewish settlements, state department spokesman Richard Boucher said: "Continuing settlement activity by Israel does risk further inflaming an already volatile situation in the region.

"This is provocative and we have consistently encouraged both sides to refrain from provocative acts."

The Islamic Jihad commander, Iyad al-Hardan, 25, was killed instantly when the phone exploded after he inserted a phone card. He had been released from a Palestinian Authority prison after the uprising began in September, but was re-arrested by Palestinian police six weeks ago. He was regularly allowed out to make calls.

A Palestinian Authority source said: "Israel is responsible for this assassination operation by putting explosive materials inside the telephone."

Israeli officials declined to comment but Israeli radio reported that Mr Hardan had been liquidated by the Israeli security forces and that he was responsible for a series of attacks on Israelis.

The shooting incident involving Mr Dahlan, who is head of security in Gaza, took place at the Israel-Gaza border as he was returning from talks in Tel Aviv with Israeli security chiefs about renewing joint security arrangements which were ended by the Palestinian uprising.

"This Israeli ambush was another assassination attack against us," Mr Dahlan said.

Nerves tend to be fraught at the border, especially in the darkness, and soldiers, police and security men on both sides are trigger-happy.

An Israeli army spokesman, Lieutenant Olivier Rafowicz, said, following a preliminary investigation, that the Palestinians "opened fire from the first Jeep, from the back right-hand window and then Israeli soldiers fired back at the source from the Jeep".

He said: "This [assassination] allegation is childish and baseless. We were sitting with him and other security people to try to resume peace talks. There is no logic [in trying to assassinate him]."

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.standfirst: Our daughter-in-law wants her new husband to adopt our grandchild
fields.trailText: Our daughter-in-law wants her new husband to adopt our grandchild.
fields.body:
"When our son died in a car accident his own son was only two months old. His wife remarried 18 months later and is expecting a baby. We have always had a good relationship with her and see a great deal of our two-and-a-half year old grandson but she has just dropped a bombshell which has left us devastated: she wants her new husband to adopt her son (it is her idea but he will go along with her wishes). She says she would like her children to share the same surname. I've always supported my daughter-in-law but I am devastated by this. How can I come to terms with the situation?"

Don't be selfish

My husband left me for another woman when my younger son was born. I remarried two years later and my second husband wanted to adopt my son and give them his surname, as did I. However my first husband would permit neither.

Having two surnames in the family has caused endless problems. I am frequently addressed by my first husband's name, as is my second husband, which we dislike, our sons' friends cannot find them in the phone book, there are problems with medical records and I have to make explanations for what must be a common situation these days.

So don't be selfish. It will make your daughter-in-law's life much easier to have both her children sharing the same surname and will help to make your grandson feel truly included in his new family. It is no insult to the memory of your son, whose genes live on with your grandson.
Name and address withheld

Wills are the answer

You and your husband should make wills leaving your estates to your grandson on condition that he revert to his father's surname, failing which the money will go to charity. He will be only too eager to comply. There's no need to mention this clause to your daughter-in-law during your lives.
Alison Hope, by email

It's about belonging

My former partner and I decided on his surname for our child when she was born two years ago. Now we have separated and she is to live with me, I can't remember the reasons why I forfeited my own name and after some heated debate, we have agreed on a double-barrel. It is important to me that she has the name of the family she is part of, just as your late son's wife feels. Names give us a sense of belonging and are an intrinsic part of children's social inclusion or exclusion. Your grandson carrying your son's name may only be a comfort to you - it may make the boy grow up feeling an outsider and not as much a part of his parents' family as his new sibling.
Name and address withheld

Think of her husband

When my brother died, his wife was pregnant with their second child. She married again after two years and they wanted to give the children the new surname. They asked me what my opinion was and I was in wholehearted agreement. The children are now grown up and the eldest has decided to revert to his biological father's surname. Maybe the other child will do the same. I am very conscious of the importance of blood ties but the most important thing is the well being of the living descendants and to care for the feelings of the new husband. All parties are happy with our solution.
Name and address withheld

Not a betrayal

This is clearly a very upsetting situation for you, but I don't think you should see your former daughter-in-law's decision as a betrayal of your son's memory. I lived with my mother, step-father and his daughters from the age of two. They all had the same surname and mine was different, which contributed to my feeling of not belonging. People always seemed to want to know why I had a different name and it was a source of embarrassment and inconvenience for me at the doctor's, the dentist's and at school.

At 13, I changed my name by deed poll to be the same as the rest of my family unit. My father was upset, but for me the name change was a practical decision rather than a symbolic gesture and I have never regretted it. I suspect your grandson's mother is trying to ensure that he feels that he totally belongs to his family unit comprising her, her new husband and their future children.

Your son will not be forgotten because of a detail like a name. Your continuing role in his life will ensure that, and later in life your grandson will come to terms with his loss in his own way. Perhaps you could create a box of mementos of your son's life for your grandson to inherit as an adult. Margaret Forster's novel The Memory Box describes a woman's discovery of such a box created by her mother.
Name and address withheld

Next week

My daughter is overweight. She eats too many snacks between meals, admits as much to me, but my wife doesn't see it. Teenage angst, looming A-levels and peer pressure might all be mitigating factors but the eating pattern has been consistent through all the highs and lows of the past 18 months. Her exam results have been disappointing and she spends a lot of time using the internet. Her mother refuses to acknowledge any of this as a problem.

Also, my son is anaemic. He eats a poor diet, is off school a lot, listless and clearly unhappy. My wife insists his condition is psychological and wants us to separate (me to get out) so that the kids see us row less often. If I thought this would work I would do it, but I feel such a step would have an irreversible effect on everybody. Is there a better solution?

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax: 020-7239 9935, email privatelives@theguardian.com (please do not send attachments).

fields.headline: Learning to cope with TB
fields.standfirst: My week: Gary Coleby
fields.trailText: My week: Gary Coleby.
fields.body:
Gary Coleby is the headmaster of Crown Hills community college, the secondary school in Leicester with the TB outbreak. He has been trying to maintain normal school life around countless media interviews and mass TB screenings

"So much has happened it's been unbelievable. Last Friday it was a very busy school week and we were also doing a lot of screenings. Several hundred kids going into the second stage of testing. I had interviews all afternoon, contact with the BBC and the local paper about what was going on. At the weekend I went home completely exhausted.

I'm always at work at 7.30am. On Monday there was a school achievement award, I interviewed a person for a post, was observing a teacher in the classroom, and had evening meetings. On Tuesday the screening continued. The first round who had had tests read were being X-rayed. At 4pm I had to attend a press conference with the area health authority. There's been significant contact with media. GMTV wanted me to go in at 6.30am to do a live interview. I made a decision to front up to the media to try and protect the kids and the teachers.

On Wednesday the shit really hit the fan. At 6.30 I was being interviewed by GMTV, then later by the Daily Mail, the Times, the Guardian, Sky Television, and PA. Also live interviews with BBC radio, both local and national, ITN, the Asia Network as well. I had to field numerous phone calls, chase up teachers, do training, everyday things you have to do at a school. My number was given out and GMTV called and wanted me to go in again at 6.30. I was not prepared to do any more television stuff outside school hours.

On Thursday there was a staff meeting, contact with concerned parents and community groups. I've also been working with Dr Phillip Monk, who is co-ordinating the screening. I met the kitchen staff who were concerned whether they should be screened and wanted to be included. There is a governor's discipline meeting at 4pm and a press conference at 4.30. Then I shall go home.

It is serious but nowhere near as serious as it's been made out to be. The way it's been reported makes it sound as if it's a highly infectious contagious disease, which it's not. One day there were five known cases, the next day 24. That doesn't mean it spread and they got it, it was just detected - they'd had it for a while. The strain is very treatable, most people don't have to be off school.

Life goes on. There is no reason to close the school. It's a community issue not a school issue. It was spotted here but started in the community. I remain cheerful and confident. I have a superb bunch of kids and a superb bunch of staff. But people are worried. I am 49 but I feel 65."

fields.headline: Take five
fields.standfirst: The daily news quiz
fields.trailText: The daily news quiz.
fields.body:
Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. All you have to do is come up with each day's answers, then send in all 25 at the end of the week. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders.

E1 Edward Spencer was the impromptu guest of which singing star?

(a) Marilyn Manson

(b) Shirley Temple

(c) Sarah Brightman

(d) Geri Halliwell

E2 Marks & Spencer aren't famous for their

(a) Knickers

(b) Sandwiches

(c) Profits

(d) Ready meals

E3 What was Spencer Tracy's middle name?

(a) Bonaparte

(b) Bonaventure

(c) Bellfield

(d) Bloomingdale

E4 Jon Spencer is best known for his

(a) Stamp collection

(b) Pointy shoes

(c) Blues Explosion

(d) Chihuahuas

E5 Edmund Spenser wrote

(a) Jingles

(b) For Chat!

(c) Poetry

(d) The Little Book of Calm

 Entries must reach Take Five, the Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER by April 11. The winner will be notified by April 20. One entry per person. No purchase necessary. The daily online news quiz is at Guardian Unlimited Quiz Room.

fields.headline: The herds and the bees
fields.standfirst: Tetbury
fields.trailText: Tetbury.
fields.body:
A gift of three fine pots of local honey from Alan came with an invitation: "I shall be looking at the bees and moving the queen soon. Would you like to come and watch the early season preparations?" I would have been very pleased to do so, having enjoyed a visit a couple of years back, in which I was fully attired in the white gauze suit and veiled hat of the apiarist to watch the hives prepared for summer. Only one bee got through the protective clothing, and since I had the sense not to become agitated, it gained its freedom without stinging me.

But one of the relatively minor implications of the foot and mouth outbreak, which has got remorselessly closer over the past week, is that Alan cannot now get access to his hives, which, although only a few hundred yards from his home in Coaley, are on farmland across the road, in a fruit-tree-shaded meadow, where a milking herd of Friesians share the space with the bees. MAFF rules to prevent the unwitting spread of the infection do not permit Alan to access his hives, and he is currently fearful that by the time he can get to them, his industrious little friends will have perished for lack of his timely spring intervention. Which would be a pity, since he was telling me that he was now stocked with a particularly calm and unaggressive strain of bee.

On a summer day it is a delight to sit in the shade of the apple trees, with the bees coming in from their foraging trips and the cattle gently ruminating beside one. Only when restrictions are lifted will he be able to check the hives and provide some start-up nourishment for the season. And whether that will be in time is entirely unpredictable.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Animal Farm | The Cincinnati Kid | Live Cricket
fields.body:
Films

Animal Farm
(John Halas, Joy Batchelor, 1954)
6pm, FilmFour

Halas and Batchelor directed, produced and wrote this full-length animated version of George Orwell's satire. No barnstormer, but a faithful rendition of Napoleon's rise to power in Jones's farm, agreeing with his comrades that all animals are equal, "but some are more equal than others".

The Cincinnati Kid
(Norman Jewison, 1965)
9pm, TCM

Taut, atmospheric and basically the card-playing brother of Robert Rossen's 1961 pool movie, The Hustler. The game is stud poker, and Steve McQueen's Kid, challenger to The Man (Edward G Robinson) in a gruelling contest in dour New Orleans, is as charismatic a brash young gambler as hustling Paul Newman; but cooler. Excellently played, too, by the likes of Karl Malden, Tuesday Weld and Ann-Margret.

Close Encounters Of The Third Kind (Special Edition)
(Steven Spielberg, 1980)
9pm, Carlton Cinema

Featuring the aliens with the five-note musical calling card: and curiously, since this is Spielberg's homage to 50s sci-fi, not a ray-gun in sight. He blew the $20m mega-budget on dazzling special effects, Douglas Trumbull's team creating alien craft of astonishing size and power, and on clever smaller tricks too - such as little Cary Guffey's toys going bonkers when the aliens arrive.

Withnail And I
(Bruce Robinson, 1986)
10pm, FilmFour

Sordid, supremely funny trudge through the pathetic lives of two destitute young actors - Paul McGann and the languidly furious Richard E Grant - who survive on drugs and drink in grotty Camden Town, then head for the hellish rural idyll of Uncle Monty's (Richard Griffiths) freezing country cottage in order to rejuvenate. A brilliantly witty, thoroughly miserable comedy, famously full of quotable lines such as Grant asking a tea-room waitress to bring "the finest wines available to humanity".

The Opposite Of Sex
(Don Roos, 1998)
1.25am, Sky Premier

Christina Ricci's breasts point to something special in the opening scene. She adjusts them as though calibrating some secret weapon, then heads off to do battle with the world; but the early intimations of a truly subversive and original comedy are soon replaced by more conventional laughs. Still, it is fun, as the utterly self-centred Ricci insinuates her way into the home of half-brother Martin Donovan and proceeds to wreck his life; and Lisa Kudrow - the funny one in Friends - is a treat as Donovan's repressed, sharp-tongued friend.

Sports

Live Cricket
3pm Sky Sports Extra
7pm Sky Sports 3

West Indies, 1-0 down in the series, take on South Africa in the fourth Test at the Recreation Ground in St John's, Antigua. The last meeting was a remarkable affair, with the home side falling from 59-1 on the final afternoon to 89-7. The first session is hidden away on Sky Sports Extra, but moves over to make way for football this evening.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Omnibus | Jazz Legends | The Arrangers
fields.body:
In 1855 some enthusiastic, but wildly misguided huntsmen released a batch of European red foxes near Melbourne in Australia. Within 40 years they had spread across the continent, and so affected native wildlife that a bounty scheme was introduced to control them. However, their continued depredations have brought the numbat and the black-flanked rock wallaby near to extinction. Nick Franklin reports for Omnibus (9.05am and 7.05pm, World Service; Saturday 1.05am, Radio 4) how a former environment minister is spending millions on a special sanctuary for such threatened species.

The apparently inexhaustible musical inventiveness of Sidney Bechet is recalled in Jazz Legends (4.0pm, Radio 3). He started his career in 1909 but the session I heard him play in Paris in 1954 is still etched on my memory. He was then nearing 60 but retained the drive and inspiration of someone 30 years younger. He was largely responsible for bringing the soprano saxophone into the jazz mainstream, playing it with such power that he could overwhelm any accompanying trumpeter.

Robert Niles's latest candidate for his series on The Arrangers (10.0pm, Radio 2) is that endlessly productive Canadian, Robert Farnon, who has written the background music for more than 40 films. Among his admirers is André Previn, who thinks he is our greatest living writer for strings.

fields.headline: Don't leave me this way
fields.trailText: Reith Lectures | It's My Story - The Baby On The Doorstep | Start The Week
fields.body:
One of the special things about radio is its portability. There are lots of places - the shower, a bus, a car next to a chip van outside a Buddhist centre - that television just cannot reach. But it's in such places that radio sneaks up on us, given some very basic technology, and where it can shine. It was in such a place this week (car adjacent to chippie and enlightenment) that I heard a modest programme about life that would steal the considerable thunder of the first of this year's Reith Lectures (Radio 4), broadcast two days later.

I wasn't in the mood for other people's misery, stuck in a freezing car, waiting for a friend to finish the world's longest yoga class, as hail stones pinged off my windscreen. What I grudgingly noticed first about It's My Story - The Baby On The Doorstep (Radio 4), the tale of Nicholas Christmas, abandoned two hours after birth by his mother, was all the stuff beyond or before speech. Nicholas gurgled his hunger through a nurse's recollections of the night he was brought in, squealing softly as a bottle of warm milk reached him. The detective leading the search for the baby's mother whis tled through his teeth as he spoke; a nurse sang a lullaby of "You Are My Sunshine" to the baby on the day he was to leave with his adoptive parents. As she sang "please don't take my sunshine away", I lost it, blubbing like a fool. This happens regularly at the end of ER, but the chip queue isn't usually watching.

It wasn't a mawkish programme, but one raising the very serious question of what a life means - to a mother who can't cope with the reality of a child, to the police and social services, and most importantly, to Nicholas himself as he grows up. Tony, a member of a support group for people abandoned as babies, says the act of being left "leaves something in you", an anxiety, a lack of confidence. Campaigners call for no-questions-asked drop-off points for babies, which all sounds a bit dystopian, until you realise that one baby a week is abandoned in the UK, and that the act remains criminalised, causing mothers to disappear without trace.

I thought again of Nicholas as Reith lecturer Professor Tom Kirkwood explained how we are programmed for survival and not death; a bit like the lectures themselves, really. There were some nice moments - Kirkwood talked of rabbits reading Freud - but a much stronger sense of the reality of ageing came from artist Frank Stella on Start The Week (Radio 4). Suffering from arthritis, he relies on the two Vs - Vitox and Viagra - to enjoy life: "I was getting stiff in all the wrong places." You could hear the very youthful twinkle in his eye.

fields.headline: Ianthe Carswell
fields.standfirst: Founding spirit of nuclear disarmament movement
fields.trailText: Founding spirit of nuclear disarmament movement.
fields.body:
I n 1957, Ianthe Carswell, who has died aged 83, and her friend Sheila Jones were the prime movers behind what they called the National Committee for the Abolition of Nuclear Tests. Soon afterwards, it became the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament.

It was Ianthe who enlisted the sponsorship of names such as Michael Foot, Bertrand Russell, EM Forster and Benjamin Britten. Nearer home, she sent her young daughters onto the streets of Hampstead, north London, to tell passers-by what strontium 90 would do to them. The pictures of women and children suffering from radiation at Hiroshima had convinced her that something must be done.

A small, delicately-made woman, Ianthe's determination, and conviction that right must be done, endured throughout her life, from the early Aldermaston marches to the day when she was the only non-Serbian - and the only woman in her 80s - demonstrating outside Downing Street the day after the bombing of Kosovo began. She could be formidable; she once told an eminent art historian to stop wringing his hands about the floods in Florence and do something about it.

Ianthe inherited her uncompromising social conscience and fearlessness from her mother, Ivy Elstob, a brilliant Edwardian beauty much admired, it is said, by Bertrand Russell. During the general strike of 1926, Ivy, a socialist and champion of the underdog, sold her wedding silver and gave the proceeds to striking miners' families. In the 1930s, she joined the Communist party, and drove to Spain with medical supplies for the International Brigade.

When Ianthe was 10, her parents divorced, and she was sent to Downe House school, the breeding ground of many successful women of her generation. She read politics, philosophy and economics at Somerville College, Oxford, and, during the war, was assigned to a special unit in the Ministry of Economic Warfare. Transferred to India, she met up with a Hampstead childhood sweetheart, John Carswell; they married in Delhi, honeymooned in the Himalayas, and returned to London.

Their marriage was one of deep mutual devotion. Ianthe abandoned her career to bring up her daughters, Deborah and Harriet, and support her husband, a man of letters whose upbringing had its roots in DH Lawrence's literary circle. He, in his turn, supported all his wife's causes - the mentally ill, one-parent families, and the United Nations children's fund. He once gave her a spirit level as a present, a symbol of her passion for what was fair and equal.

The Carswells' Hampstead flat was, people were apt to say, one of the last bastions of a truly civilised way of life. At its heart was Ianthe, whose warmth extended far beyond her own family; she was described as the guardian angel of young artists and musicians, whose work she consistently supported. If there is a Utopia, said one of her friends, it would be full of people like Ianthe.

She is survived by her brother and her daughters.

 Ianthe Carswell, campaigner, born December 12 1917; died February 25 2001

webTitle: Obituary letters: Gregory Corso | Sonia Arova

fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText: Early in August 1969, Gregory Corso (Obituary, January 20) charged through the door of City Lights publishers in San Francisco demanding his royalties. "Gregory, you don't have any royalties," I told him. "In fact, you owe us."
fields.body:
Dick McBride writes: Early in August 1969, Gregory Corso (Obituary, January 20) charged through the door of City Lights publishers in San Francisco demanding his royalties. "Gregory, you don't have any royalties," I told him. "In fact, you owe us."

He exploded, and I thought he might take a swing at me. He demanded $50, but I didn't have it. He dropped to $25 and, when I refused, stormed out, shouting Mafia-style curses. Half an hour later, he returned with a watercolour he had done and signed - and demanded $100 for it. "It'll be worth thousands some day." I gave him all I had - $25.

Three weeks later, I was at the Chelsea hotel, New York, when Corso turned up to meet Allen Ginsberg, William Burroughs and Mary Beach. He asked me to lend him $50. When I said I had less money than I'd had in San Francisco, he grinned: "I know, but I can't walk past someone I know without asking for money." It was the last time I saw him.

 Peter Rankin writes: I'd like to correct the account of the entry of the ballerina Sonia Arova (Obituary, March 28) into Britain at the start of the second world war, with my grandmother, the pianist Andrée Ratcliffe, and her two daughters. Ratcliffe showed her passport, which had on it her children - two girls and a boy. "This passport has two girls and a boy on it," said the official. "I see three girls."

"My passport has three children on it, and here are three children," answered my grandmother. It worked, and Sonia was through.

fields.headline: Nicholas Georgiadis
fields.standfirst: Painter and designer famed for sumptuous sets in theatre, ballet and film
fields.trailText: Painter and designer famed for sumptuous sets in theatre, ballet and film.
fields.body:
Earlier this year, the designer and painter Nicholas Georgiadis, who has died aged 77, reworked one of his most celebrated ballet designs, for Kenneth Macmillan's 1965 production of Romeo And Juliet, at Covent Garden. He abstracted his sumptuous Verona, opening the stage to buoyant romance, while the tragic confinement to the crypt was narrowed down to sharpen the ballet's stark conclusion.

However opulent his designs, he always retained the theatrical intelligence that informed his two great collaborative partnerships, with Macmillan and Rudolf Nureyev.

Much of Georgiadis's work drew on the past in a grand, even glitzy, style. His first work with Macmillan, Danses Concertantes (1955), suggested a green and blue palace decorated with winged sphinxes. Later productions created fantasias of the courts of Louis XIV or imperial Vienna. Even so, this was never pure escapism. The wealth-dazzled story of Manon was lavishly ornamented, but ragged squalor gnawed at its edges, and provided the setting for the heroine's death.

Georgiadis could also capture the austerity of The Song Of The Earth; a claustrophobic room with a naked light bulb, reminiscent of Anne Frank's attic, for The Burrow; or The Invitation, with Edwardian costumes as formal, and a set as gauzy, as the narrative's murky erotics. He layered and grouped costumes to great effect - as in the slumped and dozing courtiers in his Sleeping Beauty - and etched metaphors through individual dresses, marking Manon's amoral progress into embroidered black and gold.

Born in Athens, Georgiadis studied painting and architecture in Greece, and at Columbia University, New York. In 1953, he came to London on a scholarship to study at the Slade, and won first prize for stage design, attracting the attention of the Royal Ballet's Ninette de Valois.

His collaboration with Macmillan began with the choreographer's first ballet for Sadler's Wells in 1955. Macmillan, who had never previously worked with a designer, was taken by de Valois to the Slade, and chose to work with Georgiadis. Danses Concertantes was succeeded by a vicious Grimm tale, The House Of Birds, in which a beaky witch turned children into birds - played by girls with their heads held in birdcages. The following year saw their first production for the Royal Ballet, the iridescent Noctambules.

It was Georgiadis who suggested Lorca's The House Of Bernada Alba to Macmillan, who produced Las Hermanas (Stuttgart, 1963). Here the tormented sisters were contained in a monochrome stone house, shuttered away from sunlight. His Napoleonic-era setting for Swan Lake In Berlin (1969) was inspired by gardens at Villa Lanta, near Spoleto, framed by dark arching trees with thorny branches. Stark, black accents always tempered Georgiadis's splashes of colour, as in the arrow-marked leotards of that early Danses Concertantes.

One of his great triumphs was Romeo And Juliet. Macmillan called for a realistic Verona, and Georgiadis responded with a two-tiered set, its marbled arcades linked by steep staircases. Frescoes and angel candelabra carried Byzantine inflections, and the critic Richard Buckle praised the crypt - "a composition of delicate greys" - and the subtle mass of costumes, creating a "browny-pinky-greeny-gold gorgeousness". It was first performed in 1965, with Margot Fonteyn and Nureyev, and continues to be part of the Royal Ballet repertory.

In Mayerling (1978), the claustrophobia of the imperial court was reinforced by ranks of tailor's dummies, keeping the tortured hero under mute surveillance.

In 1982, Georgiadis became the first designer to win the London Evening Standard award for outstanding contribution to dance, for his Orpheus and The Tempest. In his dark and gold Orpheus, flickering with candles, Orpheus approached the underworld down gilded ladders. His final production with Macmillan was on Britten's The Prince Of The Pagodas (1989).

But it was his creative collaboration with Nureyev that gave Georgiadis's prodigal imagination full rein. Their Sleeping Beauty for La Scala (later performed by London Festival Ballet), was inspired by Louis XIV's Versailles, dark gold and extravagantly tassled. Their Nutcracker for the Royal Ballet was a visual feast seen through a child's eye - Clara's fantasy journey to the kingdom of sweets transporting her to her own toy theatre. Georgiadis designed original ballets by Nureyev, including The Tempest and Washington Square, and several works for the Paris Opera Ballet, including Don Quixote.

Georgiadis, who co-founded the Society of British Theatre Designers in 1971, also designed for theatre and opera, particularly works with classical settings. webTitle: Girls tell of hostel rape and murder

fields.headline: Girls tell of hostel rape and murder
fields.standfirst: Inquest on 13-year-old killed in Brittany in 1996 hears how roommates thought cries and sounds of struggle were girl having nightmare
fields.trailText: An inquest heard yesterday how two schoolgirls awoke when Caroline Dickinson, 13, was raped and smothered to death in their dormitory of a French youth hostel in 1996 - but though they heard her cry out and struggle, they thought she was having a nightmare.
fields.body:
An inquest heard yesterday how two schoolgirls awoke when Caroline Dickinson, 13, was raped and smothered to death in their dormitory of a French youth hostel in 1996 - but though they heard her cry out and struggle, they thought she was having a nightmare.

One heard the zip of her sleeping bag being opened, while the other heard groaning. The first saw the murderer get up from Caroline's mattress but, presuming it was the girl herself, took no further notice and fell back to sleep. Two other girls in the room slept throughout.

The extent of the girls' unwitting witness of the rape and murder emerged in statements read out at Bodmin coroner's court. The East Cornwall coroner, Edward Carlyon, ruled Caroline had been unlawfully killed, calling her death "the nightmare every parent dreads".

She and 40 other children had been on a school activity week at Pleine Fougeres in Brittany. An intruder entered their unlocked hostel in the early hours of July 18, 1996.

More than 3,500 DNA samples have since been taken by police, and 2,000 lines of enquiry have been followed up, but the killer remains unknown. Yesterday, Francis Denons, the French judge in charge of the investigation, said the search would continue.

The inquest heard a summary of evidence from the girls, who were granted anonimity by the coroner, given by Detective Superintendent Andrew Pierce, the Devon and Cornwall officer who has been liaising with the French police.

The first girl, in a bottom bunk near Caroline's mattress on the floor, woke in the early hours and was disturbed by a sound she thought was from Caroline.

"It sounded like crying, she glanced over and saw what she thought was her kicking in her sleeping bag. She then heard what she thought was the sound of the zip of her sleeping bag being undone and she concluded Caroline was hot and dreaming... She thought she also saw someone get up from that area and, thinking it was Caroline, she took no further notice," Mr Pierce told the inquest.

The girl in the bunk above was woken by a noise and "saw the sleeping bag moving around, and at the same time heard groaning noises" - but thought it was Caroline having a nightmare.

The court also heard from the teacher in charge of the party from Launceston community college. Elizabeth Barker, 56, described how she and a fellow teacher unknowingly laughed and joked on hearing the killer leave the hostel in the middle of the night.

She and her colleague, Jackie Thorpe, heard a man's footsteps crunching over gravel and a car driving off at 4.45am - but had thought nothing of it despite Mrs Thorpe being woken by noises three-quarters of an hour earlier.

"I thought Jackie was being nosey, and I told her so," she told the court. "We laughed and joked about how the man who had just left was Manu's [a waiter at the hostel] lover."

Three and a half hours later, she was called to Caroline's room by her roommates who were unable to wake her. As she rushed to her side, she noticed the zip of her sleeping bag was pulled down and "a lot of blood on her thighs". "Some blood was dry. She was cold and her lips were blue," she added.

She tried to raise her head up after placing her in the recovery position, but was unable to do so. Another teacher, who was also a nurse, came in, and told her she was dead.

A Home Office pathologist gave a description of how Caroline was suffocated not strangled, after which the coroner ruled: "A male intruder entered the room that night and assaulted and murdered Caro line. There can be no other conclusion.

"Caroline was the victim of a vicious sexual assault which included her suffocation to prevent her calling for help.

After the verdict, Caroline's father, John Dickinson, made a statement on behalf of himself, his ex-wife Sue, and daughter Jenny, 15, calling for a substantial reward to be set up to help catch her killer as well as an integrated European DNA database to help the search for him. Mr Dickinson, an environmental health office from Bodmin, has been fiercely critical of mistakes in the first inquiry by French police, as a result of which a judge was put in charge.

"Obviously, as a parent, I would like to have every conceivable police officer in the whole of Europe working full time on this investigation," said Mr Dickinson, "but I have to be realistic." Although the inquiry has been considerably scaled down, to three officers, he did not believe this meant his daughter's killer would never be found.

He added: "The passage of time has done nothing to lessen our sense of devastating loss, and we remain fully committed to seeking justice for a bright, kind and gentle young girl who should now be 18 and enjoying all the opportunities and challenges that life has to offer a young woman of today."

Timetable

4am, July 18, 1996. Caroline is murdered. Investigating magistrate Gerard Zaug sets up an inquiry with 50 officers, but two days later admits he is being hindered by being unable to find an interpreter.

July 20, 1996. Vagrant, Patrice Pade, 39, is arrested and allegedly confesses.

August 7, 1996. Pade is released after DNA tests.

August 13, 1996. A second tramp is arrested, but released two days later.

August 14, 1997. After the Dickinson's complaints, Zaug is taken off the case and replaced by Renaud van Ruymbeke, a renowned judge.

February, 1998. A photofit of the killer is released after a teacher on the trip, describes a man loitering near her room. Eight villagers from Pleine Fougeres name one man, but DNA tests eliminate the local suspect.

December 6, 1999. Police pursue a new lead after builders in the area at the time say a colleague matches the photofit. He is arrested and found to be a convicted rapist, but released after DNA tests.

December 10, 1999. Susan Dickinson loses her high court battle against Cornwall county council after a judge rules that, despite staff failing to lock doors at the hostel, the local education authority is not guilty of negligence or breach of duty.

webTitle: Tesco claims victory in European court over selling cut-price Levi jeans

fields.headline: Tesco claims victory in European court over selling cut-price Levi jeans
fields.trailText: The supermarket chain Tesco claimed to have struck a blow for consumers yesterday after the European court of justice appeared to sanction its policy of selling cut-price Levi Strauss jeans obtained via the "grey market".
fields.body:
The supermarket chain Tesco claimed to have struck a blow for consumers yesterday after the European court of justice appeared to sanction its policy of selling cut-price Levi Strauss jeans obtained via the "grey market".

Tesco sued the American company in 1998, saying it had repeatedly threatened to take Tesco to court for importing cheap Levi 501 jeans from the US and eastern Europe.

A pair of button-down 501 jeans can be bought for £25 in the chain's stores, as against at least £45 in high street shops.

Tesco, which adheres to the "pile it high, sell it cheap" policy of its founder, Sir Jack Cohen, claims to have saved British consumers £42m since it started selling the jeans.

But Levi argues that its premium brand reputation is at stake if any supermarket can sell its products at any prices it wishes.

It also asserts that staff selling its jeans need special training, so as to advise customers on how one shade of blue differs from another.

However, the court in Luxembourg yesterday referred the long-running case back to the British courts with an overt hint that the final ruling should go in favour of Tesco.

In a non-binding opinion expected to be formally endorsed by the court later this year, an advocate general ruled: "The right to control the initial distribution of goods... is not unlimited in as much as importers [such as Tesco] have interests which merit protection and which must be taken into account."

Tesco seized on the opinion as vindication of its much trumpeted policy of obtaining sought-after consumer goods through non-official, or "parallel", channels.

"It's a great day for British shoppers," John Gildersleeve, Tesco's director, proclaimed. "Today's opinion means we will be able to sell top brands from around the world at the prices our customers want. Brands like Levi have been given a clear message today that their policies to keep prices high will no longer be tolerated in Europe."

A spokesman for the Hert fordshire-based company said of the opinion: "It says a company does not have unlimited trademark rights.

"And if it is left to the national courts to decide, they will back us because there is a lot of support for what we are doing."

Levi, however, took advantage of the extraordinarily complex wording of the opinion to argue that the case was going its way. "Trademark owners have the right, according to the advocate general, to control the import... of their branded products unless they have waived that right," said Alan Christie, vice president of public affairs.

A spokesman said the decision was "the exact opposite" of Tesco's interpretation.

But sources close to the court confirmed to the Guardian yesterday that the opinion "would seem to suggest that the case will go in Tesco's favour," but cautioned that there were no guarantees in this nebulous area of law.

Tesco claims that big name brands such as Levi, Nike and Adidas have consistently refused to sell to the supermarket, so it is forced to scour cheaper markets in Europe and elsewhere to give customers what they want.

Before Christmas it got hold of 2,500 Sony Playstation 2 consoles - unavailable via official channels at that time - and sold them at the recommended retail price.

The Department of Trade and Industry said yesterday that Tesco's dispute with Levi showed there was a need to revise EU trademark legislation.

fields.headline: Humans encroach on panda haven
fields.standfirst: Satellite photographs of China suggest the giant species is more endangered than had been suspected
fields.trailText: Declassified spy satellite data of China shows the giant panda may be even more endangered than anyone suspected, scientists say.
fields.body:
Declassified spy satellite data of China shows the giant panda may be even more endangered than anyone suspected, scientists say.

The habitat of the nature reserve in Sichuan in south-west China - set aside to shelter the panda - is being destroyed more swiftly than in areas that are not protected, according to scientists who pored over declassified data.

"If biodiversity cannot be protected in protected areas, where can we protect biodiversity?" asked Jianguo Liu, of Michigan State University.

He reports in Science that he and collaborators in China have just completed a study of the Wolong region, which became a nature reserve in 1975. There are now more than 12,000 similar nature reserves around the world, but Wolong was seen as the flagship area for conservation.

The scientists used newly disclosed military photo-graphs and images made by civilian satellites to map the way humans had changed the landscape in the reserve.

About 1,000 pandas survive in the wild. Fewer than 100 of these live in the Wolong reserve. Pandas are specialised animals with a limited diet of bamboo shoots. They are notoriously difficult to breed in captivity, and very fussy about breeding in the wild. They need plenty of forest canopy, elevations at a comfortable temperature and gentle slopes.

The researchers mapped these ideal spots and then looked at the satellite record to see how, over the years, humans had begun to nudge their way on to prime panda real estate.

The total amount of prime panda habitat, the number of individual habitat patches and the size of the average patch had all declined more quickly after the reserve was formed, than before. The decline was also faster in the reserve than in similar country outside it.

The researchers also found that towns and settlements were thriving inside the Wolong reserve. The resident population had increased by 70%. The mere fact that Wolong was home to pandas had attracted tourists, and with them, restaurants and gift shops. One local product sold in the shops is smoked pork, which means a demand for wood fuel, taken from the forests that shelter the pandas.

"Panda habitat is not only being destroyed and fragmented, but it is the high quality habitat that is being selected by humans," Dr Liu said.

"Tourists don't think they have an impact on panda habitat, but indirectly, each visitor has some impact. They come, they take their summer vacations there and stimulate the local economy, which in turn uses more local natural resources."

Biodiversity is under threat everywhere. There could be 7m species on the planet, or even 70m. Only about 1.7m have been formally named and described, and the guess is that more that 20,000 species are being extinguished each year. By the end of the century, half of all creation could have been obliterated by human population increase.

The panda was adopted by the World Wildlife Fund as its symbol: huge efforts were made to establish protected reserves. But in 1974, there were 145 pandas in what became the Wolong Reserve. In 1986, there were 72.

fields.headline: Wide heels court knee injuries
fields.trailText: Women who wear shoes with broad high heels, such as court shoes, are running at least as much risk of developing crippling osteoarthritis in the knee as those who wear stilettos, according to new research.
fields.body:
Women who wear shoes with broad high heels, such as court shoes, are running at least as much risk of developing crippling osteoarthritis in the knee as those who wear stilettos, according to new research.

The team of scientists in Boston, Massachusetts, which found that walking in narrow-heeled stilettos puts damaging pressure on the knee joint - a cause of osteoarthritis - has compared the stress on the joint caused by the type of high shoes with wider heels.

Casey Kerrigan and colleagues from Harvard Medical School studied the pressure on the knee joint caused when 20 healthy women who were comfortable in both types of high-heeled shoes walked 10 metres. The women were between 23 and 44, an average of 1.62 metres tall and weighed on average 9 stones 7lbs.

Each woman completed the walk once in stilettos and once in court shoes - both pairs with heels of around 7cm high. Then they did it again barefoot.

The scientists found that both types of high heels increased the pressure on the knee joint, and that the wider heel (4.5cm) was marginally worse than the stiletto (1.2cm). Court shoes increased what is called the varus torque - a specific pressure on the joint - by 26%, compared with 22% for the stiletto heel. This increased pressure imposes greater compressive force on a part of the knee that is prone to degenerative damage.

"We have shown that wide-heeled women's dress shoes cause greater alterations in knee torques than narrow-heeled shoes, Dr Kerrigan said.

"We recommend wearing shoes with low or no heels".
