The team of scientists in Boston, Massachusetts, which found that walking in narrow-heeled stilettos puts damaging pressure on the knee joint - a cause of osteoarthritis - has compared the stress on the joint caused by the type of high shoes with wider heels. Casey Kerrigan and colleagues from Harvard Medical School studied the pressure on the knee joint caused when 20 healthy women who were comfortable in both types of high-heeled shoes walked 10 metres. The women were between 23 and 44, an average of 1.62 metres tall and weighed on average 9 stones 7lbs. Each woman completed the walk once in stilettos and once in court shoes - both pairs with heels of around 7cm high. Then they did it again barefoot. The scientists found that both types of high heels increased the pressure on the knee joint, and that the wider heel (4.5cm) was marginally worse than the stiletto (1.2cm). Court shoes increased what is called the varus torque - a specific pressure on the joint - by 26%, compared with 22% for the stiletto heel. This increased pressure imposes greater compressive force on a part of the knee that is prone to degenerative damage. "We have shown that wide-heeled women's dress shoes cause greater alterations in knee torques than narrow-heeled shoes, Dr Kerrigan said. "We recommend wearing shoes with low or no heels".

webTitle: Geordie dialect gannin out of fashion

fields.headline: Geordie dialect gannin out of fashion
fields.trailText: Forgotten voices have sounded a warning that one of England's most distinctive dialects may be doomed to disappear.
fields.body:
Forgotten voices have sounded a warning that one of England's most distinctive dialects may be doomed to disappear.

The Geordie sing-song tone familiar along the Tyne is likely to survive, according to academics, but population movements and the power of TV are killing its unique vocabulary with alarming speed.

Research into a previously unstudied archive of taped interviews with people in Gateshead recorded 33 years ago revealed words and phrases which few young contemporary Geordies would know.

Joan Beal, head of the research project, cited disused terms like "nooled" ("henpecked" in the 1960s but meaningless now) as proof of the pace of change.

The roll of verbal dinosaurs is so long that the new survey, based at Newcastle and Sheffield universities, suggests that only catchphrase cliches like "hinny", "wor lad", "gan nin" or "howay" have a more than evens chance of surviving, thanks to their place in songs or Catherine Cookson's books.

The archive, kept at the Catherine Cookson archive of Tyneside and Northumbrian dialect at Newcastle University, was collected by a previous generation of north east academics, who interviewed a 83 people to start a local "linguistic map". Apart from the language, the results showed a pattern of life - from extreme reluctance to leave the area to different children's games - which has also been destroyed.

The death of Geordie as we know it will not, however, completely wipe out regional vocabulary because of the constant minting - on Tyneside as much as in Liverpool or Bristol - of new terms. The survey points out that a 1969 Geordie might know all about "nooling" but would struggle with "charver" (a thug) or "mint" and "belter" (words in the north east for fantastic.)

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Noye granted appeal hearing
fields.body:
Noye granted appeal hearing

Ken Noye, 53, is to present fresh evidence to the appeal court in June in an attempt to overturn his conviction for murdering Stephen Cameron on the M25 in 1996. At his trial last April Noye pleaded self defence; it is understood he will try to cast doubt on reliability of witness testimony.

Jail for hosting cock fights

Javid Iqbal, 46, was yesterday given a three month sentence after having admitted using a house he owned as a cockfighting venue. He is believed to be only the fourth person in three years prosecuted for what is thought to be a widespread offence, Birmingham magistrates heard.

Fatigue blamed for crashes

Tiredness causes one in 10 car crashes ending in serious injury or death, the British Medical Journal reports. The conclusion is based on 60,000 crashes with one vehicle on a clear road in good weather; alcohol caused a fifth of crashes.

24th victim of Shipman

Another verdict of unlawful killing in a series of inquests at Hyde, Greater Manchester, brought the official total of victims of Harold Shipman to 24. Dorothy Andrew, 85, died in 1996 after a home visit by the former GP, who was convicted of 15 murders.

Suspension over child in custody

Lewisham council in south London has suspended a social services worker after investigating why a 12-year-old spent three days in custody. On Tuesday the girl admitted shoplifting and was given a conditional discharge by magistrates.

Roving eye on car theft

Lancashire police are enthusiastic about an electronic eye in patrol cars that reads number plates and checks for stolen cars on a national computer. The force plans to link with other forces' computers, so it can spot plates of visiting criminals.

fields.headline: Mandela to host 'thank you' concert
fields.trailText: Nelson Mandela is to host a free concert in London later this month to say "thank you" to the people of Britain for their stand against apartheid.
fields.body:
Nelson Mandela is to host a free concert in London later this month to say "thank you" to the people of Britain for their stand against apartheid.

Thirty thousand people are expected to pack Trafalgar Square for the celebration of seven years of freedom and democracy in South Africa on April 29 - the anniversary of the first free elections there.

American rock stars REM and The Corrs will top a bill which includes jazz legend Hugh Masekela, Baba Maal, Dave Stewart, Atomic Kitten and Scary Spice Mel B, who once famously asked the former South African president for a cuddle.

All the musicians - whose collective fees would normally top £2m - will perform for nothing for the Freedom Day concert, which will kick off more than a month of events to celebrate the "rainbow nation's" cultural and political progress since 1994.

Cheryl Carlous, the South African high commissioner, said this was the first time Trafalgar Square, the scene of countless anti-apartheid protests as well as a permanent vigil outside South Africa House, has been turned over for such a symbolic show of gratitude.

"Britain was the birthplace of the anti-apartheid movement," she said. "This is our way of thanking the British people for their support for us during those dark days. The progress we have made in the seven years since democracy would have been harder had we not had the friendship and goodwill of Britain."

She said 82-year-old Mr Mandela would not be master of ceremonies because there was a danger he might "dance too much ... We are forcing him to sit down and enjoy it all from the balcony of South Africa House. He's a great dancer, you know. He took the Queen for a jive once - he's the first person to do that, we think.

"All the artists are giving their services for free. I'm still greatly moved by the extraordinary goodwill that still exists and the wish for our democracy to succeed," she added.

Michael Stipe, REM's lead singer said, "I can't think of a more fitting way of demonstrating the real changes in South Africa today than by performing outside the South African High Commission, symbolic of many years of protest, which eventually have achieved real change."

A third of the 30,000 tickets will go to invited guests and sponsors and the rest to the first 20,000 people who call the ticket hotline on 0906 617 2904.

fields.headline: Bush unleashes transatlantic storm
fields.trailText: As President George W Bush makes his daily capitulation to the titans of US industry, most Americans writhe in embarrassment (Analysis, April 5).
fields.body:
As President George W Bush makes his daily capitulation to the titans of US industry, most Americans writhe in embarrassment (Analysis, April 5). We deplore the takeover of the executive branch of our government by the large extractive corporations and share the global community's concern over the fate of the environment.

The voices of those who opposed Mr Bush during election season were drowned in a sea of misleading advertisements, funded by these same industries. Many moderate Americans now acknowledge they were hoodwinked by campaign promises of compassion and middle-of-the-road policies.

All the while, Americans have had to look abroad to gain access to news reporting, free of the ownership and influence of wealthy corporations.The muzzled majority of Americans thank the Guardian for giving us the news of the outrage of the scientific community over Bush's policies. The bulk of Americans, even conservative, disapprove of the overwhelming anti-environmental mantra of the Bush administration.
Dennis Higgins
Kent, Washington, USA

 George Bush has done the world a favour by rejecting the Kyoto protocol (America the horrible, April 4). For 10 years the US has resisted action on climate change. The Clinton-Gore administration let carbon emissions rip, while teasing climate negotiators with worthless concessions. Let's face it, the US public and Congress will not cut their use of fossil fuels until Florida floods, tornadoes tear up Texas and US companies lose market share to climate-friendly businesses.

Thanks to Bush, the world has woken up to the fact that mainstream America would not act, and US environmentalist are beginning to unite and convince others about the dangers of climate change. Thanks to Bush, the rest of the world might unite to cut global CO2 emissions.

The protocol can be ratified without America, but Kyoto was never enough. Britain should use its presidency of the UN security council to propose climate change as a "global security issue". The Commonwealth should launch a climate initiative. The EU and developing countries like India, Bangladesh, Brazil and South Africa should form an alliance to cut emissions on the basis of equal per capita rights. This would create a huge market for sustainable technology. Emissions trading would transfer resources from north to south, creating a virtuous cycle of falling emissions, greater equality and rising prosperity. Within a decade, a storm-damaged US will beg to join the club.
Titus Alexander
Global Commons Institute titus@gci.org.uk

 Polly Toynbee's anti-American article is not the way of persuasion over global warming. Any American would certainly have their European stereotypes, so well described by Henry Porter (The great divide, G2, April 3), reinforced. Should that American also be an environmentalist, or a second world war vet with shrapnel in his backside, or even an average car owner living in the middle of North Dakota, I wouldn't at all be surprised if they were even insulted.

Probably an American reading the article would wonder at how hypocritical it is coming from a country with the worst teenage pregnancy rate in Europe, a healthcare system in chaos, and animal diseases on the rampage. Those in glass houses.
Birgit Solvbjerg
Ballerup, Denmark

 Perhaps a delayed instalment of our peace dividend is that, like the Poles, Czechs and Hungarians, we too no longer have to toe the line and keep schtoom every time our more entertaining but often obstreperous and bullying cold war big brother embarks on some daft, peace-threatening manoeuvre. Naturally this applies also to "arrangements" of the kind made in the icier days Richard Norton-Taylor describes so alarmingly (It's hard to control what the American military can do, April 5). The next stage is to realise that we could actually do something about such things: that, even if George doesn't get it, we've come to the end of that depressing bit of history at least. War game over.
WL Webb
London

 Isabel Hilton is right to point out the dangers of the US decision to transfer missile defence technology to Taiwan (In the jaws of the dragon, April 3). But the South China sea is not the only place where missile defences are increasingly in vogue. France, Italy, Germany and even the UK are all developing systems to protect forward deployed troops and naval fleets from missile attack. Nato is also investing in a more advanced system which, if deployed, would give the alliance the ability to defend border areas and even cities.

In their rush to invest in unproven missile defence technologies, European governments should ask themselves whether they are benefiting anyone but the defence manufacturers who win the contracts. They should also be aware of the extent to which their actions strengthen the arguments of those in the US who support a truly destabilising "national" missile defence network. Real security is dependent on tackling the spread of missile technology and weapons of mass destruction.
Mark Bromley
British American Security Information Council mbromley@basicint.org

fields.headline: Dam barrier
fields.trailText: No decision has yet been taken regarding support for the Ilisu dam (Letters, April 5).
fields.body:
No decision has yet been taken regarding support for the Ilisu dam (Letters, April 5). When Stephen Byers published his two reports that we commissioned on this project in December 1999, he made it clear that before a decision is made, we would need to be satisfied on a number of conditions: (i) the need for proper consultation on resettlement; (ii) maintaining water quality; (iii) assurance that water flow to downstream states will be maintained; and (iv) the preservation of as much of the archaeological heritage of Hasankeyf as possible. If these conditions are not satisfied, then there will be no support.

By setting these conditions, we are abiding by recognised minimum standards.
Richard Caborn MP
Minister for trade

webTitle: Letters: Knickers to the nation of shopkeepers

fields.headline: Knickers to the nation of shopkeepers
fields.trailText: It is amazing to know the directors of Marks & Spencer are planning to pay a performance bonus equal to one year's salary to chairman Luc Vandevelde after their decision to close all their shops in Europe (Belgium joins battle against M&S closures, April 5).
fields.body:
It is amazing to know the directors of Marks & Spencer are planning to pay a performance bonus equal to one year's salary to chairman Luc Vandevelde after their decision to close all their shops in Europe (Belgium joins battle against M&S closures, April 5). I really don't believe that this decision will improve the image of the company.

I am French and, like many French people, I have always considered M&S as a typical English shop. My friends and family would often enjoy popping into the store to get that "English feeling". It does sound like a stereotype, but it was nice to be able to purchase your English marmalade in M&S. It was "chic"!

The closure of the 18 shops in France not only means that 1,700 people will find themselves unemployed by the end of December but also that M&S does not respect the French and their legislation.

Maybe the decision was kept quiet until the last minute because of the stock exchange, but a simple email to announce the sudden closure of all the stores was not appropriate. The French have always fought for their rights and, in their country, they should be entitled to them.
Nicole Halliday
Harrogate, N Yorks

 Last week's brutal closure of 18 Marks & Spencer outlets in France has ruined the reputation of a flagship company in Europe presenting British quality and service at its best, and has left a bewildered French workforce wondering what's hit them. Their disgust (like that felt by UK citizens currently in France) is total. Marks & Spencer will now be seen on the level of mad cow disease and foot and mouth disease, as one of the plagues currently visited on Europe by the UK.
Dr Rex Andrews
Baume-les-Messieurs, France

 You describe M&S as a drop-in point for homesick expats. Well, yes, it's true that we need the Melton Mowbrays and the crumpets. Doesn't everyone? But we object to the epithet "homesick". Haven't you been reading your own paper recently. What is there left in the UK to be homesick for: a fish supper after chucking-out time perhaps?
Gerry Bond
Brussels

fields.headline: Double exposure
fields.trailText: Kevin Maxwell claims protection under the human rights legislation against disqualification as a director (Maxwell slated by report, March 31). But what of my rights? As a Mirror pensioner I have been robbed.
fields.body:
Kevin Maxwell claims protection under the human rights legislation against disqualification as a director (Maxwell slated by report, March 31). But what of my rights? As a Mirror pensioner I have been robbed; as a taxpayer I have paid to see him walk free from court. Now he has been found to be responsible for the abuse of pensioners' money, is it not our human right to see him punished?
Pamela Duveen
Marlborough, Wilts

 A massive hike in rail fares in the run up to the election (In the grip of 'rail cancer', April 5): is this Richard Branson's revenge for not getting the National Lottery contract?
Brian Moss
Tamworth, Staffs

 If Britain - with much help from the US and the Commonwealth - hadn't held out for so long, Hitler might have gained control of the Atlantic, beaten Russia, built his V3 rockets and rained them on to America. So it might be equally true to say that, if it wasn't for the British, the Americans would be speaking German (Letters, April 5).
David Garner
Southport

 If the left want to control our language, they need a better semiotician than Peter Denton (Letters, April 4). Michael Barrymore clearly felt "ashamed" of his homosexuality before he came out. Hence it was indeed an admission, not an acknowledgement.
Peter Totman
Redondo Beach, California

 I have got used to two Duncan Campbells writing for the Guardian. Now you tell us there are two Stephen Mosses and that both of them write about birdwatching (The twitching hour, G2, April 5). Who else do you possess in duplicate. A brace of Hugo Youngs? A pair of Michael Whites. Surely not a couple of Nancy Banks-Smiths?
Charles Foster
Dublin

fields.headline: Miscarriage of justice
fields.trailText: I read with sympathy the stories of miscarriages by Sally Weale and Richard Davis' wife (An unspeakable sorrow, April 4).
fields.body:
I read with sympathy the stories of miscarriages by Sally Weale and Richard Davis' wife (An unspeakable sorrow, April 4). One item of information that might help assuage their pain and grief would be to know why the miscarriages happened.

Whilst many miscarriages are due to bad luck or acts of God (ie medicine does not understand the reason), a proportion are explicable, due to lethal chromosomal abnormality, congenital malformation, and in utero infection.

In these cases, it is likely that the miscarriage was inevitable and necessary. Such data can then usefully inform on the likelihood of, and management towards, successful future pregnancies.

This is the role of the foetal and perinatal pathology - the morphological and genetic study of dead foetuses. But the hysteria over organ retention at Bristol and Alder Hey Hospitals beggar the provision of this important speciality. Before 1999, there were few perinatal pathologists in the UK. Since 2000, the number has been decimated through the early retirement and resignation of those who felt unfairly criticised. Recruitment is effectively zero - who wants to be abused by the public? So has the public, through its press and government representatives, shot itself in the foot again?
Dr Sebastian Lucas
Professor of pathology, St Guy's and St Thomas's hospital
fields.bodyText: I read with sympathy the stories of miscarriages by Sally Weale and Richard Davis' wife (An unspeakable sorrow, April 4). One item of information that might help assuage their pain and grief would be to know why the miscarriages happened. Whilst many miscarriages are due to bad luck or acts of God (ie medicine does not understand the reason), a proportion are explicable, due to lethal chromosomal abnormality, congenital malformation, and in utero infection. In these cases, it is likely that the miscarriage was inevitable and necessary. Such data can then usefully inform on the likelihood of, and management towards, successful future pregnancies. This is the role of the foetal and perinatal pathology - the morphological and genetic study of dead foetuses. But the hysteria over organ retention at Bristol and Alder Hey Hospitals beggar the provision of this important speciality. Before 1999, there were few perinatal pathologists in the UK. Since 2000, the number has been decimated through the early retirement and resignation of those who felt unfairly criticised. Recruitment is effectively zero - who wants to be abused by the public? So has the public, through its press and government representatives, shot itself in the foot again? Dr Sebastian Lucas Professor of pathology, St Guy's and St Thomas's hospital

fields.headline: For free
fields.trailText: You describe the Science Museum as a dissident charging museum (Tate Modern triumphs with 5m visitors, April 3). This is simply not the case.
fields.body:
You describe the Science Museum as a dissident charging museum (Tate Modern triumphs with 5m visitors, April 3). This is simply not the case.

Our position has long been in favour of free admission at the Science Museum if the considerable VAT and revenue obstacles could be overcome. It is to the great credit of culture secretary Chris Smith that he has now found the means to overcome these. We therefore wholeheartedly welcomed his recent announcement that free admission will be possible later this year, while working through matters of detail with officials from the Department for Culture, Media and Sport.
Lindsay Sharp
Director, Science Museum

fields.headline: Completing the final phase
fields.standfirst: The hard work is almost over and it's praise all round. Gary Williams describes the last day of the charity trek across the Great Wall of China
fields.trailText: The hard work is almost over and it's praise all round. Gary Williams describes the last day of the charity trek across the Great Wall of China
fields.body:
After an early breakfast we are once again on the move, this time heading to join the Great Wall at Mutianyu. The lower reaches of this part of the wall are particularly popular with local day-trippers and this being Sunday, they are very much in evidence as we assemble for our last set of group photos. For many of our trekkers, this is payback time as various sponsors' paraphernalia is held aloft for the camaras.

Today's walk is not going to be one of the longest, as one stretch we were due to cover is closed. Nevertheless, it is one of the toughest.

Nothing quite prepares you for the reality of the wall. Over the previous year, I had seen countless photos of it and yet none came near to capturing its majesty. On our first encounter many of us were moved to tears by the experience. Its vastness and rugged beauty are truly overwhelming; the challenge of walking it strangely life affirming.

Tired and happy, we say goodbye to the wall and speed towards Beijing for our final celebratory meal together as a group. I am delighted that Yan Ming Fu and Wu Yis Jing - president and executive director of the China Charity Federation respectively - have accepted Care for Children's invitation to join us for dinner. Mr Yan kindly agrees to present each of the trekkers with the commemorative certificates I brought from the UK. Official thanks from such a senior Chinese official, who called them "heroes", went down well.

Over the past week, this disparate group have supported and encouraged each other to overcome significant challenges. Together they have raised much needed funding for both the British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering (BAAF) and Care for Children charities, while also gaining new friends and a sense of personal achievement.

And so to next year's trek. While the rest of the group spent a final day looking around Beijing, I met with our China and UK travel agents to work on the new itinerary and visit new hotels. All we need to do now is find a new group of heroes-in-waiting willing to undertake a challenge of a lifetime.

For information about the China Trek 2002, email angela.cardoso@baaf.org.uk

 Gary Williams is head of marketing at BAAF

 China Trek 2001 has raised around £25,000 for BAAF

webTitle: Ron Atkinson: My part in Deportivo's downfall

fields.headline: Now it can be told: my part in Deportivo's downfall
fields.trailText: Keep it simple, don't become overawed and take the game to the opposition, that's the secret to success in the Champions league
fields.body:
I was talking to David O'Leary a couple of weeks ago when we found ourselves together in Dubai. And, while I wouldn't claim any credit for Leeds' fantastic victory over Deportivo La Coruna, I'm glad he did what we chatted about.

I said to David that I hoped his team wouldn't try to become too sophisticated in Europe because part of the reason for their great results has been their naivety. All through the Champions League they have played with no fear and that was obvious again on Wednesday night.

Some of the experienced teams might prefer a patient game, putting a number of passes together and playing a lot in their own half. But I think Leeds will lose a lot if they start doing that and it was good to see them playing quickly and accurately and getting plenty of ball into their front pair.

Just like Valencia last season they are going into matches without the pressure of expectancy and their performances make you wonder whether it hasn't quite hit them yet how important it all is.

Manchester United are well aware of the competition's significance because they have been there and won it and are expected by a lot of people, including themselves, to win it again. That may inhibit them to a certain extent, whereas Leeds have no inhibitions at all.

In some ways they remind me of my first experience in Europe with West Brom. We had a very attack-minded side with lots of pace and never approached those Uefa Cup games in the traditional manner. We used to go at everybody home and away, and that was one of the beauties of that. We paid some attention to the opposition but not over-much.

The danger for Leeds may be if things suddenly hit them, as it seemed to Valencia in the final against Real Madrid last May, but there are no signs of that so far. They have deserved this success because their European performances have been superb. They have been exciting and they've played with a lot of verve and aggression.

Deportivo were clearly terrified of Leeds every time there was some physical confrontation. Olivier Dacourt won about five tackles in the first two or three minutes and that set the tone. It got everyone around him gingered up, the adrenalin started flowing and after that it was hard to find a Leeds player you couldn't have made star man.

They're in a great position now but, make no mistake, Deportivo La Coruna will be better in the return. They were very disappointing on Wednesday, though it would be nice to think much of that was down to Leeds' pace, drive and tempo.

All the same O'Leary will have seen enough in the last 15 minutes, when La Coruna went a bit more attack-minded and Valeron came on and started playing well, to know that, if his players are not bang on their mettle, things could go against them.

Djalminha didn't have much of a game but I'm sure he'll have far more of an influence in La Coruna. He might be a hot-head but he's a fine player and I tried to sign him once when I was at Sheffield Wednesday.

We had a meeting in France during the Tournoi in the lead-up to the 1998 World Cup. I had been told about him by the same people who were responsible for bringing Juninho into the country but he said he was going to play in either Italy or Spain.

The one thing Leeds' mustn't do is freeze or get into the "Will they, won't they" mode. Yes, they've got to be cautious but not over-much. They have to go out to get a goal, and Alan Smith and Mark Viduka definitely had the sign on their central defenders. I expect Leeds to go through.

I've got a fancy for Arsenal as well, provided Martin Keown and Tony Adams are in the middle of their defence to protect their 2-1 lead against Valencia.

As for Manchester United, to overturn that 1-0 deficit at Bayern Munich they'll need a performance comparable to the one they gave in coming from 2-0 down to win at Juventus two years ago. Their side are good enough but they will have to learn from Tuesday night.

At Old Trafford I felt their movement and sprinting off the ball were not as good as in the past. They've become a little bit predictable for top-class opposition and I think they were taking too long to build the moves up.

That gave Bayern Munich lots of time to get behind the ball and regroup, and the German champions showed at home to Arsenal that they are good at getting back and filling in holes if you don't go very quickly and direct into the heart of them.

Andy Cole made a lot of great runs on the outside of Sammy Kuffour and you wanted him to drop the ball off quickly and get back in the middle where he's most dangerous. But the sprinting support from Ryan Giggs on the outside was not there often enough.

I hope United rediscover their best and it wouldn't surprise me if they pulled that top performance out.
